Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR Calendar Updates & Version 1.0 Teaser

Dear Mike, Ryan and Chris,

Out of due respect to the community at large as well as the individual, I
think the point taken and to reconsider here too is that:

 a) not all people listen to the same genres of music in this scene
 b) there are many different collectives, clubs, venues and promotions
groups all catering to said genres of music.
 c) there are *MANY* things going on in the bay area, underground, legit
(permitted), house party, massive, club event, weeklies, and they are
intrinsically different and unique.

As a result of diversity, what might appear to be *Nothing* going on to
one person is *something* totally different to another. It all boils down
to what kind of events you like to attend and participate in, your music
and dj preferences, and your own opinions.

I know for a fact that there is a diverse array of opinions regarding what
"is" a party that one might prefer / think is "cool" or meets their
standards.  Luckily, this applies to you (or said person) and your own
preferences. There *IS* a large array of events and subsets to choose
from.  No one person I've met yet speaks on behalf of the choices/opinions
of everyone as a whole (politically and individually speaking).

We all have a choice, and regardless of one's personal preferences and
convictions regarding the "San Francisco Electronic Music scene" at large,
there is a thumping diversity of music, culture and subsets of the larger
music scene that is alive, well and thriving.

In honour of our constitutional right to exercise freedom of speech and of
expression through artistic, musical and spoken word means, there are many
different interests which collectively are a part of this community's
preferences. These interests are as intrinsic to the individual or
collective of individuals that identify themselves with the scene and its
many facets, as the people, music and art that compose it.

An example of some of the interests/subsets/facets of the
greater scene (Including but not limited to these interests):

Interests: 80: 2-step, acidhouse, ambient, big beat, breakbeat, breaks,
breakz, brian behlendorf, candy, candy raver, clubs, core, dance, dance
music, dancesafe, deathcore, deep house, digital underground, disco, disco
house, djs, dnb, downtempo, drum & bass, drum and bass, electro,
electronica, euro dance, freestyle, gabber, gabber hardcore, garage,
ghetto tech, glowsticks, goa, goa trance, happy hardcore, hardcore,
hardhouse, hip hop, house, hyperreal, hyperreal.org, idm, jungle,
junglist, lounge core, music, partying, plur, progressive house,
psychedelia, psychedelic, psytrance, ravers, raves, raving, san francisco,
san franciso bay area, scratching records, sf nightlife, sf raves,
sf-raves, sflnc, sfr, sfraves, sfraves.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org,
speedcore, spinning, tech idm, tech-house, techniques, techno, terrorcore,
trance, triphop, turntable dragons, turntables, underground)

In retrospect, after going to events in the Bay area for a decade plus,
and watching SFRaves.org / Hyperreal and the SF Bay Area Scene grow and
change, I am rest assured that there *IS* still a scene. This scene
contains many facets thereof, that are quite alive and thumping to this
day. I believe as well that the concept of it "dying" is really just a
reflection on the one constant in life: Change. This list, the scene,
ecetera are not dying, as the calendar is still quite alive and well too.
(It wouldn't have 494 users and 170 groups created since Beta if it were
not used). The website pertaining to this community, SFRaves.org, receives
MANY hits on any given day and month, of new and *returning* users.

On a side note, I went out this week to two local collective events in San
Francisco, and both were *alive* with energy, people, smiling faces and
good music. It put a smile on my visage knowing there is such a wonderful
option for weeknights just like there still is on weekends.

Regarding this list being monitored: ANY public mailing list, webserver,
unencrypted email, non-proxy (Firewall) network connection, especially
WIFI/802.11b and unencrypted internet usage are of the same inherent risk:
This information is readily available to anyone (you, or whomever) joins
this list, reads the website, intercepts or surveys your internet and
network communications and  habits.

The Patriot Act I has broadenedd, and if passed the Patriot Act II will
continue also expand law enforcement's scope, tactic and response. As a
result, individual civil liberties and your privacy rights are at risk
and have already been compromised even more so than ever before. Many
changes to wiretap and search and seizure laws are in effect, and this
also applies to surveillance.


Since this is a public list, all information is available to anyone, and
your actions, words and disclosures should be treated with the same care
you would when speaking to a public audience or conducting yourself in
public.

To conclude that the SFR calendar died as a result of this list being
monitored, is actually a false representation of the state of it the list,
the calendar, society and law enforcement today. The logic may fit if the
peg were round (putting a square peg in a round hole), but in this case,
surveillance and list usage may affect one's own decisions on what they
dislose online, but it is the person's responsibility to be aware and
conscious that it is not the medium necessarily which leads to the end
result. A lot of it pertains directly to changes in our federal, state and
local statutes as well. If one is very concerned, try reading:

1. ACLU website on Surveillance
http://www.aclu.org
http://www.aclu.org/Cyber-Liberties/Cyber-LibertiesMain.cfm

2. Center for Democracy and Technology
(Information about Roving wiretaps)

CALEA
http://www.cdt.org/digi_tele/

"...The federal wiretap law was enacted in 1968, and has undergone major
revisions since then as Congress has tried to keep pace with changing
technology. Congress has tried to balance the often competing interests of
law enforcement, privacy rights, and technological innovation.

In 1994, Congress adopted the Communications Assistance for Law
Enforcement Act (CALEA, or the digital telephony law). CALEA was intended
to preserve but not expand law enforcement wiretapping capabilities by
requiring telephone companies to design their systems to ensure a certain
basic level of government access. But the FBI has tried to use the law to
expand its capabilities, turning wireless phones into tracking devices,
requiring phone companies to collect specific signaling information for
the convenience of the government, and allowing interception of packet
communications without privacy protections..."

3.
http://zdnet.com.com/2100-1104-980889.html

(hint: "...WASHINGTON--A Pentagon antiterrorism plan to link databases of
credit card companies, health insurers and others--creating what critics
call a "domestic surveillance apparatus"--is encountering growing
opposition on Capitol Hill.

Sen. Russ Feingold, D-Wisc., is planning to introduce a bill on Thursday
to halt the Pentagon's Total Information Awareness program. A
representative said on Wednesday that if passed, the legislation would
suspend the TIA program until Congress can "review the data-mining
issues..." )

4.
http://zdnet.com.com/2100-1105-980964.html
"...
When it comes to snooping on Americans, Big Brother has a lot more gadgets
at his disposal.

In its new study, "Bigger Monster, Weaker Chains: The Growth of an
American Surveillance Society," the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU)
blames the unchecked use of technological tracking features for an
increase in surveillance by both the government and the private sector..."

http://www.lmaeronautics.com/news/programnews/recon/

5. Information about Identity Theft
http://www.idtheft.gov

6. Big Brother Knows Your Face
http://securitysolutions.com/ar/security_big_brother_knows/index.htm

7. The Liberty Dogs
http://www.thelibertydogs.com/weblog.php

*Is it any wonder that these laws were passed after the War on Terrrorism
began?*

It is also important to note that our closest ally, Great Britain, has
used this form of survelliance and spying on it own citizens for close to
a decade. There are cameras on buses, sidewalks, building, banks,
restaurants, everywhere you go. Similarly, Your internet connectivity,
browsing habits, email, list discussions and threads, sent in plain text
without encryption are equally vulnerable.

Perhaps some people do not use the list (they unsubscribed do to moving,
drama or personal reasons) or some don't use the calendar *because* they
know that is is the request of the promoter to not have the information
listed - usually in the case of an underground. In that case, it is in the
best interest of the promoter - since his party may or may not be legit to
begin with. (Perhaps he is trying to avoid getting busted?)

If the event information is that sensitive, it isn't placed on many other
PUBLIC lists either, at the discretion of the promoter. This has, and is,
a longstanding practice of event promoters, and is not a reflection of
just SFRaves, Other public websites and calendars are subject to the same
scrutiny.

So, the main point here is, that in order to really apply the logic that
law enforcement is a concern, it is in the best interest of any person who
uses the internet and email to take the necessary and informed steps to
protect their privacy. List monitoring is a factor that has always been
used by law enforcement, just as undercover persons and surveillance has
expanded in scope and process. IMHO, The best thing to do is be prepared,
use your best judgement, and heed true to your opinions and convictions, with
a sense of awareness and compassion.

PS - I think a blanket statement of "FOO FOO SIDE" of partying is not
representative of the scene as a whole, there are many GOOD people out
there throwing events that may or may not meet your standards and tastes.
That doesn't necessarily apply to everyone.

Example: (hypothetical)

House Sucks.
Techno Sucks.
Jungle Sucks.
Trance Sucks.
Hardcore Sucks.

Why? "Cause I only listen to this"... or "that music sucks for this
reason." "This part of the scene/this party sucks because of x"

-- All personal accounts, not facts in a book

Personally, I like all forms of music, and you'll find me at a club to a
jungle party to a house party to an underground, I don't discriminate.
Unless of course, it is country music. However, that's my choice. I still
listen to classical, jazz, modern and classic rock, funk, disco, blues and
a whole gammet of other stuff that's not electronic.

-- Hope to see more of you at events in the Bay Area.

With respect,

Karina

Subject: [sfraves] more on sexy nrr

yesterday, i had my photo taken next to the word sexy. i don't think
this made me any sexier or sexy at all...actually, i am fairly
unattractive...i think human beings in general are quite ugly...i think
the word sexy gets overused and inappropriately so, just like the words
value, love, friend, family, and also, everyone's favorite: GREAT
PROMOTION! big boobs are going out of style by the way...does this make
any of them friendly though? does it make them more sexy..maybe they
used to be a GREAT PROMOTION...i think they still are. :)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:Sierra Recordings Record Release Party @ SS Monday!

This monday Apr. 7th I'm pleased to announce my Record
Release Party @ Secret Society. After starting as an
electrical impulse in my brain 7 months ago, I'm
pleased to finally manifest our new tech-house imprint
Sierra Recordings with my partner JJVaas who resides
in Minneapolis. I could not have done this without the
support of my girlfriend/friends and family. So come
down on monday and help me celebrate the birth of a
bay area label, and it's first release featuring an
original track by myself and remixes by my label
partner JJVaas and the one and only Jay Tripwire. The
DJ's for the evening will be Aradia, DJ DDub and
myself. The Savoy is located at 3546 Flora Vista Ave.
Santa Clara, CA. 95051 The party starts around 9ish
and is $1 for secret society members or print out this
e-mail, otherwise it's $5.
Sierra002 will feature a track by my parter JJVaas and
a remix from myself and Lucas Roddenbush (EBE)

Future SS tech/house dates will include
April 21st Household Recordings founders Jay and Tone
May 5th Chris Jackson Resource/Jump/Particle
May 19 Rick Preston Viva
Secret society gathers every monday...........

But wait, thats not all...................
on every 2nd and 4th friday at club 4 on Bascom ave.
I'm proud to announce a yet to be named tech/house
party :)
Starting at the end of May we'll have
May 30th - JZ SF Red Melon 
June 13th - Olivier Desmet SF Amenti/Moulton/Aroma
June 27th - Robin Porter LA Immigrant/Shva and EBE
Sierra/Grayhound/Soma
July 11th - Richard and Melony Summerhayes - SF/London

With your residents
Gabriel Black
Aradia
DJ DDub

Hope to see you on Monday!
Gabriel

At 11:38 AM 4/4/2003 -0800, _ fable _ wrote:
>"It wasn't just cops using it to bust parties either. There were 
>well-supported rumors of less-than-scrupulous promoters using the calendar 
>to screw the competition."
>
>Damn...thats some fucked up shit.

Those promoters include club and permitted party givers.  There were once a 
number of good SOMA venues where one could give unpermitted parties without 
much danger.  Not just raves.  Many Hispanic and other promoters were 
having unpermitted events.  Club owners got wind of these events and 
pressured the police to crack down.  Competition is fierce these days for 
the dwindling consumer dollar and various interests wish to protect their 
markets.

Thus, those of us who still give ugs are developing in-house lists to help 
assure we are not the target of other unhappy promoters and, of course, 
those who wish to enforce the permit requirements.  Has nothing to do with 
elitism.

Biggest problem I have these days is finding a reasonably secure ug venue 
centrally located in which to throw parties.

Love,

Apollo






Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

From sfraves-return-100818-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Apr 04 22:33:34 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-100818-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 81135 invoked by uid 1103); 4 Apr 2003 22:33:33 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 81121 invoked from network); 4 Apr 2003 22:33:33 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [12.233.244.49]
X-Originating-Email: [invibe@hotmail.com]
From: "Brandon @ Invibe" <invibe@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Fri, 04 Apr 2003 14:33:30 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F811LSZtFD80if4SUW00001128e@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 04 Apr 2003 22:33:30.0943 (UTC) FILETIME=[38147CF0:01C2FAFA]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BACK from Beijing to the bay

sfr peoples-

well, after 7 months living abroad in Beijing, China...i'm back...and 
without the SARS virus.

to everyone on SFR that i know, here's a big "what's up!" to you all.  to 
everyone else that i don't know...well, um..."hey!"

Beijing is a world away from San Francisco and while i had an absolutely 
incredible trip it feels pretty damn good to be back home.  i'm looking 
forward to going out and hearing some good music and seeing all of you on 
the dancefloor!  (note:  brandon needs to go to some bangin' parties, so 
please let me know what's up.  i'm keeping my eyes and ears open.)

with that said, here's a brief rundown of my trip (in case anyone is bored 
in front of their computer and needs a temporary diversion).

i've been in Beijing for the past 7 months studying chinese martial arts 
(wushu) at the Beijing University of Physical Education.  during the hours 
when i was not jumping, kicking and swinging long weapons around in the air, 
i was busy exploring the city and getting drunk off $0.30 bottles of beer 
and little green bottles of something called baijou (%50+ alcohol!  ack!).

and i took along a crate of records with me.  only in Beijing can a lame-o 
wannabe DJ like myself get a weekly residency at the same club that 
Oakenfold played at and get gigs at a couple of the best clubs in the city.  
(note:  people in Beijing don't really dig breakbeats <weeping weeping> but 
there is a pretty healthy house music scene).

speaking of the music scene in Beijing (i'm rhyming now!), it's a mixed bag. 
  clubs that cater to Chinese tend to play pretty cheesy techno...kind of a 
blend of eurotrash and bad Chinese pop...but people bounce to it and hey, it 
can be kinda fun.  the clubs that cater to foreigners tend to play hip-hop 
and 80s...mostly poorly mixed on CDs by people that don't know how to use a 
crossfader.  but there are a few places where you can hear good house music 
(mostly progressive and deep), some breakbeats (occasionally) and some 
decent trance.  while i was there, i was able to catch Paul van Dyk (for $8 
on a thursday), Monica Kruse, Electric Indigo and Morcheeba (live, baby!).  
and for kicks, i videotaped myself breakdancing on the Great Wall of China 
(breakin and the Great Wall...two great tastes that go great together).

anyhow, though living abroad is a magical thing and it's changed my life for 
the better...i can't tell you how many times i yearned to be right back here 
on a dark dancefloor with friends getting hot and sweaty to some bangin 
beats.  i'm just going to miss those $0.30 bottles of beer  ;)

hope to see some of you soon!

-------------
< Brandon >
http://www.invibe.com
-------------

Oh yeah... ummm... STNRRIT =3D So totally not rave related I think

I mean... I know alota of believe in our intuition powers & man... if I =
could tap into that 97% of the brain power that we don't use... Man... =
I'd be like Professor X!!  That'd be Dope!!

I mean.. I know I have Psycic abilities 'cause like well.... in  6th =
grade I was like totally able to predict what Brady Bunch episode they =
were gonna w/in the next 2-3 days... weird, huh?  But yeah... I'd be =
thinking of Brady Bunch while we were watching movies & the episode =
would like show not to long after I would think about it!

Then in 7th Grade whenever I would walk home from the bus stop... I =
always seemed 2B walking behind some1 I didn't like 'cause yeah... I =
didn't have the best early teen years!  But I would always do like all =
these Psycic yells @ them & keep telling them 2 look behind them 'cause =
a monster was gonna eat them!!  LoL... But yeah... they would always =
turned around!  I remember this Girl Monica would I kept doing that to & =
after like the 5-6th thime I did it 2 her... she got scared & ran home!! =
 I felt kinda bad 'cause she didn't show up 2 school 4 a week after =
that!

In High school, I was always like, I 4get the techinical word, but is it =
Empathic?  LIke Marina Whatsherlastname from Star Trek Next Generation & =
that power she had.... I always knew how my friends were feeling & =
talked 2 them about it all the time!

The past few years I been like been able 2 feel some1's pressence like =
if they were near/ close by!  It's weird 'cause like I can like focus & =
be able to tell where a person is @ kinda, ya know... it' s like I =
dunno... I can't describe it!!

This 1 time I was @ Ascension... this was like 2 years ago!  Anywaze... =
my Brother couldn't be there that night 'cause he had like other things =
2 do & stuff!  But there was this moment when I was like on the Dance =
floor groovin' & I got this mondo crazy weird feeling in me... like my =
brain said like "WHOA" & I had a tingley sensation in my tummy... I =
kinda heard of felt my Brothers thought that he was feeling kinda guilty =
about not showing up @ Ascension & he really wanted 2 go or like he was =
thinkin' about goin after he was done w/ his errands!  I dunno... this =
feeling was like soooooooo strong & I went up stairs & outside 2 C is he =
was there!  It was weird... I mean... he wasn't there, but I totally =
felt his thoughts that he really wanted 2 B there like there was a =
moment he thought those things & I felt it when he thought that... ya =
know! =20

Well...IO jus' thought I'd share... Food 4 thought 4 some reason! =3D)

       I have a question about ORGY. Why does Armann the Brainchild play multiple hour sets?? His choice of music isn't really that good and he isn't a BIG NAME DJ, so why is he playing a 5 hour set for ORGY? Lots of people complain because he always plays these "FOREVER-LONG" sets which just dont appeal to ORGY crowd. I bet that was why they aren't throwing ORGY at 550 barnevald anymore. The crowd is just sick of his long sets. His resident DJ's are pretty good but why aren't they getting any playtime?

       I think last year (Sept/Oct?), Armann the Brainchild went for an 8 hour set. What is up with that? How did he fit other people into the Dj Lineup? We pay to hear different styles of music and everytime I go, he's ALWAYS HEADLINING! I think he needs to chill off the "long sets" and give the people what they want... which is different styles of music, not just Armann's music all night. I swear I must have heard Armann play that vocal track by Silvio Econo between 1AM - 4AM at every ORGY that I have went to (probably because he headlines all the parties).

Mike

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <OFD0457B9E.12185BF0-ON85256CFF.0013649C@washpost.com>
From: "Mary Morris" <morrism@washpost.com>
Date: Fri, 4 Apr 2003 22:32:31 -0500
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] dieselboy in atm magazine (uk)

hello san francisco,

this is an article written for atm, a uk d 'n' b magazine, tied to the
recent european release of dieselboy's "projectHUMAN" and his upcoming tour
of the UK with bad
company uk.  just thought it might be of interest to the dsl heads.

hope you all have a good weekend.

respectfully,
mary :)


Dieselboy

      America's most in-demand and best-selling drum 'n' bass DJ and
producer might be one of its most hyper as well. You'll often see him
running when most people would just as soon walk. In February, between
cross-country gigs, he was up at 6:30 a.m., patching, painting and cleaning
his new apartment in hometown Philadelphia, PA.
      Dieselboy's latest CD, "projectHUMAN," released in the US last March
and soon to be released in the UK on Moving Shadow, is steadily catching up
to the sales of his mix-CD from 2000, "The 6ixth Session," the best-selling
drum 'n' bass mix-CD in the history of electronic music, which still
continues to sell well.
      For "projectHUMAN," he decided to continue his evolution of mix-CDs
("Drum and Bass Selection USA," "97 Octane," "611 DJ Mixseries Vol. One,"
"A Soldier's Story," "System_Upgrade," "The 6ixth Session") and break with
standard tradition.   Instead of just doing another mix of the latest drum
'n' bass anthems, why not get some of his favorite drum 'n' bass producers
(including Technical Itch, Ram Trilogy, Hive, Stakka and Skynet) to create
exclusive remixes of a variety of electronic music - from drum and bass to
filtered disco house to trance to West Coast hip-hop? Also, in the effort
to cross-pollinate scenes, why not get US artists to remix UK classics and
UK producers to remix American tracks?
      The ideas were fairly ambitious and risky - commissioning remixes
without being able to preview them - but if they worked the result would be
a groundbreaking cross-genre, cross-continental, truly human collaboration
of fresh new music. Higgins also scoured the Internet until he found the
voice heard in almost every Hollywood movie trailer, and scripted him for
the intro for the CD.
      "It was definitely a lot of blood, sweat and tears trying to get
everything tied together. Getting permission to get the remixes made,
motivating the original artists to dig up the samples for the remixers,
hassling everyone to turn in everything on time - there were moments when I
didn't think it was going to happen. In the end everything worked out
great. I am really proud of what I was able to accomplish with this CD. One
of the best things to come out of it was finding the time to get in the
studio to work on some of the remixes with my production partner Kaos and
my production team Weapon. The remix we did for Technical Itch's 'Reborn'
was something we were all pretty excited about."
      [Note to careful listeners:  Listen for the words "Planet of the
Drums" and "Reborn," and for a subtle blast from the past in the "outtro"
(hint: it's from "A Soldier's Story.")]
      Dieselboy became a label head when he used last year's stateside
release of "projectHUMAN" to launch his new drum and bass imprint HUMAN.
The first two 12"'s on the label featured tracks from the mix-CD:  Stratus
"You Must Follow" remixes and Styles of Beyond "Subculture" remixes.
Recently released was the blazing "Houston/Xanadu" 12" from Philadelphia
power producers Kaos, Karl K and Jae Kennedy and soon to be released is the
highly anticipated Bad Company UK remix 12" featuring the Stateside
reworkings of "Grunge 3" (Dieselboy, Kaos and Karl K remix) and "Mass
Hysteria" (Hive remix). Both of these tunes have been damaging dance floors
over the past couple of months. Upcoming HUMAN releases include the wicked
"Studio 54 / Moonraker" from Kaos, Karl K and Jae Kennedy, and possibly
"Plimsoul VIP" from Facs and B-Key featuring a remix from another great
American producer, E-Sassin.
            When Bad Company UK was looking to release "Shot Down on
Safari" in the States, they approached the HUMAN label. Upon the release of
the double-CD (which featured the US-only "Best of the Bad" mix-CD of their
greatest hits), Higgins began the badHUMAN tour with them and tour MC
Messinian. All involved were happy with the success of the tour that ended
in Puerto Rico on March 1. "It was one of the best tours I've been a part
of due to the consistency of the energy at the gigs. I think that the kids
were excited to see me touring with these guys. It was something a bit
different, and we each brought our own style and intensity of DJ'ing to the
shows. We had fun the whole time. In San Diego we even went skydiving for
the first time!" Higgins laughs.
      Most rewarding for Higgins were the friendships that developed during
the tour. "The Bad Company guys and I got to know each other on a more
personal level, beyond  just small talk at a random gig here and there or
reading about each other in the press. The badHUMAN tour was great not only
because the gigs were rocking, but because we all had the chance to spend
time together and talk about issues above and beyond music and scene
politics, like family, interests and other personal stuff. We had a chance
to see each other in a different light, more like real people, not just
people in the scene."
      The highlight of the badHUMAN tour was the 5th anniversary smashdown
of Platinum (Dieselboy's drum 'n' bass weekly) that featured Fresh, AK1200,
the Platinum Kru (DSL, Sine, Icon, MC Messinian, MC Armanni), and attended
by the cognoscenti of Philly's electronic music scene, including Josh Wink.
"We had to shut the door at 11:30 because the club was too full. At 1 am
there was still a line around the corner! We tried to really blow it out
this year by making admission free of charge and bringing in cases of free
champagne and a laser show. It was off the fucking hook!"
      Now Bad Company is returning the favor, touring the UK with DSL in
May to promote the European release of  "projectHUMAN." "With the Planet of
the Drums (AK1200, DJ Dara, DSL), it was the three big American drum 'n'
bass DJ's joining forces and working together to help bring even more
attention to jungle in the States and promote unity in the scene. Hopefully
this tour with Bad Company is the next step for unity on an international
level. I am extremely honored to be one of the first US guys to tour the UK
with artists of their caliber. Our collective hope is that people can
appreciate that we can ALL work together in this scene, no matter where you
come from. I respect the Bad Company guys for having the open-mindedness to
do something like this tour. First Marky represented for Brazil and now I
hope to follow Craze's footsteps and represent for the States."
      The youthful 30-year old Higgins, who has a computer degree from the
University of Pittsburgh, is an ex-skateboarder who says his fans, though
some are younger and older, are mostly ages 16 to 23. He still sports skate
T-shirts and says, "I think the vibe and speed of drum 'n' bass go hand in
hand with the intensity and high energy of skating, snowboarding and other
extreme sports."
      Higgins also enjoys playing shows outside the electronic music scene.
In recent years he's played skateboarding demos, radio festivals, and
surprisingly enough, rock concerts. "A few years back I opened for
Disturbed and Orgy, and last year Messinian and I opened for the bands
P.O.D. and System of a Down. It was definitely interesting playing hard
drum and bass to 8,000 teenagers in black T-shirts who have never heard the
music before. I love playing those shows though, not only because they are
challenging but because I know I am reaching out to a whole new audience."
One of the more interesting tours he was a part of was Moby's Area2 tour
last year which featured artists such as David Bowie, Busta Rhymes, Carl
Cox and John Digweed.
      When asked to explain the rise in popularity of drum and bass in the
US in recent years, Higgins says, "Here jungle is being viewed more and
more as main stage music. I've loved drum and bass for a long time, so I
feel it should have been as big as house and trance from day one. Some
people think that the music progression of jungle occasionally stagnates,
but I still think it changes quite a bit, constantly taking on new
influences and pushing in different directions. Drum and bass has a wicked
vitality and energy that the other genres simply don't have."
      Also out later this year will be a new record bag called KOTAN2,
which Higgins helped design for his sponsor, skate wear company DC Shoes.
"It's a pretty dope bag. After road testing the original KOTAN bag over the
past year, we made the new version extremely durable with slightly teched
out features, plenty of storage space and an extremely clean, minimal
look." Watch for its release sometime this fall.
      Currently, Higgins is gearing up to work on his next mix-CD. Though
he hasn't decided on a solid concept or title, he says it will be similar
to "projectHUMAN" with exclusive remixes of different genres of electronic
music (breaks, techno, house, trance, hip-hop, jungle) by artists from
different parts of the world. Higgins wants to work with more international
artists, continue to support the big American producers and of course,
bring in some of the heavy hitters from the UK. "With every CD I try to do
something different from the last.  'projectHUMAN' was slightly ambitious
and at this point I hope to continue to evolve and push the idea of what a
mix-CD is supposed to be, to try and set the bar higher for myself and all
of the other DJ's out there."
      The new anti-rave legislation at home is a downer. "We all hope the
legislation doesn't pass, but especially with all this war stuff going on,
it's hard not to feel a sense of helplessness that the government is going
to do whatever it wants to do. There will be meetings and fundraisers going
on in Miami at the Winter Music Conference. Hopefully we'll be able to stop
it like we did the last time. My fear is that it's going to pass, but my
hope is that even if it does we'll figure out a way to get around it or get
it revoked, prove that it's unconstitutional."
      But the upcoming trip across the Atlantic lifts his spirits. "I'm
looking forward to it. It will be fun playing to a new crowd in the
homeland of drum 'n' bass. I hope to bring something new to the table,
represent a different flavor. But at the end of the day, I'm just another
guy trying to push drum 'n' bass like everybody else in our scene.
Hopefully people in the UK appreciate what the US artists have to offer."

      mary ishimoto morris
      (pre-edited version)

Celebrate 12 Years of Free Form Funk with the full Wicked lineup!

Garth, Jeno, Markie Mark and Thomas!

Friday, April 18th.

At Audrey Joseph's new nightclub, Mezzanine, featuring a superb sound 
system from Funktion-One, (the people who built the Wicked Sound System) 
and a lovely sprung dance floor.

We're going to run all night, 11pm - 7am so we can watch the day break 
through the skylights (remember to bring your sunglasses).


Moksha Tribe

Subject: [sfraves] dj rap - was girl djs?

sorry to be so late to add to this thread, but thought some of you migh=
t
find this interview with dj rap (girl dj) of interest ...

DJ RAP:  WAY IN THE MIX

      You think you know, but you have no idea.
      All you really need to know about DJ Rap (aka Charissa Saverio) i=
s
that she will BLAST the dance floor with typhoon force, as she did on
February 8 at the packed  "Redwood Rap Session" at Buzz at Trust in
Baltimore (with DJ Bryce, Illy Emcee, Edan, Implicit). But she's even m=
ore
remarkable than that.
      The hot chick DJ you see on TV gleefully manning the turntables i=
n
the Twix commercial is also a singer/songwriter with her own band, a
promoter (an LA monthly called Hush Hush), the host of two radio shows =
(XM
satellite radio on The Move, and a rock station in Chicago), a label he=
ad
(Proper Talent), and the first female pioneer drum 'n' bass DJ and
producer. But wait, there's more.
      This Sagittarian's major passions are music (she's an avid pianis=
t),
Ninjitsu, and horseback riding. She also takes acting classes and might=

have a small part in an upcoming movie, will be making an interactive D=
VD a
la "Spinal Tap" about life on a tour bus with the "four most interestin=
g
DJ's on the planet," has a compilation CD coming out this year, and
surprise, she's begun producing and spinning breaks.
      Born in Singapore, the third oldest of three boys and three girls=
,
Saverio met her father only once. Her stepfather ran hotels around the
world and moved every 6 months, so rather than constantly moving the
children, they were placed in boarding schools, where she spent ages 6 =
to
10, after which she lived in a convent in Malta. When she was 12 she mo=
ved
with her family to England. When her family decided to move to America,=
 at
14 she left, moving into the UK rave scene and backpacking through Euro=
pe.
      "I was a lost teenager in a lot of pain, so I got into drugs. The=

fact that I'm successful and balanced  now and don't do drugs anymore i=
s a
miracle because it could have gone the other way." Saverio and her moth=
er,
who lives in Florida, worked hard to build their relationship and enjoy=

being close now.
      In 1990, DJ Rap produced her first track, "Ambience ? The Adored"=

which sold 40,000 copies. Her second, "Divine Rhythms" (1993) sold 50,0=
00
copies. Her third, "Spiritual Aura," made music history as one of the f=
irst
ambient jungle tracks. In 1994, DJ Rap launched her own label called
"Proper Talent," which released "Intelligent Woman" (1994), "Roughest
Gunark" (1995), "Rumble" (1996), and hit after hit. Proper Talent, stil=
l
"firing on all cylinders," is currently releasing "Crackdown" by Rage.
"Then we've got 'The Rift,' then my next single with a huge breaks tune=
 on
the other side called 'Out There.'"
      In 1998, the release of her first artist album "Learning Curve"
provoked cynical cries of "sell-out" from the drum 'n' bass community f=
or
crossing outside the genre, but it sold 250,000 copies worldwide, winni=
ng
DJ Rap many new fans. "People said, Oh, you shouldn't do that. But now =
look
- they're all doing it!" she laughs. Her second artist album is nearing=

completion.
      Saverio moved from England to Los Angeles in February 2002, but s=
till
goes back and forth. "In May I'm doing a tour in Europe so I'll be livi=
ng
in England for three months." One of the most in-demand DJ's in the wor=
ld,
DJ Rap constantly roves the globe. "Wherever I'm touring is my home."
      Music Monthly interviewed the charismatic DJ Rap at her hotel bef=
ore
her Buzz gig (a week after kicking off Buzzlife's first Chicago event),=

while she waited for word from the airport about her lost luggage.

Music Monthly:  You're independent, ambitious and gutsy. What were you =
like
as a child?

DJ Rap:  The first day I went to boarding school, me and my Mom walked =
up
this mountain in Pinang (Malaysia). I was six. We get to the entrance o=
f
the school and this is what I remember. Everyone in the class is making=

pottery, so I run in straightaway and start making an ashtray, and I tu=
rn
to look and my Mom is gone. The first night that I was at school, I sto=
le
all the other children's toys. I woke up the next day and the bed was f=
ull
of cuddly toys, and I was in everybody's bad books. I don't know what t=
hat
says about me (laughs) but I've always been that way. I always wanted t=
o be
loved so much. From the ages of 6 to 10, I never saw my family. So it w=
as
like, if I can't get attention from my parents, I'll get attention for
being as bad as possible, and maybe that will be something, you know.
      I was very rebellious, the clown of the class, always up for
anything, and completely a tomboy.  Very naughty, always running away,
stealing other people's children. 'You can come, too! Come on! It'll be=

fun! Your mom won't mind! Let's go!' (laughs) In England, not quite 14,=
 I
would dive off this bridge which was really high, be the first girl to =
jump
off or dive off, and the police would bring me home every day. Or I'd b=
e
shoplifting. All the classic signs of a child who's going through serio=
us
problems. I was probably just dying for some attention. Mom didn't know=

what to do with me. She was like, Why are you like this? And I would be=

like, 'Figure it out!' We just couldn't talk to each other. I was a
nightmare child.

MM: So your song "Bad Girl" ? is that about being a bad girl?

DJR: (laughs) No, this song was not about anything like that. My first
album, "Learning Curve," wasn't personal at all. It was about: I'm goin=
g to
let you see a little bit of me, but this is more about what I see about=

you. The new album I have coming out is completely personal; now I'm
prepared to let people a little bit more in. But this song was more lik=
e,
'Look how hard, how difficult, it is just to be a female in the world. =
Can
you imagine if you're Muslim, or you're born in Iraq, or you're born in=
 one
of these countries where women have their clitorises cut out?
      The first sentence is about that. (reads lyrics) "A silent
conversation passes through the world / A million voices who are never
really heard." This was triggered by the Muslim community. And: "There'=
s a
thousand reasons why our self-esteem can't stand." If we all got togeth=
er
and realized how empowering we could be, we wouldn't have the shit we h=
ave
to put up with in the world. And: "That glass ceiling should be radical=
ly
erased," is all about the DJ world and how as a girl people try and sto=
p
you. And: "I'm trying to show you that as friends we'd get along / Resp=
ect
my body 'cause that's where you came from." For men who treat women, yo=
ur
body, badly ? it's where you were born, it's where you come from. If yo=
u
don't have respect for women, then you don't have respect for yourself.=

I've lived in West Africa, Sierra Leone, Grenada. I've traveled a lot a=
nd
seen a lot of things and it really annoys me that in some countries if
you're pregnant out of wedlock you get stoned to death. "Bad Girl" was
about women all over the world, in the Third World, but it's for everyo=
ne
to interpret differently.

MM: How did your Twix commercial come about?

DJR:  They called my management and asked if I'd be interested in writi=
ng
the music for it, and if I'd be interested in starring in a commercial,=
 and
I was like, I'm a girl, I like chocolate:  Yes!  (laughs) It was very
simple. Chocolate? Yes! It's cool because I get a chance to bring that
music to a whole new audience. People who are slagging me off for doing=
 the
Twix commercial, it's so funny. It's like, oh my God, you don't underst=
and!
More people are hearing drum 'n' bass, and will be for a year, prime ti=
me,
on the TV.

MM: Has it had any affect on your DJ life?

DJR: I did a gig a few weeks ago where because I'd just shot the Twix
commercial, people were filming and taking pictures of me. I stopped th=
e
record and said, "Okay, people, two choices. You either dance or I leav=
e."
It went really quiet. I said, "I'm going to put this record on and eith=
er
you're going to dance, or I'm leaving 'cause this is so stupid," and it=
 was
really funny. People put their cameras down and started dancing and it
ended up being a great night. It's very rare that that happens, so that=
's
good. By the way, AM Only, they're such great agents. I'd like to say a=
 big
hello to Joel!

MM: Why did you pair up with Dieselboy for your Dirty Beats Tour last y=
ear?

DJR: He's the best DJ in America. He's a fantastic DJ. He cares about t=
he
music, he's very passionate about it. He makes great drum 'n' bass. I j=
ust
thought it would be really cool for us to do it together, so that's why=
. He
is a great person to tour with, so much fun, so professional. He knows =
how
to have a laugh, but he's very serious about what he does. Just from
touring with him, he made me want to try harder and be a better DJ than=
 I
was. He had really fresh cuts of music, and I had some fresh cuts but m=
aybe
not as fresh as I could have, and he made me think, I want to be the be=
st I
can be, always. Occasionally you meet a DJ who inspires you like that a=
nd
I've met a couple who really made me go, F#$@! I'd better do a little
better at this! Misstress Barbara was one and Dieselboy was the other.

[DJ Rap's cell phone rings. "Myron! How are you doing?" she says. She
whispers to me, "It's about  my luggage!" When she hangs up she says, "=
When
I went into the United office about my luggage, the guy recognized me! =
He
was like, '< Gasp! > You're DJ Rap! I have your record! I'll deliver yo=
ur
luggage! Can I come to your show?' It was so funny. He said he'll be he=
re
in 45 minutes. I've put him on the guest list for tonight. Isn't that
great?" (laughs) ]

MM:  What do you think about the anti-rave legislation in the US Congre=
ss?

DJR:  We had this in England and it didn't stop things there, it just
changed it. What are they going to do? Shut down every club in America?=

They make too much revenue. The dance scene is a huge income. In Englan=
d
they realized that eventually. They went, hold on a minute. Let's just =
make
it so they're legal, we can control it, and dadadada. At the end of the=

day, they can't stop the dance music industry.  They'd have to stop
concerts, they'd have to stop everything where drugs happen ? absolutel=
y
everywhere. There will be nowhere open! (laughs) I don't understand how=

they think they can pull this off. They have to address the issue of dr=
ugs.
It's like saying people only do drugs in clubs.  Get real! It's hilario=
us.
That's why it annoys me when films make the rave scene look so stupid a=
nd
all druggie. It's not like that, it's insulting, actually.

MM:  What's the status of your second artist album?

DJR:  I've been working on it ever since "Learning Curve," 2-3 years. T=
he
second album is so hard to make because for the first one, there are no=

expectations. The second one is like, hmm, how can I do something that =
is
not the same but still makes sense? I went off and worked with the best=

songwriters in the world, spent two years just writing songs. I've prob=
ably
written 500 tracks in the last two years, so the new songs are really
strong, really good and really meaningful. I'm working with different
producers all the time. I've just done some tracks with Erick Morillo, =
and
some with Richard Humpty Vision. I'm working with a lot of live instrum=
ents
this time, too. It's going to be quite different from the last one, but=

it's still firmly a DJ Rap record and it comes from all areas of dance
music, but I'm trying to make an album that will cross over at the same=

time. So we'll see. My title changes, but this month it's "Bulletproof.=
"

MM:  What's in your CD player right now?

DJR:  Here, I'll show you. Nirvana, the latest one with the new single.=

"Bulletproof." Radiohead, "Kid A." Foo Fighters, the new one. Christina=

Aguilera, the new one. You didn't expect that, did you? (laughs) Here's=

why, right? Not that she needs more press, and everyone's going to laug=
h
when I say Christina Aguilera, but here's the thing. I got this album
because I love that song, "Beautiful." So I listened to the album, and =
it's
great! The girl can sing! She's getting more depth, and I really feel s=
orry
for her because she has all these people saying negative stuff about he=
r.
If I had been famous in my teen-age years, you couldn't even print the
stuff I got up to. I don't care what she's like as a person. I feel ver=
y
protective towards her for some strange reason. Such a young girl, with=

such huge talent, and these songs are just great and I love it, it's my=

favorite album right now.

MM:  For up and coming female DJ's: how important are looks?

DJR:  It's a hard question because in all honesty we live in a world wh=
ere
it is about how you look.  I wish we lived in a world where it didn't
matter how you look, that it was really based on your talent, but in th=
e
music industry and in the entertainment industry, looks are a huge
three-quarters of the package for women, I think. I know it's definitel=
y
helped me because it means I get press, but at the end of the day I'm n=
ot
worried about it because I know I've got the talent to back it up. If y=
ou
have no talent, it doesn't matter how good looking you are. My advice t=
o
female DJ's is have a strong sense of yourself with the music you pick,=

play what you love, and do what you want to do.

MM:  Advice to up and coming guy DJ's?

DJR:  Same thing. Believe in yourself. Unshakable belief in yourself. B=
ut
be realistic. Know when you're crap, and know when you're good, and wor=
k on
the crap things. Don't be like, I'm great, I'm great. Look at where you=
're
not great and work on those things. A great person knows that they're n=
ot
perfect, and works on those imperfections.

MM:  Where were you on 9/11?

DJR:  I was in New York the night before. I flew back to England on
September 10, so on September 11, I was in the bank in England cashing =
and
putting in the money I'd made on tour and my phone started ringing
everywhere, people going, Are you okay? They said, Go home and put the =
TV
on. I rushed home and I couldn't believe it. I was really worried becau=
se
all of my management are in New York, and a lot of people I love and ca=
re
for were there, my whole family lives in America, and I couldn't get
through to anybody and it was really horrible. I think it's affected
everyone. I still think about it every day. Today especially, we're on =
high
alert now, so it's like, I'm getting on a plane, could something happen=
?
What would I do? But I also refuse to live my life in fear. You can't l=
ive
like that! If you go, you go. That's the way it is.

MM:  What are you contributing to society?

DJR:  A lot of the time I think I could be doing more. We're not saving=

lives with DJ'ing, but I forget how many people are really inspired by =
it,
that it means so much to so many people, which is why I do my website
(254,000 hits in the last three months) and why I answer fans every nig=
ht,
because it makes me realize how important this is to me and to other
people. Yesterday I was on a live radio show in Phoenix, KNRJ, and this=

six-year old called up. Her mom had let her stay up late, it was 10 o'c=
lock
at night, and she goes, my daughter wants to talk to you. I said, "What=
 do
you want to do when you grow up?" She said, "I want to be a DJ like you=
."
That's my contribution, I guess. It's like, yeah, now girls can do this=
,
too, it's a profitable, great career, and yeah, maybe I've made a lot o=
f
people happy and given people enjoyment with the music. If I die tomorr=
ow,
there would be two things. One, on my gravestone, it'll say "Gone to th=
e
Afterparty." (laughs) And I hope maybe people would say, I loved her mu=
sic,
and she broke some barriers. But there's a lot of stuff that I haven't =
done
yet that I want to do.
      I'm going to be in a documentary series called "The Power of Choi=
ce"
about child slave labor in Third World countries. They wanted someone w=
ho
has an audience of teenagers and I'm really excited because I'll actual=
ly
be doing something good for humans.  So yeah, sometimes I think I'm not=

doing anything that special, and other times I'm like, hold on a minute=
,
it's going to lead to something special.

mary ishimoto morris for music monthly 4/03 (pre-edited version)

          BSP:Girls Just Wanna Have Fun !UPDATE! April 4th 2003        =

                                                                       =



wow that was really rather enlightened and...not
chauvinistic of you, although I find it interesting
that there is an all girl line-up, and there is
something of a novelty to it.  As a chick it doesn't
bother me that ther IS a novelty to it, and I don't
think that people are like "wow that's a chick up
there djing" but anyway thats just me
--- Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com> wrote:
> (hahah not really-but i couldn't imagine a better
> attention-grabbing subject)
>
> I was just discussing this with an unnamed
> accomplice last week-
>
> Are we still in the stoneage here?
> There have been planty of girl djs for a long time.
> And today? they're all over the place.
> I remember a long time ago it was a novelty to have
> a girl in the linup-and a big event to have an
> all-girls thing like what's shown below-
> But today?
> It shouldn't be special that it's all-girl Djs, no
> more than it should be special that it is an
> all-black linup or something.
> Im trying to find the words to use-
> But uhm-part of acceptance and equality is
> non-segregation.
> And as long as people still have the "oh wow look a
> girl dj" attitude then djing will still be seen as
> something a girl "should not" be doing...
>
>
> On Mon, 31 Mar 2003 04:14:50 -0800, Josh.Illion
> <josh@globalparty.com> wrote:

Subject: [sfraves] It's baaaaaack - R.A.V.E. reincarnated

http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n420/a08.html?111

R.A.V.E. Reincarnated

You must wonder how a bill to rewrite statutes with almost a three decade
history dedicated solely a specific law and subject matter has now been
proposed to be broadened in scope to include all other vague descriptions
of activities once only pertained to crack, not the one in your ass or in
the sidewalk.

URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n395/a05.html
Newshawk: JimmyG
Pubdate: Thu, 13 Mar 2003
Source: Austin Chronicle (TX)
Copyright: 2003 Austin Chronicle Corp.
Contact: louis@auschron.com
Website: http://www.auschron.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/33
Author: Jordan Smith
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/mdma.htm (Ecstasy)

It's baaaack.

The proposed, and extremely draconian, Reducing Americans' Vulnerability
to Ecstasy ( RAVE ) Act has reemerged this Congressional session --
although it no longer bears that catchy little moniker.

The bill was filed last session by Sen. Joe Biden, D-Del., and proposed
extending the nets of the infamous Biden-sponsored Eighties "crack house
laws" by broadening their definition to include any businessperson, club
owner, or promoter on whose property or at whose events illicit drugs are
used or sold. The legislation was clearly aimed at squashing the rave
scene, but drug reformers and civil libertarians quickly cried foul at the
law's broad language, which could apply to any use of property, no matter
how "temporary," potentially including citizens who use drugs in their own
homes. Representatives from the ACLU, Students for Sensible Drug Policy,
and other reformers took their ire to Capitol Hill last fall when they
staged a rave dance-rally in the halls of Congress. Shortly thereafter,
the bill began to hemorrhage sponsors and then quietly disappeared.

That is, until this month, when it cropped up again attached to an omnibus
domestic-security bill -- the Justice Enhancement and Domestic Security
Act of 2003, sponsored by Tom Daschle, D-S.D. -- in a section on
"Crack-House Statute Amendments." The ploy -- attaching a controversial
provision to a fuzzy-bunny bill that no one is likely to vote against --
is common.

Indeed, the revamped RAVE Act has been dumped into legislation whose other
provisions would help protect missing and exploited children, senior
citizens, and rape victims, and would combat telemarketing fraud and
identity theft.

But RAVE wasn't hidden well enough to evade the eyes of drug reformers,
who are planning once again to protest.

For more info, check out the Drug Policy Alliance Web site at www.dpa.org.
..."

-- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

At 03:10 PM 4/5/2003 -0800, Karina wrote:
>http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n420/a08.html?111
>
>R.A.V.E. Reincarnated
>
>You must wonder how a bill to rewrite statutes with almost a three decade
>history dedicated solely a specific law and subject matter has now been
>proposed to be broadened in scope to include all other vague descriptions
>of activities once only pertained to crack, not the one in your ass or in
>the sidewalk.

I must have written thirty personalized letters on this legislation to my 
representatives in the Senate and House, including a ten page fax.  The 
most reasonable reply I've received so far has been from Nancy Pelosi, 
Democratic Leader in the House of Representatives.  Some relevant sections 
of her response to my letters appear below:

"I am aware of concerns that the language in these bills (RAVE Act (H.R. 
718) and the CLEAN-UP Act (H.R. 834) may be overly broad and could 
disproportionately target certain music genres or audiences.

The use of ecstasy and other club drugs has increased dramatically over the 
past three years, and its detrimental effects on our youth and community 
need to be addressed.  I strongly believe that education of young people is 
the best way.  Adequate funding should be supported through the National 
Institutes of Health to support and promote educational incentives to 
inform people of the dangers of ecstasy.

The RAVE Act and the CLEAN-UP Act have been referred to the Subcommittee on 
Health and the Subcommittee on Education Reform respectively.  Please be 
assured that I will keep your views in mind should either of these bills 
come before the full House."

This letter from Pelosi was sent to me on April 1.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe

are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and

-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

Subject: [sfraves] "Down Riverside"   by boomerang     (nrr)

My website is down, but I wanted to let y’all know I’m
still spinning yarns.  This one is dedicated to
Captain Fidget, who piloted the largest cargo ships in
the world, and used the stars to navigate.  Rest in
peace, Papa.

love, 
Boomy

……………………………
Down Riverside
by Boomerang Fidget (Peter Sandifer)  ©2003

We all knew Pup wouldn’t last long in Oakland.  The
kid wanted it all yesterday, and didn’t have time to
learn the rules of the game. 

That’s why none of us was surprised when Pup busted
into Jeremiah’s crib on Gilead Street, spilling
breathless about how Death was coming for him. We
thought maybe Pup had gotten a taste of the product in
the bags. His dome was shiny with sweat and his mouth
was full of babble; eyes darting and steady leaping
with fear.  

Jeremiah would squash Pup if he caught him sticking
his sniffer in the merchandise.  But we soon realized
that it wasn’t the dope that had gotten to his
grapefruit, but something else.  

Jeremiah took off his headphones and skidded the
record to a stop.  We all waited solemnly.  As a
habit, we never spoke before Jeremiah.

“I was hustling baggies down at Gilead and Six,” Pup
sputtered,  “When this car roll up.  A Lincoln
Continental, black as a hearse and bumpin out these
spooky-ass beats from the trunk.  Motherfucker behind
the wheel call me over, like he want the goods.  Then
he look at me with these black eyes.  It was Death,
man! The motherfucker come for me!  He still circling
the block like a chopper right now!  Bitch won’t
leave!  You gotta send me somewhere safe, Jeremiah!”

Jeremiah lifted the curtain and scoped, real
sniper-like and cool.  Now the spooky motherfucker in
the black Lincoln was parked right out front.  He was
dressed in a sharp tuxedo, dandy as an uptown bitch. 
We could see the man’s eyes, steady cold like a
nightmare.

Jeremiah didn’t like it one bit.  He dug into his
pocket and came up with a wad of cash for Pup. “Get to
the airport.  Catch a flight down Riverside.  Stay up
with Zip and Coochie a few days.  Tell Zip I say take
care of you.  I’ll call down when the coast is clear.”

“It’s Death.  Death comin for me.” Pup moaned, and
then he slipped out the back door into the alley.  Pup
would be fine.  Zip ran a tight safehouse down
Riverside. 

Jeremiah tucked his piece into his belt, and we
followed him out onto Gilead Street.  He went straight
up to the creepy bitch in the Lincoln. We stood back,
in Jeremiah’s shadow.

“What you trying to pull, scaring off my runner like
that?”  Jeremiah demanded.    He lifted up his shirt a
bit, flashing his steel in the afternoon sun. 

The cat smiled when he saw the .45, like it was
yesterday’s joke.  His teeth were yellow and old, his
eyes an empty vault. When he rolled down the window,
we could smell the inside of his car, the must of
ancient air.  

A creepy beat was booming low in the trunk; ghetto
synth and a heavy kick drum that bothered your soul. 
The air was hot and uncomfortable. All the
gang-bangers had scattered like ripples, and Gilead
Street felt desolate and lonely.  Our nerves were
barbed wire.

The spooky cat lifted an elegant hand and said
politely, “I didn’t mean to frighten your employee. 
But understand, I was surprised to see him here in
Oakland, because I have an appointment with the
motherfucker down Riverside tonight.”

_________________
* Down Riverside is a retelling of an Arabian folk
story.
See also Jeremiah 8:22…  “Is there no balm in Gilead? 
Is there no physician there?  Why then is there no
healing for the wound of my people?”

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) hi and a physics question.

hi,

after about a year and thanks to cell phone technology, i'm back online!

looks like a lot of people i know are still on the list, so hi to 
them ... and hi to the people i've never seen before either.  been 
hanging around this list off and on for like 9 years now or so ... 
maybe sfr will someday have a silver anniversary ... but had to unsub 
cause i was traveling and didn't want to overload my inbox, cause we 
know how chatty it gets here.

anyway, last we left, i had "transferred command codes" to osby and 
made him the city's gatekeeper.  interesting story, eh?  osby sent me 
a message saying thanks though he didn't understand what that meant. 
lately, i've been standing around scratching my head wondering what i 
might have meant too.  and i guess i just came to the conclusion it 
probably means something, but i don't necessarily feel as strongly 
about it as i did then.

on a personal symbolic level, at one time i felt it was my duty to 
watch over 'my' city though i'm not the only one born in SF, and to 
root out all the snobby people.  well, oddly enough, i recently 
visited SF again and it seems like the city's a lot more relaxed now; 
if nothing else, i can find a place to park when i go out again!

i'm kind of in the process of traveling to the washington DC area, 
where i should be for the next few years, assuming all goes well.  my 
website is currently sort of down, but in the near future i may put 
it up again with some new pictures and perhaps even new mixes, like 
that mix called 'snow watch' i've been meaning to make, but don't 
know if i will by the time i lose interest in the name.

and now, a quick question about physics, in case anyone is willing to 
tackle this one.  the other night i was getting drunk with some 
friends out here, and we were arguing about light.  does light take 
up space?  i think light is a by-product of some type of reaction, 
and it is energy.  does it take up space in a room?  like could you 
fill the room with enough light you couldn't fit any more, let's say? 
inquiring minds want to know.

i wish all the sfravErs a happy week!

deepfog

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) hi and a physics question.

--=======3AE55BC=======
Content-Type: text/plain; x-avg-checked=avg-ok-18E8665B; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

AFAIK, and IANAE,

Light is both energy and takes up space - sometime it behaves like a wave, 
and sometimes it behaves like a particle.  I don't think you could "fill a 
room with light" because I don't think we have full control over whether it 
acts like a particle or wave; we can just observe it in both states.

for a much deeper look into photons and physics, check out:

http://www.mic-d.com/curriculum/lightandcolor/particleorwave.html


sarilion

>and now, a quick question about physics, in case anyone is willing to 
>tackle this one.  the other night i was getting drunk with some friends 
>out here, and we were arguing about light.  does light take up space?  i 
>think light is a by-product of some type of reaction, and it is 
>energy.  does it take up space in a room?  like could you fill the room 
>with enough light you couldn't fit any more, let's say? inquiring minds 
>want to know.
>
>i wish all the sfravErs a happy week!
>
>deepfog
>

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] A Concert of the Arts - Sat. 4.12.03

// Saturday April 12
Second Saturday ArtWalk Festivities


Liquidcafe.com proudly presents...

Merge 3-year anniversary production

                  A CONCERT OF THE ARTS
                   Midtown, Sacramento

                Special musical guests:

        BOX JAZZ TRIO [ live jazz performance ]

Box Jazz Trio is:
MAX HART, piano (Los Angeles)
Studied jazz piano and organ with Larry Goldings. Band leader for LA
rock group “Highspeed Scene”. Keyboardist for solo artist “Kenna”.

GEORGE BAN-WEISS, bass (Berkeley)
Engineering major at UC Berkeley. Jazz tutelage by resident pianist/jazz 
educator Bevan, jazz dept. UC Berekeley.

JAMES NEIL, drums (Sacramento)
Studied jazz with Dr. Joe Gilman, American River College; Monterrey Jazz 
Festival representative; performances in Europe, Australia, and New Zealand. 
Guest performance @ Capitol Jazz Project


“It’s fair to say that all the musicians in our trio are versatile; jazz is 
what we come together to play. The trio setting allows us all a lot of space 
creatively to stretch things out. Soloists stretch out
individually during improvisation. Because of our collective experience
we are able to go “out” together. Almost everything can be stretched and 
shaped when we play: harmony and melody, rhythm, song form.”
                                         -- James Neil

Standards/Interpreted Material/Influences:
Miles Davis, John Coltrane, McCoy Tyner, Bill Evans, Brad Mehldau, and
Larry Goldings


Also featuring:

MICHAEL YAGER, comedian, actor
[ A unique comedic performance with selections from his one-man show,
“Man of the House.” Accompanied by Vinyl Artist Paul Gordon spinning
slick jazz, gospel, pop, and rock tunes ]

   -- Funky Symphony & Feel-good Vibes --
        provided by Vinyl artists:

    [ Jazzy/Deep house ]
    Kiyoshi 1 (Scientists of Sound, Santa Cruz)
    D’John (WUE, Sac)
    The Emperor’s Jazz (liquidcafe.com, Sac)

    [ Soulful & Ambient Drum n Bass ]
    Adria (Liquidcafe.com, Sac)
    Rouge (Momo Lounge/Plush, Stockton)


Works of Art:

// COALITION OF AFRO AMERICAN ARTISTS (Ronn Turner, Curator)
   Traveling exhibit of afro american works.
// STERLING GALLERY [ Pieces from the gallery ]
// SHAUN TURNER & KEVIN PRICE [ Abstract ]
// AMY ZEHNER [ Photographic Artist ]

Two Rooms of Aural and Visual stimuli.
Stylish, hip venue.

Sound:  Summit Sessions


Showtime: 9pm
18 and over
Full bar 21+ w/ID

Infoline: 916.466.9113  / 415.303.7404

Admission Affordable: No more than 8 bucks! (price roll-back!)
Unheard of in this day of 60 dollar ticket prices!!
*sorry no comp passes*


It is important that Price Point be attractive, so everyone can afford
it. This is about bringing a quality event to our community. We just want 
you all to be able to come and enjoy the show.

NOTE: This event is in conjunction with Sacramento's monthly Second
Saturday Art-Walk festivities in galleries around the midtown area. Plan 
your evening's logistics for maximum pleasure!


Liquidcafe.com
"Devoted to bringing the highest quality entertainment to Sacramento and 
surrounding communities."

I think when you have the ability to fill a room with enough light, it
would more act like a black hole?  Where the sheer massiveness of the
particles in the room exceeds its capicity and grows dark and suck in
every available bit of light and swells in size as it become super
compressed.  Of course what do I know... I failed physics on purpose and
tried to blow up my teacher because I didn't like him.

-----Original Message-----
From: Sarilion [mailto:sarilion@sarilion.org] 
Sent: Monday, April 07, 2003 9:38 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) hi and a physics question.


AFAIK, and IANAE,

Light is both energy and takes up space - sometime it behaves like a
wave, 
and sometimes it behaves like a particle.  I don't think you could "fill
a 
room with light" because I don't think we have full control over whether
it 
acts like a particle or wave; we can just observe it in both states.

for a much deeper look into photons and physics, check out:

http://www.mic-d.com/curriculum/lightandcolor/particleorwave.html


sarilion

>and now, a quick question about physics, in case anyone is willing to
>tackle this one.  the other night i was getting drunk with some friends

>out here, and we were arguing about light.  does light take up space?
i 
>think light is a by-product of some type of reaction, and it is 
>energy.  does it take up space in a room?  like could you fill the room

>with enough light you couldn't fit any more, let's say? inquiring minds

>want to know.
>
>i wish all the sfravErs a happy week!

From sfraves-return-100870-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Apr 07 20:00:22 2003

Subject: [sfraves] [Fwd: Emergency Action - RAVE Act Moving - Contact Your Senator
	Now]

*** EMERGENCY - JOE BIDEN TRYING TO SNEAK RAVE ACT INTO S151   
    Conference 
*** CALL YOUR SENATOR NOW

Senator Joe Biden (D-DE) is at this very moment attempting to sneak 
the RAVE Act into conference committee on the National AMBER Alert 
Network Act of 2003 (S151).  S151 is a popular bill about child 
abduction and has nothing to do with drug issues.  S151 has already 
been passed by the Senate and House and is now in Conference.  In 
contrast, the RAVE Act has not passed even one single committee this 
year.  It did pass a committee last year, but was so controversial 
two Senators withdrew their sponsorship after the vote.  

This means that if the RAVE Act passes the conference committee, it 
is likely to become law without ever having a hearing, a debate or a 
vote.  Drug Policy Alliance has been told that Senator Biden has told 
other conference committee members, incorrectly, that the ACLU is no 
longer in opposition to the action.  He also has told conferees that 
nightclub owners now support him (on the basis of one group that 
switched sides).  If the act makes it into the conference language it 
is likely to become law.  It must be stopped now.

PHONE YOUR SENATORS and Conference Committee Members (Background 
information below).  DO IT NOW.  If you do not respond to this alert, 
the controversial RAVE Act is likely to become law and it will be 
much harder to fix.  

ACTIONS TO TAKE:

1.  The following Members of Congress are on the conference 
committee.  They need to hear from you IF AND ONLY IF you live in 
their district.  Please be polite.  Just tell them that you oppose 
the RAVE Act, that it is controversial and it should not be included 
in the conference language of S151.  Don't stay on the phone long.  
Ask as many people as you can to call them.

HOUSE:
James Sensenbrenner (R-WI) - 202/225-5101
Howard Coble (R-NC) - 202/225-3065
Lamar Smith (R-TX) - 202/225-4236
Mark Green (R-WI)- 202/225-5665
Melissa Hart (R-PA)- 202/225-2565
John Conyers (D-MI) - 202/225-5126
Bobby Scott (D-VA) - - 202/225-8351

SENATE:
Orrin Hatch (R-UT) - 202/224-5251
Charles Grassley (R-IA) - 202/224-3744
Jeff Sessions (R-AL) - 202/224-4124
Lindsey Graham (R-SC) - 202/224-5972
Patrick Leahy (D-VT) - 202/224-4242
Ted Kennedy (D-MA) - 202/224-4543
Joseph Biden (D-DE) - 202/224-5042

2.  Everyone in the U.S. - You have two Senators who can weigh in on 
this issue with the conferees.  A list of your Senators by state can 
be found at 
http://www.senate.gov/general/contact_information/senators_cfm.cfm.  
Please call your Senators at the Capitol Switchboard at 202/224-3121 -
 please tell them that the RAVE Act is very controversial.  Senator 
Biden is holding up the AMBER Act by placing controversial bill in 
conference.  Urge them to oppose the RAVE Act by contacting the 
Senate conferees and asking them to leave it off the measure so that 
there will at least be a hearing on this issue.  

BACKGROUND INFORMATION

Congress is considering two pieces of legislation that could create 
disincentives for club owners to have water, ambulances and 
paramedics available at large dance events.  The bills might also 
threaten live music and dancing. If enacted, either bill could 
prevent you from hearing your favorite band or DJ live. Every musical 
style would be affected, including rock and roll, Hip Hop, country, 
and electronic music. The proposed laws could also shut down hemp 
festivals, circuit parties, and other events government officials 
don't like. Both bills would allow overzealous prosecutors to send 
innocent people to jail for the crimes of others. 

The two bills are the RAVE Act (H.R. 718) and the CLEAN-UP Act (H.R. 
834). The RAVE Act was first introduced last year in the Senate by 
Senator Joe Biden (D-DE). A House version was introduced by Rep. 
Lamar Smith (R-TX). Thanks to the support of thousands of voters like 
you, Drug Policy Alliance and a coalition of friends and activists 
around the country was able to stop both bills last year. 
Unfortunately, supporters of the RAVE Act are even more determined to 
pass it this year. Rep. Howard Coble (R-NC) is sponsoring a new RAVE 
Act in the House. Additionally, Senator Biden has introduced a Senate 
version entitled the Illicit Drugs Anti-Proliferation Act.

If enacted, the RAVE Act would make it easier for the federal 
government to punish property owners for any drug offense that their 
customers commit - even if they work hard to stop such offenses. If 
enacted, nightclub and stadium owners would likely stop holding 
events - such as rock or Hip Hop concerts - in which even one person 
might use drugs. 

The CLEAN-UP Act was also first introduced last year, but it failed 
to make it out of committee. This year's bill has over 60 co-sponsors 
and could become law without your help. Sponsored by Rep. Doug Ose (R-
CA), the Clean, Learn, Educate, Abolish, and Undermine Production 
(CLEAN-UP) of Methamphetamines Act is largely an innocuous bill that 
provides more money and training for the clean up of illegal 
methamphetamine lab. Hidden within the bill, however, is a draconian 
section that could make dancing and live music federal crimes.

Section 305 of the CLEAN-UP Act stipulates that: 

`Whoever, for a commercial purpose, knowingly promotes any rave, 
dance, music, or other entertainment event, that takes place under 
circumstances where the promoter knows or reasonably ought to know 
that a controlled substance will be used or distributed in violation 
of Federal law or the law of the place where the event is held, shall 
be fined under title 18, United States Code, or imprisoned for not 
more than 9 years, or both.'

This provision will allow any concert promoter, event organizer, 
nightclub owner and arena or stadium owner to be fined and jailed, 
since a reasonable person would know some people use drugs at musical 
events. 

Under both the RAVE Act and the CLEAN-UP Act, it doesn't matter if 
the event promoter and property owner try to prevent people from 
using drugs. Nor does it matter if the vast majority of people 
attending the event are law-abiding citizens that want to listen to 
music not do drugs. If enacted, either bill could be used to shut 
down raves, circuit parties, marijuana rallies, unpopular music 
concerts, and any other event federal officials don't like.

++++++++++++++++++++++++You received this message because
andy@tiedye.com is a member of the mailing list originating 
from alerts@actioncenter.drugpolicy.org. 

Please visit 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.ctsg.com/managesubscription.asp to 
learn about other lists you can subscribe to, or to unsubscribe from 
individual or all lists. 

For problems, please contact Jeanette Irwin at jirwin@drugpolicy.org .

Please join the Drug Policy Alliance:
http://www.drugpolicy.org/join
Ride the Music

AndyTiedye

Subject: [sfraves] Oppose the Culture War on Raves

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Oppose the Culture War on Raves


Members of both the House and Senate are attempting to pervert proper 
legislative processes by appending two unrelated provisions to the popular 
Amber Alert measure.  One of the two provisions would target raves -- a 
social event that mixes electronic music, light shows and dancing; the 
other provision would seek to limit the discretion of federal judges.


The rave provision would make building owners liable for their tenants' and 
customers' activities.  For example, even if they instituted excellent 
security precautions, restaurant, bar, nightclub, dance and music venue 
owners could all be fined hundreds of thousands of dollars and forced into 
bankruptcy if a customer sneaked in drugs. No matter how much security is 
put in place, they could be held responsible for the actions of just one 
customer.


The federal sentencing provision would require the Justice Department to 
report to Congress every time federal judges use their discretion to impose 
a lower sentence than recommended under federal sentencing 
guidelines.  This would intimidate judges and prevent them from using their 
judgement when handing down sentences.


These anti-civil liberties amendments should have full legislative review 
and not be allowed to piggyback on more popular, yet unrelated, legislation.


Take Action! Click here for more information and to urge proper legislative 
process for these provisions:


http://www.aclu.org/DrugPolicy/DrugPolicy.cfm?ID=12280&c=185



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

I should have prefixed this by noting the proposed legislation is a new 
attempt at passing Draconian laws against both rave and club events.  Since 
the prior two laws are tied up in subcommittees, this stuff is embedded in 
the popular Amber Alert legislation to more easily facilitate passage.  So 
if you sent letters and faxes before, send another batch now.

You can voice you opposition to this devious attempt at suppression of our 
culture by simply clicking on the link below.  ACLU will send a fax to your 
reps.  Takes less than a minute.  Do it now.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) hi and a physics question.

quoth Rayn:
> I think when you have the ability to fill a room with enough light, it
> would more act like a black hole?  Where the sheer massiveness of the
> particles in the room exceeds its capicity and grows dark and suck in
> every available bit of light and swells in size as it become super
> compressed.

Actually, photons are, for all intensive purposes, massless particles,
so they can't "fill" space. You'd need an infinite amount of light to
"fill" any given volume... which would, as you've pointed out, produce a
singularity. But by then, any semblance of a "room" that enclosed the
light would be long gone!

So no, you can't "fill" a room with light. :)
