MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:US OR: Glass Artists' Arrests Stoke 'Culture War' 

"...US OR: Glass Artists' Arrests Stoke 'Culture War'
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n380/a07.html
Newshawk: allan
Pubdate: Sun, 09 Mar 2003
Source: Register-Guard, The (OR)
Copyright: 2003 The Register-Guard
Contact: rgletters@guardnet.com
Website: http://www.registerguard.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/362
Author: Bob Keefer

GLASS ARTISTS' ARRESTS STOKE 'CULTURE WAR'

For six years, Jason Harris and Saeed Mohtadi ran their glass pipe
businesses entirely in the open.

Harris sold the smoking pipes through his retail store, Higher Source, at
133 E.  13th Ave.  The two men advertised and sold glass pipes on the
Internet, using such domain names as ghettoweb.com.  Anyone could buy one
of their pipes - which are of a kind commonly used for smoking marijuana -
with a Visa card.  Harris and Mohtadi apparently believed that the pipes,
which were advertised for use with tobacco or incense, were legal.

What they didn't know until quite recently was that agents of the federal
Drug Enforcement Administration were conducting a detailed investigation
of their businesses, involving "undercover" buys from the wide-open
businesses, secret surveillance and even a "trash pull," in which agents
rifled through the businesses' garbage.

Last month, as part of a nationwide bust called Operation Pipe Dreams,
agents swept in and arrested the two businessmen, charging them with
selling drug paraphernalia.  They each face three years in prison and
$250,000 fines, as well as forfeiture of their businesses and homes.
Across the country, 50 people were arrested in the sweep, the biggest drug
paraphernalia clampdown in the agency's history.

The arrests point up a series of deep fault lines in American culture:
over marijuana, over art, over free expression, even over states' rights.

Most of the plain facts in the Harris and Mohtadi cases are not in
dispute.  They are also somewhat unusual for a criminal case.

Harris and Mohtadi ran a national distribution company for pipes made by
Harris' firm, Jerome Baker Designs.  They had employees.  They paid taxes.
They advertised.  Their pipes were labeled "for tobacco use only" or
labeled as incense burners and can, in fact, be used to smoke tobacco or
burn incense.  Harris and Mohtadi seemed to believe that their businesses
had stayed on the legal side of federal law, which bars the sale of items
"primarily intended" for drug use.

The law, 21 U.S.  Code Section 863, originally was enacted as part of the
Controlled Substances Act of 1970.  It has been challenged repeatedly as
unconstitutionally vague but has withstood legal tests up to the Supreme
Court.  It specifically bars the sale of glass smoking pipes, as well as
those made of almost any other material, but allows pipes "traditionally
intended for use with tobacco." In determining what use a pipe is intended
for, officials can look in part at how it was advertised and what the
makers and retailers say it should be used for, the law says.

Broader issues erupted as well with the arrests here.  Harris and Mohtadi
have been heavily involved with the burgeoning art glass scene in Eugene.
Their arrests seem, to some, an attack on an underground art form that's
grown up in Lane County over the past generation.

"This has very little to do with drugs," said Lane Arts Council Executive
Director Douglas Beauchamp.  "It's part of a culture war.  I have a
personal take on this.  It has to do with the chilling of America as
fostered by ( Attorney General John ) Ashcroft, and going after people who
make craft items, artifacts, art, and wrapping it all into a coarse and
repressive attack."

But is it art?

Alder Gallery owner Candy Moffett, who has shown glass art ( though not
pipes ) by Harris at her Coburg gallery, says all his work - pipes
included - - is artistic.

"Are the glass pipes art?" she said.  "Yes.  Just as Jason has a control
and mastery of the medium, I think his pipes are artworks.  They are done
in such a masterful way, they are sculptures.  Look at meerschaum pipes.
There are meerschaum pipes considered sculptures.  These are, too."

At the Drug Enforcement Administration office in Portland, Ken Magee,
assistant special agent in charge, scoffed at the notion that glass pipes
could be considered art.

"I find that somewhat laughable, referring to drug paraphernalia as
collectible art," he said.  "I find it somewhat engaging that you would
refer to this as 'collectible art' when it's drug paraphernalia."

Magee, who said he had little time to discuss issues surrounding the case,
bristled when asked whether it makes sense to conduct a nationwide
drug-paraphernalia bust even as the nation fights terrorism at home and
across the globe and heads for war in Iraq.

"The DEA enforces drug laws within the state of Oregon as well as within
the United States," he said.  "We collectively as an agency will define
our priorities on a day-to-day basis.  It is quite obvious that an
investigation of this magnitude doesn't happen overnight."

Nationwide, the DEA has enthusiastically sought to enlarge the definition
of paraphernalia, sometimes running into First Amendment and artistic
expression issues.

Last year, a federal judge in Louisiana granted a permanent order sought
by the American Civil Liberties Union to stop the DEA from classifying
glow sticks and pacifiers at rave concerts as drug paraphernalia.

A market for other glass

Harris and Mohtadi were substantial contributors to and members of the
board of directors at Eugene Glass School, a 4-year-old nonprofit
institute founded, at least in part, to show Lane County bong makers that
a market exists for other glass as well.

In addition, Mohtadi was treasurer of the school and Harris served in an
unofficial role as coordinator, making sure the kilns were running and
supplies were on hand each day.  They both resigned from the board and
other duties shortly after the arrests.

George Kjaer, a retired physician who helped start the school, said the
Eugene Glass School has always insisted on a "Chinese wall" between the
art glass it teaches and the bong-making that has supported many of its
students.

"We have worked diligently to create a significant barrier not only
between the school and these two companies but against the production and
utilization of paraphernalia on our campus and in our teaching programs,"
he said.  "We have tried to stimulate these artisans to think in terms of
fine art.  We have gone out of our way to seek people who would otherwise
have been dropouts but have found a voice in art."

Adding to the culture-war perception is the fact that the two men are
being charged and prosecuted not here in Eugene but in Pittsburgh, Pa.,
where a large retailer selling their pipes was arrested.

After arresting the Pittsburgh retailer, DEA officials in that region
broadened their quest and began surveillance of Harris' and Mohtadi's
businesses in Eugene.

The 47-page affidavit supporting the federal search warrant used in the
arrest lists in detail the steps agents took:

In June 2000, two men were convicted in Pittsburgh of selling drug
paraphernalia that they had obtained wholesale from Jerome Baker Designs.
Following a simple trail of public records, agents identified Harris and
Mohtadi last August.

In September, agents "located and observed" the Higher Source store and,
"acting in undercover capacities," entered the store and "observed
hundreds of Jerome Baker Designs items."

While in the store, the undercover agent was told by "an unidentified
male" that Jerome Baker Designs was named after the late musician Jerry
Garcia and "baker," slang for a marijuana user.

Also in September, agents bought $741.79 worth of glass pipes, including
"1 Extra Fancy Phat Mama Bong" at $184, through ghettoweb.com, paying for
it with a Visa card.

Eugene lawyer Greg Veralrud, who is representing Mohtadi, said it was too
early to talk about any specific defense to the federal charges, but laid
out several possibilities.

Pennsylvania's burghers

Veralrud said he may seek a change of venue to bring the case back to
Eugene.  All Mohtadi's witnesses are here and would have to fly to
Pennsylvania to testify.

Is the DEA venue shopping by filing its charges in a culturally
conservative district in Pennsylvania?

"People in Oregon tend not to be as troubled" by marijuana-related issues,
Veralrud said, adding that the fact his client advertised on the Internet
may have been a key factor in his arrest.

"The impression is, 'If you kept this in your own back yard we wouldn't
bother you.  The god-honest burghers of Pennsylvania won't put up with the
liberal high-falutin' dope-smokin' ways of Eugene, Oregon.' "

Veralrud added that the federal government has long been unhappy with
Oregon's medical marijuana law.

"We have a fairly mature medical marijuana program.  It's become something
the public is ever more accepting of.  I have to think we have an
environment where even among folks who don't agree with using marijuana,
they are generally more accepting of the fact that others do," he said.

The lawyer also said that, given the seriousness of the charges, a plea
bargain is always a possibility.  "My client is a young man with a young
family.  I know he's also in a little bit of a quandary.  He made an
effort to do this aboveboard.  There is not a whiff of unlawful activity.
He's never been secretive about it."

--

Bad breath is bad - yes.  Keep brushing and flossing, and do they still make that BreathAssure stuff to take away onion breath after In-N-Out?  I smell like garlic-n-onion chips right now.  Where’s my crest?
"Don’t linger on a stranger’s cheek" – agreed; tricky move that requires tact, objectivity and awareness.  But sometimes it’s the right call.
>“speaking as a boy who usually leaves the girls alone, I’d say your  advice is pretty sound.  I’m >always in doubt, so I usually don't  bother.  everybody wins!”
Disagree.  “when in doubt, don’t” doesn’t work for me, nor Jacob apparently, because there is ALWAYS some doubt (at least for 95% of us).  If no one ever bothers due to the fear of rejection then, in my opinion, we all loose.  I mean “how trivial and boring would that be?” indeed.  
If I walk up to you on the street/ store/ club/ restaurant/ party/ etc. to be friendly and say hi, well as long as I am respectful it’s all good.  If I grab your ass as you walk by, yeah that’s pig-headed juvenile ignorance in action that shouldn’t have to be tolerated.  By you or anyone else.
But my point is, you have to take chances in life, including mustering up enough confidence to start talking to whomever it may be that makes your heart jump out of your chest.  Not interested? Just say so.  If you get offended by my chivalrous attempt at a conversation, even if it is corny and not quite suave, well I’m sorry.  I know I got good intentions.  And if some physical attribute of mine offends you?  Depending on what we’re talking about, I would mostly just say sorry, get over it.  Maybe you’re missing something else that should really be getting the attention.  And maybe not.  But never apologize for being friendly.

Subject: Re: [sfraves]How did you get started DJing?

Check it out,
   I just got my decks like a month and a half ago and for a long time I 
deliberated on getting cheaper tables or a boxed set to learn.  Boy am I 
glad that I waited.  A friend told me that you should get the equipment that 
you plan to keep and not to plan on upgrading because it is so difficult to 
get the money to spend for the upgrade when you already have equipment.  
People always push the 1200's, and mind you, there is a good reason for 
that.  They are excellent tables, but I have spun on a variety of tables and 
I decided to go with the Numark TTX1's.  They are the high end digital 
tables.  They have some cool features that the 1200's don't, like reverse 
and a lot larger range of a pitch control for when you are trying to get a 
little bit ridiculous and beat match John Denver with your happy hardcore 
collection (I do not support John Denver and I don't spin HHC, just an 
idea), or whatever.  In any case, whatever tables you decide on, make sure 
that you are happy with them and that you would like to keep them for a 
while because it generally takes an eternity and a half to upgrade.  Good 
luck with your one-man superstar show and keep us all posted on your 
progress. -Trendy

Subject: [sfraves] RE: How did you get started DJing?


When I got started Djing I couldn=92t afford technics either.  So with $27 =
I made from selling crack I converted my old BMX bike and two hubcaps off a=
 Pontiac Fiero into a makeshift turntable package.  For a mixer, I simply r=
ewired my Mom=92s 8-Trac.  This may sound like a pretty janky setup, but si=
nce I had to constantly reach under the decks to spin the pedal crankshaft =
to adjust the speed, I got pretty good at pitch control and the ability to =
make fine-tuning adjustments.  :P

Subject: Re: [sfraves]How did you get started DJing?

I don't have my own equipment, but as Jason suggested I have been building
up my collection of vinyl. I was lucky when I started learning last Sept;
M!kah was my downstairs neighbor, and he gave me a key to his place so I
could practice on his 1200's while he was gone. Dave Parlier gave me my
first lesson, and explained the basics of beatmatching and phrasing to me.
>From there, it is just a matter of practice (and I know that I still have a
long way to go.) Whenever I go someplace where I *might* have a chance to
spin, I bring my records with me. I've gotten to play on a wide variety of
decks and mixers, which has helped me to figure out what I will buy when I
purchase my own equipment. I have to say that I love the Numark TTX1's.
While it takes a little bit to get used to when you are used to Technics,
they are every bit as solid. My favorite thing is the variable pitch control
that Trendy mentioned. You can change (on the fly!) the pitch range from
+/-10% (which gives you the most control) to +/-20%(so you can pitch up to
+12% to match that track that is just outside the default range) to
+/-50%(which I have never had occasion to use, but it's nice to know it's
there.) I have a few tracks that I can only throw in on the TTX1's, because
they are more than the 16% difference that 1200's will allow you. (In order
to change the pitch range on 1200's, you have to make a mechanical change
which will give you +/-12% I believe, but you can't make that change on the
fly.)
    So, to sum up my technobabble ramble, buy some records and play them
whenever and where ever you can. And trainspot. Watch other djs and see the
choices they make. Come to Ryan and Tyler's next Open Deck Party. I got to
spin twice on Friday night  :-)

Subject: RE: [sfraves]How did you get started DJing?

How did I start DJ'ing?  Well, aside from the fact that I suck and am in
no way considering myself a dj, I had an interesting expierience on how
I started when I was po'.  When I started going to raves and started
buying techno CD's at a rate to rival Kazaa I wanted a way to practice
mixing.  I didn't have much to work with but what I ended up doing was
using a video mixer my friend had, two cd players and recording what we
did onto VHS.. Of course the mixes really sucked ass because beat
matching was non-existant but I had fun doing it :)  I'd also use sound
efx cd's and cue them to where I wanted, then throw in samples here and
there... Ahhh being poor in Utah. :)

From sfraves-return-100914-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 09 00:07:08 2003

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 24323 invoked from network); 9 Apr 2003 00:07:08 -0000
Message-ID: <20030409000700.2348.qmail@web14913.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Apr 2003 17:07:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest

so.. this is way not rave-related, but i had written
it up for another list and thought folks might want to
hear more info. about what went down w/ the wooden
bullets, etc. at the oakland docks protest.  if you
don't care, go ahead and skip it.

also, if folks are interested, the next action by
Direct Action to Stop the War will be Monday, April 14
at the Chevron-Texaco HQ in the east bay.  more info.
is available at www.actagainstwar.org.  it feels
really good to be out in the streets or on a picket
line in community w/ folks, even if we do wind up
dodging wooden bullets (which is rare.)  

there's also a large anti-war march on saturday in SF.
 see www.indybay.org for more info.  

it's hard getting up at 5 in the morning.  being still
awake is one thing, getting up is another.  the bed is
so warm, i need the sleep... but i figured that
sometimes the most interesting things happen in those
liminal hours between night and day, and it's a rare
event i see those morning hours, especially among
hundreds of pickets at the oakland port.  

i didn't make it to the action 'til about 6:30 or so
(the organizers were asking people to show up at 5:30
- 5:45, as the bosses had told workers to come in
extra early, but what can i say? i'm really slow in
the morning).  By the time I arrived there were
hundreds of lively pickets at the gates of American
President Lines (APL), who ship weapons to iraq. 
there were also three other pickets further down the
road at another APL gate and SSA, Stevedoring Services
of America.  (for more information and background on
these companies and on the action, see
www.actagainstwar.org.)  the point of the action was
to have a loud, but legal picket line.  if there were
enough folks out there, an arbitrator for the
dockworkers and maritime association  would judge
whether crossing the line was a health and safety
issue, and hopefully the dockers would not go to work.
 

so, once i got there, the tasks at hand were to find
some friends (it's better to go with friends, but
well, my "buddy" was sleeping in), and flyer for the
benefit party i'm doing (which hopefully didn't wind
up in the pocket of anyone who was arrested).  i
quickly found someone i knew and we went down to the
next gate to look for others.  around this time i saw
the first arrest i witnessed, of a man on roller
skates who i guess pissed off the police with his, uh,
rollerskating.  the police then, i think, gave an
"order to disperse" at the 2nd gate, despite the fact
that it was a legal picket, and they moved in
menacingly, in formation.  i felt wussy, but since i
hadn't been planning on getting arrested , i quickly
moved across the street and then onto the next gate.
it didn't look like people were up for arrest, as most
people seemed to move out of the way, as well, out of
the entrance, though still picketing.  

the next thing i knew, i heard a loud bang and looked
over and saw that the cops were firing what looked
like teargas (which i now think was a concussion
grenade) at people around the gate i'd just left,
especially at folks across the street (who'd probably
just dispersed themselves from the gate).  fuck.  glad
i'd brought the bandana.  i wondered if we were going
to get trapped.  i saw a bunch of police running
across the street on the railroad tracks going after
someone,  luckily they gave up the chase, but it
stressed me out.  running cops mean i might be running
soon.  i wound up moving to the main part of the 3rd
gate and milling around, not wanting to go too much
closer.   the police continued to move in.  more
concussion grenades, and i guess wooden bullets, and
cops and more cops.  a friend saying they saw a legal
observer getting arrested across the street.  loud
grenades, someone in his car frantically screeching
tires, driving backwards in the crowd, trying to turn
around, police moving in.  
this was crazy.  we pretty much all came thinking it
would be a legal picket, some folks had complained it
"wasn't really direct action", and of course you never
know what the cops will do (and i'd been somewhat
intimidated going alone), but i didn't expect seattle.
 

Down at the 4th gate now, a friend beating on a big
bass drum, interspersed with the sounds of the bullets
and grenades and police advance.  trying to stay
together with friends, and how close to the police did
we want to stay?   eventually a large group of us left
together as the police moved us along, heading down
Middle Harbor Road towards 7th.  folks picketed at
this intersection for a bit, people circling around in
the street and chanting.  i bumped into a friend who
showed me the bruise on his leg and told me he'd been
shot with a wooden dowell (sp?) while doing legal
observation.  then the cops started moving in again
and shit! that concussion grenade was really close! 
and here were more bullets.  we hurried along and
crossed a line of blocked trucks, many of whom honked
in support, and then found ourselves on a sidewalk in
the netherworld of trucks and tunnels (under the
railraod tracks and Rte. 880, I believe.)  after
emerging above ground (and happily discovering we were
not trapped by cops), we waited for people and went
back to the west oakland bart.  i left at this point
to go home and change and go to work, but i read that
people afterwards marched, in the street , to the
oakland federal building.  (more info. available on
www.indybay.org, san francisco indymedia).  
 
a few more things: i never saw anyone throwing things
at police.  i doubt that anyone did, but even if a few
rocks were thrown (which i HIGHLY doubt happened -
it's just a convenient excuse for the cops), to fire
wooden bullets and beanbag shot and concussion
grenades at a retreating demonstration is outrageous.
i have heard that people were run into w/ motorcycles
as well. apparently 6 local 10 ILWU workers were
wounded as well, and 31 people were arrested,
including an ILWU member.  people were hit in the
back, police were aiming right at people... ugh. 

when i stopped home, my partner said to me, "i'm proud
of you.  you got shot at.  you must have really hit a
sore spot."  i guess so.   

here's some more info. below, and jerry brown's # to
call if you want to support the protesters:


>  > CALL AND ASK FOR IMMEDIATE DE-ESCALATION OF
POLICE TACTICS AND 
RELEASE OF
>>  THE POLITICAL PRISONERS
>>  Mayor Jerry Brown's Office:  510.238.3141
>>  Hold him accountable for any police violence that
occurs! His 
office is
>>  responsible for the Oakland Police!!
>>
  ILWU workers who were not 
participating in
>>  the protest have been shot with rubber bullets and
a ILWU business 
agent
>>  has reportedly been arrested.
>>
>>  There has been extroadinary police violence at
this morning's dock 
action,
>>  including tear gas, concussion grenades, police
running over people 
with

called

practice on
>>  non-confrontation with pickets.  Pickets have been
entirely

>>  1,000 people turned out to shut down the port and
have been

From sfraves-return-100915-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 09 00:13:45 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-100915-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest

All I have to say is, as much as I believe in civil disobdience... DON'T
PROVOKE THE MAN!  The reason it all went downhill is because people were
throwing rocks and lead pipes, I mean c'mon!  We're not in the middle
east and we're supposed to be peaceful.  Resorting to violence to stop
violence is not an answer, you're joining them.  Like the good old Pet
Shop Boy's song... 'Violence begets violence.'  Any action that has a
direct consequence of possibly harming the massively outnumbered police
force is going to cause them to panic.  Think smart.

Love,
Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: Monikat [mailto:technoslut303@yahoo.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 5:07 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest


so.. this is way not rave-related, but i had written
it up for another list and thought folks might want to
hear more info. about what went down w/ the wooden
bullets, etc. at the oakland docks protest.  if you
don't care, go ahead and skip it.

also, if folks are interested, the next action by
Direct Action to Stop the War will be Monday, April 14
at the Chevron-Texaco HQ in the east bay.  more info.
is available at www.actagainstwar.org.  it feels
really good to be out in the streets or on a picket
line in community w/ folks, even if we do wind up
dodging wooden bullets (which is rare.)  

there's also a large anti-war march on saturday in SF.
 see www.indybay.org for more info.  

it's hard getting up at 5 in the morning.  being still
awake is one thing, getting up is another.  the bed is
so warm, i need the sleep... but i figured that
sometimes the most interesting things happen in those
liminal hours between night and day, and it's a rare
event i see those morning hours, especially among
hundreds of pickets at the oakland port.  

i didn't make it to the action 'til about 6:30 or so
(the organizers were asking people to show up at 5:30
- 5:45, as the bosses had told workers to come in
extra early, but what can i say? i'm really slow in
the morning).  By the time I arrived there were
hundreds of lively pickets at the gates of American
President Lines (APL), who ship weapons to iraq. 
there were also three other pickets further down the
road at another APL gate and SSA, Stevedoring Services
of America.  (for more information and background on
these companies and on the action, see
www.actagainstwar.org.)  the point of the action was
to have a loud, but legal picket line.  if there were
enough folks out there, an arbitrator for the
dockworkers and maritime association  would judge
whether crossing the line was a health and safety
issue, and hopefully the dockers would not go to work.
 

so, once i got there, the tasks at hand were to find
some friends (it's better to go with friends, but
well, my "buddy" was sleeping in), and flyer for the
benefit party i'm doing (which hopefully didn't wind
up in the pocket of anyone who was arrested).  i
quickly found someone i knew and we went down to the
next gate to look for others.  around this time i saw
the first arrest i witnessed, of a man on roller
skates who i guess pissed off the police with his, uh, rollerskating.
the police then, i think, gave an "order to disperse" at the 2nd gate,
despite the fact that it was a legal picket, and they moved in
menacingly, in formation.  i felt wussy, but since i hadn't been
planning on getting arrested , i quickly moved across the street and
then onto the next gate. it didn't look like people were up for arrest,
as most people seemed to move out of the way, as well, out of the
entrance, though still picketing.  

the next thing i knew, i heard a loud bang and looked
over and saw that the cops were firing what looked
like teargas (which i now think was a concussion
grenade) at people around the gate i'd just left,
especially at folks across the street (who'd probably
just dispersed themselves from the gate).  fuck.  glad
i'd brought the bandana.  i wondered if we were going
to get trapped.  i saw a bunch of police running
across the street on the railroad tracks going after
someone,  luckily they gave up the chase, but it
stressed me out.  running cops mean i might be running
soon.  i wound up moving to the main part of the 3rd
gate and milling around, not wanting to go too much
closer.   the police continued to move in.  more
concussion grenades, and i guess wooden bullets, and
cops and more cops.  a friend saying they saw a legal
observer getting arrested across the street.  loud
grenades, someone in his car frantically screeching
tires, driving backwards in the crowd, trying to turn
around, police moving in.  
this was crazy.  we pretty much all came thinking it
would be a legal picket, some folks had complained it
"wasn't really direct action", and of course you never
know what the cops will do (and i'd been somewhat
intimidated going alone), but i didn't expect seattle.
 

Down at the 4th gate now, a friend beating on a big
bass drum, interspersed with the sounds of the bullets
and grenades and police advance.  trying to stay
together with friends, and how close to the police did
we want to stay?   eventually a large group of us left
together as the police moved us along, heading down
Middle Harbor Road towards 7th.  folks picketed at
this intersection for a bit, people circling around in
the street and chanting.  i bumped into a friend who
showed me the bruise on his leg and told me he'd been
shot with a wooden dowell (sp?) while doing legal
observation.  then the cops started moving in again
and shit! that concussion grenade was really close! 
and here were more bullets.  we hurried along and
crossed a line of blocked trucks, many of whom honked
in support, and then found ourselves on a sidewalk in
the netherworld of trucks and tunnels (under the
railraod tracks and Rte. 880, I believe.)  after
emerging above ground (and happily discovering we were
not trapped by cops), we waited for people and went
back to the west oakland bart.  i left at this point
to go home and change and go to work, but i read that
people afterwards marched, in the street , to the
oakland federal building.  (more info. available on www.indybay.org, san
francisco indymedia).  
 
a few more things: i never saw anyone throwing things
at police.  i doubt that anyone did, but even if a few
rocks were thrown (which i HIGHLY doubt happened -
it's just a convenient excuse for the cops), to fire
wooden bullets and beanbag shot and concussion
grenades at a retreating demonstration is outrageous.
i have heard that people were run into w/ motorcycles
as well. apparently 6 local 10 ILWU workers were
wounded as well, and 31 people were arrested,
including an ILWU member.  people were hit in the
back, police were aiming right at people... ugh. 

when i stopped home, my partner said to me, "i'm proud
of you.  you got shot at.  you must have really hit a
sore spot."  i guess so.   

here's some more info. below, and jerry brown's # to
call if you want to support the protesters:


>  > CALL AND ASK FOR IMMEDIATE DE-ESCALATION OF
POLICE TACTICS AND 
RELEASE OF
>>  THE POLITICAL PRISONERS
>>  Mayor Jerry Brown's Office:  510.238.3141
>>  Hold him accountable for any police violence that
occurs! His 
office is
>>  responsible for the Oakland Police!!
>>
  ILWU workers who were not 
participating in
>>  the protest have been shot with rubber bullets and
a ILWU business 
agent
>>  has reportedly been arrested.
>>
>>  There has been extroadinary police violence at
this morning's dock 
action,
>>  including tear gas, concussion grenades, police
running over people 
with
>>  motorcycles and rubber bullets. It is likely that
this violence was 
called
>>  for by the Mayor's office, which generally has a
practice on
>>  non-confrontation with pickets.  Pickets have been
entirely 
peaceful. Over
>>  1,000 people turned out to shut down the port and
have been 
extremely
>>  successful.
>>  Jerry Brown's Office: 510-238-3141  Ask that the
police violence 
stop
>  > immediately and that the political prisoners be
released.

Hey Mike/Catharsis,

A friend was telling me about the discussion thread regarding the Trust 
event, and I thought I'd chime in.

I've seen you out quite a bit, you seem to be quite the techno fan which I 
can certainly relate with... so I think it's reasonable to assume you've 
seen most of the local techno folks play out around town.  I think it then 
follows that your given your comments below that the feelings you express 
here apply to all the techno DJs who you've met and seen play and since 
coming into town.  Let me just say thank you for your wonderful support and 
positivity in this regard.  I guess next time we're out and you look me or 
any of the other techno DJs in our scene in the eye and say, "Great set", as 
you have to me in the past, we will know that what you really mean is "You 
must be rich and can buy yourself lots of cool records, but you have no 
skills as a DJ", and that you are saying what you are saying for some other 
reason or motive.  Thanks for clearing up that misunderstanding. ;)

Chris

in s.f., people complain a lot about the bikers.....cyclists, really...not the harley riders...aren't too, too many of those on the streets....the real cyclists though aren't the ones you have to worry about....you know you have to worry when some guy swerves past you as you walk on the sidewalk.....when he gets past you, you know he's totally out of his element, because he has a big, BIG GIGANTIC ass....a big, soft ass, and a real cyclist, basically loses his ass, and also, is quite agile and not stupid when it comes to maneuvering. this is not a gender specific post...it is simply an example of language without barriers. :)

some man i tried to give a seat to today decided to try to grab me between my legs...he is lucky he survived...it is like, HELLO, reality check, gents! don't grab my ass unless we have a complete understanding either...my nails dig hard into the hand of the grabber, and my pinch makes you wish you lost your nerve. :)
 Pedro <don_pedro11@yahoo.com> wrote:
Bad breath is bad - yes. Keep brushing and flossing, and do they still make that BreathAssure stuff to take away onion breath after In-N-Out? I smell like garlic-n-onion chips right now. Where’s my crest?
"Don’t linger on a stranger’s cheek" – agreed; tricky move that requires tact, objectivity and awareness. But sometimes it’s the right call.
>“speaking as a boy who usually leaves the girls alone, I’d say your advice is pretty sound. I’m >always in doubt, so I usually don't bother. everybody wins!”
Disagree. “when in doubt, don’t” doesn’t work for me, nor Jacob apparently, because there is ALWAYS some doubt (at least for 95% of us). If no one ever bothers due to the fear of rejection then, in my opinion, we all loose. I mean “how trivial and boring would that be?” indeed. 
If I walk up to you on the street/ store/ club/ restaurant/ party/ etc. to be friendly and say hi, well as long as I am respectful it’s all good. If I grab your ass as you walk by, yeah that’s pig-headed juvenile ignorance in action that shouldn’t have to be tolerated. By you or anyone else.
But my point is, you have to take chances in life, including mustering up enough confidence to start talking to whomever it may be that makes your heart jump out of your chest. Not interested? Just say so. If you get offended by my chivalrous attempt at a conversation, even if it is corny and not quite suave, well I’m sorry. I know I got good intentions. And if some physical attribute of mine offends you? Depending on what we’re talking about, I would mostly just say sorry, get over it. Maybe you’re missing something else that should really be getting the attention. And maybe not. But never apologize for being friendly.

purple turbosound system used by Wicked at the FMRs.

Neuroscience Creations described it.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) hi and a physics question.

Just a little more about light:
light is an electro-magnetic wave.. meaning it contains an electric and 
magnetic field.. its just like a radio or x-ray/wave.. the only difference 
is the wavelength which is of the order of about 400nm (violet) to 700nm 
(red), thats the range our eyes can see (just like for sound we can only 
hear a certain range of frequencies/wavelengths).. light can travel in a 
vacum (just look at the stars).. hence it doesn't take up space..
latah..
david..
~physics is fun =)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Funktion-One Sound system


If you are itchin to hear this new sound system in action, come on down
and celebrate 12 years of Wicked ! (AND YES, I've loved and gone to this
collective's parties for that long)...

Thanks for all the wonderful full moons, bonnie dunes, and FINE FINE DJS


1) Wicked, San Francisco
Wicked turns 12, and to celebrate this fine accomplishment we're throwing
a party! At a brand new space, Mezzanine. It has a fantastic new sound
system made by Funktion-One (UK), the same people that made our purple
sound system. I went to the opening of Mezzanine last Friday and can
firmly and unequivocally attest that this system absolutely rocks!!!!
Devastating!!! We are honored to the first outside promoters to get to use
this venue. The new home to Audrey Joseph, the former owner of the now
closed Townsend Club which Wicked graced  the past 11 years.

For such an occasion we had to give you the full Wicked line up!  Hence
Thomas will be joining Markie, Garth and Jeno for a glorious all night
affair. Get plenty of rest beforehand, eat plenty of carbohydrates and
hydrate well :)

It all goes down Friday April 18 at Mezzanine, 444 Jessie @ Mint, San
Francisco. 11pm -7am.


<3 Karina

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) hi and a physics question.

Light acts like both a particle and a wave.

Mark

> Just a little more about light:
> light is an electro-magnetic wave.. meaning it contains an electric and
> magnetic field.. its just like a radio or x-ray/wave.. the only difference
> is the wavelength which is of the order of about 400nm (violet) to 700nm
> (red), thats the range our eyes can see (just like for sound we can only
> hear a certain range of frequencies/wavelengths).. light can travel in a
> vacum (just look at the stars).. hence it doesn't take up space..
> latah..
> david..
> ~physics is fun =)

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: TSUNAMI! Friday, April 18th! $5 Presales/All Ages!

LiquidVinylDjs.com & Presto Parties are teaming up to bring you an event to 
rock ya right! After a long hiatus and a much needed break, we're back to 
bring you..

TSUNAMI!
Friday, April 18th 2003!
11pm-6am
$5 Presales
ALL AGES!

7 hours of outdoor madness! Join us as we celebrate the change from the cool 
winter months into the warm months of Spring and Summer! DJ's helping to 
bring you that vibe:


AREA ONE: TIDAL

CLOUDSKIPPER (LiquidVinylDjs.com/SonicFury.net: SPECIAL WELCOME BACK SET!)
We're very proud to welcome Cloudskipper, Hardcore extraordinaire, back to 
the Bay! After his move to Kentucky, he just couldn't stay away for long, 
and now he's back where he belongs! Fresh off his tour of the UK and working 
with several prominent producers and labels, he'll be dropping all the fresh 
dubplates and upfront material you've come to expect from him! Madness 
prevails here, no boundries!

DJ TRONIC (Resistance Recordings/LiquidVinylDjs.com)
In one of his last appearances before he starts his much anticipated tour in 
Spain, Tronic is coming out to drop only the Hardest material you've come to 
know! Expect the unexpected here, with a set ranging from Hard House to 
Hardcore to anything in between, this will be the one set to keep you on 
your toes and bangin' your head!

VALERIE SPARKS (ValerieSparks.com/Resistance Recordings)
With smooth mixing, energetic stage presence, and a smile to melt even the 
strongest, it's no wonder why Valerie is one of the most in-demand DJs on 
the West Coast. She'll be coming out to bring you the Hardcore like only she 
can.. so get your ass up, get movin!

ANTHONY MAD vs. KID COSMO (Mad Beats vs. Presto Parties)
The mad man meets the kid like whoa! In what's becoming one of the most 
requested pairings in all of Bay Area Hardcore, Anthony Mad and Kid Cosmo 
are coming to out to drop all the favorites you've come to known and love!

NO LEFT TURN vs. DJ REESE (LiquidVinylDjs.com - Nice Guys Finish Last 
Special Set!)
Proving that even if Nice Guys Finish Last, good skill will take you places! 
These two are coming out to rock just a bit harder, a bit faster, and a bit 
stronger!

PETER GO-ZANIA vs. LEON COOK (HCFTP vs. Neuroscience Creations)
What to expect from these two? Well quite frankly, we have no idea. What we 
do know for sure is that it's going to be fast. It's going to be hard. And, 
it's going to be in your face. Don't say we didn't warn you.

DJ VIRTUE vs. DJ BEEZ (ROT vs. Preserve)
Rounding out the night we have the pairing to take you over the top! The 
only limit here: NOTHING UNDER 200BPM. That's right, with Gabber becoming 
more and more popular here in the Bay, it's no wonder why these guys will be 
dropping 200+BPM bombs!


AREA TWO: WAVE.

JOEY MAZZOLA (Solmatic Records/JoeyMazzola.com)
Gaining wide acclaim for his work on the Solmatic label, Joey is quickly 
becoming one of the most sought after House DJ's in all of America! With his 
precise mixing, awesome scratching, and his overall nice guy status, it's no 
wonder to anyone why Joey is enjoying his continued success.

BAZOOKA JOE vs. RECKLESS RYAN (DJBazookaJoe.com vs. KSJS 90.5/Zero Magazine)
Two of the most talented DJs in the Bay collide for what promises to be one 
helluva set! From that funky ass shakin' house to that hard hittin' 
hardstyle, this set comes complete with scratching for days! Get your 
dancing shoes ready, this is the one to get wild to!

MICHAEL LIU vs. NEUROPSYNTIST (Illumination Records vs. Neuroscience 
Creations/Secret Psychadelica)
In need of some Psy in your life? Well, we've got the cure: Michael Liu & 
Neuropsyntist, two of the most underrated and underappreciated DJs here in 
the Bay. These two are responsible for the largely popular Neu Light events, 
as well as the always packed Secret Psychadelica nights! Sure to twist your 
mind in all new ways!

J-MARR vs. CARLOS ALFONZO (LiquidVinylDjs.com/Bayraves vs. 
Bayraves/Resistance Recordings)
The Ghetto Rice Maker meets The Carne Asada Chef in this showdown of food 
technicians! In all seriousness, these two are some of the nicest DJs you'll 
ever meet, and they're comin' out to prove that what they have in kindness, 
they double in skill!

PAUL THE FANMAN vs. DJ FOXX (Audio Metamorphosis/Kidz At Play vs. House on 
the Hill/Remix)
Ready for your beats a bit harder and energetic? These two will have you 
stompin the whole time as they lay down their signature sounds in a rare 
appearance together on the decks! Expect some serious crowd rockin!

THE DOCTOR VS. DJ DOUBLE DAY (Bayraves/Deciblast vs. Swatchdog Recordings)
With the growing popularity of Drum and Bass at all ages events, these two 
are looking to lead the pack of DJs eager to drop beats! If you like your 
Drum and Bass energetic, hard, and fun, this will be the set for you!

J-BIRD vs. ATHENA (Gravity Crew Madness Set)
Two of Tahoe's best, from one of the best and respected promotional outfits 
in the whole Tahoe area-the Gravity Crew! Expect nothing short of everything 
with this set, from breaks to house to hardstyle to NRG, it's gonna be 
covered, and covered right!

stars!
Centrally Located in the Immediate Bay Area!

Subject: [sfraves] HOW TO SUCESSFULLY OVERTHROW OUR GOVERNMENT and potentially save raving too!

--part1_14f.1dbbe666.2bc54255_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  Are you, like me and millions of other people here and around the world, 
disgusted at what America has become and rapidly devolving into, and want to 
help start a revolution to get rid of this corporate/oligarchist/fascist 
government that doesn't show any concern and welfare for the people but for 
the ones who can afford to corrupt it? There is a way to subvert this 
government and they can't do anything about it, totally legal. Our sinister, 
traitorous plan? Not demonstrations and acts of civil disobedience, which I'm 
totally for and it does have it's place but, unfortunately can be easily and 
brutally squelched, take what the Oakland police (always trying to have one 
up on San Francisco police when they brutalize) did to 700 unarmed 
demonstrators Monday at the Oakland ship yard as an example! White folks 
getting a little sample of what people of color experience every day from the 
police, and this might finally start to wake people up, and once poor/common 
white folks and people of color finally find each other and see that they 
have more in common and realize that skin color is just an abstract thing, a 
diversion technique, a divide and conquer strategy of the ruling elite, this 
can be the subversive wrench, as an act of treason, thrown in the wheels of 
this new world order our troops are fighting for, not freedom and democracy, 
neither for the Iraqis or us. This means people are beginning to realize this 
not exactly a race issue as popularly believed, but a class issue; what gives 
you power and authority in society is not, sadly, who you are but what you 
have, and the potential (dangerous to the ruling class) mass enlightenment of 
this truth is not the subversive act, but one of the two main components of 
the fuel that helps flame the fire of subversion and revolution that can 
evict Bush and company and all his oligarch benefactors along side Sadam 
Hussen and all forms of despots, foreign and domestic from the (illusionary) 
institutions of power. The other component is true spirituality, not the 
religion that blesses bombs, prays for victory, AKA mass killing and claims 
exclusivity over divine partiality. Spiritually that helps us see that all 
these despots have no power after all, we do! They just make us believe they 
do. They have money, guns, rubber bullets and propaganda to convince us that 
they have power, but we can have knowledge, and that is our weapon to 
overthrow the government. Think about it, why are these despots cutting 
funding to education? Why have 1,000 Oakland teachers lost their jobs? Not 
because there's no money, remember 10% own 90% of our nation's wealth, but 
because as all despots, religious, political, intellectual, who ever 
throughout history have learned that ignorance = power, knowledge = liberty. 
Ignorance is their power over you. Keep the peasants down by keeping them 
uneducated.
  So how do we use knowledge to overthrow our government and perhaps save 
raving while at it? Knowledge is not passive, it is something you have to 
peruse, you have to want it and desire it like a lover. But knowledge can be 
a bad lover as well. What kind of lover you get depends on your intent. If 
your intent to get knowledge is to be able to compete with others, to make 
more money to get more stuff, to have more (illusionary) power, or to make 
one feel superior, you will just gained the same knowledge that has brought 
us to the pitiful state we are in today, knowledge that makes you part of the 
problem. If you intent to gain knowledge is to be free and to discover the 
truth that will set you free, then you will gain the same knowledge many are 
beginning to discover that will literally save the world, knowledge that 
makes you part of the solution.
  Here are some ways that this knowledge can enable you as well as me and 
others help subvert the government and overthrow it, more effectively than 
riots, demonstrations and acts of civil disobedience, actually educating 
yourself is powerful act of civil disobedience, like I said earlier no one 
can stop you from doing it. When you gain knowledge to be free and to find 
truth, you see what makes and breaks our present order of things and it's 
government over us, that Achilles' heel of this capitalistic mega giant, 
spreading the "gospel" of profits and the bottom line, the salvation of 
personal wealth, the morality of completion, and the joys of conspicuous 
consumption all over the world, our missionaries spreading (really bombing) 
the "gospel" in Iraq whether they like it or not, and coming soon to Iran, 
Syria and a country or distinct ethnic region near you whose culture and 
community ethics hasn't yet been subdued by this so called "gospel." 
Knowledge for the sake of truth and freedom tells us that what they, the 
oligarchs, call democracy isn't what we normally think of democracy, but a 
choice of which corrupt politician we wish to be controlled by, how we are to 
be exploited, dumbed down, which mainstream rave to pay $50 to go to; the 
type of democracy that gives a choice of 200 cable channels, worthless goods 
made by the labor of kids and the poor in the temples of this new world 
religion called sweat shops, processed, GM foods, not the type of democracy 
that gives us the power, or really tells us that the power is in us now and 
the ability to utalize it not just for our happiness but for every sentient 
beings! Here are the tools, coming from knowledge, of revolution and the 
overthrow of our government:
  Support your local business as much as possible. Remember the wise 
statement, "Think globally by acting locally." When you support your local 
business, you keep the profits here, chain stores move profits elsewhere and 
pay off local governments (political contributions) to avoid paying their 
share of taxes to make it easier to set up low pay jobs on every block, which 
means higher taxes are dumped on locals to make up the slack, and unfair 
taxes and competition have killed small business in SF and in communities all 
over the bay area and California. We can stop the proliferation of Starbucks 
and Wal-marts and their destruction of the local economy and good stable jobs 
by not giving them the fuel that feeds their insatiable appetite of 
"convenient locations" by not giving them our dollar bills. Simply, no money, 
no credit card, no Walgreens on every block! Find a local alternative to 
monolithic chain stores. Eat at a local restaurant rather than a McDonalds or 
Taco Bell. Better food and cheaper. 
  Find a local hardware store and say no to Home Depo as much as possible, 
know your local grocery stores and cut down depending on Safeway and 
Albertsons. Usually you can find healthier and just as cheep foods in the 
locals. 
  Rent more movies at a local rental store and kick the habit of going to 
chains all the time like Blockbuster which supports extreme right wing 
causes, And Even if they and other local alternatives are a little more 
expensive, you are making a better job possible for a neighbor, and keeping 
your neighborhood unique. Locals don't worry about share holders and jobs are 
more secure. Taxes are fairer when local businesses are in control, and thus 
more revenue. This is one of our means to overthrow the government and not 
give these corporate union busting entities that will lay you off in a second 
if the bottom line is threatened the $100,000 contributions (coming from our 
$$$ given to them from our support) to corrupt government and destroy our 
local economy.
  Open a bank account at a local bank or credit union. Remember, your money 
will stay here and help business here, not in NYC or Atlanta. Let the folks 
in NYC and Atlanta find their own alternatives and not send their money here 
and keep their communities unique and prosperous like ours. Remember, "Think 
globally by acting locally!"
  Find alternatives to AOL, which I'm doing. So far for me, Juno looks like a 
better alternative. A simi-huge corporation, but not an awful as AOL. And I 
will tell them why I switched over to them to said adios to AOL for these so 
and so reasons, and I can say "adios!" to them just as fast as I said that to 
AOL. If enough people will do that to who ever they choose to support, they 
will listen. Knowledge tells us money and the ruling elite's love of it is 
our weapon and subversion!
  Turn off the TV, especially the news and video games more and relearn the 
pleasure of just kicking it with friends and being present with them. Have no 
friends to chill with? Go out and meet new people and stop letting the media 
tell you that everyone "out there" are rapists, con artists, molesters, 
murders and competitors for your job, and that you need to be suspicious of 
everyone and close yourself off. 99% of people are generally nice people, 
it's just we've all been told to be afraid.
  Learn to grow a garden, that's what my household is going to try to do this 
year. Grow enough to share and help rediscover the lost concept of neighbor 
knowing and helping neighbor. Learn to bake things and save money, eat 
healthier, and practice subversion by sharing.
  Buy less, learn to live with less, "Live simply that others may simply 
live." Knowledge will teach you to find happiness and self esteem by being 
who you are, not what you buy. Even upgrading your computer instead of buying 
a new one every year can save you money and keep a poor person in China or 
Mexico from becoming sick from the toxic waste of your thrown out computer. 
Learn that there are beautiful trees and plants out in a forest, and that you 
don't have to go to a mall and shop to see pretty plants. Nature is still 
free!
  Get rid of your SUVs and drive something more economical and stop 
contributing to global warming. Learn to walk more and you turn off the $$$ 
spicket for oil companies that made this war in Iraq possible. Don't want 
anymore wars? Don't give your money to companies that depend on wars to 
expand their economic opportunities.
  Register to vote and support a third party. Didn't vote? Why are you 
complaining about Bush, Davis and Brown, Willie and Jerry? They win by 
apathy. Bush (technically) "won," not because Nader siphoned votes off Gore, 
Bush "won" by people sitting at home watching TV. Apathy gave the Republicans 
the opportunity to cheat and do old school Southern Jim Crow style techniques 
to keep blacks from voting in Florida, thus working the system to get 
selected, not elected. If enough people voted and voted for alternatives, we 
could be living in a real democracy today, which means better jobs and having 
a job, better education and universal healthcare for all, homes for the 
homeless and the right to smoke a ganja in the privity of our own homes 
without the post man/woman or the cable person, trained by the TIPS program 
spying on us and having gestapo looking police suited up for war breaking 
down our door and hauling us off to jail!
  Now to raves. Support more the UG's and the small promoters who keep it 
real. The karma of your attitude will help you find each other. Find out who 
still remembers what PLUR is all about and give them your money. support the 
promoters who support the local scene and who give local DJ's a chance. I'm 
not against out of town DJ's, but no one is worth six figures! Don't like the 
mainstream scene who flyer everybody and brings in everybody who usually 
bring the vibe down? Don't go to their parties. Turned off to the egos, rock 
star attitudes, 15 year old e-tards and the bottom line promoters? Don't 
support the parties that enable these influences. Once in a while, take you 
and your friend's $50 you'd spend for a ticket at a mega "rave" and throw a 
small house party, give that bedroom DJ you know a chance to show his/her 
skills, invite a few people you meet that are cool and make a positive, 
intimate party happen, not just waste energy talking about it or remissness 
about "back in the day." Subvert the corrupted rave scene the same way I 
suggest how we can subvert our corrupted government, being aware of what you 
support with your money and knowledge.
  It's like this, I sit and watch the pro-war news channels and all I hear 
over and over again is this constant redundancy of rumors, edited good news 
and propaganda. You kind of start to believe all this is true and actually 
start to like seeing buildings getting blown up and people getting killed, 
because the propaganda and scenes of violence and destruction, like being 
hypnotized, are being repeated over and over and over again and video 
footage's looped over and over again. Little information, just repeated to 
nausea to make you believe. Not until I either turn it off or go to the BBC, 
CBC, DW-TV or KPFA that I see that there is more to this war than what is 
being told. Basically, Americans are being played, we got the government we 
deserved and I have no sympathy for those who will not get off, and I say 
this in a compassionate Buddhist way, their cyber asses and work their search 
engines and find another story to this war instead of regurgitating 
propaganda and resorting to Bill O'Reilly style name calling. Neither will I 
shed tears when the police start shooting rubber bullets and bean bag 
grenades at ravers soon because ravers in mass choose to be apathetic, self 
absorbent and more concerned about where they are going to get their pills 
and who is playing at the next "rave" to not see the connection between civil 
rights, phony wars for oil and world domination and the right to dance. Those 
who are facilitating this war in Iraq are the same ones who want to wage war 
on dancing. Some of you are cheering and supporting the same ones who may 
brutalize you like the protesters at the Oakland ship yard and put you in 
jail for having records and loving techno. The same soldiers who shot Iraqis 
may soon shoot you in your own town. It's all connected and knowledge will 
help you fill in the dots and gain knowledge to begin to over throw our 
government and have a world of true democracy! It may be illegal to violently 
overthrow the government, but it's not illegal yet to overthrow it by our 
knowledge and how we choose to live and not support the corporate entities as 
much as possible that prop it up. Wake up and start the subversion and 
revolution!
  Peace and love to all, Bodhi ^ _ ^
  

--part1_14f.1dbbe666.2bc54255_boundary--

From sfraves-return-100933-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 09 11:37:27 2003

Date: Wed, 9 Apr 2003 04:37:23 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

cc: innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com>,
  _ fable _ <fable4our@hotmail.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20030409031723.56521.qmail@web41812.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0304090337300.8467-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer


On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Psychedelic Armadillo wrote:
-&e->um...did I miss a Final Scratch discussion? I would
-&e->really really REALLY like to see someone break it down
-&e->as far as the differences between Traktor and Final
-&e->Scratch (and any other serious alternatives).

Just wait a little bit, they'll be one and the same product very shortly.

For the time being -
Final Scratch is an interface that allows the playback position and speed
of an mp3 (or aif or wav) to be controlled by a special record on a
turntable.  Basics - you select files in the interface, then use the
record to mix them in very similarly to traditional vinyl DJing.  Very
straighforward analog of normal DJing, you just get to use mp3s.

Traktor is a software package that allows the mixing of multiple mp3 or
wav/aif whatever using a software interface.  Points for a solid EQ
section, elegant interface and auto beatmatch features (yay, play for 30
hours and not have to actually mix :\ ).

Native Instruments and Stanton are working to tie the best of breed
interface for file management and effects (NI's Traktor) and physical
speed and position control (Stanton's Final Scratch) into one pimping
thing for the migration to OSX (and this merging will probably rear it's
head with the PC version eventually as well).  With endorsements from DJs
like John Tejada, DJ Hell, Richie Hawtin, Josh Wink and more coming... I'm
sure they'll do fine.

The big question comes down to what people are willing to spend, what you
want to do, and how well audiences accept the technology (because DJing is
a performance art, like it or not... and DJing using digital tools will
face the same challenges as a pianist going to synthesizers).  I prefer
the undeniable simplicity of a hefty ass box o' records, 2 technics and a
mixer, but as I'm looking into new ways of playing live I've been dabbling
a bit with miss pinky - a product that also allows interfacing using a
vinyl style system, but allows direct interface to cycling74's max/msp
development environment (and can be used to drive/scratch video or midi or
whatever you can whip up in max... not just audio files).

Information Sites:
www.finalscratch.com
www.traktor-dj.com
www.mspinky.com

andyw

On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Chris Yap wrote:
-&e->
-&e->Hey Mike/Catharsis,
-&e->
-&e->A friend was telling me about the discussion thread regarding the Trust
-&e->event, and I thought I'd chime in.

For purposes of this discussion...
Mike = dj catharsis
Chris = dj yap

Conversely, I've known Mike for a long time, and he should be entitled to
speak freely.  You're a damn good dj Chris, but you're not god's gift to
hotmixing or doubles, a label head, a guy with 20+ records out, or a ten
year veteran dj either, and I know Mike's had some exposure to some of the
best of the best.  Mike threw one of the best regular techno events I've
had the pleasure of playing at on the west coast and he's entitled to his
opinion as a promoter.  While local techno in SF was getting thin and
trance was taking over locations like 2nd and jackson etc, Mike was
getting world class techno DJs to drop bombs at Tortilla Flats... an 18+
space with full bar (and deadly tokyo iced teas) in quaint little downtown
SLO of all places.

In defense of Ed and this event, Trust has always had a reputation for
incredible sound systems... the kind that cost bank to put together (as
well as overall production).  Treating a non-massive crowd to that kind of
sound costs money, but it's how techno should be appreciated.

I'm stoked about the event... (aside from not getting asked to play
*WHAAAA*).  Let's not bite each other's nuts here, if techno is going to
get it's due audience, we gotta be a community.

If price is an issue, jump the opportunity to get at some $15 tix.  $15 is
reasonable by just about any standards for the level of bang that should
be coming in for this.

And if anybody should be getting defensive about Mike's post, it should
probably be Chris Jackson, who IS a ten year veteran dj, mixes cleaner
(and faster when the mood suits him) than most anybody I've heard locally
or from out of town, currently runs four labels, has some 20+ releases on
vinyl on labels from japan to nyc, and has had his ass flown all over the
states bombing no compromise dancefloor techno.

andyw

andyw-mutorsoundsystem-andy@saturn5.com

Andy,

Thanks a lot for the comments... I appreciate them and I wholeheartedly 
agree with you that Mike and anyone else 100% has the right to speak freely. 
  I simply felt compelled to speak up about my personal disagreement with 
his comments... he is certainly entitled to like or dislike all the DJs in 
the local techno scene, however is it really necessary to make a blanket 
statement to the effect of "All local bay area techno DJs do is throw money 
at great records and mix crappily"?  I simply disagree with this, and am 
stating this.  And very humble thanks for the compliments Andy... but 
putting that aside for a moment, there are lots of good techno DJs around 
here, too many to mention here (but Andy W. and Catharsis most certainly 
included), that can do a lot more than throw on "5 minutes of track followed 
by a quick cut over or a forced/unstable mix less than 20 seconds".  And by 
the way, yes, I also wholeheartedly agree with you that I am not God's gift 
to... anyone!   God forbid! ;-)

That said, Mike please make all the comments you wish with my blessings of 
course, I meant in absolutely no way to censor anybody... I simply did not 
want the comments to go "un-rebutted", so to speak, given my disagreement 
with them.

I love this techno community.

Peace,
Chris

>year veteran dj either, and I know Mike's had some exposure to some of the
>best of the best.  Mike threw one of the best regular techno events I've
>had the pleasure of playing at on the west coast and he's entitled to his
>opinion as a promoter.  While local techno in SF was getting thin and
>trance was taking over locations like 2nd and jackson etc, Mike was
>getting world class techno DJs to drop bombs at Tortilla Flats... an 18+
>space with full bar (and deadly tokyo iced teas) in quaint little downtown
>SLO of all places.
>
>In defense of Ed and this event, Trust has always had a reputation for
>incredible sound systems... the kind that cost bank to put together (as
>well as overall production).  Treating a non-massive crowd to that kind of
>sound costs money, but it's how techno should be appreciated.
>
>I'm stoked about the event... (aside from not getting asked to play
>*WHAAAA*).  Let's not bite each other's nuts here, if techno is going to
>get it's due audience, we gotta be a community.
>
>If price is an issue, jump the opportunity to get at some $15 tix.  $15 is
>reasonable by just about any standards for the level of bang that should
>be coming in for this.
>
>And if anybody should be getting defensive about Mike's post, it should
>probably be Chris Jackson, who IS a ten year veteran dj, mixes cleaner
>(and faster when the mood suits him) than most anybody I've heard locally
>or from out of town, currently runs four labels, has some 20+ releases on
>vinyl on labels from japan to nyc, and has had his ass flown all over the
>states bombing no compromise dancefloor techno.
>
>andyw
>
>andyw-mutorsoundsystem-andy@saturn5.com
>\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\
>
>-&e->
>-&e->I've seen you out quite a bit, you seem to be quite the techno fan 
>which I
>-&e->can certainly relate with... so I think it's reasonable to assume

>-&e->seen most of the local techno folks play out around town.  I think it 
>then
>-&e->follows that your given your comments below that the feelings you

>-&e->here apply to all the techno DJs who you've met and seen play and

>-&e->positivity in this regard.  I guess next time we're out and you look

Subject: ATP: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest

I feel they acted as best they could; How do you expect them to deal
with/treat un-civilized folk, who have nothing better to do then act like
"victims"? Wake up people.

be prepared. Finally Oakland does something right; SFPD should take note.
Civil disobedience should not be tolerated. Everyone who is out there, knows
what "could" happen.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Rayn" <acydrayn@hotmail.com>
To: "'Monikat'" <technoslut303@yahoo.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 5:13 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest


> All I have to say is, as much as I believe in civil disobdience... DON'T
> PROVOKE THE MAN!  The reason it all went downhill is because people were
> throwing rocks and lead pipes, I mean c'mon!  We're not in the middle
> east and we're supposed to be peaceful.  Resorting to violence to stop
> violence is not an answer, you're joining them.  Like the good old Pet
> Shop Boy's song... 'Violence begets violence.'  Any action that has a
> direct consequence of possibly harming the massively outnumbered police
> force is going to cause them to panic.  Think smart.
>
> Love,
> Rayn
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Monikat [mailto:technoslut303@yahoo.com]
> Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 5:07 PM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest
>
>
> so.. this is way not rave-related, but i had written
> it up for another list and thought folks might want to
> hear more info. about what went down w/ the wooden
> bullets, etc. at the oakland docks protest.  if you
> don't care, go ahead and skip it.
>
> also, if folks are interested, the next action by
> Direct Action to Stop the War will be Monday, April 14
> at the Chevron-Texaco HQ in the east bay.  more info.
> is available at www.actagainstwar.org.  it feels
> really good to be out in the streets or on a picket
> line in community w/ folks, even if we do wind up
> dodging wooden bullets (which is rare.)
>
> there's also a large anti-war march on saturday in SF.
>  see www.indybay.org for more info.
>
> it's hard getting up at 5 in the morning.  being still
> awake is one thing, getting up is another.  the bed is
> so warm, i need the sleep... but i figured that
> sometimes the most interesting things happen in those
> liminal hours between night and day, and it's a rare
> event i see those morning hours, especially among
> hundreds of pickets at the oakland port.
>
> i didn't make it to the action 'til about 6:30 or so
> (the organizers were asking people to show up at 5:30
> - 5:45, as the bosses had told workers to come in
> extra early, but what can i say? i'm really slow in
> the morning).  By the time I arrived there were
> hundreds of lively pickets at the gates of American
> President Lines (APL), who ship weapons to iraq.
> there were also three other pickets further down the
> road at another APL gate and SSA, Stevedoring Services
> of America.  (for more information and background on
> these companies and on the action, see
> www.actagainstwar.org.)  the point of the action was
> to have a loud, but legal picket line.  if there were
> enough folks out there, an arbitrator for the
> dockworkers and maritime association  would judge
> whether crossing the line was a health and safety
> issue, and hopefully the dockers would not go to work.
>
>
> so, once i got there, the tasks at hand were to find
> some friends (it's better to go with friends, but
> well, my "buddy" was sleeping in), and flyer for the
> benefit party i'm doing (which hopefully didn't wind
> up in the pocket of anyone who was arrested).  i
> quickly found someone i knew and we went down to the
> next gate to look for others.  around this time i saw
> the first arrest i witnessed, of a man on roller
> skates who i guess pissed off the police with his, uh, rollerskating.
> the police then, i think, gave an "order to disperse" at the 2nd gate,
> despite the fact that it was a legal picket, and they moved in
> menacingly, in formation.  i felt wussy, but since i hadn't been
> planning on getting arrested , i quickly moved across the street and
> then onto the next gate. it didn't look like people were up for arrest,
> as most people seemed to move out of the way, as well, out of the
> entrance, though still picketing.
>
> the next thing i knew, i heard a loud bang and looked
> over and saw that the cops were firing what looked
> like teargas (which i now think was a concussion
> grenade) at people around the gate i'd just left,
> especially at folks across the street (who'd probably
> just dispersed themselves from the gate).  fuck.  glad
> i'd brought the bandana.  i wondered if we were going
> to get trapped.  i saw a bunch of police running
> across the street on the railroad tracks going after
> someone,  luckily they gave up the chase, but it
> stressed me out.  running cops mean i might be running
> soon.  i wound up moving to the main part of the 3rd
> gate and milling around, not wanting to go too much
> closer.   the police continued to move in.  more
> concussion grenades, and i guess wooden bullets, and
> cops and more cops.  a friend saying they saw a legal
> observer getting arrested across the street.  loud
> grenades, someone in his car frantically screeching
> tires, driving backwards in the crowd, trying to turn
> around, police moving in.
> this was crazy.  we pretty much all came thinking it
> would be a legal picket, some folks had complained it
> "wasn't really direct action", and of course you never
> know what the cops will do (and i'd been somewhat
> intimidated going alone), but i didn't expect seattle.
>
>
> Down at the 4th gate now, a friend beating on a big
> bass drum, interspersed with the sounds of the bullets
> and grenades and police advance.  trying to stay
> together with friends, and how close to the police did
> we want to stay?   eventually a large group of us left
> together as the police moved us along, heading down
> Middle Harbor Road towards 7th.  folks picketed at
> this intersection for a bit, people circling around in
> the street and chanting.  i bumped into a friend who
> showed me the bruise on his leg and told me he'd been
> shot with a wooden dowell (sp?) while doing legal
> observation.  then the cops started moving in again
> and shit! that concussion grenade was really close!
> and here were more bullets.  we hurried along and
> crossed a line of blocked trucks, many of whom honked
> in support, and then found ourselves on a sidewalk in
> the netherworld of trucks and tunnels (under the
> railraod tracks and Rte. 880, I believe.)  after
> emerging above ground (and happily discovering we were
> not trapped by cops), we waited for people and went
> back to the west oakland bart.  i left at this point
> to go home and change and go to work, but i read that
> people afterwards marched, in the street , to the
> oakland federal building.  (more info. available on www.indybay.org, san
> francisco indymedia).
>
> a few more things: i never saw anyone throwing things
> at police.  i doubt that anyone did, but even if a few
> rocks were thrown (which i HIGHLY doubt happened -
> it's just a convenient excuse for the cops), to fire
> wooden bullets and beanbag shot and concussion
> grenades at a retreating demonstration is outrageous.
> i have heard that people were run into w/ motorcycles
> as well. apparently 6 local 10 ILWU workers were
> wounded as well, and 31 people were arrested,
> including an ILWU member.  people were hit in the
> back, police were aiming right at people... ugh.
>
> when i stopped home, my partner said to me, "i'm proud
> of you.  you got shot at.  you must have really hit a
> sore spot."  i guess so.
>
> here's some more info. below, and jerry brown's # to
> call if you want to support the protesters:
>
>
> >  > CALL AND ASK FOR IMMEDIATE DE-ESCALATION OF
> POLICE TACTICS AND
> RELEASE OF
> >>  THE POLITICAL PRISONERS
> >>  Mayor Jerry Brown's Office:  510.238.3141
> >>  Hold him accountable for any police violence that
> occurs! His
> office is
> >>  responsible for the Oakland Police!!
> >>
>   ILWU workers who were not
> participating in
> >>  the protest have been shot with rubber bullets and
> a ILWU business
> agent
> >>  has reportedly been arrested.
> >>
> >>  There has been extroadinary police violence at
> this morning's dock
> action,
> >>  including tear gas, concussion grenades, police
> running over people
> with
> >>  motorcycles and rubber bullets. It is likely that
> this violence was
> called
> >>  for by the Mayor's office, which generally has a
> practice on
> >>  non-confrontation with pickets.  Pickets have been
> entirely
> peaceful. Over
> >>  1,000 people turned out to shut down the port and
> have been
> extremely
> >>  successful.
> >>  Jerry Brown's Office: 510-238-3141  Ask that the
> police violence
> stop
> >  > immediately and that the political prisoners be
> released.

Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer

    I have gotten to use Final Scratch a few times, and in general I like
it. I like having an actual needle and record to play with. Once you have a
song assigned to a turntable, it feels just like vinyl. My #1 complaint is
that you cannot see the grooves in the record. You can look at the computer
screen and see the waveform of the song and how much time is remaining, but
I missed being able to look at the record and see where the breaks are, and
how far the record has to spin before it reaches the end of the track. I
fantasize about somehow being able to project the grooves for each song onto
the record.  :-)

Happy  :-)

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs

"People are about as happy as they make up their minds to be." -Abraham
Lincoln

"Very little is needed to make a happy life;
it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking." -Marcus Aurelius
Antoninus

----- Original Message -----
From: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>
To: "Psychedelic Armadillo" <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
Cc: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>; "_ fable _"
<fable4our@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 4:37 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer


>
> On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Psychedelic Armadillo wrote:
> -&e->um...did I miss a Final Scratch discussion? I would
> -&e->really really REALLY like to see someone break it down
> -&e->as far as the differences between Traktor and Final
> -&e->Scratch (and any other serious alternatives).
>
> Just wait a little bit, they'll be one and the same product very shortly.
>
> For the time being -
> Final Scratch is an interface that allows the playback position and speed
> of an mp3 (or aif or wav) to be controlled by a special record on a
> turntable.  Basics - you select files in the interface, then use the
> record to mix them in very similarly to traditional vinyl DJing.  Very
> straighforward analog of normal DJing, you just get to use mp3s.
>
> Traktor is a software package that allows the mixing of multiple mp3 or
> wav/aif whatever using a software interface.  Points for a solid EQ
> section, elegant interface and auto beatmatch features (yay, play for 30
> hours and not have to actually mix :\ ).
>
> Native Instruments and Stanton are working to tie the best of breed
> interface for file management and effects (NI's Traktor) and physical
> speed and position control (Stanton's Final Scratch) into one pimping
> thing for the migration to OSX (and this merging will probably rear it's
> head with the PC version eventually as well).  With endorsements from DJs
> like John Tejada, DJ Hell, Richie Hawtin, Josh Wink and more coming... I'm
> sure they'll do fine.
>
> The big question comes down to what people are willing to spend, what you
> want to do, and how well audiences accept the technology (because DJing is
> a performance art, like it or not... and DJing using digital tools will
> face the same challenges as a pianist going to synthesizers).  I prefer
> the undeniable simplicity of a hefty ass box o' records, 2 technics and a
> mixer, but as I'm looking into new ways of playing live I've been dabbling
> a bit with miss pinky - a product that also allows interfacing using a
> vinyl style system, but allows direct interface to cycling74's max/msp
> development environment (and can be used to drive/scratch video or midi or
> whatever you can whip up in max... not just audio files).
>
> Information Sites:
> www.finalscratch.com
> www.traktor-dj.com
> www.mspinky.com
>
> andyw
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

the "idea" is great, what happens in the middle of a gig when your laptop
crashes?? I am under the impression you would be rather screwed, seeing as
Win OS isn't the most stable.
