----- Original Message -----
From: "Happy" <happy@happycandykid.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 10:21 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer


>     I have gotten to use Final Scratch a few times, and in general I like
> it. I like having an actual needle and record to play with. Once you have
a
> song assigned to a turntable, it feels just like vinyl. My #1 complaint is
> that you cannot see the grooves in the record. You can look at the
computer
> screen and see the waveform of the song and how much time is remaining,
but
> I missed being able to look at the record and see where the breaks are,
and
> how far the record has to spin before it reaches the end of the track. I
> fantasize about somehow being able to project the grooves for each song
onto
> the record.  :-)
>
> Happy  :-)
>
> "A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
> but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs
>
> "People are about as happy as they make up their minds to be." -Abraham
> Lincoln
>
> "Very little is needed to make a happy life;
> it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking." -Marcus Aurelius
> Antoninus
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>
> To: "Psychedelic Armadillo" <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
> Cc: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>; "_ fable _"
> <fable4our@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 4:37 AM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer
>
>
> >
> > On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Psychedelic Armadillo wrote:
> > -&e->um...did I miss a Final Scratch discussion? I would
> > -&e->really really REALLY like to see someone break it down
> > -&e->as far as the differences between Traktor and Final
> > -&e->Scratch (and any other serious alternatives).
> >
> > Just wait a little bit, they'll be one and the same product very
shortly.
> >
> > For the time being -
> > Final Scratch is an interface that allows the playback position and
speed
> > of an mp3 (or aif or wav) to be controlled by a special record on a
> > turntable.  Basics - you select files in the interface, then use the
> > record to mix them in very similarly to traditional vinyl DJing.  Very
> > straighforward analog of normal DJing, you just get to use mp3s.
> >
> > Traktor is a software package that allows the mixing of multiple mp3 or
> > wav/aif whatever using a software interface.  Points for a solid EQ
> > section, elegant interface and auto beatmatch features (yay, play for 30
> > hours and not have to actually mix :\ ).
> >
> > Native Instruments and Stanton are working to tie the best of breed
> > interface for file management and effects (NI's Traktor) and physical
> > speed and position control (Stanton's Final Scratch) into one pimping
> > thing for the migration to OSX (and this merging will probably rear it's
> > head with the PC version eventually as well).  With endorsements from
DJs
> > like John Tejada, DJ Hell, Richie Hawtin, Josh Wink and more coming...
I'm
> > sure they'll do fine.
> >
> > The big question comes down to what people are willing to spend, what
you
> > want to do, and how well audiences accept the technology (because DJing
is
> > a performance art, like it or not... and DJing using digital tools will
> > face the same challenges as a pianist going to synthesizers).  I prefer
> > the undeniable simplicity of a hefty ass box o' records, 2 technics and
a
> > mixer, but as I'm looking into new ways of playing live I've been
dabbling
> > a bit with miss pinky - a product that also allows interfacing using a
> > vinyl style system, but allows direct interface to cycling74's max/msp
> > development environment (and can be used to drive/scratch video or midi
or
> > whatever you can whip up in max... not just audio files).
> >
> > Information Sites:
> > www.finalscratch.com
> > www.traktor-dj.com
> > www.mspinky.com
> >
> > andyw
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> >
>

Subject: Re: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer

Correct, when you install FS it sets up a dual boot allowing you to boot to
FS on Linux, or to your favorite flavor of Windoze, allowing you to run FS
in isolation. But yeah, if your laptop crashed, you would be screwed. If *I*
were performing with FS, I would probably have vinyl with me too, so you
could throw on a couple of tracks while your laptop reboots, or just finish
your set with vinyl if your comp is dead.

Happy  :-)

> > > >
> > > > For the time being -
> > > > Final Scratch is an interface that allows the playback position and
> > speed
> > > > of an mp3 (or aif or wav) to be controlled by a special record on a
> > > > turntable.  Basics - you select files in the interface, then use the
> > > > record to mix them in very similarly to traditional vinyl DJing.
Very
> > > > straighforward analog of normal DJing, you just get to use mp3s.
> > > >
> > > > Traktor is a software package that allows the mixing of multiple mp3
> or
> > > > wav/aif whatever using a software interface.  Points for a solid EQ
> > > > section, elegant interface and auto beatmatch features (yay, play
for
> 30
> > > > hours and not have to actually mix :\ ).
> > > >
> > > > Native Instruments and Stanton are working to tie the best of breed
> > > > interface for file management and effects (NI's Traktor) and
physical
> > > > speed and position control (Stanton's Final Scratch) into one
pimping
> > > > thing for the migration to OSX (and this merging will probably rear
> it's
> > > > head with the PC version eventually as well).  With endorsements
from
> > DJs
> > > > like John Tejada, DJ Hell, Richie Hawtin, Josh Wink and more
coming...
> > I'm
> > > > sure they'll do fine.
> > > >
> > > > The big question comes down to what people are willing to spend,
what
> > you
> > > > want to do, and how well audiences accept the technology (because
> DJing
> > is
> > > > a performance art, like it or not... and DJing using digital tools
> will
> > > > face the same challenges as a pianist going to synthesizers).  I
> prefer
> > > > the undeniable simplicity of a hefty ass box o' records, 2 technics

--------- Original Message --------
From: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.org" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:US OR: Glass Artists' Arrests Stoke 'Culture War'
Date: 08/04/03 14:58


"...US OR: Glass Artists' Arrests Stoke 'Culture War'
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n380/a07.html
Newshawk: allan
Pubdate: Sun, 09 Mar 2003
Source: Register-Guard, The (OR)
Copyright: 2003 The Register-Guard
Contact: rgletters@guardnet.com
Website: http://www.registerguard.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/362
Author: Bob Keefer

GLASS ARTISTS' ARRESTS STOKE 'CULTURE WAR'

For six years, Jason Harris and Saeed Mohtadi ran their glass pipe
businesses entirely in the open.

Harris sold the smoking pipes through his retail store, Higher Source, at
133 E. 13th Ave. The two men advertised and sold glass pipes on the
Internet, using such domain names as ghettoweb.com. Anyone could buy one
of their pipes - which are of a kind commonly used for smoking marijuana -
with a Visa card. Harris and Mohtadi apparently believed that the pipes,
which were advertised for use with tobacco or incense, were legal.

What they didn't know until quite recently was that agents of the federal
Drug Enforcement Administration were conducting a detailed investigation
of their businesses, involving "undercover" buys from the wide-open
businesses, secret surveillance and even a "trash pull," in which agents
rifled through the businesses' garbage.

Last month, as part of a nationwide bust called Operation Pipe Dreams,
agents swept in and arrested the two businessmen, charging them with
selling drug paraphernalia. They each face three years in prison and
$250,000 fines, as well as forfeiture of their businesses and homes.
Across the country, 50 people were arrested in the sweep, the biggest drug
paraphernalia clampdown in the agency's history.

The arrests point up a series of deep fault lines in American culture:
over marijuana, over art, over free expression, even over states' rights.

Most of the plain facts in the Harris and Mohtadi cases are not in
dispute. They are also somewhat unusual for a criminal case.

Harris and Mohtadi ran a national distribution company for pipes made by
Harris' firm, Jerome Baker Designs. They had employees. They paid taxes.
They advertised. Their pipes were labeled "for tobacco use only" or
labeled as incense burners and can, in fact, be used to smoke tobacco or
burn incense. Harris and Mohtadi seemed to believe that their businesses
had stayed on the legal side of federal law, which bars the sale of items
"primarily intended" for drug use.

The law, 21 U.S. Code Section 863, originally was enacted as part of the
Controlled Substances Act of 1970. It has been challenged repeatedly as
unconstitutionally vague but has withstood legal tests up to the Supreme
Court. It specifically bars the sale of glass smoking pipes, as well as
those made of almost any other material, but allows pipes "traditionally
intended for use with tobacco." In determining what use a pipe is intended
for, officials can look in part at how it was advertised and what the
makers and retailers say it should be used for, the law says.

Broader issues erupted as well with the arrests here. Harris and Mohtadi
have been heavily involved with the burgeoning art glass scene in Eugene.
Their arrests seem, to some, an attack on an underground art form that's
grown up in Lane County over the past generation.

"This has very little to do with drugs," said Lane Arts Council Executive
Director Douglas Beauchamp. "It's part of a culture war. I have a
personal take on this. It has to do with the chilling of America as
fostered by ( Attorney General John ) Ashcroft, and going after people who
make craft items, artifacts, art, and wrapping it all into a coarse and
repressive attack."

But is it art?

Alder Gallery owner Candy Moffett, who has shown glass art ( though not
pipes ) by Harris at her Coburg gallery, says all his work - pipes
included - - is artistic.

"Are the glass pipes art?" she said. "Yes. Just as Jason has a control
and mastery of the medium, I think his pipes are artworks. They are done
in such a masterful way, they are sculptures. Look at meerschaum pipes.
There are meerschaum pipes considered sculptures. These are, too."

At the Drug Enforcement Administration office in Portland, Ken Magee,
assistant special agent in charge, scoffed at the notion that glass pipes
could be considered art.

"I find that somewhat laughable, referring to drug paraphernalia as
collectible art," he said. "I find it somewhat engaging that you would
refer to this as 'collectible art' when it's drug paraphernalia."

Magee, who said he had little time to discuss issues surrounding the case,
bristled when asked whether it makes sense to conduct a nationwide
drug-paraphernalia bust even as the nation fights terrorism at home and
across the globe and heads for war in Iraq.

"The DEA enforces drug laws within the state of Oregon as well as within
the United States," he said. "We collectively as an agency will define
our priorities on a day-to-day basis. It is quite obvious that an
investigation of this magnitude doesn't happen overnight."

Nationwide, the DEA has enthusiastically sought to enlarge the definition
of paraphernalia, sometimes running into First Amendment and artistic
expression issues.

Last year, a federal judge in Louisiana granted a permanent order sought
by the American Civil Liberties Union to stop the DEA from classifying
glow sticks and pacifiers at rave concerts as drug paraphernalia.

A market for other glass

Harris and Mohtadi were substantial contributors to and members of the
board of directors at Eugene Glass School, a 4-year-old nonprofit
institute founded, at least in part, to show Lane County bong makers that
a market exists for other glass as well.

In addition, Mohtadi was treasurer of the school and Harris served in an
unofficial role as coordinator, making sure the kilns were running and
supplies were on hand each day. They both resigned from the board and
other duties shortly after the arrests.

George Kjaer, a retired physician who helped start the school, said the
Eugene Glass School has always insisted on a "Chinese wall" between the
art glass it teaches and the bong-making that has supported many of its
students.

"We have worked diligently to create a significant barrier not only
between the school and these two companies but against the production and
utilization of paraphernalia on our campus and in our teaching programs,"
he said. "We have tried to stimulate these artisans to think in terms of
fine art. We have gone out of our way to seek people who would otherwise
have been dropouts but have found a voice in art."

Adding to the culture-war perception is the fact that the two men are
being charged and prosecuted not here in Eugene but in Pittsburgh, Pa.,
where a large retailer selling their pipes was arrested.

After arresting the Pittsburgh retailer, DEA officials in that region
broadened their quest and began surveillance of Harris' and Mohtadi's
businesses in Eugene.

The 47-page affidavit supporting the federal search warrant used in the
arrest lists in detail the steps agents took:

In June 2000, two men were convicted in Pittsburgh of selling drug
paraphernalia that they had obtained wholesale from Jerome Baker Designs.
Following a simple trail of public records, agents identified Harris and
Mohtadi last August.

In September, agents "located and observed" the Higher Source store and,
"acting in undercover capacities," entered the store and "observed
hundreds of Jerome Baker Designs items."

While in the store, the undercover agent was told by "an unidentified
male" that Jerome Baker Designs was named after the late musician Jerry
Garcia and "baker," slang for a marijuana user.

Also in September, agents bought $741.79 worth of glass pipes, including
"1 Extra Fancy Phat Mama Bong" at $184, through ghettoweb.com, paying for
it with a Visa card.

Eugene lawyer Greg Veralrud, who is representing Mohtadi, said it was too
early to talk about any specific defense to the federal charges, but laid
out several possibilities.

Pennsylvania's burghers

Veralrud said he may seek a change of venue to bring the case back to
Eugene. All Mohtadi's witnesses are here and would have to fly to
Pennsylvania to testify.

Is the DEA venue shopping by filing its charges in a culturally
conservative district in Pennsylvania?

"People in Oregon tend not to be as troubled" by marijuana-related issues,
Veralrud said, adding that the fact his client advertised on the Internet
may have been a key factor in his arrest.

"The impression is, 'If you kept this in your own back yard we wouldn't
bother you. The god-honest burghers of Pennsylvania won't put up with the
liberal high-falutin' dope-smokin' ways of Eugene, Oregon.' "

Veralrud added that the federal government has long been unhappy with
Oregon's medical marijuana law.

"We have a fairly mature medical marijuana program. It's become something
the public is ever more accepting of. I have to think we have an
environment where even among folks who don't agree with using marijuana,
they are generally more accepting of the fact that others do," he said.

The lawyer also said that, given the seriousness of the charges, a plea
bargain is always a possibility. "My client is a young man with a young
family. I know he's also in a little bit of a quandary. He made an
effort to do this aboveboard. There is not a whiff of unlawful activity.
He's never been secretive about it."

--

& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.

was there, and while i couldn't see every single thing

was not violent at all.  it was peaceful picketing and
milling around.  it was chanting and singing and lots
of older people, too. there was no full-on black bloc
(not that that means there will automatically be
attacks on police) and no "edge" by the protestors.  i
really don't believe that any of that happened,
honestly, and that the police are just saying that
because they think people will believe it and they're
using it as an excuse.

defend ourselves, and i don't believe that those who
are in power will give it up without a fight. however,
that's neither here nor there, as the protest we're
talking about was organized with nonviolent
principles, and like i said, i haven't heard from
anyone who saw anybody throwing things at the cops

and the media that just parrot their li(e)nes.  

and besides, even if, (and i do say if, because i
don't think it happened), a few people were throwing
stones, does it make sense to fire grenades, etc. into
the whole crowd, and continue firing into the whole
crowd for hours while people retreat, and fire at
people's backs and heads?  i don't think so.   police
have shields.  they can deflect rocks. they are also
supposed to be trained to deal with individuals doing
things like that, not to terrorize and injure masses
of people (well, actually, as we know, they are
trained for that.)

don't believe the lies.

> force is going to cause them to panic.  Think smart.

> is available at www.actagainstwar.org.  it feels
> really good to be out in the streets or on a picket
> line in community w/ folks, even if we do wind up
> dodging wooden bullets (which is rare.)  
> 
> there's also a large anti-war march on saturday in
> SF.
>  see www.indybay.org for more info.  
> 
> it's hard getting up at 5 in the morning.  being
> still
> awake is one thing, getting up is another.  the bed
> is
> so warm, i need the sleep... but i figured that
> sometimes the most interesting things happen in
> those
> liminal hours between night and day, and it's a rare
> event i see those morning hours, especially among
> hundreds of pickets at the oakland port.  
> 
> i didn't make it to the action 'til about 6:30 or so
> (the organizers were asking people to show up at
> 5:30
> - 5:45, as the bosses had told workers to come in
> extra early, but what can i say? i'm really slow in
> the morning).  By the time I arrived there were
> hundreds of lively pickets at the gates of American
> President Lines (APL), who ship weapons to iraq. 
> there were also three other pickets further down the
> road at another APL gate and SSA, Stevedoring
> Services
> of America.  (for more information and background on
> these companies and on the action, see
> www.actagainstwar.org.)  the point of the action was
> to have a loud, but legal picket line.  if there
> were
> enough folks out there, an arbitrator for the
> dockworkers and maritime association  would judge
> whether crossing the line was a health and safety
> issue, and hopefully the dockers would not go to
> work.
>  
> 
> so, once i got there, the tasks at hand were to find
> some friends (it's better to go with friends, but
> well, my "buddy" was sleeping in), and flyer for the
> benefit party i'm doing (which hopefully didn't wind
> up in the pocket of anyone who was arrested).  i
> quickly found someone i knew and we went down to the
> next gate to look for others.  around this time i
> saw
> the first arrest i witnessed, of a man on roller
> skates who i guess pissed off the police with his,
> uh, rollerskating.
> the police then, i think, gave an "order to
> disperse" at the 2nd gate,
> despite the fact that it was a legal picket, and
> they moved in
> menacingly, in formation.  i felt wussy, but since i
> hadn't been
> planning on getting arrested , i quickly moved
> across the street and
> then onto the next gate. it didn't look like people
> were up for arrest,
> as most people seemed to move out of the way, as
> well, out of the
> entrance, though still picketing.  
> 
> the next thing i knew, i heard a loud bang and
> looked
> over and saw that the cops were firing what looked
> like teargas (which i now think was a concussion
> grenade) at people around the gate i'd just left,
> especially at folks across the street (who'd
> probably
> just dispersed themselves from the gate).  fuck. 
> glad
> i'd brought the bandana.  i wondered if we were
> going
> to get trapped.  i saw a bunch of police running
> across the street on the railroad tracks going after
> someone,  luckily they gave up the chase, but it
> stressed me out.  running cops mean i might be
> running
> soon.  i wound up moving to the main part of the 3rd
> gate and milling around, not wanting to go too much
> closer.   the police continued to move in.  more
> concussion grenades, and i guess wooden bullets, and
> cops and more cops.  a friend saying they saw a
> legal
> observer getting arrested across the street.  loud
> grenades, someone in his car frantically screeching
> tires, driving backwards in the crowd, trying to
> turn
> around, police moving in.  
> this was crazy.  we pretty much all came thinking it
> would be a legal picket, some folks had complained
> it
> "wasn't really direct action", and of course you
> never
> know what the cops will do (and i'd been somewhat
> intimidated going alone), but i didn't expect
> seattle.
>  
> 
> Down at the 4th gate now, a friend beating on a big
> bass drum, interspersed with the sounds of the
> bullets
> and grenades and police advance.  trying to stay
> together with friends, and how close to the police
> did
> we want to stay?   eventually a large group of us
> left
> together as the police moved us along, heading down
> Middle Harbor Road towards 7th.  folks picketed at
> this intersection for a bit, people circling around
> in
> the street and chanting.  i bumped into a friend who
> showed me the bruise on his leg and told me he'd
> been
> shot with a wooden dowell (sp?) while doing legal
> observation.  then the cops started moving in again
> and shit! that concussion grenade was really close! 
> and here were more bullets.  we hurried along and
> crossed a line of blocked trucks, many of whom
> honked
> in support, and then found ourselves on a sidewalk
> in
> the netherworld of trucks and tunnels (under the
> railraod tracks and Rte. 880, I believe.)  after
> emerging above ground (and happily discovering we
> were
> not trapped by cops), we waited for people and went
> back to the west oakland bart.  i left at this point
> to go home and change and go to work, but i read
> that
> people afterwards marched, in the street , to the
> oakland federal building.  (more info. available on
> www.indybay.org, san
> francisco indymedia).  
>  
> a few more things: i never saw anyone throwing
> things
> at police.  i doubt that anyone did, but even if a
> few
> rocks were thrown (which i HIGHLY doubt happened -
> it's just a convenient excuse for the cops), to fire
> wooden bullets and beanbag shot and concussion
> grenades at a retreating demonstration is
> outrageous.
> i have heard that people were run into w/
> motorcycles
> as well. apparently 6 local 10 ILWU workers were
> wounded as well, and 31 people were arrested,
> including an ILWU member.  people were hit in the
> back, police were aiming right at people... ugh. 
> 
> when i stopped home, my partner said to me, "i'm
> proud
> of you.  you got shot at.  you must have really hit
> a
> sore spot."  i guess so.   
> 
=== message truncated ===

On the evening of December 16, 1773, three companies of fifty men each, =
masquerading as Mohawk Indians, passed through a tremendous crowd of =
spectators, went aboard the three ships, broke open the tea chests, and =
heaved them into the harbor.As the electrifying news of the Boston "tea =
party" spread, other seaports followed the example and staged similar =
acts of resistance of their own.'=20

Was this not civil disobedience that made a difference? When the =
Bostonians refused to pay for the property they had destroyed, George =
III and Lord North decided on a policy of coercion, to be applied only =
against Massachusetts, the so-called Coercive Acts. In these four acts =
of 1774, Parliament closed the port of Boston, drastically reduced the =
powers of self-government in the colony, permitted royal officers to be =
trailed in other colonies or in England when accused of crimes, and =
provided for the quartering of troops in the colonists' barns and empty =
houses. The acts sparked new resistance up and down the coast.=20

Nick

I've heard lots about this new club. I just want to go for Wicked, but more
for the sound system. Funktion-One is the offshoot of TurboSound after
TurboSound was bought by AKG. Pretty damn cool stuf... And it's PURPLE. I'm
just glad to see it's not EAW for once. Everyone and their mother *loves*
EAW in the SF Bay Area. I think JK has something to do with that...

thanks for the tip. i like to go hear real techno artists in obscure places too! it is possible to do so, and have it be safe and fun...also, on another sujet du jour, i think beauty bar is just one of the sweetest little places, but i guess due to popular demand and short on space, it is kind of not fun at all to go to on the weekends. they have various dj nights, chairs with blow dryer to sit under...basically, completely cute decor, but sometimes, a really, extra rotten crowd lately...lots of ciggie smoke, no air whatsoever, and men who throw beer deliberately on women....so, just saying so since i am out here, and since that is kind of important for people to know...thursdays are kicking though. you might get a seat.   :)

Is there any instance in which you -would not- chant 'My country, right or
wrong'?

On Wed, 9 Apr 2003, Jack Triumph wrote:

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Rayn" <acydrayn@hotmail.com>
> To: "'Monikat'" <technoslut303@yahoo.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 5:13 PM
> Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest
>
>
> > All I have to say is, as much as I believe in civil disobdience... DON'T
> > PROVOKE THE MAN!  The reason it all went downhill is because people were
> > throwing rocks and lead pipes, I mean c'mon!  We're not in the middle
> > east and we're supposed to be peaceful.  Resorting to violence to stop
> > violence is not an answer, you're joining them.  Like the good old Pet
> > Shop Boy's song... 'Violence begets violence.'  Any action that has a
> > direct consequence of possibly harming the massively outnumbered police
> > force is going to cause them to panic.  Think smart.
> >
> > Love,
> > Rayn
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Monikat [mailto:technoslut303@yahoo.com]
> > Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 5:07 PM
> > To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest
> >
> >
> > so.. this is way not rave-related, but i had written
> > it up for another list and thought folks might want to
> > hear more info. about what went down w/ the wooden
> > bullets, etc. at the oakland docks protest.  if you
> > don't care, go ahead and skip it.
> >
> > also, if folks are interested, the next action by
> > Direct Action to Stop the War will be Monday, April 14
> > at the Chevron-Texaco HQ in the east bay.  more info.
> > is available at www.actagainstwar.org.  it feels
> > really good to be out in the streets or on a picket
> > line in community w/ folks, even if we do wind up
> > dodging wooden bullets (which is rare.)
> >
> > there's also a large anti-war march on saturday in SF.
> >  see www.indybay.org for more info.
> >
> > it's hard getting up at 5 in the morning.  being still
> > awake is one thing, getting up is another.  the bed is
> > so warm, i need the sleep... but i figured that
> > sometimes the most interesting things happen in those
> > liminal hours between night and day, and it's a rare
> > event i see those morning hours, especially among
> > hundreds of pickets at the oakland port.
> >
> > i didn't make it to the action 'til about 6:30 or so
> > (the organizers were asking people to show up at 5:30
> > - 5:45, as the bosses had told workers to come in
> > extra early, but what can i say? i'm really slow in
> > the morning).  By the time I arrived there were
> > hundreds of lively pickets at the gates of American
> > President Lines (APL), who ship weapons to iraq.
> > there were also three other pickets further down the
> > road at another APL gate and SSA, Stevedoring Services
> > of America.  (for more information and background on
> > these companies and on the action, see
> > www.actagainstwar.org.)  the point of the action was
> > to have a loud, but legal picket line.  if there were
> > enough folks out there, an arbitrator for the
> > dockworkers and maritime association  would judge
> > whether crossing the line was a health and safety
> > issue, and hopefully the dockers would not go to work.
> >
> >
> > so, once i got there, the tasks at hand were to find
> > some friends (it's better to go with friends, but
> > well, my "buddy" was sleeping in), and flyer for the
> > benefit party i'm doing (which hopefully didn't wind
> > up in the pocket of anyone who was arrested).  i
> > quickly found someone i knew and we went down to the
> > next gate to look for others.  around this time i saw
> > the first arrest i witnessed, of a man on roller
> > skates who i guess pissed off the police with his, uh, rollerskating.
> > the police then, i think, gave an "order to disperse" at the 2nd gate,
> > despite the fact that it was a legal picket, and they moved in
> > menacingly, in formation.  i felt wussy, but since i hadn't been
> > planning on getting arrested , i quickly moved across the street and
> > then onto the next gate. it didn't look like people were up for arrest,
> > as most people seemed to move out of the way, as well, out of the
> > entrance, though still picketing.
> >
> > the next thing i knew, i heard a loud bang and looked
> > over and saw that the cops were firing what looked
> > like teargas (which i now think was a concussion
> > grenade) at people around the gate i'd just left,
> > especially at folks across the street (who'd probably
> > just dispersed themselves from the gate).  fuck.  glad
> > i'd brought the bandana.  i wondered if we were going
> > to get trapped.  i saw a bunch of police running
> > across the street on the railroad tracks going after
> > someone,  luckily they gave up the chase, but it
> > stressed me out.  running cops mean i might be running
> > soon.  i wound up moving to the main part of the 3rd
> > gate and milling around, not wanting to go too much
> > closer.   the police continued to move in.  more
> > concussion grenades, and i guess wooden bullets, and
> > cops and more cops.  a friend saying they saw a legal
> > observer getting arrested across the street.  loud
> > grenades, someone in his car frantically screeching
> > tires, driving backwards in the crowd, trying to turn
> > around, police moving in.
> > this was crazy.  we pretty much all came thinking it
> > would be a legal picket, some folks had complained it
> > "wasn't really direct action", and of course you never
> > know what the cops will do (and i'd been somewhat
> > intimidated going alone), but i didn't expect seattle.
> >
> >
> > Down at the 4th gate now, a friend beating on a big
> > bass drum, interspersed with the sounds of the bullets
> > and grenades and police advance.  trying to stay
> > together with friends, and how close to the police did
> > we want to stay?   eventually a large group of us left
> > together as the police moved us along, heading down
> > Middle Harbor Road towards 7th.  folks picketed at
> > this intersection for a bit, people circling around in
> > the street and chanting.  i bumped into a friend who
> > showed me the bruise on his leg and told me he'd been
> > shot with a wooden dowell (sp?) while doing legal
> > observation.  then the cops started moving in again
> > and shit! that concussion grenade was really close!
> > and here were more bullets.  we hurried along and
> > crossed a line of blocked trucks, many of whom honked
> > in support, and then found ourselves on a sidewalk in
> > the netherworld of trucks and tunnels (under the
> > railraod tracks and Rte. 880, I believe.)  after
> > emerging above ground (and happily discovering we were
> > not trapped by cops), we waited for people and went
> > back to the west oakland bart.  i left at this point
> > to go home and change and go to work, but i read that
> > people afterwards marched, in the street , to the
> > oakland federal building.  (more info. available on www.indybay.org, san
> > francisco indymedia).
> >
> > a few more things: i never saw anyone throwing things
> > at police.  i doubt that anyone did, but even if a few
> > rocks were thrown (which i HIGHLY doubt happened -
> > it's just a convenient excuse for the cops), to fire
> > wooden bullets and beanbag shot and concussion
> > grenades at a retreating demonstration is outrageous.
> > i have heard that people were run into w/ motorcycles
> > as well. apparently 6 local 10 ILWU workers were

At 11:04 AM 4/9/2003 -0700, Jack Triumph wrote:
>I have a question about FS; I have played the "in-store" models and while
>the "idea" is great, what happens in the middle of a gig when your laptop
>crashes?? I am under the impression you would be rather screwed, seeing as
>Win OS isn't the most stable.

I wouldn't do a complete FS set for this reason.  It is quite simple to 
move from FS to traditional vinyl (switch from line to phono) while you reboot.


>I heard a rumor that a MAC OS version will be out shortly?

I understand from FS tech support it's a matter of weeks.

Love,

Apollo



>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Happy" <happy@happycandykid.com>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 10:21 AM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer
>
>
> >     I have gotten to use Final Scratch a few times, and in general I like
> > it. I like having an actual needle and record to play with. Once you have
>a
> > song assigned to a turntable, it feels just like vinyl. My #1 complaint is
> > that you cannot see the grooves in the record. You can look at the
>computer
> > screen and see the waveform of the song and how much time is remaining,
>but
> > I missed being able to look at the record and see where the breaks are,
>and
> > how far the record has to spin before it reaches the end of the track. I
> > fantasize about somehow being able to project the grooves for each song
>onto
> > the record.  :-)
> >
> > Happy  :-)
> >
> > "A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
> > but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs
> >
> > "People are about as happy as they make up their minds to be." -Abraham
> > Lincoln

> > "Very little is needed to make a happy life;
> > it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking." -Marcus Aurelius
> > Antoninus
> >
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>
> > To: "Psychedelic Armadillo" <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
> > Cc: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>; "_ fable _"
> > <fable4our@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 4:37 AM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves]MP3 digital mixer
> >
> >
> > >
> > > On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Psychedelic Armadillo wrote:
> > > -&e->um...did I miss a Final Scratch discussion? I would
> > > -&e->really really REALLY like to see someone break it down
> > > -&e->as far as the differences between Traktor and Final
> > > -&e->Scratch (and any other serious alternatives).
> > >
> > > Just wait a little bit, they'll be one and the same product very
>shortly.
> > >
> > > For the time being -
> > > Final Scratch is an interface that allows the playback position and
>speed
> > > of an mp3 (or aif or wav) to be controlled by a special record on a
> > > turntable.  Basics - you select files in the interface, then use the
> > > record to mix them in very similarly to traditional vinyl DJing.  Very
> > > straighforward analog of normal DJing, you just get to use mp3s.
> > >
> > > Traktor is a software package that allows the mixing of multiple mp3 or
> > > wav/aif whatever using a software interface.  Points for a solid EQ
> > > section, elegant interface and auto beatmatch features (yay, play for 30
> > > hours and not have to actually mix :\ ).
> > >
> > > Native Instruments and Stanton are working to tie the best of breed
> > > interface for file management and effects (NI's Traktor) and physical
> > > speed and position control (Stanton's Final Scratch) into one pimping
> > > thing for the migration to OSX (and this merging will probably rear it's
> > > head with the PC version eventually as well).  With endorsements from
>DJs
> > > like John Tejada, DJ Hell, Richie Hawtin, Josh Wink and more coming...
>I'm
> > > sure they'll do fine.
> > >
> > > The big question comes down to what people are willing to spend, what
>you
> > > want to do, and how well audiences accept the technology (because DJing
>is
> > > a performance art, like it or not... and DJing using digital tools will
> > > face the same challenges as a pianist going to synthesizers).  I prefer
> > > the undeniable simplicity of a hefty ass box o' records, 2 technics and
>a
> > > mixer, but as I'm looking into new ways of playing live I've been
>dabbling
> > > a bit with miss pinky - a product that also allows interfacing using a
> > > vinyl style system, but allows direct interface to cycling74's max/msp
> > > development environment (and can be used to drive/scratch video or midi
>or
> > > whatever you can whip up in max... not just audio files).
> > >
> > > Information Sites:
> > > www.finalscratch.com
> > > www.traktor-dj.com
> > > www.mspinky.com
> > >
> > > andyw
> > >

Subject: [sfraves] RAVE ACT ON THE FLOOR FOR VOTE IN 12-24 HOURS -- ACT NOW

------=_NextPart_000_012A_01C2FEB0.5FF5AAF0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

THE RAVE ACT IS MOVING!=20
IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO STOP IT: FAX YOUR SENATORS & EMAIL THIS TO YOUR=20
FRIENDS

Late on Tuesday, April 8, a Senate and House Conference Committee,=20
without a hearing, public notice or a debate in Congress, attached=20
the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (formerly known as the RAVE=20
Act) to the Amber Alert Bill (a child abduction bill). =20

It is not too late to stop the bill - Fax your senators. The main=20
floor fight is likely to take place in the Senate in the next 12-24=20
hours so do it NOW
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=3D2&item=3D1578

Representatives John Conyers (D-MI) and Bobby Scott (D-VA) valiantly=20
opposed this sneaky effort to pass controversial legislation. =20
Unfortunately they were outvoted and RAVE Act provisions did become=20
part of the bill.  These provisions make it clear that "crackhouse=20
laws" apply to temporary events, such as concerts, dances or=20
festivals, and add civil penalties of up to $250,000 to the=20
statute.  If passed, property owners can be punished for any drug=20
offense that their customers commit - even if they work hard to stop=20
such offenses. This is likely to deter nightclub and stadium owners=20
from holding events.=20

On a more positive note, the word "rave" and an earlier "findings"=20
section that implied that water, glow sticks and other legal items=20
could be construed as evidence of drug use have been removed from the=20
bill. We hope that this will ensure that nightclub and other property=20
owners will not be prosecuted for having these legal items available=20
to customers. Your faxes achieved this!

With your help we will continue to fight to remove the RAVE Act=20
provisions from the AMBER Alert legislation, even if the Senate and=20
House act and the President signs the bill into law.  We urge you to=20
take immediate action. =20

Fax your two Senators to let them know that you oppose the inclusion=20
of RAVE Act provisions in the AMBER Alert Bill.  The main floor fight=20
is likely to take place in the Senate in the next 12-24 hours=20
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=3D2&item=3D1578

Let Representatives John Conyers and Bobby Scott know that you=20
appreciate their fight.  Write a thank you note, card, postcard, or e-
mail:

Representative John Conyers
669 Federal Office Building
231 West Lafayette Boulevard
Detroit, MI 48226
John.Conyers@mail.house.gov <mailto:John.Conyers@mail.house.gov>=20
mailto:John.Conyers@mail.house.gov

Representative Bobby Scott
The Jackson Center
501 N Second Street
Richmond, VA  23219
bobby.scott@mail.house.gov <mailto:bobby.scott@mail.house.gov>=20
mailto:bobby.scott@mail.house.gov

Thank you to everyone who responded to our earlier e-mail alerts, and=20
to the hard work of all of our coalition partners in the electronic=20
dance, beverage and hotel industries, along with freedom of speech=20
and public health organizations. We especially wish to thank those=20
people who responded to our sign-on letter - Representative Conyers=20
read parts of it to the Conference Committee. =20

Finally, we want you to know that regardless of whether these=20
provisions pass or not, Drug Policy Alliance and our coalition=20
partners will work with you to mobilize to protect property owners=20
and prevent the further criminalization of dance or music events.  We=20
will scrutinize law enforcement raids of clubs and properties.  We=20
will work to find ways to help property owners, hotel owners,=20
nightclub owners and others to keep their customers safe.  Finally we=20
will continue to advocate for legislation that helps ensure the=20
safety and free speech of the dance and music community and of all=20
people who are affected by this law.


++++++++++++++++++++++++You received this message because
bryano@sachaven.org is a member of the mailing list originating=20
from alerts@actioncenter.drugpolicy.org.=20

Please visit=20
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/managesubscription.asp to=20
learn about other lists you can subscribe to, or to unsubscribe from=20
individual or all lists.=20

For problems, please contact Jeanette Irwin at jirwin@drugpolicy.org .

Please join the Drug Policy Alliance:
http://www.drugpolicy.org/join

Subject: [sfraves] Still Time to Act on the Rave Act!!!

--=====================_2244150==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

THE RAVE ACT IS MOVING!
IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO STOP IT: FAX YOUR SENATORS & EMAIL THIS TO YOUR
FRIENDS


Late on Tuesday, April 8, a Senate and House Conference Committee,
without a hearing, public notice or a debate in Congress, attached
the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (formerly known as the RAVE
Act) to the Amber Alert Bill (a child abduction bill).


It is not too late to stop the bill - Fax your senators. The main
floor fight is likely to take place in the Senate in the next 12-24
hours so do it NOW
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1578


Representatives John Conyers (D-MI) and Bobby Scott (D-VA) valiantly
opposed this sneaky effort to pass controversial legislation.
Unfortunately they were outvoted and RAVE Act provisions did become
part of the bill.  These provisions make it clear that "crackhouse
laws" apply to temporary events, such as concerts, dances or
festivals, and add civil penalties of up to $250,000 to the
statute.  If passed, property owners can be punished for any drug
offense that their customers commit - even if they work hard to stop
such offenses. This is likely to deter nightclub and stadium owners
from holding events.


On a more positive note, the word "rave" and an earlier "findings"
section that implied that water, glow sticks and other legal items
could be construed as evidence of drug use have been removed from the
bill. We hope that this will ensure that nightclub and other property
owners will not be prosecuted for having these legal items available
to customers. Your faxes achieved this!


With your help we will continue to fight to remove the RAVE Act
provisions from the AMBER Alert legislation, even if the Senate and
House act and the President signs the bill into law.  We urge you to
take immediate action.


Fax your two Senators to let them know that you oppose the inclusion
of RAVE Act provisions in the AMBER Alert Bill.  The main floor fight
is likely to take place in the Senate in the next 12-24 hours
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1578


Let Representatives John Conyers and Bobby Scott know that you
appreciate their fight.  Write a thank you note, card, postcard, or e-
mail:


Representative John Conyers
669 Federal Office Building
231 West Lafayette Boulevard
Detroit, MI 48226
John.Conyers@mail.house.gov <mailto:John.Conyers@mail.house.gov>
mailto:John.Conyers@mail.house.gov


Representative Bobby Scott
The Jackson Center
501 N Second Street
Richmond, VA  23219
bobby.scott@mail.house.gov <mailto:bobby.scott@mail.house.gov>
mailto:bobby.scott@mail.house.gov


Thank you to everyone who responded to our earlier e-mail alerts, and
to the hard work of all of our coalition partners in the electronic
dance, beverage and hotel industries, along with freedom of speech
and public health organizations. We especially wish to thank those
people who responded to our sign-on letter - Representative Conyers
read parts of it to the Conference Committee.


Finally, we want you to know that regardless of whether these
provisions pass or not, Drug Policy Alliance and our coalition
partners will work with you to mobilize to protect property owners
and prevent the further criminalization of dance or music events.  We
will scrutinize law enforcement raids of clubs and properties.  We
will work to find ways to help property owners, hotel owners,
nightclub owners and others to keep their customers safe.  Finally we
will continue to advocate for legislation that helps ensure the
safety and free speech of the dance and music community and of all
people who are affected by this law.




Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) report from anti-war oakland docks protest

Given the actions of the OPD, I don't even think it's relevant AT ALL if the
so-called "black block" was involved in the protest or not.  Those tear gas
grenades the cops fired into the crowd don't discriminate.  Shrapnel from the
wooden sabot the news reported as being fired into the crowd doesn't
discriminate.

Collective punishment (hell... collective CORPERAL punishment, without so much
as a trial even...) is just flat out evil.  Punishment of the innocent for the
hypothetical actions of their assumed associates should NEVER be tolerated.

Did even one person, who was not throwing rocks at the cops, get so much as a
breath of the tear gas?  Did even one person, who was not throwing rocks at the
cops, get so much as a splinter in their behind from those wooden sabot?  Was
even one person, who was not physically violent against another human being,
arrested?  Was even one person, who was not physically violent against another
human being, harrased by the cops in any way?

Somehow, I suspect the answer to all four is: "yes".  And that is full-out
intolerable.  And every single pig involved should be instantly and permanently
terminated for their obscene abuse of power in the incident.  And the fact that
that has not happened is ample proof that neither the department nor the
government of oakland believes in anything resembleing justice.


cya,
john

every address that requests to be subscribed. It's not possible to
subscribe someone else without their permission with ezmlm.

Visit www.deciblast.org/ for more information.

:: Popsicle 5 Ticket Giveaway ::
presented by Deciblast

Details

- We want to hear about your best experience at any Skills party. 
Please send in a short story describing what happenned and why it was a 
good experience.
- We will be giving away 1-2 pairs of tickets depending on the turnout.
- Please submit your stories to dee@deciblast.org

Rules

- Stories can be of any length but must be well thought out. Please 
spend some time on them.
- The best stories will be chosen by staff members May 10th.
- Between May 10th and May 17th the stories will be posted here and 
Deciblast visitors will vote on the best one.
- In order to stop people's friends from voting up their stories, the 
final vote will be weighted with staff votes.


:: Popsicle 5 Information ::

Electro-Techno-Disco-Popsicle 5
Saturday May 24th, 2003

Located at the Concourse Exhibition Center. From 6PM-2AM. 100% 
permitted. 18+. For more detailed information call 415.437.4460, 
510.869.4601, 408.920.2180

For more information visit www.skillsdjworkshop.com/pop5.html. Tickets 
availible from www.tickets.com and www.groovetickets.com

*AREA 1*  Euro-Trance
AGNELLI & NELSON (Ireland), THE THRILLSEEKERS (UK), ART OF TRANCE (LIVE 
PA) (UK), SUPERFAST OZ, ST. JOHN, TELENE, JEFF RYAN & 007

*AREA 2* Cyber-Trance
STEVE BALTES (LIVE PA) (Germany), MARS & MYSTRE, DYLOOT & TOMSLIK, 
THEE-O, ENEMY, DENISE

*AREA 3* Jungle & Turntablism
TOTAL SCIENCE (UK), ROC RAIDA  of the X-ecutioners!, UFO!, JUJU, FLUX, 
BICOLAS & B-DUB, DOS

*AREA 4* Funky & Progressive House
MAC ZIMMS (UK), YOMANDA (UK), H-FOUNDATION (Hippi-E & Halo), DJ HUEY, 
DAVID GARCIA, JOEY MAZZOLA, RON REESER, DJ TORQUE

*AREA 5* Nu-School Breaks & 2-step (21+ area with 2 bars)
10-SUI (UK), SYRUP GIRLS, ADAM OHANA, ANON, DOV, GHOST & FRANK NITTY, 
MADAME MERCURY

*AREA 6* Local Showcase
DISKO SHAWN, TRONIC, DRAGN'FLY, PAUL THE FANMAN, RECKLESS RYAN, BAZOOKA 
JOE, AJAX, SASCHA 23, JINX, ANGELICA X, TUFF TWINS

Sunkissed was a blast. I missed the last few, but made a point to head to
this one. Michael was in rare form. Saw a  lot of people I hadn't seen in a
while (including you Luke!). Ate some damn fine food compliments of Terry
Estioko and Sukissed family. 25lbs of 7 layer dip. YUM. We brought the keg
of Golden Gate Pale Ale with us since we had so much left over from
Marshal's bday last Friday. Thank him for the keg. I just drove it there.
That was a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. Nice park too.

keep it up!

AMEN TO THAT! I go everywhere on a bike or public transportation and nothing pisses me off more than the idiots who ruin it for everybody by riding on the sidewalks and riding against traffic. I'll be out walking my dog and some moron will be like "excuse me," but that's not what they mean because they almost run you and your little dog over, and then they try to start a fight with you if you yell at them or even say "moron" under your breath. And I get treated to ice thrown on me from cars going 60, and "GET OFF THE ROAD BITCH!" just because I want to save a little gas and the planet and keep my own gigantic ass from getting bigger. Also helmets arent for dangling fom your handlebars.

Nicole's Birthday & Wow... what a fun night!  OK... B4 I 4get... got 2 =
hang out w/ Mystic (from here, SFR) & I ain't seen that dude in like =
sooooo long, so it was Dope hangin' out w/ Homeboy again!  I'm very =
proud of Dude workin' on his own set of Tunes & spinning!!  YAY! =3D)

But the party itself was very interesting!!  Met alota people I didn't =
know that night & well.... I got on the decks & spun Aussie's HOuse, =
Trance, & Breakbeats Records 4 like an hour & a 1/2 almost!  It was =
fun!!  LoL

Danny Picard came by later on & spun this really wicked Acid Break Beats =
set which I was soooooo Diggin... YUM... then later he spun this =
PsyTrance set which was gRoovy 2!!!

OH Yeah... since DAnny was my ride home to Hercules... we stayed there =
'til like the next day & HELLO 2DAY... Aussie took us boating & we went =
2 this like Small lil' island beach & man... it was fun!

OK... Last FRiday, went 2 Ryan & Tyler's 4 Marshal's bday shindig!!  =
OK.. that was Sooooooooo Fun!

Oh Yeah... B4 that... went 2 Penny's birthday thingie @ the Brewery in =
the City! That was Groovy!!  Hung out w/ Ghrahm, Dreg, Zack, Steve, My =
Bday bro Chris, mmmmm, that's all I could like remember right now... Oh =
Yeah.. Penny was there ofcourse! Oh oh oh... Jessica was there 2! =3D)

After hangin' out there 4 like 2 hours I guess... we went 2 Ryan & =
Tyler's for Marsh's shindig where Delia was also celebrating her bday =
also!!  OK... Music:

As soon as we got in there... Happy was on the Decks spinnning some =
Yummy Jungle!!  YUUUUUUUUM!!!  OK... Then I finally met Anton Styles & =
WHOA... him & some1 else I guess were tagging this Awesome Fuckin' =
Techno set!!

But that was was So Dope!!  So many people showed up & alota people I =
haven't seen in so long!!  It was such a Groovy Reunion 2 hang out w/ so =
many people again!!! =3D)

OK... I promised myself I was gonna catchup on my post 2 SFR 2day.... so =
I got a couple more KLP's I gotta type out & letcha all know where I =
been groovin' lately! I jus' figured since these ODP thingies were =
posted 2 SFR... I'll talk baout htem 1st & well... I didn get my Groove =

    I have been reading a book recently on Rev Martin Luther King Jr and =
the
civil rights movement. They blocked traffic and disrupted businesses for
YEARS for their beliefs. They were beaten by the police and had dogs =
sicked
on them. Their homes and churches were bombed. They were castrated, =
burned
alive and lynched. Then, just as now, while the majority of protesters =
were
non-violent, a few would throw rocks and bottles at the police. Did that
warrant the retaliation they received?

Happy  :-)

> "civil disobedience should not be tolerated"
>
> Really?  Never?
>
> Does that mean the actions of protesters in the 60's fighting for the
recognition of civil rights for non-whites in America was bad?

Gotta kinda keep in mind though those were turbulant times back when segregation was still being battled, and back then there were less incidents that warrented a closer eye on non protestors and cops and such.  they never should have recieved such retaliation, i agree, but back then a lot of things were diferant and handled differantly, they'd use whatever they could as an excuse to above and beyond what was neccissary force, and a lot of the cops back then were pretty corrupt and racist especailly, as we all know, in the south.  It was mostly pure anger and hatred that fueled them and not just a simple opposing opinion on something.

alive and lynched. Then, just as now, while the majority of protesters were
non-violent, a few would throw rocks and bottles at the police. Did that
warrant the retaliation they received?

spring roll!! =20

Anywaze... we called up Sol & ended up going 2 Elastiq!!!  Wow man... it =
was fun!!!  I never been 2 Il Pirata yet, so that was Groovy goin' =
there!!  Nice lil hole in the wall! =20

Telene spun 1st & it was a Groovy lil' Prog House set!!  But I dunno... =
it was kinda hard 2 Dance to on a full tummy... so I kinda jus' kicked =
back & drank alot during her set!

OK... BUt Amber hit the decks & ooooooh shiiiiiiiiiiieeeeeeeeet... she =
totally spun this crazy set filled w/ Techno, some electro if I remember =
correctly, some acid, & some Break Beats, oh yeah.. some Trance here & =
there!!  it was a total wild set & I totally spent most of dancing my =
ass off & yelling "I Hate Amber" & flipping her off like I usualy do =
when she spins!!  LoL

But it was fun!!  Really fun!!! =20

Oh Yeah... I also hong out w/ Carter =

& man... I ain't seen Homeboy in soooooooo long!!!  It was Dope!!!  We =
totally caught up w/ each other & Grooved during Amber's set!!!  =

OK... Such a fun night!!!  Hell yeah! =20

Subject: [sfraves] News: Rave Bill riding Amber Alert into law

Please note: The opinions reflected in this article are representative
of the Daily Trojan.

"...Fair Use Provision of the Copyright Act - The Statutory Decree:

§107. Limitations on exclusive rights: Fair Use

Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 106 and 106A, the fair use of a
copyrighted work, including such use by reproduction in copies or
phonorecords or by any other means specified by that section, for purposes
such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching (including multiple
copies for classroom use), scholarship, or research, is not an
infringement of copyright. In determining whether the use made of a work
in any particular case is a fair use the factors to be considered shall
include

-the purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is of a
commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes;..."

US CA: Edu: Column: RAVE Bill Has No Place Riding AMBER Alert Into Law
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n507/a05.html
Newshawk: End Marijuana Prohibition: www.mpp.org
Pubdate: Wed, 09 Apr 2003
Source: Daily Trojan (CA Edu)
Copyright: 2003 Daily Trojan
Contact: dtrojan@usc.edu
Website: http://www.dailytrojan.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/1162
Author: Rebecca Zak
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)

RAVE BILL HAS NO PLACE RIDING AMBER ALERT INTO LAW

The mere mention of Democratic Sen.  Joe Biden's name should send
partygoers everywhere into paroxysms of sputtering rage for hours.  He's
the decrepit brain behind the putrid RAVE Act, which bizarrely tried to
equate a crack house with a rave and threatened anyone who sponsored a
rave where drugs were used with up to 20 years in prison.

Ravers everywhere thought Biden got the hint last year when the RAVE (
that's an acronym for "Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to Ecstasy" ) Act
basically died the graphic, explosive death of a hamster in a microwave.
His pet legislation violated people's rights to party and Americans let
him know that they didn't appreciate his efforts.

Now, Biden is back at his dastardly machinations, trying desperately to
make his draconian RAVE Act and the AMBER Alert legislation odd bed
fellows.

Here's the deal: After the high-profile abductions of several children
punctured the nation's consciousness this past year, legislators decided
to author the National AMBER Alert Network Act of 2003 to help law
enforcement officials deal with kidnapping cases.  Basically everyone
thinks that the AMBER Alert bill is a good idea.  It's already been passed
in the Senate and the House.

Enter Biden, a sinister, sneaky senator trying to befoul the AMBER Alert
bill while it's in conference by attaching it to his RAVE Act.  If Biden
succeeds, the RAVE act might slip undetected into the legal atmosphere
before you can say, "Let's roll."

The Drug Policy Alliance has heard that Biden has been spouting lies to
other members on the conference committee for the AMBER bill.  He's
whispering that the American Civil Liberties Union no longer objects to
the RAVE Act, despite the fact that he's made no significant changes to
the oppressive legislation.  In his self-aggrandizing delusions, he
believes that nightclub owners no longer oppose the bill because a single
club owner came out in favor of it.

In short, Biden is a raving maniac and he's got to be stopped.

The last time Biden tried to force his RAVE Act on an unwilling populace,
Americans sent more than 35,000 faxes opposing the legislation to their
respective members of Congress.  More than 500 protesters turned out in
front of the Federal Building in Westwood for a five-hour dance-a-thon to
voice their displeasure with the bill.

But more importantly, groups such as the Drug Policy Alliance and the ACLU
voiced their adamant opposition to the bill, along with the thousands of
nightclub and business owners who cried that the act holds them
responsible for the crimes of their customers.

Under the terms of the RAVE Act, anyone who organizes or owns a venue for
a rave, concert or nightclub where anyone uses an illegal drug can be held
responsible for any harm that results from the illegal drug use.  In other
words, a nightclub owner could be fined $250,000 or thrown in jail for 20
years if someone drops "E" in his club and then drives off a cliff.

Oh, but it gets worse.  If my boyfriend's hippie mom and I decided to
smoke a fat bowl at her house and some belligerent bastard called the
cops, she could be fined $500,000.  If we were smoking pot on an Amtrak
train, the owner of Amtrak could also be held liable under the terms of
the act.  Therefore, the government could be legally responsible for drug
use.

Can it get more hideous than that? You betcha.  The RAVE Act also holds
concert promoters liable for the drug use of concertgoers.  So yeah, the
Dave Matthews Band would basically never have a concert ever again.

The RAVE Act should be used as congressional toilet paper and flushed into
a sewer of forgettable legislation.  Biden's attempts to use AMBER Alert
legislation to force this ridiculous act into the books without proper
debate is utterly reprehensible.

--

& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.

At 01:24 PM 4/10/2003 -0700, Adams, Tyler S wrote:
>Gotta kinda keep in mind though those were turbulant times back when 
>segregation was still being battled, and back then there were less 
>incidents that warrented a closer eye on non protestors and cops and 
>such.  they never should have recieved such retaliation, i agree, but back 
>then a lot of things were diferant and handled differantly, they'd use 
>whatever they could as an excuse to above and beyond what was neccissary 
>force, and a lot of the cops back then were pretty corrupt and racist 
>especailly, as we all know, in the south.  It was mostly pure anger and 
>hatred that fueled them and not just a simple opposing opinion on something.


Civil disobedience and, need one remind all "patriots," armed revolution 
are traditional American modes of dissent.

I grew up in a time when political assassination, riots, and civil 
disobedience were commonplace.  After King's assassination virtually every 
city in the USA was under martial law and curfews and National Guard troops 
fired machine guns in Watts.  Students were shot and killed at Kent 
State.  When I went to anti-war demonstrations in those days I wore a 
helmet and gas mask.  We would throw tear gas canisters back at the police 
and troops.

I have been reading parts of "Yes Yes, Y'all:  The Experience Music Project 
Oral History of Hip-Hop's First Decade" by Jim Fricke and Charlie Ahearn 
(Cambridge:  Da Capo).  I quote one revealing passage:  "Could hip-hop have 
been born in the tightly policed, gentrified, self-congratulatory Big Apple 
of the 90's"  Cowboy asks.  "My guess is no.  The very lack of civil 
control (and concern) that marked New York in the 1970's aided the 
culture's incubation."  Interesting note.  During the blackout in July, 
1977, when there was widespread looting, lots of upcoming DJs stole 
turntables and mixers -- that "sprung a whole new set of DJs."

I lived in New York in the seventies and I don't recall feeling threatened 
by civil chaos but, rather, energized by a exhilarating innovation.  Order 
produces mediocrity, in my mind.  Chaos, the natural order of the universe, 
is the foundation of creation.

Then came the eighties and nineties, when safety was seen as far more 
valuable than freedom.  Predictability was what we all yearned for in life, 
and we will make any effort, even if it means bombing anyone who even 
mildly disagrees with us and handing over civil liberties, to assure our 
comfort and security.  Now we have a new generation who, according to a 
recent Harper's "index,", rank Mom, Dad, and Rudolph Giuliani as one, two, 
and three among the people they want to emulate.  Hmmmm......

Another book crossed my desk:  Alissa Quart's "Branded:  the Buying and 
Selling of Teenagers (Perseus).  For modern teens, so the argument goes, 
brand affiliation substitutes for personal identity and expression.  Take a 
look at William Gibson's latest book, "Pattern Recognition."  No longer 
writing about the future, Gibson's protagonist is a present-day corporate 
cool-hunter on assignment to research an Internet subculture that her 
employer wishes to incorporate into their brand-loyalty strategies.

So the young today, in many cases, are horrified by dissonance and 
chaos.  Minds are shaped by viral marketing -- designed by major 
corporations in bed with the government.  Yes, we live in interesting times.

Love,

Apollo

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

Fair Use Provision of the Copyright Act - The Statutory Decree:

§107. Limitations on exclusive rights: Fair Use

Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 106 and 106A, the fair use of a
copyrighted work, including such use by reproduction in copies or
phonorecords or by any other means specified by that section, for purposes
such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching (including multiple
copies for classroom use), scholarship, or research, is not an
infringement of copyright. In determining whether the use made of a work
in any particular case is a fair use the factors to be considered shall
include

-the purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is of a
commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes;


US: Supreme Court To Take Up Case Of Traffic-Stop Arrest
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n447/a05.html
Newshawk: chip
Pubdate: Tue, 25 Mar 2003
Source: Wall Street Journal (US)
Copyright: 2003 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
Contact: wsj.ltrs@wsj.com
Website: http://www.wsj.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/487
Author: Associated Press


"...Law

SUPREME COURT TO TAKE UP CASE OF TRAFFIC-STOP ARREST

WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Court said Monday it will consider the scope of
police power to arrest all occupants of a car during a traffic stop,
agreeing to look at a case from Maryland in which everyone in a car denied
knowledge of drugs and a roll of cash found inside.

Separately, the Supreme Court rejected a civil-liberties challenge to
post-Sept.  11 law-enforcement spying, refusing to expedite hearing a
dispute over the boundaries of a law that gave the government broader
surveillance authority after the terrorist attacks.

The case from Maryland continues a line of Supreme Court cases clarifying
when officers have probable cause and can apprehend someone without a
warrant.  In this case, the court will consider whether it was an
unconstitutional stretch for the officer to link the front-seat passenger
to drugs found in a back armrest, and then to arrest all three people in
the car.

Twenty states had urged the court to hear the case, involving a 1999
early-morning traffic stop in Baltimore County that yielded $763 in the
glove compartment and five baggies of cocaine in an armrest in the
backseat.

"Countless times each day, officers make traffic stops and uncover
contraband in multipassenger situations.  Police need the clarity of
authority to know who may be arrested in such cases," Maryland Attorney
General Joseph Curran argued in a court filing.

Joseph Jermaine Pringle, the front-seat passenger, was convicted of drug
charges and sentenced to 10 years in prison.  He later told police that
the drugs were his and that he had planned to swap them for sex or money
at a party.

An appeals court threw out Mr.  Pringle's conviction on grounds that his
arrest was unconstitutional and the confession was tainted.

The Constitution's Fourth Amendment prohibits unreasonable searches or
seizures.  That means police almost always need a warrant to search
someone's house without permission, but the Supreme Court has interpreted
the protection more narrowly when it comes to automobiles and public
transportation.  ( Maryland v.  Pringle )

ACLU Challenged Surveillance Powers

In the domestic spying case, the American Civil Liberties Union and other
organizations wanted the justices to consider when the government should
be allowed to monitor someone's telephone conversations and e-mail, then
use the information to prosecute them.

The Bush administration has argued that the surveillance, and a special
court that oversees sensitive domestic-espionage tactics, are
indispensable tools in the war on terror.

The ACLU used an unusual maneuver to get the case to the Supreme Court,
filing an appeal on behalf of people who don't even know they are being
monitored.  The justices would have had to give special permission to
allow it.  They refused, without comment.

The action wasn't a ruling on the merits of the ACLU's challenge, and the
issue is expected to return to the high court later.

The administration has aggressively defended its use of wiretaps approved
by the super-secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, or "spy
court," which deals with intelligence requests involving suspected spies,
terrorists or foreign agents.

Issues that have inspired the court challenges include government spying,
secret detentions, confidential deportation hearings, imprisonment of
wartime prisoners without lawyers and access to suspected foreign
terrorists held at undisclosed overseas locations.

Even the spy court had reservations about that aggressiveness.  In May,
the court ruled that the USA Patriot Act didn't justify the use of certain
investigative techniques proposed by the administration.  Attorney General
John Ashcroft appealed to a review court, which had never met or issued a
decision during the spy court's 25-year existence.

That review court sided with the administration and said government
officials didn't have to limit their monitoring to foreign intelligence.
That means law-enforcement officers can use the information to build cases
for prosecution.

The review-court decision "opens the door to surveillance abuses that
seriously threatened our democracy in the past," justices were told in the
filing by the ACLU, the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers,
the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee and the Arab Community
Center for Economic and Social Services.

To get a warrant from the spy court, the government must show that a
suspect probably is a "foreign power or agent of a foreign power." Law
enforcement must meet a higher standard -- probable cause that a crime was
committed -- to get an ordinary criminal warrant for wiretapping or other
electronic intrusion.

The administration didn't respond to the ACLU's appeal.  Any of the nine
justices could have demanded a response, but none did.

The spy court has approved thousands of warrants since it was established
by Congress in 1978, and it only rarely turns down the government.  In
testimony to Congress earlier this month, Mr.  Ashcroft said there were
more than 1,000 applications in 2002 for warrants under the Federal
Intelligence Surveillance Act.

Since the 2001 terror attacks, Mr.  Ashcroft personally has approved more
than 170 emergency domestic spying warrants, authorized by the FISA and
expanded by the USA Patriot Act.  That's triple the number of emergency
warrants used in the FISA's previous 23 years.  The warrants let
authorities tap telephones and fax numbers and conduct physical searches
for up to 72 hours before they are subject to the spy court's review.

The case is one of two at the Supreme Court involving issues related to
the terrorist attacks.  The other challenges the government's holding of
closed deportation hearings after the attacks.

Decision Stands In Discrimination Case

In other action Monday, the court let stand a lower court decision that
ruled a gay employee can sue under federal discrimination laws for
harassment over their sexual orientation.  The question arose after a gay
butler at MGM Grand Hotel LLC, a unit of MGM Mirage Inc.  of Las Vegas,
complained of sexual harassment after the hotel fired him.  ( MGM Grand
Hotel v.  Rene )

The Supreme Court also rejected an appeal over contested rules for
competition for telephone and Internet services.  The appeal had
essentially become moot because the contested rules were being overhauled
by the Federal Communications Commission, the Bush administration told the
court.  New rules were approved last month.

AT&T Corp., WorldCom Inc.  and other companies appealed a ruling that
forced federal regulators to reconsider how to allow telecommunications
companies to compete against each other.  ( WorldCom Inc.  v.  United
States Telecom Association )..."

From sfraves-return-101012-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 10 21:29:21 2003

Subject: [sfraves] News: (San Jose) Desperate Effort to Avoid Jail results in Man's
