My condolences to the Villalpando family...

Fair Use Provision of the Copyright Act - The Statutory Decree:

§107. Limitations on exclusive rights: Fair Use

Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 106 and 106A, the fair use of a
copyrighted work, including such use by reproduction in copies or
phonorecords or by any other means specified by that section, for purposes
such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching (including multiple
copies for classroom use), scholarship, or research, is not an
infringement of copyright. In determining whether the use made of a work
in any particular case is a fair use the factors to be considered shall
include

-the purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is of a
commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes;

 US CA:
Desperate Effort To Avoid Jail Ended
In Man's Death URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n396/a09.html
Newshawk: M & M Family
Pubdate: Thu, 13 Mar 2003
Source: San Jose Mercury News (CA)
Copyright: 2003 San Jose Mercury News
Contact: letters@sjmercury.com
Website: http://www.bayarea.com/mld/mercurynews
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/390
Authors: Roxanne Stites, Dan Reed and Elise Banducci Mercury News
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/meth.htm (Methamphetamine)

DESPERATE EFFORT TO AVOID JAIL ENDED IN MAN'S DEATH, POLICE SAY

San Jose's special weapons team had Willie Villalpando surrounded, guns
drawn.  He knew he was in trouble, police said, so he ate the evidence --
what authorities believe was a half-ounce of methamphetamine.

Then he refused medical treatment, police said, telling them he'd just
"ride it out."

For nearly eight hours on Tuesday, the 20-year-old Milpitas man was at
Santa Clara Valley Medical Center until he died.  A hospital spokesman
declined to discuss the case, but said that without a patient's consent
nothing can be legally done to save him.

Such decisions, medical ethics experts say, reside in a gray area.  The
key lies in determining whether the patient is competent to know the risks
of refusing treatment.  It's unclear what police and hospital officials
did Tuesday to determine if the 20-year-old, apparently high on
methamphetamine and in police custody, was able to offer informed consent.

Family members can't believe Villalpando, with a 2-month-old son and two
stepchildren, would refuse treatment.  He was caught in an undercover
sting operation, said San Jose police.  Because he was considered a threat
to himself and others, authorities arranged to have highly trained SWAT
officers help in his arrest.  It was about 1:30 p.m.  Tuesday when they
pulled him over in his Volkswagen Jetta at the busy intersection of
Hamilton Avenue and North Winchester Boulevard.

Police say a 2-year-old was in the back seat, but they would not identify
the boy.

As police approached Villalpando's car and ordered him to raise his hands,
at least one of the officers saw him put something in his mouth,
authorities said.  Trying to preserve the evidence and keep the man from
hurting himself, the officer reached through the window, grabbed
Villalpando's arm and tried to open his mouth.  The officer then yelled
for him to spit it out and tried putting pressure on the man's throat.

"We tried to prevent him from swallowing the drugs, suspected drugs, but
we can't force people to throw up," said San Jose police spokeswoman
Catherine Unger.  "If a person wants to do that, unfortunately, it's their
bad decision."

Villalpando got out of the car, and police drove him to the emergency
room, where he repeatedly refused treatment, according to San Jose police.

"I know I'll get a long time in jail," Villalpando reportedly said at the
hospital.  "I'm going to ride this out."

With Villalpando still at the hospital about 7 p.m., a jail employee
logged him into the booking computer on a charge of possession of drugs
for sale.  Police say he may have swallowed as much as a half-ounce of
methamphetamine.  When a person overdoses on methamphetamine, body
temperature soars, heart and respiratory rates skyrocket and blood
pressure shoots up.  Villalpando was pronounced dead at 9:10 p.m.

Because of patient confidentiality requirements, a Valley Medical
spokesman wouldn't say what happened at the hospital.  Spokesman Matt
Schenone said, in general, a patient can refuse care.

Coroner's officials conducted an autopsy Wednesday on Villalpando, but
didn't determine a cause of death.  Toxicology tests should confirm how
much drugs he had in his bloodstream.

Santa Clara County coroner Gregory Schmunk said that once a stimulant such
as methamphetamine enters the bloodstream, it's only a matter of minutes
before the heart is drastically affected.

Villalpando's right to refuse treatment -- rather than have potential
evidence pumped from his stomach -- has its roots in long established law.
But it's not always simple to apply, medical experts say.

If one is deemed competent he or she can refuse treatment.  U.S.  courts
have ruled, for example, that a Jehovah's Witness or Christian Scientist
can refuse potentially life-saving treatments, such as a blood
transfusion, because such a practice is against their religion.

If a doctor touches someone "without his or her permission," said Bruce
Hilton, director of the National Center for Bioethics in Sacramento,
"that's battery."

But if a patient is in dire need of medical aid and does not seem to be
rational or able to make an informed decision, the physicians must provide
treatment, Hilton said.

Howard Slyter, a neurologist and chair of the bioethics committee at
Kaiser Permanente in Sacramento, said it's called determining a patient's
"decision-making" power.  In addition to ensuring patients understand the
risks, he also asks why they are refusing treatment.

The answer may not be one the doctor agrees with, but it would provide
further information about whether it's reasonable within the patient's
values and beliefs.

Moreover, Slyter said, the doctor should try to bargain with the patient,
cut a deal where the medical staff can intervene if the patient's
condition becomes life-threatening.  Hospital officials will not say what
happened in Villalpando's case.

Dr.  Rene Binder, director of the Psychiatry and Law program at the
University of California-San Francisco, also noted that not all
emergencies allow for such niceties.

"If someone comes into an emergency room and they're choking," she said,
"you save their life and talk about it later."

Doctors can involuntarily treat a patient who they deem mentally unfit or
suicidal, for up to 72 hours, but can only administer medication if the
patient is in imminent danger.  But it wasn't clear if Villalpando
intended to die.

Because he died while in the custody of police, the Santa Clara County
Sheriff's Department sent homicide detectives to the hospital to
investigate.  After interviews and witnessing the autopsy, the
investigators determined there was no foul play, according to sheriff's
spokesman Terrance Helm.

Villalpando's family isn't convinced.

They said they don't believe he refused treatment.  They can't understand
what he was doing with drugs and said he had never been in trouble before.
They don't believe police took him immediately to the hospital, but
instead took their time filling out paperwork.

Police arrived at the family's home in Milpitas on Tuesday afternoon with
a search warrant, looking for methamphetamine, plastic bags, balloons and
scales.  They took Villalpando's brother Joseph, 21, to the police station
and told him Willie was in custody but never mentioned his overdose,
family members say.

The first the family heard that Willie was in the hospital was about 7:30
p.m.  when an officer returned to their home with the news.

They rushed to the hospital, but didn't arrive in time.

"He was like the oldest, because he was more responsible than I am," said
Joseph Villalpando, the eldest of seven siblings, who admits being a drug
user, but swears his brother was not.  "He was a role model for the
family.  Plus he has a 2-month-old baby.

"You think he'd want to die?"  --

Crystal,

thank you so much for your feedback!  i am so glad to hear from someone who
has actually seen them!  :)

they are coming to this area soon (dc/baltimore).  i am going to try to
check them out!  their cd is very nice!  ("spending time on the
borderline")

there is one song "utsukushii shibuya" that i love!  it's very pretty,
sweet and sad.

does anyone possibly know what the title means?

also, anyone know what a "gaijin glar" is?

the lyrics go:

"i've been thrown the gaijin glar for so long
by now i take the scorn in stride
got no time for pride
that only serves to divide
got no time for
miscommunication

i've been trying o get this straight for so long
trying to hammer out what's bent
you trust in my intent
you must be heaven sent
and i've been trying to let you know
i love you so

i've been trying to find a girl for so long
that tears have often filled my eyes
under azure skies
as we said our last goodbyes
i was trying to let you know
that i love you so

you'll never know
but i love you so"

*sigh*

so tragic!  :(

but what the heck is a "gaijin glar"?

if anyone knows, i'd be grateful to be enlightened.  thank you!

much respect and appreciation,
mary :)

morrism@washpost.com



                                                                                                           
                      "Crystal"                                                                            
                      <c24b@angelfire.c        To:       sfraves@hyperreal.org, "Mary Morris"              
                      om>                       <morrism@washpost.com>                                     
                                               cc:                                                         
                      04/09/2003 09:53         Subject:  Re: [sfraves] nrr - ozma ?                        
                      PM                                                                                   
                      Please respond to                                                                    
                      c24b                                                                                 
                                                                                                           
                                                                                                           




 Ozma is pretty cool in concert; I have seen them a couple of times. Their
fans are VERY devoted and really get into the music, (especially the Tetris
song!), which makes the concerts really fun. Their shows are either free or
pretty cheap so I definitely suggest seeing them. Hope this helps.

-Crystal

P.S. If you like emo-sounding bands, check out Cursive.

--

Actually Christmas is a pagan holiday adopted by Christians to go hand
in hand with the birth of Christ. I don't know much more than that but

paganism is tied to mainstream culture. So please if anyone on here
feels comfortable about it, educate us. Peace

Paganism is one of the oldest religions around....do a search on their holidays, you'll notice that several of their holidays coincide with Christian holidays.  This is no coincidence; the christians used this to convert pagans to christianity. 
Also there are tons of places to meet pagans:  
http://www.pagannation.com/
just my little thoughts for today!!

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Planting Seeds of Peace....the summer festival circuit officially begins here!


May Day Fest Of All is presented by Fifth Sun Visionary Producers 
Collective, uniting Amazon Productions, Anon Salon, Earthdance, Groove 
Garden, Health & Harmony, Mystic Beat Lounge, Unexpected Company, and 
UrsaMinor.


Come celebrate and plant seeds of peace at the 11th Annual May Day Fest Of 
All which moves to picturesque Stafford Lake Park (outside Novato in Marin 
County) on Saturday, May 3rd, 2003. Conjuring up the ancient spirit of May 
Day, this wildly popular Spring celebration renews community spirit through 
an array of powerful interactive performances by artists, musicians, 
dancers, daredevil stilt walkers and children of the greater Bay Area 
community. Join us for a spectacular day filled with multiple stages 
featuring eclectic music from distant lands, stunning cirque ambience, a 
Rites of Spring Spiral Dance, the Waltz of the Flowers, the Enchanted 
Children's Parade, an enticing vendors bizarre, incredibly delicious foods, 
the Garden of Vineyard & Ale Tasting, and of course, the annual MAYPOLE 
Dance led by the Fairy Queen!

A fantastic line-up and an amazing day out!
The 11th Annual
MAY DAY FEST OF ALL!
"Planting Seeds Of Peace"

SATURDAY MAY 3
Noon to 10 PM plus
a Fun-for-All Ages Affair at the mystical
STAFFORD LAKE PARK
Novato, Marin County
(directions below)

Who will Plant the Seeds of Peace on May Day?
The energy of the maiden, fresh and new.
The energy of the Mother, loving and warm.
The energy of the Crone, wisdom and tranquility.
The energy of the Goddess, radiant and pure.

www.maydayfestival.com

LIVE MUSIC LINE-UP:

LADY OF THE LAKE STAGE

Groundation - True Roots Reggae Vibrations
West African Highlife Band - Traditional African Grooves
Suzanne Sterling & Bhakti - Goddess Gypsy Funk
Avalon Rising - Celtic Rock with the Pipe & Bowl Morris Dancers
Eagle Spirit - Native American Singers & Dancers
Aspara - Ancient Temple Dancing
Xeno - Urban Drum Circus
Rites of Spring Spiral Dance & Beltane / Fertility Ritual
Maypole Dance of the Fairies
w/Fiddler's Fancy & the Pipe and Bowl Morris Dancers
DJs Zack Darling & Rhythmystic

AVALON STAGE

Foxgluv - Funky Trip-hop
Alcyone - Deep grooves from members of Medicine Drum
Shabaz -- Middle Eastern groove
Kate Price - Angelic Vocal Dreamscapes
Copper Wimmin - Inspirational Harmonies and Fearless Lyrics
Scott Huckabay - Dolphin Trance Guitar
Michelle Starr - Rich Vocals & Lush Melodies
Makaela - 15-Year Old R&B Singing Sensation
Round Robin of Songstresses:
Kimberly Bass, Pollyanna Bush, Marca Cassity, Lakshmi Devi, Mamazon, 
CaroLuna Michelson


CIRQ-CLE MEADOW & KID'S DELL
Danger Ha Ha!, Dhyanis, Estara, Exist Dance, Mystic Family Circus,
Stone Circle Players, Sun & Moon Puppet Ensemble, White Dragon


Plus the Fairy Fashion Show Off!, Earth Fertility Ritual, People Planting, 
Shuar Indian Blessing,
Peace Seed Plantation, and silly people and YOU!


FOR MORE INFORMATION CONTACT: info@maydayfestival.com / (707) 522-9735


22 LIVE MUSIC ACTS, TEN PERFORMANCE ACTS IN THREE AREAS


Directions:
Stafford Lake Park
30 minutes from San Francisco
Take Highway 101 to Novato in Marin County. Exit Atherton Avenue San Marin 
Drive.
Go West on San Marin Drive for 2.7 miles. Turn Right on Novato Boulevard 
and go 2.4 miles to Stafford Lake Park on the Left.
No Dogs and No Glass Bottles Please

TICKETS: $15 in advance and $20 at the door. Children 12 and under FREE. 
Tickets are available online at 
<http://www.inhousetickets.com/evinfo.php?eventid=2593>
or order by phone at: 1-866-384-3060
Gate opens at 11:30 AM


Local ticket outlets:

Marin County
Avant Garde - 1328 4th Street, San Rafael
Famous for Our Look - 96 Throckmorton Ave., Mill Valley
Culture Shock - 7 Incredible Records - 113 N. Main Street, Sebastopol
The Opened Heart - 609 4th Street, Santa Rosa

  East Bay

Sponsored by A.C.E. and Higher Octave

Special thanks to these community businesses whose generous donations help 
make this event possible: Bordenave's, Good Earth Natural Foods, Manhattan 
Bagels, Marin Bagel Co., Peacock Gap Golf & Country Club, San Rafael 
Safeway, SJM Communications, Whole Foods Market, Wildwood Natural Foods, As 
You Like It Productions (hosts of the Renaissance Faire at Stafford Lake 
July 12- Aug. 10 - www.forestfaire.com)
Lagunitas Brewery and Topolos Winery

The Groove Garden
Saturday Night, May 3
2398 Sir Francis Drake Blvd, Fairfax
www.thegroovegarden.com

707-829-7897 or email her at iam@amandazon.com

DRUG WAR PUSHES U.S. INMATE POPULATION OVER 2 MILLION


Drug offenses account for nearly 60% of the federal prison population
and more than 20% of the state inmate population.  For the first time
in history, the number of inmates in American prisons and jails has
exceeded 2 million.  As of June 30, 2002, there were 1.35 million
prisoners in State and Federal prisons and an additional 665, 475 in
local jails, according to a new report by the Bureau of Justice
Statistics. This represents an increase of nearly 2% over the first
six months of 2002.  The rate of incarceration in the United States,
702 inmates per 100,000 residents, continues to be the highest in the
world.  Among black males 25 to 29, 12.9% were in prison or jail.
Overall, 4.8% of black males were in prison or jails, compared to
1.7% of Hispanics and 0.6% of whites. Black women in prisons and
jails continue to outnumber their white (5 times as many) and
Hispanic (more than twice as many) counterparts.


The Bureau's report demonstrates state and federal policies continue
to drive up incarceration rates despite sharp drops in violent crime
rates since 1994 and efforts by many state governors and legislators
from both political parties to reduce swollen prison populations and
corrections budgets during an economic downturn.  "The relentless
increases in prison and jail populations can best be explained as the
legacy of an entrenched infrastructure of punishment that has been
embedded in the criminal justice system over the last 30 years," says
Malcolm C. Young, Executive Director of The Sentencing Project.
Despite harsh mandatory minimum laws that send many low-level drug
offenders to prison, drug use as evidenced by survey information and
emergency room admissions remains flat.  The numbers contained in the
Bureau's report demonstrate the role of policy over actual crime
trends in determining incarceration.


For additional information and analysis, please visit The Sentencing
Project's web site at: http://www.sentencingproject.org


For information on crime rates, please visit the Bureau of Justice
Statistics web site at: http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/cvict.htm

Moksha Tribe

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

At 07:18 PM 4/10/2003 -0700, Dragn'fly wrote:


>  Can someone point out to me where the RAVE ACT measures were snuck into
>this "Amber Alert" Bill?
>
>Our searches have been futile.
>
>And yes, I see that S. 151 has passed, but I'll be damned if I can see
>anything in the bill pertaining to what we're so hell bent on fighting
>for.
>
>Maybe I'm just blind.
>
>Can someone help me out here?

It is not listed under RAVE ACT.  The tactic that is being used is to add 
it to a popular bill, Amber Alert.

Go to Thomas ( thomas.loc.gov )

Scroll down to 4/9/2003 at 11:28 A.M. (The conference reports the Bill)

Click on Text of Conference Report (CR H2950-2968)

Page H2961

Title:  SEC. 608. ILLICIT DRUG ANTI-PROLIFERATION ACT.

Text:

(a) SHORT TITLE.--This section may be cited as the ``Illicit Drug 
Anti-Proliferation Act of 2003''.

     (b) OFFENSES.--

     (1) IN GENERAL.--Section 416(a) of the Controlled Substances Act (21 
U.S.C. 856(a)) is amended--

     (A) in paragraph (1), by striking ``open or maintain any place'' and 
inserting ``open, lease, rent, use, or maintain any place, whether 
permanently or temporarily,''; and

     (B) by striking paragraph (2) and inserting the following:

     ``(2) manage or control any place, whether permanently or temporarily, 
either as an owner, lessee, agent, employee, occupant, or mortgagee, and 
knowingly and intentionally rent, lease, profit from, or make available for 
use, with or without compensation, the place for the purpose of unlawfully 
manufacturing, storing, distributing, or using a controlled substance.''.

     (2) TECHNICAL AMENDMENT.--The heading to section 416 of the Controlled 
Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 856) is amended to read as follows:

    ``SEC. 416. MAINTAINING DRUG-INVOLVED PREMISES.''.

     (3) CONFORMING AMENDMENT.--The table of contents to title II of the 
Comprehensive Drug Abuse and Prevention Act of 1970 is amended by striking 
the item relating to section 416 and inserting the following:


    ``Sec..416..Maintaining drug-involved premises.''.


     (c) CIVIL PENALTY AND EQUITABLE RELIEF FOR MAINTAINING DRUG-INVOLVED 
PREMISES.--Section 416 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 856) is 
amended by adding at the end the following:

     ``(d)(1) Any person who violates subsection (a) shall be subject to a 
civil penalty of not more than the greater of--

     ``(A) $250,000; or

     ``(B) 2 times the gross receipts, either known or estimated, that were 
derived from each violation that is attributable to the person.

     ``(2) If a civil penalty is calculated under paragraph (1)(B), and 
there is more than 1 defendant, the court may apportion the penalty between 
multiple violators, but each violator shall be jointly and severally liable 
for the civil penalty under this subsection.

     ``(e) Any person who violates subsection (a) shall be subject to 
declaratory and injunctive remedies as set forth in section 403(f).''.

     (d) DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE REMEDIES.--Section 403(f)(1) of the 
Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 843(f)(1)) is amended by striking 
``this section or section 402'' and inserting ``this section, section 402, 
or 416''.

     (e) SENTENCING COMMISSION GUIDELINES.--The United States Sentencing 
Commission shall--

     (1) review the Federal sentencing guidelines with respect to offenses 
involving gamma hydroxybutyric acid (GHB);

     (2) consider amending the Federal sentencing guidelines to provide for 
increased penalties such that those penalties reflect the seriousness of 
offenses involving GHB and the need to deter them; and

     (3) take any other action the Commission considers necessary to carry 
out this section.

     (f) AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR A DEMAND REDUCTION 
COORDINATOR.--There is authorized to be appropriated $5,900,000 to the Drug 
Enforcement Administration of the Department of Justice for the hiring of a 
special agent in each State to serve as a Demand Reduction Coordinator.

     (g) AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR DRUG EDUCATION.--There is 
authorized to be appropriated such sums as necessary to the Drug 
Enforcement Administration of the Department of Justice to educate youth, 
parents, and other interested adults about club drugs.

Subject: [sfraves] Which Rave Act are you Interested IN? (INFO)

Here are some more articles re: The Amber Alert/Rave Act combo:

1.
http://www.lindesmith.org/news/pressroom/pressrelease/04_07_03biden.cfm

http://www.emdef.org/bills_us/2002/s2633_rave_act_2002.html


2. Which "RAVE Act" you are interested in?

A)
RAVE Act of 2003  (H.R. 718)
U.S. House

http://www.emdef.org/hr718

RAVE Act of 2003  (H.R. 718)
U.S. House of Representatives


The "RAVE Act of 2002" (H.R. 5519) has been re-introduced in the U.S.
House as the "RAVE Act of 2003" (H.R. 718).

The "RAVE Act" expands the scope of applicability of Section 416(a) of the
Controlled Substance Act, often refferred to as the "crack house statute"
(21 U.S.C. 856).  This bill would make it easier for the federal
government to prosecute owners and managers of businesses and/or real
estate if customers, employees, tenants, or other persons on their
property commit a drug-related offense.  Persons convicted under this new
law could be sentenced to up to 20 years in prison, fined $500,000 and
have their business or property confiscated.

This legislation also adds a civil liability clause to the "crack house
statute".

Sponsor:   	Rep. Howard Coble  [NC-6] 	Introduced:   	Febuary
12, 2003
Co-Sponsor:   	Rep. Lamar Smith  [TX-21]

CRS Summary

Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to Ecstasy Act of 2003 or RAVE Act -
Amends the Controlled Substances Act to prohibit knowingly leasing,
renting, or using, or intentionally profiting from, any place (as well as
opening, maintaining, leasing, or renting any place, as provided under
current law), whether permanently or temporarily, for the purpose of
manufacturing, storing, distributing, or using a controlled substance.
Subjects violators to: (1) a civil penalty of the greater of $250,000 or
twice the gross receipts derived from each violation; and (2) declaratory
and injunctive remedies.

Authorizes the court to apportion the penalty between multiple violators,
but makes each violator jointly and severally liable.

Directs the U.S. Sentencing Commission to review and consider amending the
Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses involving gamma hydroxybutyric
acid to provide for increased penalties.

Authorizes appropriations to the Drug Enforcement Administration for: (1)
a Demand Reduction Coordinator in each State; and (2) educating youth,
parents, and other interested adults regarding drugs associated with
raves.

[ from the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress
]


B) RAVE Act Renamed
Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act of 2003  (S. 226)
U.S. Senate

http://www.emdef.org/s226

Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act  (S. 226)
The RAVE Act Renamed - U.S. Senate


The "Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act of 2003" (S. 226) is essentially
the "RAVE Act of 2002" (S. 2633) with the word "rave" removed.

S. 226 expands the scope of applicability of Section 416(a) of the
Controlled Substance Act, often referred to as the "crack house statute"
(21 U.S.C. 856).  This bill would make it easier for prosecutors to
charge, convict, and imprison business owners, property owners, and
managers who fail to prevent drug-related offenses committed by customers,
employees, tenants, or other persons on their property .

This legislation also adds a civil liability clause to the "crack house
statute".

(SEE URL ABOVE FOR COMMENTS FROM SENATOR BIDEN)


C)
 RAVE Act of 2002
(S. 2633) U.S. Senate

http://www.emdef.org/s2633

The RAVE Act - S.2633
Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to Ecstasy Act of 2002

THE 107TH CONGRESS FAILED TO PASS THE RAVE ACT BEFORE
THEY ADJOURNED IN 2002, THEREFORE THE BILL IS DEAD

Subject: [sfraves] RR: Amber Alert - Rave Act Reincarnated (INFO)

http://maine.indymedia.org/front.php3?article_id=5245&group=webcast

Contact your Reps - Amber Alert Legislation Contains Dangerous Riders
by h 12:30pm Tue Apr 8 '03

        In the final days before a long Congressional recess, members of
the House and Senate are seeking to override normal legislative processes
by dumping two pieces of dangerous, anti-civil liberties legislation into
an unrelated but more popular bill. One of the two provisions would target
raves -- a social event that mixes electronic music, light shows and
dancing; the other provision would seek to limit the discretion of federal
judges.

April 7, 2003


In the final days before a long Congressional recess, members of the House
and Senate are seeking to override normal legislative processes by dumping
two pieces of dangerous, anti-civil liberties legislation into unrelated
but more popular bill "Amber Alert" bill, designed to help find missing
children. One of the two provisions would target raves -- a social event
that mixes electronic music, light shows and dancing; the other provision
would seek to limit the discretion of federal judges.

In fact, both provisions seek to intimidate through legislative fiat. The
measure that targets raves would allow prosecutors to argue that common
rave items like glow sticks and massage oils are drug paraphernalia and
would impose huge fines and even prison time on owners of venues into
which customers bring controlled substances. No matter how much security
is put in place, owners could be held responsible for the actions of just
one customer and would therefore be much less likely to allow raves to
take place in their clubs or concert halls.

The other dangerous provision would require the Justice Department to
report to Congress every time federal judges uses their discretion to
impose a lower sentence than recommended under federal sentencing
guidelines. This measure represents the latest effort by some in Congress
to politicize the criminal justice system by removing the already limited
ability that judges have to take into account unusual circumstances that
could argue for leniency against some people convicted of federal
offenses.

Take Action! Urge Congress to reject the popular Amber Alert legislation
unless the unrelated anti-rave and judicial discretions measures are
removed.

Urge Your Members of Congress to Oppose Bills Designed to Intimidate

The anti-rave act threatens free speech.
If it becomes law, property owners may be too afraid to rent or lease
their space for events rightly or wrongly perceived as attracting drug
users -- essentially any event that attracts a young crowd. Out of fear of
massive fines and prison sentences, law-abiding business owners may stop
hosting raves and other musical events, driving them further underground
and away from public health and safety regulations.

The bill threatens to remove checks and balances on our law enforcement
system.
Under current law, federal judges are permitted to serve as a check on law
enforcement by taking into account special circumstances and granting
people convicted of certain federal crimes lower sentences. Requiring the
Justice Department to report to Congress virtually every time a judge does
so is a calculated attempt to intimidate federal judges and make them much
less willing to use common sense in sentencing.

Congress should debate these dangerous and unrelated measures.
Some in Congress are seeking to amend the anti-rave legislation and the
limits on judicial discretion onto a popular Amber Alert measure that
would expand the system for notifying the public about kidnapped or
missing children. Congress should remove these unrelated anti-civil
liberties provisions from the Amber Alert measure and allow them to
proceed through a normal legislative process of full hearings and debate.

TAKE ACTION!
Contact your reps!

Representative Thomas H. Allen (D - 01)
202-225-6116
202-225-5590
rep.tomallen@mail.house.gov

Representative Mike Michaud (D - 02)
202-225-6306
202-225-2943
http://www.house.gov/writerep/

www.aclu.org/DrugPolicy/DrugPolicy.cfm?I...

Subject: [sfraves] RR: DPA's Perspective on the Amber Alert Network Act of 2002 (S151)

http://www.drugpolicy.org/drugbydrug/rave/

" ...

Anti-Rave Bills

Background
Introduced into the Senate and House in 2002 the RAVE Act proposed to
expand the federal "crack house statute" making it easier for the federal
government to fine or imprison businesspeople for failing to prevent
customers or tenants from selling or using drugs on their premises or at
their events. Essentially, business owners were expected to become
law-enforcement officers, and those who failed to prevent the presence of
drugs . a job even the DEA and police together cannot successfully achieve
. would be punished. Any business or event could be targeted under such a
law.

Thanks to thousands of our supporters who sent over 35,000 faxes to the
Senate and attended protests around the country, we were able to stop the
proposed federal legislation in 2002. However, supporters of the draconian
drug war bill are back with a vengeance.

It's Back
Most recently, Senator Joe Biden (D-DE) in an attempt to sneak
controversial legislation through the Senate introduced the RAVE Act into
conference committee as an add on to the National AMBER Alert Network Act
of 2003 (S151). S151 is a bill about child abduction that has nothing to
do with drug policy issues. The RAVE Act, in contrast, has not passed a
single committee this year. In addition, it was so controversial when it
was introduced last year that two Senators withdrew their sponsorship. The
RAVE Act is a bill that would make it easier for the federal government to
punish business owners for the drug offenses of their customers - even if
they take steps to stop such activity.

S151 has passed the Senate and House and is now in Conference. If the
Democrats are successful in their efforts to attach the RAVE Act onto an
unrelated bill, it is likely to become law without ever having a public
hearing, debate or a vote. Opponents of the RAVE Act argue that it would
put innocent business owners at risk of criminal prosecution, threaten
free speech, be detrimental to public health, and could be used by
overzealous prosecutors to target racial minorities or politically
unpopular groups..."


Please read source cited above for full text of article.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, April 10, 2003 10:57 PM
Subject: [sfraves] RR: Amber Alert - Rave Act Reincarnated (INFO)


> http://maine.indymedia.org/front.php3?article_id=5245&group=webcast
>
> Contact your Reps - Amber Alert Legislation Contains Dangerous Riders
> by h 12:30pm Tue Apr 8 '03
>
>         In the final days before a long Congressional recess, members of
> the House and Senate are seeking to override normal legislative processes
> by dumping two pieces of dangerous, anti-civil liberties legislation into
> an unrelated but more popular bill. One of the two provisions would target
> raves -- a social event that mixes electronic music, light shows and
> dancing; the other provision would seek to limit the discretion of federal
> judges.
>
> April 7, 2003
>
>
> In the final days before a long Congressional recess, members of the House
> and Senate are seeking to override normal legislative processes by dumping
> two pieces of dangerous, anti-civil liberties legislation into unrelated
> but more popular bill "Amber Alert" bill, designed to help find missing
> children. One of the two provisions would target raves -- a social event
> that mixes electronic music, light shows and dancing; the other provision
> would seek to limit the discretion of federal judges.
>
> In fact, both provisions seek to intimidate through legislative fiat. The
> measure that targets raves would allow prosecutors to argue that common
> rave items like glow sticks and massage oils are drug paraphernalia and
> would impose huge fines and even prison time on owners of venues into
> which customers bring controlled substances. No matter how much security
> is put in place, owners could be held responsible for the actions of just
> one customer and would therefore be much less likely to allow raves to
> take place in their clubs or concert halls.
>
> The other dangerous provision would require the Justice Department to
> report to Congress every time federal judges uses their discretion to
> impose a lower sentence than recommended under federal sentencing
> guidelines. This measure represents the latest effort by some in Congress
> to politicize the criminal justice system by removing the already limited
> ability that judges have to take into account unusual circumstances that
> could argue for leniency against some people convicted of federal
> offenses.
>
> Take Action! Urge Congress to reject the popular Amber Alert legislation
> unless the unrelated anti-rave and judicial discretions measures are
> removed.
>
> Urge Your Members of Congress to Oppose Bills Designed to Intimidate
>
> The anti-rave act threatens free speech.
> If it becomes law, property owners may be too afraid to rent or lease
> their space for events rightly or wrongly perceived as attracting drug
> users -- essentially any event that attracts a young crowd. Out of fear of
> massive fines and prison sentences, law-abiding business owners may stop
> hosting raves and other musical events, driving them further underground
> and away from public health and safety regulations.
>
> The bill threatens to remove checks and balances on our law enforcement
> system.
> Under current law, federal judges are permitted to serve as a check on law
> enforcement by taking into account special circumstances and granting
> people convicted of certain federal crimes lower sentences. Requiring the
> Justice Department to report to Congress virtually every time a judge does
> so is a calculated attempt to intimidate federal judges and make them much
> less willing to use common sense in sentencing.
>
> Congress should debate these dangerous and unrelated measures.
> Some in Congress are seeking to amend the anti-rave legislation and the
> limits on judicial discretion onto a popular Amber Alert measure that
> would expand the system for notifying the public about kidnapped or
> missing children. Congress should remove these unrelated anti-civil
> liberties provisions from the Amber Alert measure and allow them to
> proceed through a normal legislative process of full hearings and debate.
>
> TAKE ACTION!
> Contact your reps!
>
> Representative Thomas H. Allen (D - 01)
> 202-225-6116
> 202-225-5590
> rep.tomallen@mail.house.gov
>
> Representative Mike Michaud (D - 02)
> 202-225-6306
> 202-225-2943
> http://www.house.gov/writerep/
>
> www.aclu.org/DrugPolicy/DrugPolicy.cfm?I...
>
> --
> **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
> **************************************************************

Why don't we actually INVITE our senators to a party?  I mean, let them see for themselves that it isn't a bunch of kids getting all fucked up and passing out; let them see that the majority is a bunch of kids (And adults) that are out having fun dancing their hearts out?  I know the chances of them agreeing to come out to one is slim to none, but has anyone ever thought about trying to get them to attend one?  I haven't been to a party in CA as of yet; but I know from the ones in NYC and everywhere within driving distance I could get to, not everyone was fucked up on drugs....we need to show them that we are all just out having a good time and if a few people decide they need to do drugs to have a good time, it's not at the fault of the party hosts or the DJ's.  I know you all agree with that so what would it take do you think to get them out to a party?    

Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:http://www.drugpolicy.org/drugbydrug/rave/

" ...

Anti-Rave Bills

Background
Introduced into the Senate and House in 2002 the RAVE Act proposed to
expand the federal "crack house statute" making it easier for the federal
government to fine or imprison businesspeople for failing to prevent
customers or tenants from selling or using drugs on their premises or at
their events. Essentially, business owners were expected to become
law-enforcement officers, and those who failed to prevent the presence of
drugs . a job even the DEA and police together cannot successfully achieve
. would be punished. Any business or event could be targeted under such a
law.

Thanks to thousands of our supporters who sent over 35,000 faxes to the
Senate and attended protests around the country, we were able to stop the
proposed federal legislation in 2002. However, supporters of the draconian
drug war bill are back with a vengeance.

It's Back
Most recently, Senator Joe Biden (D-DE) in an attempt to sneak
controversial legislation through the Senate introduced the RAVE Act into
conference committee as an add on to the National AMBER Alert Network Act
of 2003 (S151). S151 is a bill about child abduction that has nothing to
do with drug policy issues. The RAVE Act, in contrast, has not passed a
single committee this year. In addition, it was so controversial when it
was introduced last year that two Senators withdrew their sponsorship. The
RAVE Act is a bill that would make it easier for the federal government to
punish business owners for the drug offenses of their customers - even if
they take steps to stop such activity.

S151 has passed the Senate and House and is now in Conference. If the
Democrats are successful in their efforts to attach the RAVE Act onto an
unrelated bill, it is likely to become law without ever having a public
hearing, debate or a vote. Opponents of the RAVE Act argue that it would
put innocent business owners at risk of criminal prosecution, threaten
free speech, be detrimental to public health, and could be used by
overzealous prosecutors to target racial minorities or politically
unpopular groups..."


Please read source cited above for full text of article.
--

& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Subject: [sfraves] RAVE Act, Measure to Limit Judicial Sentencing Discretion Pass
  House and Senate

--=====================_1139595==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Save the Children, Screw the Rest of Us: RAVE Act, Measure to Limit 
Judicial Sentencing Discretion Pass House and Senate

Sen. Joe Biden (D-DE) and Rep. Tom Feeney (R-FL) took advantage of 
Congress' engrained inability to vote against anything that might "save the 
children" to win passage of two measures destined to cause pain and misery 
for untold numbers of adult partygoers, club owners, event organizers and 
criminal defendants. Biden, an inveterate drug warrior who authored the 
notorious "crack house" legislation of 1984, hitched his widely criticized 
RAVE Act (S226, now known officially as the "Illicit Drug 
Anti-Proliferation Act," Biden having dropped the inflammatory moniker 
after running into unexpected opposition last year) to the popular Amber 
Alert bill (S151/HR1104), which sets up a national system of alerts for 
kidnapped kids and increases child pornography penalties, while Feeney used 
the bill to pass a measure to limit the ability of federal judges to grant 
downward departures in sentences -- a measure not limited to sex crimes 
against children and much more likely to be used to prevent federal judges 
from lightening sentences for drug offenders.

The Amber Alert bill passed both chambers this week, with the House 
approving 400-25 and the Senate approving with a unanimous 98-0 vote 
Thursday evening.

Under Biden's RAVE Act, anyone who organizes an event or owns a venue where 
someone uses an illegal drug can be held liable for that drug use. Although 
expressly crafted and advanced as an attack on the rave culture, the bill's 
implications are frighteningly broad. It could be used against promoters of 
hemp fests, rock concert promoters or even -- in theory -- against 
professional sports franchises if fans are smoking joints in the stands.

Biden first advanced the bill last year, but pressure from a coalition of 
drug reform, civil liberties, electronic music and business groups led by 
the Drug Policy Alliance (http://www.drugpolicy.org) and its subsidiary, 
the Electronic Museum Defense and Education Fund (http://www.emdef.org), 
peeled off initial supporters and stopped the legislation in its tracks. 
But in a move demonstrating his mastery of legislative legerdemain, Biden 
attached his pet project to the Amber Alert bill last week.

In a bit of understatement, DPA national affairs director William McColl 
told DRCNet "it is unusual for a bill to appear with zero votes in 
committee and zero floor votes." But pushed on the Senate floor today by 
Sens. Orrin Hatch (R-UT) and Charles Grassley (R-IA), Biden's RAVE Act did 
just that. "This was real back door legislative sausage making," said McColl.

"This is not a good situation," said McColl. "This opens up clubs and 
one-day events to increased scrutiny, civil fines, and even arrest for club 
owners or event organizers. How this plays out will rely to a great extent 
on prosecutorial discretion. The language of the bill applies to owners who 
'knowingly' open a business for the 'purpose' of drug use, but a pair of 
federal circuit courts have ruled that the 'knowingly' applies to owners 
even when it is not the owner's but the customer's 'purpose' to use drugs."

Still, said McColl, the bill is a slight improvement over last year's 
version, and the coalition against the RAVE Act is prepared to continue to 
fight to undo it. "While this is obviously disappointing, the coalition's 
efforts did change the bill for the better. The overt discrimination 
against electronic music by using the word 'rave' has been removed, as have 
findings that suggested that harm reduction measures, such as the presence 
of glow-sticks or the sales of water, were evidence of an owner's 
ill-intent." Still, said McColl, that wasn't enough. "This is just the 
beginning. We will be back and people will come out of the woodwork to help 
us now."

But the RAVE Act wasn't the only stinker hidden in the Amber Alert bill. 
Rep. Feeney's amendment further restricts federal judges' ability to grant 
downward departures from mandatory minimum sentences or the federal 
sentencing guidelines and includes provisions that require the Justice 
Department to report to Congress almost every time a judge does so. The New 
York Times in a Monday editorial branded the amendment "a brazen attempt to 
intimidate judges" and called on Senate Judiciary Committee chairman Orrin 
Hatch, "who certainly knows better than to unduly limit judicial sentencing 
authority," to kill the language. Hatch and the Congress disagreed, fending 
off efforts to defeat the amendment and passing it as part of the effort 
"to stop those who prey on children before they can harm children," as 
House Judiciary Committee chairman James Sensenbrenner (R-WI) put it.

Still, the news could have been much worse. A bulletin distributed online 
by Families Against Mandatory Minimums this morning (4/11) reported that 
the amendment was weakened somewhat from its original form, in that the 
specific limitations on departure authority are more limited, though it 
will still have a chilling effect on judicial discretion. (Visit 
http://www.famm.org/si_federal_sentencing_feeney_update.htm for further 
information on the Feeney amendment and to subscribe to FAMM action alerts.)

In the Alice in Wonderland world of the US Congress, a bill to protect 
children has become a bill that threatens the rights of all and the freedom 
of those unfortunate enough to get in the path of its extraneous drug war 
provisions.



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Anyone going to the Pagan Parade?

I think you are a bit confused. You are talking like "paganism" is 
just ONE religion, which it is not. The word pagan is primarily a 
word coming from a mono-theist-centric point of view to describe the 
MANY religions of those who follow polytheistic and other non-"one 
god" based religions.

The ancient greeks were pagans. Celtic druids are pagans. There are 
pagans in Africa. Pagans in Australia. Most if not all Native 
American religions are pagan relgions. Pagans are everywhere but many 
of them have quite different beliefs. The only thing that they really 
have in common at all is that they don't believe in the modern one 
god religions.

Look here for a start: http://dspace.dial.pipex.com/robotics1/pagan.htm

or google "what is paganism"

BS

some comments on the article and media spin in general :

first, mr. jolly's comment that "So-called designer drugs are becoming all too prevalent in certain
types of rave nightclubs or rave events." i'd like to retort that "the media and general public's
use of the term RAVE to refer to any event that involves music and dancing is becoming all too
prevalent ."

"rave nightclub" ?  what is that ?  and rave events ? i wasn't aware of any raves being thrown where
the ABC was under regulation. but then, perhaps i'm an ignorant dork.

and i luv how they just throw in a completely random paragraph that states two men recently died
from ecstasy use at the cow palace in order to hype the article.  it's like saying "these undercover
officers were able to buy hand guns at a convenient store located not far from this high school.
recently, two high school students in Columbine opened fire on the students in their school with
guns." =  media spin.

and wasn't E use at clubs at it's high (pun always intended) around 98-2000 ?  it's still there, but
comparably it seems magnitudes less.  i remember puddles of people around the back side of that
island bar area they had at 1015 everytime i went back then.

i swear i get more matter-of-fact reporting with less media spin fluff from my local town paper.

damn, why am i in such a pissy mood today x)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


It's all downhill from here...
 Drug Policy Alliance <alerts@actioncenter.drugpolicy.org> wrote:Date: Fri, 11 Apr 2003 12:53:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: Drug Policy Alliance 
To: cosmicdancer777@yahoo.com
Subject: RAVE Act Passes - Tell Ashcroft Not to Abuse It 

Dear Members, Subscribers and Friends, 

I do not normally use our alert channel to send a personal message. 
However, I wanted to let you know that the Illicit Drug Anti-
Proliferation Act (also called the "RAVE Act"), which was attached to 
the AMBER Alert bill, passed both the House and Senate late yesterday 
(April 10). 

The RAVE Act threatens free speech and musical expression while 
placing at risk any hotel/motel owner, concert promoter, event 
organizer, nightclub owner or arena/stadium owner for the drug 
violations of 3rd parties - real or alleged - even if the event 
promoter and/or property owner made a good-faith effort to keep their 
event drug-free. It applies not just to electronic-music parties, 
but to any type of public gathering, including theatrical 
productions, rock concerts, DJ nights at local bars, and potentially 
even political rallies. It gives heightened powers and discretion to 
prosecutors, who may use it to target events they personally don't 
like - such as Hip-Hop events and gay and lesbian fundraisers. 

Sadly, the RAVE Act was added to the AMBER Alert bill conference 
report at the very last minute by Senator Biden (D-DE), its original 
sponsor. The AMBER Alert bill creates a system for responding to 
child abduction. It has nothing to do with drug policy. The RAVE 
Act had not passed even a single committee in the House or Senate 
this year. One senator's pet issue made a mockery of the Democratic 
process - becoming law without any public hearing or opportunity for 
input whatsoever.

You should be aware that your letters and faxes clearly had an 
effect. (FYI - you sent Congress 13,000 faxes this week alone!!) 
For example, the word "rave" was removed from the version of the bill 
that passed. Eliminating such blatant discrimination is a victory 
for our continued freedom of speech. Also, the original bill 
suggested that prosecutors should view the sale of water and the 
presence of glowsticks or massage oil as evidence of drug use. These 
ludicrous "findings" were completely removed thanks to you. 

President Bush will sign this child abduction bill, which means the 
RAVE Act will become law as well. We will be working with the 
legislators who opposed this provision - such as Senators Durbin, 
Kennedy and Leahy and Representatives Conyers and Scott - for its 
repeal. In the meantime, however, it is up to all of us to be the 
watchdogs of its enforcement. 

Attorney General John Ashcroft will have to make decisions about its 
enforcement priority among the many public safety issues the 
Department of Justice handles. He must be held responsible when he 
implements this scheme. We want him to know that he is not free to 
shut down our dance clubs, our festivals and our freedoms. We will 
be watching the activities of law enforcement and prosecutors, and we 
will act when our rights are violated. You can help us by faxing 
Attorney General Ashcroft here. 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1581

We thank our many partners in this effort for your hard work: EM:DEF, 
ROAR, Buzzlife Productions, Davey D., electronic dance and music 
organizations throughout the U.S., club owners, hotel organizations, 
beverage and licensing groups, the ACLU and many, many others. But 
most of all, I want to say thank you personally to our members and 
supporters. 

You truly deserve credit for reacting so quickly and so forcefully. 
It has really been amazing. When Bill McColl, our Director of 
National Affairs, told me about this issue last June he said that he 
thought the RAVE Act would pass in about 2 weeks. You proved us 
wrong. It took 10 months, a change in control of the Senate, 
backroom maneuverings and substantial changes to the bill. I'm 
proud of the hard work of our members, friends and our coalition. 
Rest assured we will continue to work together to mobilize opposition 
and advocate to fix this dangerous law. 

Sincerely, 


Ethan Nadelmann
Executive Director
Drug Policy Alliance



++++++++++++++++++++++++You received this message because
cosmicdancer777@yahoo.com is a member of the mailing list originating 
from alerts@actioncenter.drugpolicy.org. 

Please visit 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/managesubscription.asp to 
learn about other lists you can subscribe to, or to unsubscribe from 
individual or all lists. 

For problems, please contact Jeanette Irwin at jirwin@drugpolicy.org .

Please join the Drug Policy Alliance:
http://www.drugpolicy.org/join
--0-299152700-1050091394=:68531--

I don't think Ashcroft is going to listen to us, but here is a message from 
the Drug Policy Alliance.

I guess one could say it isn't over until the fat lady sings....

Love,

Apollo


Dear Members, Subscribers and Friends,


I do not normally use our alert channel to send a personal message.
However, I wanted to let you know that the Illicit Drug Anti-
Proliferation Act (also called the "RAVE Act"), which was attached to
the AMBER Alert bill, passed both the House and Senate late yesterday
(April 10).


The RAVE Act threatens free speech and musical expression while
placing at risk any hotel/motel owner, concert promoter, event
organizer, nightclub owner or arena/stadium owner for the drug
violations of 3rd parties - real or alleged - even if the event
promoter and/or property owner made a good-faith effort to keep their
event drug-free.  It applies not just to electronic-music parties,
but to any type of public gathering, including theatrical
productions, rock concerts, DJ nights at local bars, and potentially
even political rallies. It gives heightened powers and discretion to
prosecutors, who may use it to target events they personally don't
like - such as Hip-Hop events and gay and lesbian fundraisers.


Sadly, the RAVE Act was added to the AMBER Alert bill conference
report at the very last minute by Senator Biden (D-DE), its original
sponsor.  The AMBER Alert bill creates a system for responding to
child abduction.  It has nothing to do with drug policy.  The RAVE
Act had not passed even a single committee in the House or Senate
this year.  One senator's pet issue made a mockery of the Democratic
process - becoming law without any public hearing or opportunity for
input whatsoever.


You should be aware that your letters and faxes clearly had an
effect.  (FYI - you sent Congress 13,000 faxes this week alone!!)
For example, the word "rave" was removed from the version of the bill
that passed.  Eliminating such blatant discrimination is a victory
for our continued freedom of speech.  Also, the original bill
suggested that prosecutors should view the sale of water and the
presence of glowsticks or massage oil as evidence of drug use.  These
ludicrous "findings" were completely removed thanks to you.


President Bush will sign this child abduction bill, which means the
RAVE Act will become law as well.  We will be working with the
legislators who opposed this provision - such as Senators Durbin,
Kennedy and Leahy and Representatives Conyers and Scott - for its
repeal.  In the meantime, however, it is up to all of us to be the
watchdogs of its enforcement.


Attorney General John Ashcroft will have to make decisions about its
enforcement priority among the many public safety issues the
Department of Justice handles.  He must be held responsible when he
implements this scheme.  We want him to know that he is not free to
shut down our dance clubs, our festivals and our freedoms.  We will
be watching the activities of law enforcement and prosecutors, and we
will act when our rights are violated.  You can help us by faxing
Attorney General Ashcroft here.
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1581


We thank our many partners in this effort for your hard work: EM:DEF,
ROAR, Buzzlife Productions, Davey D., electronic dance and music
organizations throughout the U.S., club owners, hotel organizations,
beverage and licensing groups, the ACLU and many, many others.  But
most of all, I want to say thank you personally to our members and
supporters.


You truly deserve credit for reacting so quickly and so forcefully.
It has really been amazing.  When Bill McColl, our Director of
National Affairs, told me about this issue last June he said that he
thought the RAVE Act would pass in about 2 weeks.  You proved us
wrong.  It took 10 months, a change in control of the Senate,
backroom maneuverings and substantial changes to the bill.   I'm
proud of the hard work of our members, friends and our coalition.
Rest assured we will continue to work together to mobilize opposition
and advocate to fix this dangerous law.


Sincerely,



Ethan Nadelmann
Executive Director
Drug Policy Alliance




Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

I don't understand why everyone's so upset about this. It comes as no
surprise to many of us that club employees have been running drugs for a
long time now, stip-searching patrons at the door to prevent them from
competing with their lucrative dealing business.

1015 got their just desserts, people. Legitimate clubs need not be
worried about getting shut down for the same reasons -- unless, of
course, local officials start enforcing the new crack house statute...
The wording about bottled water and light sticks in the originally
quoted article is absolutely rediculous -- thankfully, all that language
was removed from the recently passed legislation.

We have just experienced a shock and awe attack, and this just is the 
beginning.  Our communities nationwide must organize and fight against 
these club shutdowns and Draconian anti-dance laws.

I'm not sure what the SFLNC's reaction to all this is -- specifically the 
closure of 1015 and possibly other clubs.  But this action is a federal and 
state operation and, other than refuse local police cooperation in these 
activities, there is not much the City can do.

Also, it is time to begin writing to your local CA state reps about closures.

Love,

Apollo

>FOOTLOOSE!    ;)
>
>(sorry, couldn't help myself)

Yes...well:)  Seriously, the rave and dance community has been 
characterized by an apolitically induced apathy until very recently.  No, 
it is not "all downhill from here" if we organize and fight back.

Begin by writing your Senators and Representatives in Congress expressing 
disappointment in the passage of this legislation under the cover of the 
Amber Alert Bill.  This is antithetical to the democratic process.

Write your state representatives indicating displeasure at the closure of 
clubs, and use the American values system:  bad for business in already 
poor economic times.

Support financially those organizations, like the ACLU, the Drug Policy 
Alliance, EDMDF and others who will carry this battle to the courts.

Then, perhaps we hit the streets.....

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CA ABC contact info & FAQ

The ABC is alleging that numerous staff and promoters at 1015 sold drugs
and knew that drugs were being sold. I guess I'm not cynical/paranoid
enough to believe that the ABC made all of this up, and if true this isn't
just using drug possession by a few patrons as a reason to shut down the
club. There will be appeals and 1015 will get the chance to present their
side of the story. This seems more than simple harrassment by law
enforcement though, what they are alleging is blatant complicity and
conspiracy to break the drug laws by the club itself. What other clubs
have been cited and/or closed by the ABC lately?

Subject: Re: [sfraves]1015 getting shutdown

Who would have thought...
   Actually, I went to 1015 last friday and there was a hint of blood in the 
water.  Outside I was searched and they found a pill in my fifth pocket.  It 
wasn't ecstacy however; it was the ativan that I take for anxiety attacks.  
I talked to the club manager, he looked at the pill and let me go in with 
it.  While I was inside I was randomly searched by what looked like the 
incarnates of Notorious B.I.G. and Big Pun.  I actually showed them my pill 
and they almost shit their pantaloonies.  They called the manager over and 
he again dismissed me with my Pharmacuetical contraband.  It appeared to me 
that if the undercovers, who are supposed to know what E is and they can't 
figure it out, are randomly searching kids with water bottles; that the club 
was having some drug issues even if it wasn't public yet.  I thought that 
they did a pretty good job searching folks outside, so many of ABC's 
allegations about the internal problem may be correct.  Who knows?  Anyway, 
that's my 2.5 Cents. -Trendy

At 02:20 PM 4/11/2003 -0700, Dan Haskovec wrote:
>The ABC is alleging that numerous staff and promoters at 1015 sold drugs
>and knew that drugs were being sold. I guess I'm not cynical/paranoid
>enough to believe that the ABC made all of this up, and if true this isn't
>just using drug possession by a few patrons as a reason to shut down the
>club. There will be appeals and 1015 will get the chance to present their
>side of the story. This seems more than simple harrassment by law
>enforcement though, what they are alleging is blatant complicity and
>conspiracy to break the drug laws by the club itself. What other clubs
>have been cited and/or closed by the ABC lately?

I have not been to 1015 personally since they enacted security measures 
that included emptying pockets, pat downs, removal of shoes, hats and the 
like as a condition of admission. Cameras monitoring activities on the 
dance floor and in the bathrooms were installed. Of course, they couldn't 
do anal probes on the street. I suppose that if dealers want to sell at an 
event they can find ways of taking drugs into a club. How can this be 
prevented? Complete strip search? Scan drivers' licenses for outstanding 
warrants? Have clearly identified DEA agents walking the floor doing random 
searches? Flashing lights into pupils?

As for the club management, I doubt in this environment they would have 
staff selling drugs on the floor, eh? Of course, I don't have evidence of 
this. As to what clubs may be next, again who knows.  I suppose we can all 
view the evidence and react when it is presented at the hearing, and watch 
the papers for the next government action to protect us from ourselves.

But, again, it is up to the dance community to help assure that there is 
fair play here.  Taking the position that government action "seems more 
than simple harassment" makes no good sense either.  IMHO.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

At 02:19 PM 4/11/2003 -0700, Jack Triumph wrote:
>Should we begin a petition of SF Raves member, who can download PDF's to 
>have signed to let the ABC know we do not support these actions?
>
>The best way I can see to do this is to mimic the www.recallgraydavis.com 
>website - calm down everyone, I am not trying to hate, just provide 
>examples...if we could post the petition and make it universally 
>avaialble, then I am sure getting sigs wouldn't be a prob. I am sure every 
>business owner who serves liquor and operates and night would sign it...

>It sure beats throwing bolts at cops; sorry had to get a little 
>conservative propaganda in there ;) - this might turn out to be a good 
>friday after all.

That sounds like a good idea, Jack.  As you may know, I favor traditional 
action before resorting to more aggressive tactics.  It's important to 
create some dialogue with both the ABC and our state representatives.  Use 
all the tools available first:  press; letters; faxes; and the law.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CA ABC contact info & FAQ

IIRC, the cameras were never implemented at 1015.... but anyway, here is
what the ABC alleges in the press release:

   "During the investigation, ABC investigators were able to purchase
ecstasy on eleven occasions, six from music promoters allegedly employed
by the club, and five from patron drug dealers which involved the direct
knowledge of club employees.  A total of four bartenders permitted the
violations to occur inside the club as undercover investigators conversed
with the employees regarding their narcotic buys."

It certainly seems that employees and contractors (promoters) of 1015 knew
about the drug sales. That is what is being alleged, anyway. The major
argument against shutting down clubs because of patrons' drug use is that
the club has no way of knowing about or controlling drug use, and that
people do drugs outside of clubs too. Here is a case alleging that the
club did know about the activity. I am just saying that it's good pick
your battles based on the facts of each case. Law enforcement activity is
not always unreasonable.


On Fri, 11 Apr 2003, Apollo wrote:

> I have not been to 1015 personally since they enacted security measures
> that included emptying pockets, pat downs, removal of shoes, hats and the
> like as a condition of admission. Cameras monitoring activities on the
> dance floor and in the bathrooms were installed. Of course, they couldn't
> do anal probes on the street. I suppose that if dealers want to sell at an
> event they can find ways of taking drugs into a club. How can this be
> prevented? Complete strip search? Scan drivers' licenses for outstanding
> warrants? Have clearly identified DEA agents walking the floor doing random
> searches? Flashing lights into pupils?
>
> As for the club management, I doubt in this environment they would have
> staff selling drugs on the floor, eh? Of course, I don't have evidence of
> this. As to what clubs may be next, again who knows.  I suppose we can all
> view the evidence and react when it is presented at the hearing, and watch
> the papers for the next government action to protect us from ourselves.
>
> But, again, it is up to the dance community to help assure that there is
> fair play here.  Taking the position that government action "seems more
> than simple harassment" makes no good sense either.  IMHO.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo

Date: Fri, 11 Apr 2003 15:13:27 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20030411221327.GK2154@pion.local>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 getting shutdown

Folks,

I'd like to make an important distinction between the two seemingly
related rave-related events that have gotten everyone all up in a huff
recently.

1015 is alleged to have been observed /selling drugs directly to
patrons/ (not just by the ABC, mind you, but by other patrons as well).
They've enacted a strict, invasive search policy at the door not to curb
drug use at their club, but specifically to prevent other dealers from
stepping on their turf. People have known about this for *years*. 

The new RAVE Act (now a formal extension to the "Crack House" statute)
will allow promoters, club owners, and party throwers of anything from
massives to 100-person undergrounds to be prosecuted if a single person
is found with drugs on the premises (temporary or permanent) of their
event.

/This/ is what you should be pissed about. Until now, clubs frequented
by drug users have at least been able to avoid being shut down by not
becoming involved with the deals (and better yet, curbing drug dealing
on their premises). Now any club may be shut down regardless of how hard
owners and promoters attempt to stop drugs from entering their venues.
Nobody can stop drugs from getting in, and the cost (both emotional and
financial) of having to practically strip-search people at the door may
be too much for most clubs to handle. I have no doubt that this will
lead to /illegitimate/ closures, and yes, I'm pissed about that too.

The closure of 1015, hower, is most likely legitimate. If they were
genuinely attempting to curb drug use, I'd be in an uproar. But that's
not the case. They've been capitalizing on young club kids by shutting
out dealers to increase drug sales that they profit from. Why any raver
would choose to defend such actions is simply beyond me.

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: RE: [sfraves] 1015 getting shutdown

standard practice of many clubs because if you shut out other dealers
there is less a chance of a club kid buying from an undercover. It is
supply and demand. If the kids want it they will take it. I don't agree
with using in clubs as I find clubs more suitable for drinking and

-----Original Message-----
From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net] 
Sent: Friday, April 11, 2003 3:13 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 getting shutdown

Folks,

I'd like to make an important distinction between the two seemingly
related rave-related events that have gotten everyone all up in a huff
recently.

1015 is alleged to have been observed /selling drugs directly to
patrons/ (not just by the ABC, mind you, but by other patrons as well).
They've enacted a strict, invasive search policy at the door not to curb
drug use at their club, but specifically to prevent other dealers from
stepping on their turf. People have known about this for *years*. 

The new RAVE Act (now a formal extension to the "Crack House" statute)
will allow promoters, club owners, and party throwers of anything from
massives to 100-person undergrounds to be prosecuted if a single person
is found with drugs on the premises (temporary or permanent) of their
event.

/This/ is what you should be pissed about. Until now, clubs frequented
by drug users have at least been able to avoid being shut down by not
becoming involved with the deals (and better yet, curbing drug dealing
on their premises). Now any club may be shut down regardless of how hard
owners and promoters attempt to stop drugs from entering their venues.
Nobody can stop drugs from getting in, and the cost (both emotional and
financial) of having to practically strip-search people at the door may
be too much for most clubs to handle. I have no doubt that this will
lead to /illegitimate/ closures, and yes, I'm pissed about that too.

The closure of 1015, hower, is most likely legitimate. If they were
genuinely attempting to curb drug use, I'd be in an uproar. But that's
not the case. They've been capitalizing on young club kids by shutting
out dealers to increase drug sales that they profit from. Why any raver
would choose to defend such actions is simply beyond me.

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 03:13 PM 4/11/2003 -0700, shawn allen wrote:
>Folks,
>
>I'd like to make an important distinction between the two seemingly
>related rave-related events that have gotten everyone all up in a huff
>recently.
>
>1015 is alleged to have been observed /selling drugs directly to
>patrons/ (not just by the ABC, mind you, but by other patrons as well).
>They've enacted a strict, invasive search policy at the door not to curb
>drug use at their club, but specifically to prevent other dealers from
>stepping on their turf. People have known about this for *years*.

That's the rumor, circulated by drug dealers.  At least, this is the source 
of the information I have received on the matter.  True or not, I must 
honestly say I have no proof of these allegations.  And that's what they 
are.  Must be very careful about making comments like this on a public list.

Further, there are much larger issues here as you know.  Can anyone really 
control private use of illegal drugs?  The lesson we have learned from 
years of the WOD is, no.  The solution to abuse is treatment and 
education.  A much more realistic approach to recreational drug use in 
public settings, like a club, is harm reduction.  Of course, most of us 
have backed off from the latter because it is now dangerous and personally 
inconvenient.

However, one result of the new legislation, and the current pressure on 
club owners and any promoter who throws parties, is to eliminate harm 
reduction efforts.  All efforts at harm reduction would be suicidal for the 
promoter. Having, for example, DanceSafe at your event would be an 
admission that you are throwing a drug-infested party. Club owners...guess 
they start dropping the bodies of those who OD out on the streets, and pack 
those in trouble in a cab and hope for the best. That's what used to happen 
at clubs and sex venues under scrutiny in seventies NYC.

Protect us from ourselves....yes. By putting us in jail; pushing events 
further underground; and placing the consumer in even greater danger.

In over thirty years of partying I have never been to an event where 
someone was not on something.  Same can be said of rock events, concerts 
and, hell, movies.

Why focus on EDM events?  To be fair, perhaps one should close down any 
public event for fear that there may be illegal drugs available at that 
event.  (Knock on wood, don't want to put ideas into the heads of law 
enforcement).  EDM events are the current targets for a number of reasons, 
both rational and irrational.  The rational argument seems to be that 
legislators must protect those under 21 who go to massives and other 
"rave-type" parties.  Of course, this makes no sense when discussing 21+ 
clubs.  There is the irrational, Puritanical, fear of pleasure and dancing 
in the background.  This motive has been pretty consistently applied over 
the years in the USA.  Need one review this?:)

My position is that until real evidence is available I will support any 
community member in trouble.  I have no personal interest in keeping 1015 
open these days, and I rarely go to clubs.  Why?  Don't like being treated 
as a criminal.  Back to the above.  And this treatment will only become 
more invasive.  Why?  Because we allow it.  We all seem to tacitly agree 
that any hired thug or officer of the law can invade our personal space for 
some common need for "security."  From "terrorists."  From...what...ourselves?

Love,

Apollo

    In my mind, the important distinction about the 1015 thing is the
difference between knowing that people are on drugs when they are in your
establishment, versus supplying them with drugs. If in fact 1015 employees
were dealing, then I agree that they should be shut down. Any legitimate
business that engages in illegal activity is asking for a spanking. But
selling water and glowsticks is not even in the same ballpark as selling
ecstasy or ghb.

At 03:12 PM 4/11/2003 -0700, Jack Triumph wrote:
>Doesn't appear that "Traditional" tactics are providing results...how long 
>till it is a good idea to try other things?

That is both a personal and collective decision.  When I was a young 
teenager opposed to the war in Viet Nam I began working in traditional 
politics.  I bought a used suit (big thing for me in those days) and joined 
the Presidential campaign for McCarthy.  Then, I hitched to the Democratic 
convention in Chicago where the police beat the shit out of me, suit and 
all, as I was walking to the convention site.  Wasn't even 
demonstrating.  After that, I was finished with "traditional" politics and 
I became progressively more confrontational.

One problem I see with the EDM community right now is that it not 
unified.  Hip hop, techno, house, goa, HHC -- all dancers, producers and 
artists face the same oppression, yet many of us don't talk to each 
other.  Even worse, we see each other as competitors.

Further, oppression separates the posers from those really passionate about 
music and dance.  Many people who have no strong beliefs about the 
importance of the ancient rite of dance will fall away.  It's important to 
organize those who do have a strong commitment to the community -- and most 
of them are not on this list alone -- and develop collective strategies to 
protect our personal life choices.  One can't just depend on the ACLU and 
the like to protect our civil rights.  We have to do this.

Unity.  A coalition of the willing.  Driven by passion.  A dedicated few 
can move the earth.  We are just beginning, I think.

Love,

Apollo
