Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

Beware of strange happenings at Dillion Beach…for those that want to waste time at work on a Friday afternoon.  

http://www.nuforc.org/webreports/008/S08521.html

 

I love this story – great Cesar’s ghost batman, what’s that floating green light?  If I am at this party, I will definitely be hoping for a repeat occurrence – just don’t tell the ABC.  How I conjure up green alien vessels is completely up to me.

 

Which brings me to the drug law/bust/obsession issue: when is the US going to obtain some sanity when it comes to the drug issue?  Drugs in themselves are not the all-powerful scary domineering evil that so many people seem to think and profess.  Yes they can be abused and even kill people.  But guess what?  Tons/many/a whole lot of law abiding (sans drug laws), sane, hard working, productive, positive, happy, nice, thoughtful, decent, respectful, etc, etc. citizens of this country use illegal drugs.  As much as the politicians would like to make you believe this makes people evil, it does not.  One toke will not turn you into a raving lunatic.  Some people abuse drugs and destroy their health and lives.  Some people do the same thing with alcohol.  Some people do the same thing with just their negative outlook on life.  Some people do the same thing with food.  So why not ban twinkees?

 

I believe wholesale change in our drug policies is what we should really push for.

From sfraves-return-101085-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Apr 11 23:34:01 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101085-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 48310 invoked by uid 1103); 11 Apr 2003 23:34:01 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 48295 invoked by uid 1101); 11 Apr 2003 23:34:01 -0000
Date: Fri, 11 Apr 2003 16:34:01 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20030411163154.X47514-100000@taz3.hyperreal.org>
SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Left perspective on Title VI, Section 608 RAVE Act provisions


Source: http://www.talkleft.com/archives/002907.html#002907

Rave Act and Feeney Amendment Set for Full Congress Vote Thursday

Yesterday, Tuesday, April 8, 2003, a Senate and House Conference
Committee, without a hearing, public notice or a debate in Congress,
attached the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (formerly known as the
RAVE Act) to the Amber Alert Bill (a child abduction bill). As Drug Policy
Alliance comments, "This is .backdoor. policy-making at its worst and in
no way upholds the democratic principles rooted in our legislative
process." Take action in three easy steps here.

Congress will also vote on the Hatch-Sensenbrenner amendment to the Feeney
Amendment to the Amber Alert Child Protection bill. This bill puts in
effect puts sentencings in the hands of prosecutors while tying the hands
of federal judges. Go here to act now.
 Thursday :: April 10, 2003

"...Amber Alert Bill Passes Congress

>From Kyle O'Dowd, Legislative Director of the National Association of
Criminal Defense Lawyers:

    The Amber Alert Bill, with its provisions restricting downward
departures in sentencing passed the House and the Senate today. The House
vote was 400-yea, 25-nay, 2-present, 8-not voting. You can see how
individual House members voted here. For more information on the
sentencing aspects of the bill, go here.

    The Senate vote was 98-0. Senators Kennedy, Leahy and Durbin all
sharply criticized the last-minute add-on in floor speeches -- but, in the
end, not a single Senator was willing to vote against the Child Abduction
Prevention Act.

Here are some of the better comments we've found.

    Virginia Democrat Bobby Scott, a leading critic of the bill, said it
is "loaded down with an array of crime sound bite provisions that make the
AMBER Alert an afterthought." He said "egregious" criminal justice
provisions might be good politics but it was bad policy and bad law.

Chief Justice William Rehnquist weighed in by letter:

    Senate Democratic Leader Tom Daschle of South Dakota quoted a letter
Thursday from Supreme Court chief Justice William Rehnquist saying that
sentencing language could do "serious harm."

Perhaps the best statement came from Congressman and former prosecutor
Bill Delahunt (D-MA), which Kyle O'Dowd forwarded to us. If you have a few
moments, we encourage you to read it--we've reprinted it below:

    .S. House of Representatives

    Statement of the Honorable William D. Delahunt of Massachusetts
    Regarding the Conference Report on S. 151, the PROTECT Act of 2003
    Thursday, April 10, 2003

    Mr. Speaker, I would like to be able to vote for this bill. It
includes provisions that I strongly support?including the "AMBER Alert"
system that would aid in finding missing children. But those children have
been taken hostage by a bill that also includes so-called "sentencing
reforms"?radical, sweeping changes to the federal sentencing system that
were never considered by any committee of either House. Provisions that
would cause an explosion in the number of people behind bars,including
many who simply do not belong there.

    Just three days ago, the Justice Department reported that the number
of people living behind bars in the United States had exceeded two million
for the first time in our history. Two million. And included in that
number is a staggering 12 percent of African-American men aged 20 to 34.

    If this bill is the congressional response to that situation, the
public may well conclude that we have finally taken leave of our senses.

    The rate of incarceration in the U.S. is seven times higher than that
of such advanced nations as Germany, Italy, and Denmark. A primary reason
for this is that a large number of our prisoners are serving long terms
for minor nonviolent offenses. And if this bill becomes law, there will be
a lot more of them.

    Men in prison cannot raise families, cannot hold jobs, cannot pay
taxes, and cannot support the economy. And when they get out, many who
might have
    turned their lives around will have become hardened criminals, ready
to return to the only life they know. Conservatives and liberals alike
have recognized that this situation poses a threat to the future of our
cities, our families, our economic well-being, and the health of our
democracy itself. Growing numbers of prominent conservatives have joined
in calls for an end to mandatory minimum sentences. Yet this bill takes a
giant?and potentially catastrophic--step in the wrong direction.

    When Congress enacted the Sentencing Reform Act of 1984, it created a
system of guidelines for judges to follow. But Congress also recognized
that no system of guidelines can anticipate all of the facts and
circumstances of a given case. And it wisely preserved sufficient
flexibility to allow the judge to depart from the guidelines when
necessary.

    This bill would substantially eliminate that safety valve, barring
judges from making "downward departures" in a large number of
cases?effectively transforming the federal guidelines into a system of
mandatory minimum
    sentences.

    When Chief Justice Rehnquist learned of this proposal, he wrote: "this
legislation, if enacted, would do serious harm to the basic structure of
the sentencing guideline system and would seriously impair the ability of
courts to impose just and responsible sentences." Justice Rehnquist is
certainly no liberal. But even his concerns have been brushed aside.

    Similar opposition was expressed by the Judicial Conference of the
United States, the American Bar Association, the Leadership Conference on
Civil Rights, the Washington Legal Foundation, the Cato Institute and many
other
    groups and individuals. All to no avail.

    It is true that during conference, a number of improvements were made
to the original language. But the final version retains many features of
the original, and barely begins to address the concerns raised by the
Chief Justice.

    The bill prohibits all downward departures in connection with
child-related offenses and sex offenses. In all other cases, it
discourages judges from making downward departures by subjecting them to
burdensome reporting requirements and Justice Department scrutiny if they
do so. And it directs the Sentencing Commission to amend the guidelines to
ensure that downward departures are "substantially reduced."

    Since there has been virtually no debate on these radical proposals,
we must guess at the reasons for them. Apparently, they are based on the
belief that judges have been abusing their departure power by handing down
overly lenient sentences.

    No doubt errors and abuses occur. Judges are human, and some sentences
    will be too lenient while others are too harsh. But the system already
provides a remedy for this: the government can and does appeal downward
departures it considers inappropriate. And it wins approximately 80% of
such appeals.

    The truth is that the vast majority of the downward departures are
sought,
    not by the judge, but by the government itself. Of the nearly 20,000
downward departures granted in 2001, 79 percent were requested by the
prosecution, most in return for the cooperation of the defendant, and the
rest in five Mexican border districts in which the government uses
departures to clear cases more quickly.

    If the sponsors of the bill have concerns about the rate of downward
departures, the Justice Department is where they should be making
inquiries. As a former prosecutor, I can see plenty of reasons to question
the overuse of departures as a law enforcement tool.

    But depriving judges of the ability to exercise discretion cannot be
the answer. A rigid, mechanical system of sentences cannot do justice,
either to the accused or to the society to which the millions we imprison
today will one day return..."

--

& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Beware of strange happenings at Dillion Beach.for those that want to
waste time at work on a Friday afternoon.  

http://www.nuforc.org/webreports/008/S08521.html

 

I love this story - great Cesar's ghost batman, what's that floating
green light?  If I am at this party, I will definitely be hoping for a
repeat occurrence - just don't tell the ABC.  How I conjure up green
alien vessels is completely up to me.

 

Which brings me to the drug law/bust/obsession issue: when is the US
going to obtain some sanity when it comes to the drug issue?  Drugs in
themselves are not the all-powerful scary domineering evil that so many
people seem to think and profess.  Yes they can be abused and even kill
people.  But guess what?  Tons/many/a whole lot of law abiding (sans
drug laws), sane, hard working, productive, positive, happy, nice,
thoughtful, decent, respectful, etc, etc. citizens of this country use
illegal drugs.  As much as the politicians would like to make you
believe this makes people evil, it does not.  One toke will not turn you
into a raving lunatic.  Some people abuse drugs and destroy their health
and lives.  Some people do the same thing with alcohol.  Some people do
the same thing with just their negative outlook on life.  Some people do
the same thing with food.  So why not ban twinkees?

 

I believe wholesale change in our drug policies is what we should really
push for.

Subject: [sfraves] anti-rave legislation reported in the washington post

hello sfravers,

very sad to read about 1015's worries.

i wanted to share with you an article that ran in today's post.  the re=
ason
this got reported in the post was a reporter named david montgomery who=

previously covered a rally in front of the local fox station to protest=
 a
sensational news segment which caused the temporary shutdown of our
legendary buzz party (which sadly is no more after being forced to end =
last
september); last year montgomery also wrote a story about the rave act =
that
ran on the front page of the post.  yesterday, he tipped the post's
national desk congressional pod to the amber bill, noting the rave
amendment (had he not done that, this article probably would not have
appeared, so i am deeply grateful to david montgomery for caring!).

hope you guys will come to dc for the national protest on june 13!  wou=
ld
love to dance with you, if you do!  =3DD

if anyone here would be so kind as to write to david montgomery to than=
k
him for caring enough about us to have put in the good word for us, his=

email address is montgomery@washpost.com - thanks!!!

have a good weekend!

respect,
solidarity,
mary



http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A5176-2003Apr10.html

washingtonpost.com


Congress Approves 'Amber Alert' System
Bill Also Heightens Sex Offense Penalties


By Juliet Eilperin and Helen Dewar
Washington Post Staff Writers
Friday, April 11, 2003; Page A02


The House and Senate overwhelming approved legislation yesterday
establishing a nationwide, federally subsidized alert system to help re=
scue
abducted children and impose tougher penalties on sexual offenders.


The "Amber alert" system, already operating in many states, conveys
information about suspected child abductions via highway signs and radi=
o
and TV notices. The program attracted renewed attention recently after =
the
safe return of abducted Utah teenager Elizabeth Smart.


The House approved the bill 400 to 25; the Senate, 98 to 0. Of the 25 H=
ouse
members who voted nay, the only Republican was Rep. Ron Paul of Texas. =
The
measure awaits the signature of President Bush, who said in a statement=

that the bill "provides us with additional tools to prevent, investigat=
e
and prosecute violent crimes against our children."


Although the legislation had strong support in both parties, some Senat=
e
Democrats accused Republicans of exploiting its popularity to ram throu=
gh
more controversial provisions they said would unduly limit judges'
discretion to impose lighter sentences than those prescribed by federal=

guidelines. "I am extremely disappointed that Republicans are kidnappin=
g
the Amber alert bill in an attempt to achieve partisan and wholly unrel=
ated
goals," Senate Minority Leader Thomas A. Daschle (D-S.D.) said.


Daschle and other Democrats cited a letter from Chief Justice William H=
.
Rehnquist, who as head of the Judicial Conference wrote that the bill
"would do serious harm to the basic structure of the sentencing guideli=
ne
system and would seriously impair the ability of courts to impose just =
and
responsible sentences."


The bill calls for a mandatory life sentence for twice-convicted sexual=

offenders; denies pretrial release for alleged child rapists or child
abductors; and extends the statute of limitations for child abductions =
and
sex crimes to the life of the alleged victim.


House Republicans such as Rep. Tom Feeney (Fla.), who spearheaded the f=
ight
for the sentencing proposals, said they were critical to "deter and pun=
ish"
sex offenders as well as communicate to the public about kidnappings.


But Sen. Edward M. Kennedy (D-Mass.) said several provisions would, in
effect, restrict judges' discretion in sentencing for all federal crime=
s,
not just those involving children and molestation. Among the provisions=
 he
cited was one calling on the U.S. Sentencing Commission to amend its
guidelines to reduce discretion for lighter sentences.


A few House Democrats shared such concerns. Rep. Robert C. "Bobby" Scot=
t
(D-Va.) suggested that the bill assumes that "judges can't be trusted o=
n
who should be sentenced to life and who should be sentenced to less."


In response, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Orrin G. Hatch (R-Utah=
)
said the changes would affect only 2 percent of the federal criminal
caseload, and only crimes that involve children and sex offenses.


"This legislation will toughen the law to make abduction and abuse less=

common in the first place," House Majority Leader Tom DeLay (R-Tex.) sa=
id.


Senate negotiators also included language to expand the federal crack-h=
ouse
law -- which makes it a felony to provide a space for illegal drug use =
--
to include promoters of "rave" parties, club owners and others if they
"knowingly and intentionally" make space available for that purpose.
Several groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, restaurat=
eurs
and hotel owners, have protested the move. The ACLU said it would punis=
h
the innocent, target a particular genre of music and drive raves
underground.


Supporters of the bill said a national alert system would make it easie=
r
for law enforcement officers to capture kidnappers. Rep. Martin Frost
(D-Tex.) noted that since the establishment of the Amber alert system i=
n
north Texas six years ago -- it is named after Amber Hagerman, 9, who w=
as
abducted and murdered in Texas -- 53 children have been safely returned=
 to
their families. "But it doesn't work where it doesn't exist," Frost sai=
d.


The bill would provide $20 million annually to the Center for Missing a=
nd
Exploited Children and expand prosecutors' ability to obtain wiretaps f=
or
monitoring suspected sex crimes, including pornography, kidnapping,
prostitution and sex trafficking.


                    =A9 2003 The Washington Post Company
=

Subject: [sfraves] Supplemental Information on the "Rave Act II"


Amber Alert Bill passes:
http://abcnews.go.com/wire/US/reuters20030410_606.html

 The House vote was 400-yea, 25-nay, 2-present, 8-not voting. You can see
how individual House members voted here:
http://clerkweb.house.gov/cgi-bin/vote.exe?year=2003&rollnumber=127


		YEAS	NAYS	PRES	NV
REPUBLICAN	225	1	 	3
DEMOCRATIC	175	23	2	5
INDEPENDENT	 	1
TOTALS	400	25	2	8


For more information on the
sentencing aspects of the bill, go here.

http://www.nacdl.org/departures
"...
Defeat the Feeney Amendment to S. 151

The House of Representatives passed legislation on March 27 that would,
among other things, radically limit judicial discretion to grant downward
departures from the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. This legislation --
sometimes referred to as the Feeney Amendment -- constitutes an
extraordinary transfer of power to federal prosecutors, dramatic changes
to the laws and procedures that govern sentencing and a drastic
encroachment on the independence of the federal judiciary. It places
virtually all sentencing discretion in the hands of federal prosecutors.
The amendment was attached to child abduction legislation at the last
minute in an effort to avoid a debate of its merits and a discussion of
its flaws. No input from the Sentencing Commission, the bar or federal
judges was sought."
Other articles
http://www.talkleft.com/archives/002872.html#002872

Check out information on the Feeny Amendment,
http://www.talkleft.com/archives/002902.html#002902

Joe Biden's Sneak attack:
http://www.talkleft.com/archives/002894.html#002894
 --

Subject: [sfraves] Where to petition against the Rave Act II

Tired or tried convential means?

Try this:

Online Petition....

http://www.petitiononline.com/s2633rav/petition.html

These provisions are also part of S. 22, a domestic security bill
sponsored by Senator Tom Daschle (D-SD).

*** Fax your two Senators. Tell them to oppose S. 226 the Illicit Drug
Anti-Proliferation Act.
Go to:
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448

Please visit these other website for full info and to find out how to lend
your support

For more detailed information, see

Congress Passes "RAVE Act" Snuck Into "Amber Alert" Legislation
Without public notice, a hearing, or debate in Congress, the "Illicit Drug
Anti-Proliferation Act" S.226 (a.k.a. the "RAVE Act") was passed by both
houses of Congress after being snuck into to the "PROTECT Act" S.151 in a
conference committee.  Read the full text of the "PROTECT Act" (118 page
PDF) or just the "Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation" section (4 page PDF).

  CLEAN-UP Act Re-introduced in House:   H.R. 834
The "CLEAN-UP Act of 2002" (H.R. 3782) has been re-introduced in the U.S.
House as the "CLEAN-UP Act of 2003" (H.R. 834).   details


  RAVE Act Re-introduced in the U.S. House:   H.R. 718
The "RAVE Act of 2002" (H.R. 5519) has been re-introduced in the U.S.
House as the "RAVE Act of 2003" (H.R. 718).   details


  2 RAVE Acts in the Senate:   S. 22  &  S. 226
There are 2 different bills currently pending in the Senate that both
impliment the same provisions contained in the failed RAVE Act of 2002.
The bill that EM:DEF is most concerned about is S. 226 because it has
bipartisan support.
S.22   	A bill to enhance domestic security, and for other purposes.
S.226   	Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act of 2003...

See emdef.org NEWS section for this information.

Regards
Karina

--

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 getting shutdown

Hey Everyone Gianni here, Hey just to let you all know, 1015 is NOT shut 
down. This is from 1015's website, Thought it might be of interest to you, 
Take care. See you tonight at 1015!! Haa!! 


      Gianni  :0)
________________________________________________________________

Some of you may have heard in the news about certain action being brought by 
the The California Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC).

Let us state clearly now:

***TEN15 IS NOT CLOSED***......we are most definately open for business and 
will continue to be so.

It's seen that potentially slanderous press releases like this one are an 
attempt to affect the business of ten15 for the worse, with what has been 
suggested as a weak case against the club.

What we need from you is your upmost support right now. People hear things 
like this press release and the word gets around and before you know it 
something that was rumour is taken as fact. What we need from you is:

a) YOU! On the in the club, on the dancefloor, enjoying what you've enjoyed 
all this time. Without you there is no club, and if this club goes, what's 
next to go? This is about standing up for something, not being trampled on! 
b) SPREAD THE WORD! Tell your friends, tell your friends friends, tell your 
friends friends friends, tell the guy sitting opposite you on the BART, tell 
the girl you've been chasing after who works at the diner down the road, tell 
everyone that the club is OPEN!

So called "news" releases like this are part of an exagerated campaign to try 
to bring the club to its knees. For instance, the ABC cites "Bottled water 
was available to the users of ecstasy who often become dehydrated when taking 
the drug" - This is a requirement of the City which we comply with in order 
to maintain the agreement of our license! Can we have some common sense 
please?!?!

to put it bluntly.......Your Club Needs You! Rally the troops, time to haul 
ass and hit that dancefloor, show them that this club is more than just a 
building, it's about the people!


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] RAVE Act

I emailed a friend of mine who is a lawyer about the legality of the RAVE
Act, and what follows is his response.

>Hi,
> >     You mentioned before that the RAVE Act " will never hold up in court
> > upon a constitutional challenge." Can you give me any more information
> about
> > that? It has been attached to the Amber Alert bill, much to the dismay
of
> > many groups such as the ACLU
> > (http://www.aclu.org/DrugPolicy/DrugPolicy.cfm?ID=12280&c=185) Do you
> still
> > think that the fears of us in the music scene are unfounded?
> >
>Happy  :-)
>
>
> OK! I have not seen the bill's (I guess now Law's) actual language so any
> opinion I have is based solely on the articles you have forwarded to me.
>
> Based on that, I believe this "Law" would not pass constitutional muster
on
> any number of grounds!
>
> If it imposes criminal liability on venue owners - it fails because it
> imposes strict criminl liability (no intent element "mens rea").
>
> Also, it is violative of first amendment free speech and freedom of
assembly
> guarantees.
>
> Last it is invasive of State's Rights to dictate their own "criminal"
laws.
> Although "Drug" enforcement is a Federal responsibility - this "law" is
> narrow enough in my opinion so as to vest exclusive Federal jurisdiction
in
> the matter.
>
> The ACLU should do a fine job combating this law.  It will require a
"test"
> case for enforcement, but I'm sure that will be organized in short order.
>
> Even with and increasingly "conservative" Supreme Court - If our
> Constitution and Stare Decisis are still hold water - I can't believe this
> is good "law."
>
>


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 07:26 PM 4/11/2003 -0700, Happy wrote:
>I emailed a friend of mine who is a lawyer about the legality of the RAVE
>Act, and what follows is his response.

I believe your friend is correct.  The legislation seems to have been 
hurled together without careful thought.  It is a good thing that 
Washington attracts mediocre minds.

The clubs will be the initial targets of the legislation. There will be 
challenges, legal battles and the like. One would not want to be the "test" 
case:) Thank the gods for the ACLU.

But it is really time, I think, that the various elements of the dance 
community come together and organize politically.  These people may often 
be inept, but they are tenacious.  Their goals are clear.  And given the 
current abuse of civil liberties in the name of security, anything is possible.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Anyone going to the Pagan Parade?


Um. Which kind of paganism are you referring to?
Presuming you're using 'pagan' as a catch-all for all european
polytheistic religions, are we talking... romans? greeks? celts? What?

Technically, the term 'pagan' could cover pretty much anything that isn't
judeo-christian. Wasn't 'Pagan' a term dished out by middle ages
christians? Kinda like 'barbarian'?

'Paganism', in the sense of the current pop-pagan movement? I mean, if
that's what you mean -- and I think most of the PPs are into the celtic
pantheon -- it's predated by countless numbers of animist religions, which
predate most pantheon-driven religions. You know, spirit of the typewriter
and what what.

Not flaming or trying to be JT, here -- I'm just curious for a definition
of terms.

The Rational Hatter

Subject: [sfraves] simple steps to go with the flow regarding the rave act

people all say the rave act is scary an will end raves but  i just thought of how the law and promoters can have fun together.  . . . and that is kicking out the e-dealers.

if you had somebody dressed like a candy raver going around asking for e you can give them authority to just escort the dealer to the door and they don't get arrested they take their chances with the cops you don't get fined. and the feds don't bust you.

that way the dealers will think of it as some sort of 'game'. and sell more outside the venue to people they know who are more hardcore users than the frequent OD's at a rave. e becomes less available out in the open, -the govt's happy, the e-dealer gets a stiff warning, raves can co-exist and nobody gets hard feelings.  

also sell more blinky rings and flashing stuff like LEDS instead of glowsticks.
have the paramedics on speed-dial instead of uniformed staff. or have specially trained ravers to deal with patrolling around and taking more charge and getting more responsible with the clientelle. the govt. says promoters aren't being responsible, simple solution- > be responsible.
  
  i propose that there be plainclothed volunteer crews at any event, especially the crew working the event. there should be trained volunteers at the rave as the response crew with the right laminates. they could check for people on 'gib', kick out the sellers, and alert med staff if need be.   we all know we can't stop people from taking e but we can keep people having fun on both sides.
i guess the only question is now is why didn't anybody do this sooner?
if anything the rave act has done it has made things better for raves. may have made them more of a pain in the ass to throw massives but better for raves in general. more sober/sober looking clientelle who like the music more than as an excuse to get fukked up. more intimate venues where you can actually have a party and talk to people. more people interested in having raves for rave's sake. mor emoney on lights quality sound djs that play for free or get paid in other ways besides 900 bucks per engagement.
i see the only drawback is that you can't be a raver in public. `;( i just hope the police realize there is a constitution they learned about in 5th grade (unlike the senators) before they want to search my car. sean ocean

Received: (qmail 33498 invoked from network); 12 Apr 2003 16:55:22 -0000
Message-ID: <20030412165520.9203.qmail@web41810.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sat, 12 Apr 2003 09:55:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr: location/creativity; sf/az

so, a footnote to that thread from a while back. when
i started it, with all its propounding and
noisemaking, i was in new mexico. then i went to
arizona. then i came back, expecting to go to cali,
and now i appear to be temporarily marooned here in nm
owing to factors which don't really have anything to
do with anything as far as this discussion goes.

so - in arizona, i experienced a dramatic surge in
creativity which was much greater than i had
anticipated. it didn't really lead to increased
quality, tho, just increased quantity.

back in nm, i'm still going stronger than i was in san
francisco, but not as strong as i was in arizona.
where, to be honest, things kinda got out of hand. i
posted a lot of tracks when i was there, but i didn't
post everything. i was sposed to do a job search, in
fact, but i spent all my time making music and
enjoying the sunshine. i'm such a lazy bum. anyway!

also, one big difference is that arizona seems to be
more about business while california is more about
parties. like the way you can find superstar djs
playing in sf every night of the week, but frequently
to smaller crowds than they normally command (eg dj
rush and gaetano parisio at tiny asr undergrounds a
few years ago, or, for further examples, just read the
guardian any given day). meanwhile in arizona less
people spin, but more of those people who do spin are
really djs. also there are less club nights, less
parties in general; but derrick may's pr firm has an
office in phoenix - as well as detroit, ny, and la,
but not sf - and people are making tv shows about the
rave scene there. in general it seems like the culture
is less diy and more professional, which is both a
good thing and a bad thing. good because it means the
stuff that does happen is more polished and efficient.
bad because there's something raw and beautiful abt a
good diy party.

anyway, this is all pretty subjective. obviously
different people will react differently to different
places. but, i figure, i spent a lot of time talking
here abt this, so i might as well share some of the
stuff i learned on the trip. i was in az for about a
month or so, and i'll be back later this year. (more
news as events warrant.)

one final thing, phoenix almost has a big-city vibe to
it, which i like, being a chicago kid at heart. (i'd
almost move back there, except i can't take the snow.)
there's only a million and a half ppl in metro
phoenix, i'm not sure if that includes the satellite
cities or not, but it feels big because that's twice
as many folks as live in sf. the biggest culture shock
experience i had when i moved to sf was the huge
number of places that don't stay open 24 hours. before
i moved to san francisco, i had never seen a closed
walgreens. the first time i saw such a thing, i just
stood there on the street looking at it for a good
five minutes, trying to figure it out, wondering if it
would be vanishing if i blinked. anyway, this unique
walgreensological phenomenon does not appear to exist
in arizona, and 24-hr restaurants proliferate there.


giles


ps! of course there's a ps.

cool project idea. raver travel guide.

new-school breaks are big in australia, to the point
of being essentially mainstream. the only other places
i'm aware of where breaks are also big are london and
florida. (dj icey has released over 200 singles.) in
arizona, acid trance is big, and happycore appears to
have a strong following too. sf used to be the place
for hard dark american jungle, chicago used to be the
place for house - you wouldn't believe how amazingly
cool chicago radio was in the late 80s/early 90s,
techno was on late at night and house was on
constantly, you couldn't even walk into a restaurant
without hearing todd terry vs. everything but the girl
"like the deserts miss the rain" etc. prior to the
advent of london pirate radio, chicago radio was the
coolest in the world. anyway what was i talking about?
ah. i think it would be really interesting if somebody
would put together a comprehensive guide to what
styles are big where, publish it on a yearly basis,
and distribute it to booking agencies or something. kz
you gotta figure, it's not really a consumer product.
it'd be trivial to publish, and the agencies would
find it both inexpensive and useful.

blah blah blah...


giles (again)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 11 Apr 2003 21:52:15 -0700
From: ten15 <update@1015.com>
To: "karina@hyperreal.org" <karina@hyperreal.org>
Subject: TEN15 IS OPEN!

TO THE FRIENDS OF 1015 FOLSOM:
 You may have seen a press release, issued by the ABC on
April 11, 2003, under the headline "ABC to Shut Down Well Known S.F.
Nightclub." The headline is false. Here is the reality of the situation.

THE ABC HAS NO ABILITY TO SHUT DOWN 1015 AND NO PRESENT ABILITY TO REVOKE OR
SUSPEND 1015'S LIQUOR LICENSE.

 The ABC has simply filed an accusation in which it alleges
that 1015 engaged in certain actions which, if proven at a hearing before an
administrative law judge, could allow the judge, at most, to revoke or
suspend 1015's liquor license. 1015 believes it will receive a favorable
decision from the administrative law judge, or from the court of appeal
should an appeal become necessary.

THE ABC'S ALLEGATIONS AGAINST 1015 ARE FALSE.

 The ABC first alleges five incidents in which its
investigators were supposedly able to purchase ecstasy from employees of
1015. The five incidents involve only two persons, neither of whom has ever
been an employee or agent of 1015 or of any of the promoters that put on
events at 1015.

 The ABC next alleges six incidents in which 1015 bartenders
supposedly "permitted" ecstasy sales at the club. What did the bartenders
actually do? According to the ABC's own report, an investigator would
approach a bartender and say "Do you know where I can get some ecstasy?" In
every case, the bartender said "No." The investigator would then disappear
into the crowd and seek to purchase a tablet of ecstasy from a customer. If
he succeeded, he would come back to the bartender -- who, the ABC admits,
had not witnessed the purchase -- and say "Well, I was able to get some
ecstasy." Apparently, the ABC is contending that the bartender can be
deemed to have "permitted" the ecstasy purchase because he did not have the
ABC investigator arrested in response to the investigator's statements.
That is simply not the law.

SAFETY PROCEDURES EMPLOYED AT 1015 ARE MANDATED BY COURT ORDER AND CANNOT BE
DEEMED EVIDENCE THAT 1015 ENCOURAGES OR ACCEPTS DRUG USE AT THE CLUB.

 Finally, the ABC suggests that certain safety procedures
employed by 1015 -- EMT's on site, free water, a cool-down room -- are
"evidence" that 1015 encourages or accepts drug use at the club. The ABC
ignores the fact that all of those procedures are mandated by court order,
in accordance with a stipulated injunction entered into by 1015 and the City
and County of San Francisco three years ago. The City and County of San
Francisco insisted on those procedures, and 1015 agreed to them, because
they understood -- as the ABC apparently does not -- that even the most
rigorous procedures to keep drugs out of a club cannot totally eliminate the
possibility that some patrons may experience medical problems, whether
related to drug use or to the mere fact of dancing for hours in a crowded
room. It is sadly ironic that the very steps taken by 1015 to protect its
patrons and to comply with the law are now being cited by the ABC as
"evidence" that 1015 -- the only club in San Francisco that carries out
rigorous patron searches and that arrests anyone found with drugs -- is
somehow encouraging or accepting drug use at the club.

1015 WILL FIGHT THESE SPECIOUS CHARGES AND ASKS FOR YOUR CONTINUING
PATRONAGE AND SUPPORT.

 1015 will do everything it can, at the administrative level
and, if necessary, at the judicial level, to show that the ABC's charges are
completely specious and that no discipline should be imposed against 1015's
liquor license. We ask that you continue to support 1015 by coming to the
club to dance -- we will be open, at the usual times, for the indefinite
future -- and by letting people know that you oppose the ABC's efforts to
drive 1015 out of business.

Thank you.



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] deedrah this saturday night at (((THUMP)))!!!


the wonderful, wacky, wicked and terribly trance talented deedrah is on his
way so SF for (((thump))) this saturday night - be prepared for new music
from the french trancer behind deedrah, synthetic, dado, cypher, transwave,
dandado, fredrico baltimore, chicago and many other magical musical
monikers.  from his email,

"The new album of deedrah is finished - my new album is so dance floor
oriented it s going to be a killer event."

he's also DJing so it will be another ripper - his last live/dj set for
thump at the barn well over a year ago was one of the best shows we've ever
had!  of all the "live" acts we have the good fortune to hear here, fred
really does a nice job injecting some of his live energy into the set thru
more equipment use and sonic manipulation.

also large house beats from kinetic grooves upstairs.  :)

presales are available on the site - http://www.thumpradio.com

his last show on our site is available for listening to too -
http://www.thumpradio.com/index.cfm?showid=204

and fred was our first live interview ever for thump radio back in 1999.
you can hear that interview @ http://www.thumpradio.com/dadointerview.cfm

we have another AMAZING interview with him from 10/2001 that we'll be
putting on the site soon after the site relaunch in the next 2 weeks...the
second interview is nearly 2 hours long!

deedrah is coming back!!!!!  big smiles 'round here!

-brian

ps - let's hear it for alliteration!

"my kid died and somebody's gotta pay..." 
to avoid that type of thinking ravers have to take charge. possibly like knowmadae has said everybody take control (for real this time) or have the actual promoter and crew find and get rid of the dealers inside their event<the outside world is not the promoter's responsibility> and help or tell the people who're too fukt up to sober up or leave or if worse call a medic. do regular bars have medical staff? no.

and lastly regarding the clientelle and especiallyt the whole sfraves list in general. negativity. it is all the haters out there that drag the outlook of the scene down.

what happened to unity? and peace? hell if positivity wasn't in plur maybe it's time it should. in general if not recovering from psychotherapy and replacing e for prozac or vice verse, ravers are a happy bunch and should learn from their e trips. so stay happy and forgive me if i'm off topic.
`;) let's stay happy kids.
sean.

In a message dated 4/12/2003 5:20:37 AM Pacific Daylight Time, PHietala 
writes:

> Calling in sick to work makes me uncomfortable. No matter how 
> legitimate my illness, I always sense my boss thinks I am lying. On one 
> occasion, I had a valid reason, but lied anyway because the truth 
> was too humiliating. I simply mentioned that I had sustained a head injury 
> and I hoped I 
> would feel like coming in the next day. By then, I thought, I could 
> think up a doozy to explain the bandage on my crown. The accident occurred 
> mainly because I conceded to my wife's wishes to 
> adopt a cute little kitty. Initially, the new acquisition was no problem, 
> but one morning I was 
> taking my shower after breakfast when I heard my wife, Deb, call out to 
> me from the kitchen. "Ed!! The garbage disposal is dead. Come and reset 
> it." "You know where the button is," I protested through the shower 
> (pitter-patter). "Reset it yourself!" "I am scared!" she pleaded. "What if 
> it starts going and sucks me in?" 
> (Pause) "C'mon, it'll only take you a second." So out I came, dripping wet 
> and buck naked, hoping to make a statement 
> about how her cowardly behavior was not without consequence.I crouched 
> down and stuck my head under the sink to find the button. It is the last 
> action I remember performing. It struck without warning, 
> without any respect to my circumstances. Nay, it wasn't a hexed disposal 
> drawing me into its gnashing metal 
> teeth. 
> It was our new kitty, clawing playfully at the dangling objects she 
> spied between my legs. She had been poised around the corner and stalked me 
> as I took the bait 
> under the sink. At precisely the second I was most vulnerable, she leapt at 
> the toys I 
> unwittingly offered and snagged them with her needle-like claws. I lost all 
> rational thought to control orderly bodily movements, while 
> rising upwardly at a violent rate of speed, with the full weight of a 
> kitten hanging from my masculine region. Wild animals are sometimes faced 
> with a "fight or flight" syndrome. 
> Men, in this predicament, choose only the "flight" option. Fleeing 
> straight up, the sink and cabinet bluntly impeded my ascent; the impact 
> knocked me out cold. When I awoke, my wife and the paramedics stood over 
> me. Having been 
> fully briefed by my wife, the paramedics snorted as they tried to 
> conduct their work while suppressing hysterical laughter. At the office, my 
> colleagues tried to coax an explanation out of me. I 
> kept silent, claiming it was too painful to talk about. "What's the matter, 
> cat got your tongue?" If they had only known.

Return-path: <BBMuench@aol.com>
From: BBMuench@aol.com
Full-name: BBMuench
Message-ID: <18d.18644b28.2bc77b55@aol.com>
Date: Thu, 10 Apr 2003 21:58:45 EDT
Subject: Best Cat Story Ever
To: kitis3@earthlink.net
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part4_155.1dec48d0.2bc77b55_boundary"
X-Mailer: 8.0 for Windows sub 6014


--part4_155.1dec48d0.2bc77b55_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Calling in sick to work makes me uncomfortable. No matter how 
legitimate my illness, I always sense my boss thinks I am lying. On one 
occasion, I had a valid reason, but lied anyway because the truth 
was too humiliating. I simply mentioned that I had sustained a head injury 
and I hoped I 
would feel like coming in the next day. By then, I thought, I could 
think up a doozy to explain the bandage on my crown. The accident occurred 
mainly because I conceded to my wife's wishes to 
adopt a cute little kitty. Initially, the new acquisition was no problem, but 
one morning I was 
taking my shower after breakfast when I heard my wife, Deb, call out to 
me from the kitchen. "Ed!! The garbage disposal is dead. Come and reset it." 
"You know where the button is," I protested through the shower 
(pitter-patter). "Reset it yourself!" "I am scared!" she pleaded. "What if it 
starts going and sucks me in?" 
(Pause) "C'mon, it'll only take you a second." So out I came, dripping wet 
and buck naked, hoping to make a statement 
about how her cowardly behavior was not without consequence.I crouched 
down and stuck my head under the sink to find the button. It is the last 
action I remember performing. It struck without warning, 
without any respect to my circumstances. Nay, it wasn't a hexed disposal 
drawing me into its gnashing metal 
teeth. 
It was our new kitty, clawing playfully at the dangling objects she 
spied between my legs. She had been poised around the corner and stalked me 
as I took the bait 
under the sink. At precisely the second I was most vulnerable, she leapt at 
the toys I 
unwittingly offered and snagged them with her needle-like claws. I lost all 
rational thought to control orderly bodily movements, while 
rising upwardly at a violent rate of speed, with the full weight of a 
kitten hanging from my masculine region. Wild animals are sometimes faced 
with a "fight or flight" syndrome. 
Men, in this predicament, choose only the "flight" option. Fleeing 
straight up, the sink and cabinet bluntly impeded my ascent; the impact 
knocked me out cold. When I awoke, my wife and the paramedics stood over me. 
Having been 
fully briefed by my wife, the paramedics snorted as they tried to 
conduct their work while suppressing hysterical laughter. At the office, my 
colleagues tried to coax an explanation out of me. I 
kept silent, claiming it was too painful to talk about. "What's the matter, 
cat got your tongue?" If they had only known. 










































--part4_155.1dec48d0.2bc77b55_boundary
Content-Type: text/html; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Subject: [sfraves] Springs Beats 2.. my car was broken into..

I went up to Carson City for Spring Beats 2.. the first location was 
busted by the cops.. they said the permits weren't right.

The next place involved going into the cuts on a really shitty dirt 
road. There were lots of rocks.. and my car hates rocks. There is no 
clearance with my Greddy exhaust. Eventually the exhaust ripped off 
from the Catalytic Converter and bent around to the back.

I left my car down the road from the rave area. I didn't think anyone 
would fuck with it since it had the exhaust hanging off it. Well a few 
hours later i'm chilling in the tent, and Andy/Mike tell me someone 
broke into my car.

They broke: passenger window, rear hatch window, center console stole: 
air filter, oil dipstick, jack, kenwood mpv-419 mp3 deck, coin box, 
razo shift knob, radar detector, nokia car charger.

I put a sock on the air filter and a pen in the dipstick (so dirt 
wouldn't get in). We tried garbage bagging the windows with duck tape 
but this storm that rolled through was REALLY windy (20-40 mph). It 
started snowing as soon as we hit the summit from South Lake Tahoe. And 
rain/hail all the way from Placerville to Vallejo.

I'll post pictures on http://www.deciblast.org/ soon as Tatoo Mike 
sends them to me.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] something..... on the dance floor...part two nrr

--0-1828953080-1050284214=:39093
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


i didn't think i would have more time to write today, but i do..so this is part two of the first post, or rather a continuation i would have made earlier had i the time:

 the woman goes home after dancing and rests, and then, she has to go to her job, because she needs the money to feed her dancing habit that people resent her for having...the secret dance habit, that she speaks of occasionally, but more often 

than not, keeps to herself, because if she doesn't, she has found that there are generally grave consequences to pay...on a side note, just a few years ago, she couldn't have made the journey that she was accused of 

and then PROMPTLY acquitted of by a handsome actor even if she had really wanted to, because at the time of notification, she was traveling exactly as 

far as she could based on finance and emotional stability which were both sort of short on hand, but now, she goes whereever she wants to and remembers 

as usual, that maybe someone will try to stop her, but she also knows that she is completely loved and adored, and she isn't planning on going anywhere that wouldn't be appreciated anyway, so sometimes, she will NOT do EXACTLY what she wants to in the order that she does, because sometimes 

things are very much worth waiting for...anyway though, she went out dancing like i said, and lots of good things happened too..not just a bunch of rottenness from the usual rotten types, and so, she actually was able to 

sort of drag herself to work, and just by circumstance of her industry, she caters often to the whims of romantic couples. she is kind of like an outside 

consultant of love, and her clients know this, and that is why they go to visit her, except that sometimes, there are problems, but she really want to go dancing again, so she hangs in there even though sometimes, the girlfriend who 

is visiting the woman at her job for assistance, will also immediately ask her boyfriend what he is looking at when he glances unavoidably momentarily 

at the woman who is there to service them both as a distant consultant to their day, and the woman immediately thinks to herself, "well, here we go again, and i am already in a lot of pain and loneliness." and of course, the same tension and 

discomfort pours all over her...the same discomfort that she felt when the girl at the dance club appeared to be so angry as she passed the woman later on that 

her boyfriend had tried to feel all over....the woman who saw the look on the girlfriend's face...the woman who was frightened, and who also thought to herself, "this girl thinks i appreciate the disrespect. will anyone ever 

apologize?" do rapists ever? and sometimes, nothing can make up for the tedium of that...especially not when these kinds of things happen all of the time, and when people think it is something to appreciate and garnish and live for and admonish all at once. :) .............nice writing, huh? dedicated to the one i love. ;)...oh, before i go, i just thought of this...jonny hartman and john coltrane...they did a song together..."dedicated to you", i believe it is called..jonny hartman sings those words anyway..must be a jazz standard of some sort...i fugg'in love that song. :)

I was mobbed at Kennedy International in New York on my way back to cali 
from a gig. Ahh...well kinda sorta. Only this time unfortunately, it wasn't 
for wanting my autograph. Pleasant thought nonetheless. It was around the 
time of 9-11, and a herd of angry passengers were trying to catch a flight 
that was about to leave the gate. I got caught up in a bottleneck at the 
checkpoint as we were all(100's of us) forced to take off our shoes for a 
thorough scanning. It wasn't pretty.


Paulie Paul

Subject: [sfraves] Letter to a Young Activist During Troubled Times

Will Penna forwarded this to me, and though it's not directly rave 
related, the scene definitely has fallen on hard times, that is, what 
remains of it.  when i first started going to parties, i thought it 
would be a big movement, but lately, it seems like it's largely 
become a passing fad.  the music is omnipresent in every shopping 
mall, but good parties are harder to come upon, and young people seem 
to be losing interest.

of course, i'm not in san francisco right now, so maybe others might 
disagree with me, but i think i'd be hearing about it through my 
channels of communication.  anyway, enjoy.

deepfog

--

Thanks to Joel for forwarding this. He writes:

We are in a time that seems dark and gloomy.  But, as the piece below
elucidates for each of us, yes, I said us, the millions of us that love
fairness, non-violence, compassion, empathy, love, and work towards a better
self and therefore a better world, it's time to turn up the volume...
>
------------------------------------------------------
Letter to a Young Activist During Troubled Times:

Do not lose heart. We were made for these times. I have heard from
so many recently who are deeply and properly bewildered. They are
concerned about the state of affairs in our world right now...Ours is a
time of almost daily astonishment and often righteous rage over the
latest degradations of what matters most to civilized, visionary people.

You are right in your assessments. The lustre and hubris some have
aspired to while endorsing acts so heinous against children, elders,
everyday people, the poor, the unguarded, the helpless, is breathtaking.
Yet, I urge you, ask you, gentle you, to please not spend your spirit dry
by bewailing these difficult times. Especially do not lose hope. Most
particularly because, the fact is - we were made for these times. Yes.
For years, we have been learning, practicing, been in training for and
just waiting to meet on this exact plane of engagement...

I grew up on the Great Lakes and recognize a seaworthy vessel when
I see one. Regarding awakened souls, there have never been more
able crafts in the waters than there are right now across the world. And
they are fully provisioned and able to signal one another as never
before in the history of humankind....Look out over the prow; there are
millions of boats of righteous souls on the waters with you. Even though
your veneers may shiver from every wave in this stormy roil, I assure
you that the long timbers composing your prow and rudder come from
a greater forest. That long-grained lumber is known to withstand storms,
to hold together, to hold its own, and to advance, regardless.

We have been in training for a dark time such as this, since the day
we assented to come to Earth. For many decades, worldwide, souls just
like us have been felled and left for dead in so many ways over and
over brought down by naivete, by lack of love, by being ambushed and
assaulted by various cultural and personal shocks in the extreme.
We have a history of being gutted, and yet remember this especially -
we have also, of necessity, perfected the knack of resurrection. Over
and over again we have been the living proof that that which has been
exiled, lost, or foundered can be restored to life again.

In any dark time, there is a tendency to veer toward fainting over how
much is wrong or unmended in the world. Do not focus on that. There
is a tendency too to fall into being weakened by persevering on what
is outside your reach, by what cannot yet be. Do not focus there. That
is spending the wind without raising the sails. We are needed, that is
all we can know. And though we meet resistance, we more so will meet
great souls who will hail us, love us and guide us, and we will know them
when they appear. Didn't you say you were a believer? Didn't you say
you pledged to listen to a voice greater? Didn't you ask for grace?
Don't you remember that to be in grace means to submit to the voice
greater?...

Understand the paradox: If you study the physics of a waterspout,
you will see that the outer vortex whirls far more quickly than the inner
one. To calm the storm means to quiet the outer layer, to cause it to
swirl much less, to more evenly match the velocity of the inner core -
till whatever has been lifted into such a vicious funnel falls back to
Earth, lays down, is peaceable again. One of the most important steps you
can take to help calm the storm is to not allow yourself to be taken in
a flurry of overwrought emotion or desperation thereby accidentally
contributing to the swale and the swirl.

Ours is not the task of fixing the entire world all at once, but of
stretching out to mend the part of the world that is within our reach.

Any small, calm thing that one soul can do to help another soul, to
assist some portion of this poor suffering world, will help immensely.
It is not given to us to know which acts or by whom, will cause the
critical mass to tip toward an enduring good. What is needed for
dramatic change is an accumulation of acts, adding, adding to, adding
more, continuing. We know that it does not take "everyone on Earth"
to bring justice and peace, but only a small, determined group who
will not give up during the first, second, or hundredth gale.

One of the most calming and powerful actions you can do to intervene
in a stormy world is to stand up and show your soul. Soul on deck shines
like gold in dark times. The light of the soul throws sparks, can send up
flares, builds signal fires, causes proper matters to catch fire. To
display the lantern of soul in shadowy times like these -- to be fierce and
to show mercy toward others, both, are acts of immense bravery and
greatest necessity. Struggling souls catch light from other souls who
are fully lit and willing to show it.

If you would help to calm the tumult, this is one of the strongest
things you can do.

There will always be times when you feel discouraged. I too have felt
despair many times in my life, but I do not keep a chair for it; I will not
entertain it. It is not allowed to eat from my plate. The reason is this:
In my uttermost bones I know something, as do you. It is that there
can be no despair when you remember why you came to Earth, who you
serve, and who sent you here. The good words we say and the good
deeds we do are not ours: They are the words and deeds of the One
who brought us here. In that spirit, I hope you will write this on your
wall: When a great ship is in harbor and moored, it is safe, there can
be no doubt. But that is not what great ships are built for.

This comes with much love and prayer that you remember who you
came from, and why you came to this beautiful, needful Earth.

--Clarissa Pinkola Estes, Ph.D., Author, Women Who Run With the Wolves

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

There are a few others but those are some of the ones off the top of my head 
that I enjoy.. But then again I rarely go out..

Subject: [sfraves] Benefit party April 17 @ 111 Minna

--============_-1161770621==_ma============
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

Hey folks ... it's been a looong time since I posted to this list. 
Sorry for the lurker/spam ...

Anyway, we're having a benefit DJ party for the Expo for the Artist & 
Musician on Thursday, April 17, at 111 Minna. The first part of the 
evening's a reception, you can meet some cool/vital arts/culture 
organizations, eat the free food and so on. After 9pm we crank up the 
tempo a bit.

The details are pasted-in below. Email me w/ any questions. THANK YOU 
KINDLY for your indulgence!!

Josh W.

A Benefit for EXPO for the Artist & Musician 2003
Thursday April 17th 2003
111 Minna St. Gallery, San Francisco
Info Line: (415) 820-1607

Welcome Reception from 7-9pm / Admission: $5
Complimentary Hors d'oeuvres / No Host Bar
Main Event from 9 PM - 2 AM / Admission $8-$20 sliding scale

Featured DJs, in alphabetical order:
Corey Black (Imperial Dub) -- Deep and funky house maestro ... jazzy 
soul and ecstatic beats converge

Ms. E (Future Breaks FM) -- Drum 'n' bass/breaks/two-step trailblazer 
... electrifying jump-up music from a Bay Area original

Ren the Vinyl Archaeologist (True-Skool) -- Crucial hip-hop curator 
and historian ... head-nodding grooves and deep-rooted soulful 
selections

Jonah Sharp (Reflective Records/Spacetime Continuum) -- 
Psychedelicized techno/ambient DJ & composer ... propulsive sounds 
from the Bay Area underground

Tomas (XLR8R/Voltage Music) -- Reggae/roots/broken-beat mixmaster! 
Omnivorous and dynamic tempos smash the status quo

Zeph (Wide Hive) -- Master turntablist and Bay Area treasure ... 
ranked by URB mag as one of the top U.S. DJs

Featured Organizations:
ArtSF -- Dedicated to founding a multi-faceted new San Francisco arts 
community space

ArtSpan -- Building a bridge between artists and the greater San 
Francisco community

Electric W.O.M.B. (Women in the Music & Media Business) -- Creating 
community and promoting opportunity for emerging and established 
generations

Independent Arts & Media -- Supporting public arts and community 
media in an era of dumbed-down Pavlovian infotainment

Media Alliance -- Fighting for democratic media in an era of 
corporate consolidation

Planet Drum Foundation -- Saving the world through ecologically 
sustainable culture and community!!

Rhythm & Motion Dance Center -- Freedom for the body and the spirit 
through dance and movement

SoundSafe -- Dedicated to supporting music and arts rehearsal and 
performance space in San Francisco


Pre-Sale Tickets available for $8.00 (starting Mon 4/7)
Open Mind Music
342 Divisadero @ Oak
PH: 415.621.2244
HOURS: M-SAT 11- 9pm / SUN 12-8pm

Sponsored by the Craigslist Foundation, Remix Magazine and True-Skool.org

Please feel free to pass this info on to your community and we'll see 
you there !

-- 
--============_-1161770621==_ma============--

DISH Collective & The Billion Bunny March
presents the 3rd Annual Bunny Jam...
Operation Bunny Jam:
The Hares Stand Up! ...

Saturday, April 19, 2003:
9pm - late
@ a unique location: hop around the vintage
Firehouse 43 & Garden!
724 Brazil St. @ Athens, SF
(This is in the Outer Mission/ Excelsior District /
only 8 minutes from SOMA - Directions below)

$10 FullBunny Regalia, $15 SomeBunny, $20 UnBunny

http://www.telecircus.com/bunnyjam
________________________________________
The HUMAN PROBLEM you see, has gotten out of hand,
and this is the night we hares stand UP!

So, put on yer finest Easter helmets and your rabbit feets  and march
on over for an evening of funny bunny antics, hare-brained plotting
and candy-coated scheming as we launch...
Operation Bunnytopia!

Featuring:
- Mass Bunnification Station
- Mr. MacGregor's Garden & Wee Three Carrots
- Springtime for Bunnies Puppet Theatre

-  Hare Apparent Projections

-  Bunny BoozBar
-  Live Music: Nik Phelps and the BunnyBand
         plus LunaBunny Arias
- DJs and VJs: Dr. Furrriendly, Barcode Bunny, Hellgabunny.

And featuring  the unbunnievable talents of the Bay Area's
most hareified (but unafraid) artistes:

- CameraBunny
- CarolunaBunny
- CC Clark Bunny
- Marcia CrosBunny
- Dr. Furrriendly
- Ron RabbitRun Hare-bert

- Karen Lewis Bunny

- $teven Ra$pa Bunny

DIRECTIONS to 274 Brazil Ave/ San Francisco, CA/ 94112:  Take Mission 
Street -Go past Cesar Chavez, Past Silver and 1 block past Excelsior St, 
make a left onto Brazil. Go about 5 blocks up the hill and it's on the 
right. Enter through Mr. McGregor's Garden Gate. Plenty of  parking at end 
of Brazil at McLaren Park (corner of La Grande).

- 280 SOUTH toward DALY CITY.
- ALEMANY BLVD. exit toward MISSION ST.
- SLIGHT LEFT onto ALEMANY BLVD.
- Turn LEFT onto COTTER ST.
- Turn RIGHT onto MISSION ST.
- Turn LEFT onto BRAZIL AVE.

PLEASE Tiptoe through the Neighborhood! It's way residential out there.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Reefer Madness Redux

--=====================_16759594==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Reefer Madness Redux

By Silja J.A. Talvi, The Nation
April 11, 2003

He'll huff, and he'll puff, and he'll blow your house down. He'll act out=20
violently, get your next door neighbor's daughter pregnant, and he may even=
=20
be supporting terrorism while he's at it.


This imaginary pot smoker composite is drug czar John Walters's big bad=20
wolf, and only a duct-taped cottage window seems to stand in the path of=20
the cannabis-fueled monster that lurks around the corner.


That, and $150 million earmarked in the current fiscal year to further a=20
propagandistic anti-marijuana campaign, courtesy of Walters's Office of=20
National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP). Full-page advertisements from the=20
ONDCP in national newspapers and magazines (including The Nation) are just=
=20
the latest gambit aimed at generating a heightened sense of parental=20
anxiety and moral panic, suggesting that aggressive or violent behavior =96=
=20
and even psychoses =96 are among the consequences awaiting young people who=
=20
try marijuana.


Health consequences for teens who smoke marijuana are, of course, something=
=20
kids and their parents should talk about openly, but with real facts at=20
hand. Compared to much more common binge drinking =96 to say nothing of=20
consequent car accidents, and sexual and physical abuse =96 pot smoking=20
should, logically, rank much lower on the list of parental concerns.


Not so, says the drug czar. Parents need to know that they are the=20
"anti-drug" and millions are being spent telling them there's no drug more=
=20
dangerous to the nation's teenagers than marijuana. And if the parent=20
"fails" to protect society from a pot-smoking teen, then law enforcement is=
=20
eager to step in, to the tune of nearly 126,000 juvenile arrests for=20
marijuana offenses in 2000 alone. "We have policy on marijuana being made=20
by fanatics and ideologues," says Bruce Mirken of the Marijuana Policy=20
Project in Washington, DC. "I think the current campaign is seen as a safe=
=20
way to fire up their socially conservative base and to squash the movement=
=20
to rethink our marijuana laws and drug laws in general," adds Mirken. "It's=
=20
certainly not any sort of a rational attempt to prevent harm to our young=20
people."


For his part, Walters has been busy crisscrossing the nation, trying to=20
extinguish even the slightest moves to alter the nation's draconian drug=20
laws. In Nevada last year, Walters spent months campaigning to help defeat=
=20
Question 9, which would have legalized and regulated marijuana there. When=
=20
Nevada's Secretary of State demanded disclosure of the monies spent=20
campaigning against a state initiative =96 as required by Nevada law =96=20
Walters and the ONDCP shrugged it off and simply refused to disclose. More=
=20
recently, Walters and a small cadre of aides paid a well-timed visit to=20
Santa Fe, New Mexico, just days before a medical marijuana initiative was=20
introduced in the state legislature. The drug czar talked about the dangers=
=20
of marijuana and handed out packets featuring pictures of smiling,=20
drug-free Native American children.


And in Maryland in late March, Walters campaigned in full force, trying to=
=20
prevent passage of that state's conservatively worded medical marijuana=20
bill. The arguments for medical marijuana, Walters announced, make no more=
=20
sense than "an argument for medical crack."


It's reefer madness, all over again. In the 1930s, Federal Bureau of=20
Narcotics head Harry Anslinger oversaw a well-timed, post-alcohol=20
prohibition crusade to criminalize and demonize the use of marijuana.=20
Movies of the era, including the cult-classic Reefer Madness, depicted the=
=20
"demon weed" changing the personalities of high school kids, who after=20
partaking went insane, immersed themselves in "evil" jazz music and then=20
went on murder sprees. Sometimes it seems that Walters is no more=20
sophisticated than his crude 1930s-era counterpart, explains University of=
=20
Southern California psychology professor Mitch Earleywine.


Professor Earleywine, who wrote last year's "Understanding Marijuana: A New=
=20
Look at the Scientific Evidence," notes that Walters is resorting to=20
emotionally provocative and hysterical imagery =96 including televised=
 images=20
of a teen being molested and another girl ending up with an unwanted=20
pregnancy because they smoked weed. Another commercial shows a boy=20
accidentally shooting his friend after getting high. "[That's] the best=20
argument for gun control I've seen in years," says Earleywine. "But lies=20
like these cost us credibility [with teens]. Even true statements about=20
dangerous drugs like cocaine and heroin become suspect."


And there's absolutely no evidence that the ONDCP campaign, which included=
=20
the creation of websites such as TheAntiDrug.com, Freevibe.com,=20
TeachersGuide.org and DrugStory.org (for entertainment and health=20
journalists, no less), is working. An independent group hired by the=20
government to evaluate the campaign last year found that there had been "no=
=20
statistically significant decline in marijuana use, to date, and some=20
evidence of an increase in use from 2000 to 2001...Also there's no tendency=
=20
for those reporting more exposure to Campaign messages to hold more=20
desirable beliefs."


Perhaps in response to this study, the ONDCP announced on April 1 that it=20
was ending its 'drugs=3Dterrorism' campaign in favor of other approaches. At=
=20
the same time, the drug czar's office also mentioned that it was putting a=
=20
stop to the aforementioned annual study.


The persistence of grossly exaggerated antidrug propaganda has been a=20
uniquely American approach since Anslinger's time. Only today, the stakes=20
are higher, with the drug-war budget at record levels: Nearly $20 billion=20
for the current fiscal year, according to analysis from Common Sense for=20
Drug Policy. The lifelong societal consequences for a drug arrest are ever=
=20
more severe in the form of denied student aid, public housing and welfare=20
to those with felony drug records. As millions of ex-offenders have found=20
out, decent, well-paying jobs are nearly impossible to come by once a drug=
=20
charge has found its way onto a criminal record.


In 2001, on average, marijuana offenders served more than three years in=20
federal prison. But much longer prison terms =96 even life sentences =96 for=
=20
marijuana-related offenses are being meted out, disrupting and sometimes=20
destroying the lives of mostly ordinary, otherwise law-abiding Americans.=20
Altogether, nearly 734,000 people were arrested in the United States for a=
=20
marijuana-related offense in 2000, the most recent year for which such=20
figures are available. Of those arrests, according to the FBI's division of=
=20
Uniform Crime Reports, 88 percent were for possession.


In perhaps the most devastating example of a drug-war policy gone awry, a=20
married couple, Dennis and Denise Schilling, chose to end their lives=20
rather than face a house forfeiture and time in prison. They had been=20
arrested for selling $120 worth of marijuana to an undercover police=20
office, who subsequently raided their house and arrested the couple in=20
Wisconsin last fall. After his parents hung themselves in a motel, son=20
Joshua Schilling was spared prison for his part in the small-scale sale but=
=20
sentenced to thousands of dollars in fines, three years' probation and=20
other assorted forms of punishment. "Perhaps someday, people like me will=20
not be so persecuted," Denise Schilling wrote in her suicide note. Perhaps=
=20
someday, indeed.


Silja J.A. Talvi writes on prison and criminal justice issues for In These=
=20
Times, the Christian Science Monitor, The Nation and other publications.=20
Her work appears in the newly released anthology, "Prison Nation"=20
(Routledge, 2003).



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or=20
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence.=20
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we=20
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and=20
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918
