----- Original Message -----
From: "Deepfog" <sfraves@deepfog.com>
To: "SFRavEs Mailing List" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, April 14, 2003 7:41 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Letter to a Young Activist During Troubled Times


> Will Penna forwarded this to me, and though it's not directly rave
> related, the scene definitely has fallen on hard times, that is, what
> remains of it.  when i first started going to parties, i thought it
> would be a big movement, but lately, it seems like it's largely
> become a passing fad.  the music is omnipresent in every shopping
> mall, but good parties are harder to come upon, and young people seem
> to be losing interest.
>

BUT HARDER PARTYIES ARE GOOD TO COME UPON.if there is such a thing,.....but
what do i know? ;_*
>

 of course, i'm not in san francisco right now, so maybe others might
> disagree with me, but i think i'd be hearing about it through my
> channels of communication.  anyway, enjoy.
>
> deepfog
>
> --
>
> Thanks to Joel for forwarding this. He writes:
>
> We are in a time that seems dark and gloomy.  But, as the piece below
> elucidates for each of us, yes, I said us, the millions of us that love
> fairness, non-violence, compassion, empathy, love, and work towards a
better
> self and therefore a better world, it's time to turn up the volume...
> >
> ------------------------------------------------------
> Letter to a Young Activist During Troubled Times:
>
> Do not lose heart. We were made for these times. I have heard from
> so many recently who are deeply and properly bewildered. They are
> concerned about the state of affairs in our world right now...Ours is a
> time of almost daily astonishment and often righteous rage over the
> latest degradations of what matters most to civilized, visionary people.
>
> You are right in your assessments. The lustre and hubris some have
> aspired to while endorsing acts so heinous against children, elders,
> everyday people, the poor, the unguarded, the helpless, is breathtaking.
> Yet, I urge you, ask you, gentle you, to please not spend your spirit dry
> by bewailing these difficult times. Especially do not lose hope. Most
> particularly because, the fact is - we were made for these times. Yes.
> For years, we have been learning, practicing, been in training for and
> just waiting to meet on this exact plane of engagement...
>
> I grew up on the Great Lakes and recognize a seaworthy vessel when
> I see one. Regarding awakened souls, there have never been more
> able crafts in the waters than there are right now across the world. And
> they are fully provisioned and able to signal one another as never
> before in the history of humankind....Look out over the prow; there are
> millions of boats of righteous souls on the waters with you. Even though
> your veneers may shiver from every wave in this stormy roil, I assure
> you that the long timbers composing your prow and rudder come from
> a greater forest. That long-grained lumber is known to withstand storms,
> to hold together, to hold its own, and to advance, regardless.
>
> We have been in training for a dark time such as this, since the day
> we assented to come to Earth. For many decades, worldwide, souls just
> like us have been felled and left for dead in so many ways over and
> over brought down by naivete, by lack of love, by being ambushed and
> assaulted by various cultural and personal shocks in the extreme.
> We have a history of being gutted, and yet remember this especially -
> we have also, of necessity, perfected the knack of resurrection. Over
> and over again we have been the living proof that that which has been
> exiled, lost, or foundered can be restored to life again.
>
> In any dark time, there is a tendency to veer toward fainting over how
> much is wrong or unmended in the world. Do not focus on that. There
> is a tendency too to fall into being weakened by persevering on what
> is outside your reach, by what cannot yet be. Do not focus there. That
> is spending the wind without raising the sails. We are needed, that is
> all we can know. And though we meet resistance, we more so will meet
> great souls who will hail us, love us and guide us, and we will know them
> when they appear. Didn't you say you were a believer? Didn't you say
> you pledged to listen to a voice greater? Didn't you ask for grace?
> Don't you remember that to be in grace means to submit to the voice
> greater?...
>
> Understand the paradox: If you study the physics of a waterspout,
> you will see that the outer vortex whirls far more quickly than the inner
> one. To calm the storm means to quiet the outer layer, to cause it to
> swirl much less, to more evenly match the velocity of the inner core -
> till whatever has been lifted into such a vicious funnel falls back to
> Earth, lays down, is peaceable again. One of the most important steps you
> can take to help calm the storm is to not allow yourself to be taken in
> a flurry of overwrought emotion or desperation thereby accidentally
> contributing to the swale and the swirl.
>
> Ours is not the task of fixing the entire world all at once, but of
> stretching out to mend the part of the world that is within our reach.
>
> Any small, calm thing that one soul can do to help another soul, to
> assist some portion of this poor suffering world, will help immensely.
> It is not given to us to know which acts or by whom, will cause the
> critical mass to tip toward an enduring good. What is needed for
> dramatic change is an accumulation of acts, adding, adding to, adding
> more, continuing. We know that it does not take "everyone on Earth"
> to bring justice and peace, but only a small, determined group who
> will not give up during the first, second, or hundredth gale.
>
> One of the most calming and powerful actions you can do to intervene
> in a stormy world is to stand up and show your soul. Soul on deck shines
> like gold in dark times. The light of the soul throws sparks, can send up
> flares, builds signal fires, causes proper matters to catch fire. To
> display the lantern of soul in shadowy times like these -- to be fierce
and
> to show mercy toward others, both, are acts of immense bravery and
> greatest necessity. Struggling souls catch light from other souls who
> are fully lit and willing to show it.
>
> If you would help to calm the tumult, this is one of the strongest
> things you can do.
>
> There will always be times when you feel discouraged. I too have felt
> despair many times in my life, but I do not keep a chair for it; I will
not
> entertain it. It is not allowed to eat from my plate. The reason is this:
> In my uttermost bones I know something, as do you. It is that there
> can be no despair when you remember why you came to Earth, who you
> serve, and who sent you here. The good words we say and the good
> deeds we do are not ours: They are the words and deeds of the One
> who brought us here. In that spirit, I hope you will write this on your
> wall: When a great ship is in harbor and moored, it is safe, there can
> be no doubt. But that is not what great ships are built for.
>
> This comes with much love and prayer that you remember who you
> came from, and why you came to this beautiful, needful Earth.
>
> --Clarissa Pinkola Estes, Ph.D., Author, Women Who Run With the Wolves
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves]When purchasing turntables...

From sfraves-return-101155-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Apr 14 21:43:15 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101155-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 7203 invoked by uid 1103); 14 Apr 2003 21:43:15 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 7189 invoked from network); 14 Apr 2003 21:43:14 -0000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <OFAD80BF3E.345D7882-ON85256D08.007737E3@washpost.com>
From: "Mary Morris" <morrism@washpost.com>
Date: Mon, 14 Apr 2003 17:42:54 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Sen. Leahy comments on Rave Act

posted by Eric of ROAR on ROAR listserv:

Sen. Leahy comments on the entire Bill and the amendments. Here are his
specific
comments on the Rave Act inclusion

http://leahy.senate.gov/press/200304/041003c.html

RAVE ACT

I am also concerned about the inclusion of the Illicit Drug
Anti-Proliferation
Act in this conference report.  This bill has drawn serious grass-roots
opposition, and I know that I am not alone in hearing from many
constituents
about their serious and well-considered objections to it.  Despite this
opposition, and even though the Senate has never held a hearing on this
bill, the conference committee agreed to include it in this
hastily-assembled
package.

I know that Senator Biden has made changes to the bill since the last
Congress,
beginning with its title, and I appreciate his flexibility.  But these
changes
do not address some of the questions that have been raised about this
legislation.


The bill's primary purpose is to expand the existing "crack house statute,"
(21 USC 856) which makes it unlawful to knowingly open or maintain any
place
for the purpose of manufacturing, distributing, or using any controlled
substance, or to make a place available to someone else for use for such
purposes or for storing a controlled substance.  The bill would expand the
statute to include those who lease, rent, or use property, including
temporary
occupants, and would allow for civil suits against violators.

The crack house statute has been on the books for more than 15 years, and
for most of its existence, federal prosecutors have used it solely against
property owners who have been directly involved in committing drug
offenses.
 The House Judiciary Committee, however, heard evidence last year that the
Drug Enforcement Administration and prosecutors are now using the "crack
house statute" to pursue even business owners who take serious precautions
to avoid drug use at their events.  Business owners have come to Congress
and told us there are only so many steps they can take to prevent any of
the thousands of people who may attend a concert or a rave from using
drugs,
and they are worried about being held personally accountable for the
illegal
acts of others.  Those concerns may well be overstated, but they deserve
a fuller hearing.

In addition, the provision allowing civil suits dramatically increases the
potential liability of business owners.  Of course, this is a good thing
when applied against those who are knowingly profiting from illegal drug
use.  But we have been told that even conscientious promoters may think
twice before holding large concerts or other events where some drug use
may be inevitable despite their best efforts.  I do not know enough to know
whether that claim is exaggerated, but I think we would have been
well-served
by making a greater effort to find out.


Eric
RPM : ROAR : DCNC
www.rpmonline.org
www.roargroup.org
www.dcnc.org

-----

to write to senator leahy:

senator_leahy@leahy.senate.gov



respectfully,
mary :)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From sfraves-return-101165-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Apr 15 00:05:05 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101165-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 56582 invoked by uid 1103); 15 Apr 2003 00:05:05 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 56533 invoked from network); 15 Apr 2003 00:05:05 -0000
Message-ID: <20030415000501.36927.qmail@web12308.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 14 Apr 2003 17:05:01 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RE:  More Info: TEN15 IS OPEN! (fwd)

Well, as someone rathar trollishly pointed out in an earlier thread on this
topic, there's no love between me and 1015.  And, in fact, when they finally DO
get shut down for good, I'll do a little happy dance.  But at the risk of
biting on the flamebait, I've got to jump in on one small bit:

> According to the ABC's own report, an investigator would
> approach a bartender and say "Do you know where I can get some ecstasy?" In
> every case, the bartender said "No." The investigator would then disappear
> into the crowd and seek to purchase a tablet of ecstasy from a customer. If
> he succeeded, he would come back to the bartender -- who, the ABC admits,
> had not witnessed the purchase -- and say "Well, I was able to get some
> ecstasy." Apparently, the ABC is contending that the bartender can be
> deemed to have "permitted" the ecstasy purchase

Now that is just a big and sleazy crock of bullshit on the part of the pigs.

When I was going to college in Florida, one of the ways I made money to live
on, was by tending bar.  I took a four week night class (made the tuition back
in ONE week of working) to learn to do so, the main value of which was: 1) the
connections the school had with the local bars and clubs, and 2) the week.

The first week of class, before we were taught ANY drinks, or so much as
allowed to touch the Wunderbar gun, were all about the legal rights and
obligations of a bartender, plus a fair bit of practice at recognising fake
IDs.

And to over-simplify a bit, the bartender's obligation begins and ends at the
bar.  He has an obligation not to serve anyone who is "too intoxicated" (that's
left as a judgement call).  And he has an obligation not to serve anyone he
believes is underage (Even if the person has a convincing ID, or even a real
one (like an older sibling's).).  Moreover, he has the RIGHT to do so, and is
protected from liability and fireing when he does so (Though, in practice, if
the boss wants you gone, he'll find some excuse.  But it's nice to be shielded
from lawsuits and criminal prosecution.)

OTOH, if someone's at the bar or in the club stoned off his ass or obviously
rolling balls, SO LONG AS THE BARTENDER DOES NOT SERVE THEM, it's NOT his
problem.  It's security's problem.  Where/when I tended bar was Daytona Beach
during the bike week/race week/spring break/black college reunion season.  Any
one of those crowds could get quite rowdy, and every place I worked had a
seperate, TRAINED, security force which was, not infrequently, beefed up by
off-duty cops.  Anything beyond not serving people who needed to be cut off,
from fights, to mosh pits, to illegal drugs, to ejecting people for the above,
was THEIR job, NOT mine.

(Quite frankly, I don't believe that the drugs should be *secutity's* problem
either.  Beyond the fact that the cops' war on (some) drugs is disgustingly
wrong in the first place...  If the cops are too damn lazy or incompetent to
enforce the laws on their own they should have *NO* business extorting private
citizens or business owners to do their jobs for them.  But that's another
arguement.)

Now, if I had been SELLING drugs (other than alcohol) at the bar, yeah, I'd
been in a world of shit.  But since I wasn't selling (other drugs), anything
non-alcohol related that went on was not my problem.  (And hell, even some
alhohol-related problems wouldn't have been mine.  Had somebody snuck a 40' in
from the corner store, drank it there, then driven off and killed himself, I,
the bartender, would not have liable so long as *I* had not served him.  The
convinence store clerk would eat that prosecution/lawsuit.)

So yeah.  I still have no intention of setting foot in the place before I have
absolute confirmation that they change their ways and start treating their
patrons like customers, and NOT like criminals before the fact...  I gotta call
it like I see it.  And 1015's 100% in the right on this one.  They don't
deserve to be shut down for this bullshit charge.  They deserve to die, from
lack of business, because of the way they treat their customers.


cya,
john

Message-ID: <20030415174034.35185.qmail@web41810.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 15 Apr 2003 10:40:34 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: Osby Jamz <osbyjamz@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F125l3zZxKuMTueD0We0001a02b@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Psychic Spells

Osby, you do indeed jam, but I'm in total disagreement
with you here. I don't think the folks at that Web
site are psychics at all. I think they're either
charlatans or insane fools. They're offering revenge
spells (among other things). That stuff is bad news.

Michael Jackson gave millions to an East African witch
to put a hex on some Hollywood people. He even had a
huge number of pigs killed on his property in order to
summon evil spirits to do his bidding at the witch's
request. Now look at his situation. He's fucked. You
wanna know why? Partly kz he's a psychotic pedophile,
and partly because summoning evil spirits makes the
evil spirits hungry. If they're not successful in
going after the target you've given them, guess who
they go after instead? Whoever summoned them. And you
know what is the deciding factor in whether or not an
evil spirit actually gets thru?

It's guilt. Swear to God. If the target feels guilty
or in any way believes they've done wrong, even at the
most subconscious level, then the evil spirit gets
thru. If not, it bounces off the target's sense of
innocence like a bullet plowing into an indestructible
giant marshmallow -- and then with a resounding
spiritual "BOING!!!" it ricochets directly at you.

This means, of course, that the only time revenge
spells work is when the subject believes they've
really done something wrong -- or, in other words,
when either their own sense of guilt or the simple
inevitability of karma would have taken them out
anyway.

Revenge spells are for idiots.

Apologies for being a downer, but I'm not sharing your
enthusiasm for that Web site.


Giles

(ps: this also explains why a man with a clear
conscience has nothing to fear from anyone -- and from
that you can even figure out the real secret of
Shaolin, if you really, really want to.)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Psychic Spells

Damn, you know your shit.  Follow the white and the wood and you shall
forever have peace ;)  The only sacrifices I make are my offerings of
food and nourishment to mother nature when I go into my duridic state of
mind in a forest. =20

The weirdest thing that has happened to me through all my life is random
unknown strangers would come up to me talk to me, then whisper in my ear
so my parents couldn't hear.. 'You are a warlock and have much power, be
careful.'  Being raised mormon I had no idea what he meant but it hasn't
stopped, people still to this day, on drugs, sober, young, old, random
people always tell me I'm a warlock without even a conversation having
been started.  Its kinda scary because I never think of the occult but
I've had manifestations of things that I try to dismiss as coincidence
or something.  My ability to calm almost any animal or human, when I'm
around old trees they entrance me to the point where I almost feel like
burying myself in their roots... Weird shit.  There is definitely
something out there in this world that is more powerful than any
religion can put a finger on, I just try to stay away from it because I
don't think its something I can handle.

Call me a loon now, but that=92s my 2 cents.

Never dabble with the dark for the dark is insatiable and expects
payment of some sort and if you don't know what your dealing with and
haven't practiced you will lose part of your goodness.  Especially with
trying to invoke revenge or hurtful spells.

oh, look, i found the first one. i don't know why that happened, but also, last night i heard today's chanson du jour: jimmy hendrix goes, " hey, joe, where you go'in with that gun in your hand? hey, joe, i said, where you go'in with that gun in your hand?." "oh, i'm go'in down to shoot my old lady. you know, i caught her mess'in with another man. HUH! and that ain't cool."......i must be lost in the sixties or something like that, because whenever we are at war, i always find it very jimmy hendrix appropriate...i can think of a ton of other jimmy hendrix appropriate times, but he's just so water out of a dusty canteen though, isn't he? also, i have been using hemp seed salve for a few years now, because i recieved a large supply of it a few years ago...finally, i am almost out...i must say though, that whenever i have the kind of lip chapping that causes a bit of rawness at the corners of my lips, it is the best stuff...now, there are a ton of other essential oils in the mix, but what i find, is that the hemp seed salve that i am using is hydrating while slightly drying, and that helps to heal without extending the raw part. i don't know if the healing can be specifically attributed to the hemp seed oil itself though. do you know what i mean? the two sides, right where you mouth opens...like the hinges to your mouth...those don't really get cracked, but sometimes, when your lips get chapped, the hinges feel like they are cut or something, and the more moisture that is in there, the longer it takes for them to go back to normal, or not to get more inflamed and red and raw, and then the hinge looks like it has extended a little bit, and then it is pink outside of your actual lip line...you can't where lipstick during that time, or it looks dumb, besides, it hurts...just my opinion...you can't not moisturize your mouth though either, because, while the hinge part needs to be sort of dried, the rest of your lips need tons of moisture, because they are totally chapped...so, in closing, i find the hemp seed salve to be a combination of moisturizing and drying, so that my lips heal fast. when i run out though, there is always a good glob of carmex..i like menthol and camphor too. :)

From: LittleEtoile@aol.com

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Help with an Underwater Disco

--part1_132.1dc51fed.2bcdc90c_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sorry, I know I very rarely post anymore and now I'm only posting a NRR 
letter, but I needed some ideas and I thought this was a good resource since 
what I need help with is similar to planning a rave...   Please, PLEASE 
respond privately since this is *very* NRR and I don't want to fill up this 
list with it. Even one NRR post is one too many sometimes.

Ok.. so I may have mentioned to some of you before
that I was elected to host and plan this year's
Teacher Appreciation Dinner at my college campus. The
theme selected was Underwater Disco. It gives me a lot
of room to work with (Hawaii, underwater seascape,
disco, funk, nightlife etc.) and I think that's why
I'm at a loss. I think I work better with more
limitations because it forces creativity sooo...

Any ideas? Pretend you were throwing a party ... 
what sort of decorations would you put up?
Any key features? I've come up with a bunch of random
ideas.... Hawaiian dancers, goldfish on the table with
maybe a drawing or game you can win to take it home,
blue/green lights flooding the place,
tiki (or whatever you call them) lamps outside with
maybe some kiddie pools filled with sand etc. etc.... I was
basically thinking inside would be underwater,
outside patio area would be the beach. Oh, and the
best part.. I need someone to dress up and walk around
as Disco Stu... who's up for it?? I'll pay you even!

Any entertainment/activity ideas would be cool too.
For example, last year was Renaissance theme so
throughout the night they would stop everything and a
spot would focus on someone in a corner dressed up and
they would spout off a Shakespeare selection.

Anyways... let your imagination run wild. Anything goes. Disco,
beaches, underwater.. how can you go wrong?

heart,
Alida

--part1_132.1dc51fed.2bcdc90c_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  LIBERTY VANISHES WHILE THE PRESS SLEEPS

--=====================_14597361==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

LIBERTY VANISHES WHILE THE PRESS SLEEPS

Nat Hentoff, Village Voice

Our most basic civil liberties are under attack and the media doesn't seem
to notice or care.
*In Rights&Liberties: http://www.alternet.org/rights/

And the ACLU, for the first time in its history, is holding conferences, 
workshops and a lobby day in DC.  I urge you to support this organization 
in any way you can.  Details below.

Love,

Apollo

From: ACLU Executive Director, Anthony Romero
To: ACLU Action Network
Date: April 15, 2003


I last wrote to you in December. Normally, you would not hear from me again 
until the end of the year. But these are not normal times.


The government is resorting to detentions, deportations, and other tactics 
reminiscent of the Palmer Raid period that led to the ACLU's founding 83 
years ago.


New approaches are required. I want to tell you about an exciting 
initiative and its opportunities for you as a concerned individual.


In less than two months, ACLU members and activists from across the country 
will converge on Washington for four days of critical debate and 
conversations with high-level decision-makers, highlighted by the ACLU's 
first-ever lobby day.


This event, the ACLU's Inaugural Membership Conference, is designed to 
remind our political leaders that Americans of all backgrounds and from all 
regions believe that keeping us free is as important as making us safe.


This will be an exciting opportunity for you to lobby your Members of 
Congress and help shape policy. Your faxes to Congress have made a 
difference. Attending this conference is a great way for you to take your 
activism to the next level. You will have an amazing opportunity to meet 
like-minded activists from across the country and exchange ideas, 
strategies and experience.


We will spend one day of the conference at the ACLU's first-ever lobby day 
on Capitol Hill, bringing our civil liberties concerns directly to Members 
of Congress and their staffs. A training session will explain how to make 
our case and become even more effective participants in the nation's 
democratic process.


Following the lobby day, the ACLU takes the debate into point-counter-point 
plenary sessions with important officials and pundits representing the 
Administration's approaches to the balance between security and liberty.


Throughout the conference, workshops and other sessions will help sharpen 
our knowledge of key issues such as racial profiling and the treatment of 
Arabs and Muslims in America, data mining and data surveillance, lesbian 
and gay rights, reproductive freedom and the ill-conceived drug policy.


We have also organized special youth programs, and participants between the 
ages of 16 and 27 are eligible for reduced conference rate.  This special 
rate is also available to full-time students.


Today, ACLU stands at the very center of the American purpose. And for four 
days in June, at our Inaugural Membership Conference, we will have an 
unprecedented opportunity to communicate that message to our leaders and to 
our fellow citizens.


This is our time. This is your meeting. As the conference headline urges: 
Stand Up For Freedom. Because Freedom Can't Protect Itself.


For further information and to register, visit the ACLU Web site 
www.aclu.org, email mem_conf@aclu.org, or call 212 549 2561.


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"The West won the world not by the superiority of its ideas or values or 
religion but rather by its superiority in applying organized violence. 
Westerners often forget this fact, non-Westerners never do."
-Samuel P. Huntington

"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or that we 
are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only unpatriotic and 
servile but it is morally treasonable to the American public."
-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

--=====================_14597361==_.ALT--

X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Full Moon Party tonight; 4/15/03

YAY!
Full Moon is when the moon has reached its zenith, it forms a perfect
silvery sphere in the sky. This is a time for spells that transform,
increase pyschic ability, for fertility spells and invocation to lunar
goddesses. This is a time of strength, love and power. At this time the
moon represents the Goddess in her Mother aspect, give praise to
Cerridwen, Isis or one of the other Mother Goddesses. The period of the
Full Moon lasts from about 3 days before to 3 days after the actual full
moon.

April's Full Moon had several interesting names -- Pink Moon for the
flowers (mostly pink) that covered the land at this time, Fish Moon,
Sprouting Grass Moon, Egg Moon and Shad Moon.

http://www.space.com/spacewatch/full_moon_names_030214-4.html
Pink Moon
April 16, 2003, 3:36 p.m. EDT

The grass pink or wild ground phlox is one of the earliest widespread
flowers of spring. Other names were the Full Sprouting Grass Moon, the Egg
Moon, and -- among coastal tribes -- the Full Fish Moon, when the shad
came upstream to spawn.

In 2003, this will be the first full Moon of spring, hence it is also the
Paschal Full Moon. The feast of Passover begins at sundown on this night
and the first Sunday following the first full Moon of spring (April 20) is
designated as Easter Sunday.

Lastly, the Moon will arrive at perigee at 1:00 a.m. on April 17, at a
distance of 221,937 miles (355,987) kilometers from Earth. Very high tides
can be expected from the near- coincidence of perigee with Full Moon
(referred to as an astronomical spring tide).

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************

At 16:43 -0400 4/15/03, LittleEtoile@aol.com wrote:
>Sorry, I know I very rarely post anymore and now I'm only posting a NRR
>letter, but I needed some ideas and I thought this was a good resource since
>what I need help with is similar to planning a rave...   Please, PLEASE
>respond privately since this is *very* NRR and I don't want to fill up this
>list with it. Even one NRR post is one too many sometimes.
>
>Ok.. so I may have mentioned to some of you before
>that I was elected to host and plan this year's
>Teacher Appreciation Dinner at my college campus. The
>theme selected was Underwater Disco. It gives me a lot
>of room to work with (Hawaii, underwater seascape,
>disco, funk, nightlife etc.) and I think that's why
>I'm at a loss. I think I work better with more
>limitations because it forces creativity sooo...
>
>Any ideas? Pretend you were throwing a party ...
>what sort of decorations would you put up?
>Any key features? I've come up with a bunch of random
>ideas.... Hawaiian dancers, goldfish on the table with
>maybe a drawing or game you can win to take it home,
>blue/green lights flooding the place,
>tiki (or whatever you call them) lamps outside with
>maybe some kiddie pools filled with sand etc. etc.... I was
>basically thinking inside would be underwater,
>outside patio area would be the beach. Oh, and the
>best part.. I need someone to dress up and walk around
>as Disco Stu... who's up for it?? I'll pay you even!
>
>Any entertainment/activity ideas would be cool too.
>For example, last year was Renaissance theme so
>throughout the night they would stop everything and a
>spot would focus on someone in a corner dressed up and
>they would spout off a Shakespeare selection.
>
>Anyways... let your imagination run wild. Anything goes. Disco,
>beaches, underwater.. how can you go wrong?
>
>heart,
>Alida

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 19916 invoked from network); 15 Apr 2003 23:49:23 -0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
X-Sender: blindspot@mail.mac.com
Message-Id: <p04330102bac249e357ba@[172.16.2.25]>
In-Reply-To: <132.1dc51fed.2bcdc90c@aol.com>
References: <132.1dc51fed.2bcdc90c@aol.com>
Date: Tue, 15 Apr 2003 16:49:28 -0700
To: LittleEtoile@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: blindspot <blindspot@mac.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Help with an Underwater Disco

Depict underwater scenes on all walls. Hang large sheets of the 
thinnest clear plastic sheeting you can find (Home Depot paint 
section) from the ceilings about 2 inches from and parallel to the 
walls. Make sure bottom edge of plastic does not touch ground so 
plastic can sway a bit. Try to get  plastic to shimmer gently and 
slowly. Thickness of plastic will determine this effect. Modulate if 
necessary with stratgically placed fans to get a more controllable 
"wave" effect. Blue light and bubbles will also help.

BS

The Official How Weird Street Faire Afterlife Party!

?TRANZWEIRD!

Rebirth of the Cosmic Egg

Sunday, 4/20/03
8 pm - 4 am
@ Studio Z
314 11th Street @ Folsom
(just one block from the Street Faire!)

TICKETS: (at the door only!)
$10 with weirdware - $12 w/o

After the High Weirdness of the Street Faire (see below)... join us
for an inner-dimensional evening of deep psy-trance rhythms,
downtempo fusions, tribal communions and sacred reunions!

In the Trance Cube: (in scheduled order)

Psy-Trance Mass  with

- ABA STRUCTURE (Kenji Williams/Fungus)
- PENTA (Spectral Concepts)
- KJ (Hypnopedia)
- GOZ (Verbum/Radio-V)
- KODE IV (Ceiba)

- ALCYONE (Entactogen)
- WATERJUICE + IRINA MIKAILOVA (Medicine Drum/Lumin)
- SHAKATURA (Groove Garden/CyberOctave)

- NIKKI LASTRETO

Subject: [sfraves] RE:  More Info: TEN15 IS OPEN! (fwd)

this is an interesting discourse on the rights and potential pitfalls 
of bartenders.  it kind of goes with common sense to think that one 
wouldn't serve someone if they look too drunk or whatever.

we've all seen the attempts by the various law enforcement agencies 
over the years try to shut down this particular club.  i highly doubt 
it will happen ... every time they get close, ira finds some way out 
of it, the last time it was adding more obnoxious security.  i 
personally haven't gone there in years.  it's not the simple little 
club it used to be when i went to my first party back in '91.

but hey, what do they care about simple?  there are plenty of people 
that do want to go there, they are willing to go through the security 
and pay high cover prices.  it would be nice, though, to see some of 
these big clubs start to properly train and demand a higher standard 
of behavior from the security personnel.

peace,

DF

>
>
>OTOH, if someone's at the bar or in the club stoned off his ass or obviously
>rolling balls, SO LONG AS THE BARTENDER DOES NOT SERVE THEM, it's NOT his
>problem.  It's security's problem.  Where/when I tended bar was Daytona Beach
>during the bike week/race week/spring break/black college reunion season.  Any
>one of those crowds could get quite rowdy, and every place I worked had a
>seperate, TRAINED, security force which was, not infrequently, beefed up by
>off-duty cops.  Anything beyond not serving people who needed to be cut off,
>from fights, to mosh pits, to illegal drugs, to ejecting people for the above,
>was THEIR job, NOT mine.
>
>(Quite frankly, I don't believe that the drugs should be *secutity's* problem
>either.  Beyond the fact that the cops' war on (some) drugs is disgustingly
>wrong in the first place...  If the cops are too damn lazy or incompetent to
>enforce the laws on their own they should have *NO* business extorting private
>citizens or business owners to do their jobs for them.  But that's another
>arguement.)

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 38295 invoked from network); 16 Apr 2003 17:31:22 -0000
Date: Wed, 16 Apr 2003 10:31:19 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20030416173119.GD9113@pion.local>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <Law9-F62rClaQMEC6uI000095b8@hotmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <Law9-F62rClaQMEC6uI000095b8@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-help a female dj out!

quoth Alicia C.:
> hi everyone!  I just had a question for all you seasoned dj's out
> there!  I have been trying to dj for the past year or so.....and im
> not toooo good.  When i practice i dont use the same records..i just
> keep going on to the next.  What would you all recommend?  Should i
> just keep practicing with the same records over and over, or shouldi
> not?  any general tips in that arena would be much appreciated..or
> anything that helped you learn!

Playing the same records over and over again can get tiresome and
frustrating. You've got to have a wide variety of music to practice
with. If possible, find a friend with tons of records and ask him/her if
you can either play at their house, or better yet, borrow some of their
older records (that they presumably don't play anymore, or are perhaps
willing to part with). Trainspot DJ's you respect.

Another piece of advice: KEEP BUYING VINYL. Even if it's stuff from the
bargain bin, keep exposing yourself to different music and try to
venture outside your musical "comfort zone". Join mailing lists
frequented by DJ's and producers with similar tastes to find out about
both new and classic releases.

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

My first interaction with him was being asked for my phone number via SFR,
("just in case I need to cantact you!") after asking about a ride to a
party in 1995 - no offer of a ride, but he did point out his
self-aggrandizing web page. I was 17, and a freshman at UCB. He also has
an ego streak a mile wide - at one Pt. Molate party, he would leave copies
of his business card lying around, and then exclaim "Oh! Look, it's my
business card!" to try to get people to notice who he was.

I don't think anyone ever said "child molester", or accused him of doing
anything illegal... But if you're youngish, and male, watch yer cornhole.

In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV19tUUQDjWC500000b2e@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: DJ Equipment Questions

quoth Jack Triumph:
> I have a pair of Ortofon Nightclub Needles. I need to replace the
> stylus...a friend recommended that I get the Ortofon Blue DJ Stylus',
> as he relayed that they are of better quality and will last longer
> ?!?! Is this true; and if so, will the fit the nightclub cartridge?

Yes, the blue "DJ" styli are a bit more durable. They're also shaped
differently, so they impart a little less "direct" impact on your
records (which increases their life as well), and are easier to scratch
with. The sound difference is negligible, IMO -- especially in a club
setting.

All of the similarly-shaped Ortofon cartidges can accomodate the various
styli, too -- I used to use the Nightclub styli on the silver cartridges
because the contacts were a bit less succeptible to oxidization. YMMV,
of course :)

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Message-ID: <20030416131452.S37805-100000@taz3.hyperreal.org>
SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] The Crunchman resurfaces

There is something to be said for the art of taking a whistle out of a
cereal box, and using it to emulate a tone of 2600hz to sound like a
quarter, dime, and nickel dropping into a payphone. (Back in the day
anways).

blue box http://www.catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/entry/blue-box.html

n. 1. obs. Once upon a time, before all-digital switches made it possible
for the phone companies to move them out of band, one could actually hear
the switching tones used to route long-distance calls. Early phreakers
built devices called `blue boxes' that could reproduce these tones, which
could be used to commandeer portions of the phone network. (This was not
as hard as it may sound; one early phreak acquired the sobriquet `Captain
Crunch' after he proved that he could generate switching tones with a
plastic whistle pulled out of a box of Captain Crunch cereal!) There were
other colors of box with more specialized phreaking uses; red boxes, black
boxes, silver boxes, etc. There were boxes of other colors as well, but
the blue box was the original and archetype. 2. n. An IBM machine,
especially a large (non-PC) one.

How WOZ and Crunch Made it:

http://www.woz.org/letters/general/03.html

All other rumours aside, I've spoken with Crunch offlist. How many folks
must echo a rumour without personal knowledge of someone? Truth or not,
Freak or not, who are we to judge? - Are you one of the people
affected directly by it? (People like us have been labeled ravers as
freaks for a decade).

K

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The Crunchman resurfaces

Actually-that's a red box-I own one-but these days it only works in places like Nebraska :)

The 2600hz tone from the crunch whistle is the trunk-switching tone that the phone company used.
So you could just blow it in to the phone and... :D

On Wed, 16 Apr 2003 13:18:16 -0700 (PDT), Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:

> There is something to be said for the art of taking a whistle out of a
> cereal box, and using it to emulate a tone of 2600hz to sound like a
> quarter, dime, and nickel dropping into a payphone. (Back in the day
> anways).
>
> blue box http://www.catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/entry/blue-box.html
>
> n. 1. obs. Once upon a time, before all-digital switches made it possible
> for the phone companies to move them out of band, one could actually hear
> the switching tones used to route long-distance calls. Early phreakers
> built devices called `blue boxes' that could reproduce these tones, which
> could be used to commandeer portions of the phone network. (This was not
> as hard as it may sound; one early phreak acquired the sobriquet `Captain
> Crunch' after he proved that he could generate switching tones with a
> plastic whistle pulled out of a box of Captain Crunch cereal!) There were
> other colors of box with more specialized phreaking uses; red boxes, black
> boxes, silver boxes, etc. There were boxes of other colors as well, but
> the blue box was the original and archetype. 2. n. An IBM machine,
> especially a large (non-PC) one.
>
> How WOZ and Crunch Made it:
>
> http://www.woz.org/letters/general/03.html
>
> All other rumours aside, I've spoken with Crunch offlist. How many folks
> must echo a rumour without personal knowledge of someone? Truth or not,
> Freak or not, who are we to judge? - Are you one of the people
> affected directly by it? (People like us have been labeled ravers as
> freaks for a decade).
>
> K
>
> On Wed, 16 Apr 2003, innocentchild wrote:
>
>> I've met the guy. He's a bit left of center shall we say. Now what's really
>> funny is just last week I went and saw Cowboy Bebop and *Cap'n Crunch* is
>> mentioned in the movie! Talk about him as this uber 1337 hacker type. Too
>> damn funny to suddenly see slashdot and sfraves talking about him now. Did
>> he hire a PR firm or something??
>>
>> ryan.bailey

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ATP: DJ Equipment Questions

They fit. They sound a bit different than the nightclub tips. But I
disagree that they last longer. 

I now use only nightclub tips on my dj's (blue) OM and concord. 

I found that I was replacing my Dj tips way too often compared to the
nightclub tips. 

And these are rental carts, not home use. So you know they got beat up
by dirty records, overweighting the tips and scratch Dj's.

For home use I only use Shure. 44-G's and 35X's.





-andy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-help a female dj out!

    Let me see if I understand your question. I think you are saying is that
when you are trying to mix 2 records, and you don't get it right, you move
on to the next record, is that right? If so, I say put the needle back on
the first track and keep trying to get the mix. If you just can't get it
after several tries, try a different record for the second track. Some songs
just don't work with each other. Sometimes you can struggle to get 2 tracks
mixed and get really frustrated, then you can grab a new track and have it
slide right in.
    BTW - You don't have to qualify yourself as a *female* dj. We will give
you our advice and opinions no matter what your plumbing ;-)

Happy  :-)

"Very little is needed to make a happy life;
it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking." -Marcus Aurelius
Antoninus

Hey folks, I'm hoping everyone gets a chance to tune in to my show
tomorrow.  We're bringing in some really nice, bumpin' tekno courtesy of
S. Ghael via a Final Scratch set tomorrow.  A native of Texas who got
his techno chops in the mid 90's Houston scene, Sandeep has been
spinning for 6+ years.  Most notably he created and hosted the long
running Friday night mix show MKUltra Radio on 91.7fm in Houston.  Now
in the SF Bay Area, California, he's working hard on techno mixes and
productions. Visit http://www.spectrumzero.com for more info.

>i guess the good thing is with this guy is that he didn't just hack your
>number or address even, and just show up at your doorstep one day.  i'd
>say don't be too paranoid, but i've heard stories from different sources,
>so probably true.

he would've had to deal with the wrath of the Griffiths Hall dorm security
monitor - ph33r! :)

Subject: [sfraves] Re: TRUST / MINDCONTROL

At 07:00 AM 4/15/2003 +0000, you wrote:
>There are 4 days left to get your "no bitching" tickets to mindcontrol.
>After that, the price will go up to $20 and any additional complaints
>about the pricing can go to /dev/null

Well, how about "more people at my party" tickets or "expand my community" 
tickets. :)

I saw your effort to offer a "pre-pre-sale" ticket as a gesture of goodwill 
therefore I invited 4 friends who would have otherwise not attended your 
event; net gain from my circle: $55 and that is nothing to "bitch about"..

My intention in writing to SFRaves about this event was not to gripe about 
price, but question where your efforts/collective fall between being 
commercial or a totally community oriented event. I was also interested on 
your view of how much Trust desires to participate with the international 
techno community.

You clearly answered this second question; the first one is more open ended 
and I am still gathering info at the moment...

My comments regarding Chris J's post were directed at the SF techno scene 
as an abstract whole and not any particular individual.. I certainly did 
not mean to disrespect anyone. I stopped by the t-loft on Saturday to chat 
with Chris Yap and Lisa Fox among others, so things are cool.. :)

I do firmly believe that we don't have it all here in SF in regard to 
techno; that there is not enough variety or people pushing boundaries. 
Events seem to follow tradition (albeit at most ~10 years old) rather than 
find a new niche. I am not complaining that the grass is greener elsewhere; 
it is just different colors and other dazzling patterns.

Admittedly, email is not the best medium for gauging my concerns.. I am 
bummed I didn't get a chance to run into you in person yet, etc. Perhaps 
all of this is moot...

Best,
--Mike

Subject: [sfraves] stoked to see Capn Crunch was with sfraves

Feel like I've gone full circle. As a kid growing up in Australia, was definitely inspired by Crunch and his pioneering work. If you want to claim he didn't discover it, at least he was largely responsible for it's quick spread, and is probably the most famous phreaker ever.

The 2600Hz tone is used to seize international trunk lines, and could be used until very recently to seize trunk lines when dialling to 1800 numbers in other countrys, like in south east asia. The man gets his name from the cereal which had a whistle that had a tone close enough to 2600Hz to do the job.

Am stoked to hear that Capn Crunch was with the sfraves crew, and busted out into the rave scene. Certainly interesting to hear the stories from his raving side rather than his phreaking side. Did he serve some time behind bars? I recall that he did, and would like to hear his take on that, as have often wondered how to survive as weedy man behind bars. I think I remember him being quoted once as saying he had to get a member of the 500lb club on his side in order to survive. 500lb club being ppl who could bench 500lbs.

Anyway, livened up my day.

matt

This message was sent through MyMail http://www.mymail.com.au

i am hungry, and in just a moment, i will eat, but i wanted to share with you what people have been randomly feeding me in the last two days....it is just interesting, because it is good food...and also, because, wow, food from a few different random people in  just two days is kind of like, woah! okay, so yesterday, i was at my job, and a lady i never met before gave me a really fancy truffle, then another man who owns a really fancy restaurant gave me his business card and invited me to dine at his restaurant ( i don't think i am going though :)....also, a lady i work with gave me free reign over a big ass american apple pie that had the best pastry shell and gooie stuff all over the freshly baked apples...oh my gosh, okay, then today,  i was bitching, and a man who works behind a food counter gave me my coffee free of charge and a train conductor paid for my lunch...crazy, huh? now, if i had no money in my pocket, i bet none of that would have happened though...things go like that sometimes. :)

Message-ID: <3E9E10B8.4030601@nodeOne.com>

X-Accept-Language: en-us, en
MIME-Version: 1.0
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
 boundary="------------080108010504050104060207"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] bsp and/or thinking on trust and mindcontrol - rr

--------------080108010504050104060207
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

unclassified document 51723
on trust and mindcontrol...

*ideas:*
mindcontrol, like all trust conceptual propaganda, is open to 
interpretation. does it mean that we control your minds? or that you 
control ours? or that all of our minds are being controlled? by the 
government? the media? secret societies? each other? or does it 
emphasize and promote resistance - one's own ability to control her/his 
mind, regardless of external forces and pressure?

we offer suggestions. and sometimes contradicting ones. we ask questions 
that start conversations, to evoke feelings and emotions. the individual 
and community exploration of an idea, and the resulting dialogue is what 
we're after. what does it mean to you? how do you interpret it?


*the event:*
whenever we sit down and decide to organize a trust event, we always ask 
ourselves: What do we want out of this? What would we like people to 
come away with? What would make me want to go to this? -- there are some 
things that are going to happen at this event, in terms of the way the 
'theme' is going to be extended into how you interact with it, that we 
can't talk about, because we don't want to ruin some of the surprises we 
have in store. so just imagine a little bit of what you might possibly 
call interactive/participatory theater going on. things you don't 
expect, and have never seen before. a recent quote from one of our 
planning meetings, "whoa, you guys aren't fucking around"

at assemble, a campout festival we did in wyoming a couple years ago, we 
gave out little tags with the ticketpacks, encoded with symbol sets, in 
triplicate - both a metaphor and practical method for encouraging people 
to 'link' with potential strangers to find the other people tagged with 
same markings. it was fun, and it caused some people to meet and make 
connections that they otherwise might not have made. when you get your 
laminate for mindcontrol you'll find some other fun things stuffed into 
the envelopes... suggestive ideas, pieces of a process...

okay so what else? well, if you know the trust posse - you know that we 
like it hard. we like to turn up the intensity a couple notches. full 
sensory assault. although this is certainly true of mindcontrol in every 
aspect (from the lineup to the colors of the flyer), this is the first 
trust event that'll have no gabber/hardcore in a long long time. we 
still love it, and we still support it - but one of the answers to our 
own questions for this one came up as: we'd like the entire night to be 
irresistably danceable from beginning to end.

but make no mistake. it will be relentless.

we like it live too. we support original and live performance, and 
encourage that above all else. replicate, our summer campout festival 
last year was comprised entirely of live performances plus a few dj's 
playing their own original music.. (that's something like 20 live pa's 
over a weekend, from devoted artists who dragged their gear up into the 
mountains in the middle of nowhere) ... we've managed to get at least 4 
live performances into this one, and we're working on some extra 
surprises there.

we are also pretty serious gearheads, or at the very least, we care 
deeply about technical aspects of the experience. we believe in using 
quality tools. for mindcontrol, as part of feeling somewhat like a big 
oldschool warehouse party - we wanted kick-ass, shake the ground 
soundsystems. massive bass. crisp mid-highs. loud enough that you have 
to go elsewhere to sit around and talk, because at this one - we want 
full dancefloors and people seriously rocking out. that's also why there 
is no chill room and no ambient this time. there will be no escape... no 
rest for the wicked. be prepared.


*expense:*
we've been getting a lot of feedback (and a little static) regarding the 
cost of the event. again, if you know our history, you know that we have 
spent the majority of the last decade organizing free and donation based 
events. our budgets add up to the cost of what it will take to produce 
the vision. in this case, that entails bringing in concert-class 
cabinets from three hours away, for a relatively small underground 
event. we don't do guest lists. we don't make distinctions between 'us' 
and 'you' -- we are all participants. we literally pay for our own 
tickets. the dj's are paying for their own tickets. the people working 
the door are paying for their tickets. people are even footing their own 
travel costs to come out and play from other cities. and this is 
standard procedure for trust events.

for mindcontrol, we are hell-bent on achieving a certain level of 
technical and conceptual quality - and the cost reflects the numbers we 
came up with in order to be able to do it. all that said - we've still 
tried to be accomodating without sacrificing the quality of what we're 
trying to do, and offered a presale break on the cost of participation 
for the rest of this week (ending 4/18) ... so no complaints: go get 
them right now and it shouldn't hurt so much.

 >>>

so. we hope you'll come out to experiment and experience with us. there 
are a lot of great people working really hard to bring down something 
unique and different and memorable, and we want you to be a part of it. 
if the level of intensity is too high or the cost just too steep, take 
heart - we're concepting an all-ambient-ish super-mellow and fun 
loungefest for later in the year, and a classic trust / family donation 
style campout on the smaller scale tip at the end of the summer. so keep 
in touch.

looking forward to being with you.

trust.


--------------080108010504050104060207--

From sfraves-return-101264-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 17 02:49:51 2003

Subject: [sfraves] old school TRUST events and audio


I have started the process of going through all the past
flyers/pictures/recordings to create a definitive time line of trust
history.  For those of you that are unfamiliar with trust events, here's
a window into what we have been doing all this time.

The events section of the web site now reflects a partial history of
events.  Photos and flyer scans to come (hopefully tomorrow).

http://www.trust-components.com/events

There is a new page devoted to dj sets from these events:

http://www.trust-components.com/audio

Some sets worth noting/downloading:

* Snuggles and maddgroove from 1994 (with very dated mc-ing)

* Dan efex playing "hard" trance from 1994

* One of John Carel's last storming techno sets, 1998

* Brian Behlendorf playing ambient and dub in 1998

Enjoy!

-e-

From sfraves-return-101265-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 17 03:15:17 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101265-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 96393 invoked by uid 1103); 17 Apr 2003 03:15:17 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 96377 invoked from network); 17 Apr 2003 03:15:17 -0000
Message-ID: <20030417031513.12108.qmail@web41808.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 16 Apr 2003 20:15:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] wonderful transforming Target raver pants

this here is a remarkable so so def rant:

so, Target has raver pants now. not just the big baggy
jncos, also the cool smart well-designed nifty
transformer pants. one minute they're pants, next
minute they're shorts. the good pants. with lots of
pockets. you know what I mean.

so, this inspired a thought or two:


1. first time I saw raver pants at Target, it bugged
the hell out of me. I was like, dude, this can't be
something Target knows about! I have to be different!
then I remembered I'm such a freak that I couldn't be
normal if I tried. thus my insecurities were quelled.


2. it's awesome that Target has these pants. I could
have got them online or at True on Haight Street for
$150. instead I got them at Target for $14.99.


3. what I can't figure out, tho, is why there isn't
more co-branding between clothing labels and record
labels. saw a thing on MTV about how every rapper has
their own clothing line. the reason: clothes sell
more. Outkast guy: "with clothes you're not talking
about five million units, ten million units; you're
talking about a hundred million, a hundred and fifty
million." even read a thing last year where Hype
Williams, who makes a lot of high-profile rap videos
and is kinda responsible for the current dominant
visual style on MTV, explaining that, with ppl like
Versace planning their fall lines around rap videos,
it's a situation like there was in the 1940s, when the
fashion and music industries organized themselves into
mutually beneficial cartels.

now rap sells way more than electronic dance music, at
least in the US, but all the same -- picture somebody
like Oakenfold, or Sasha & Digweed when they ruled the
world. it'd be trivial for folks like that to attach
clothing lines to their record labels. but even the
overwhelmingly focused Roni Size and his Full Cycle
crew haven't done anything along those lines. they
have founded a community center, where kids can learn
how to use music gear. I think that's a cultural thing
-- in England they get free health care and if you
don't have a job the government just gives you money.
it's a great country. so perhaps the entrepreneurial
incentive is less powerful there, and community
concerns are more of a priority. who can say?

anyway, it kinda boggles the mind that I can buy these
pants for $15 from Target, and I can buy them for $150
from planetxusa, but I can't buy them from my favorite
DJ for some price in between. you know what's even
weirder about that? think about how fashion and music
organize along the same lines. junglists always wear
camo, candy kids listen to plur trance, etc. here's a
fun experiment -- go into a record store, check out
the different ppl at the different turntables, and
guess based on their clothes what music they're
listening to.


4. another fun experiment, unrelated to anything --
make a list of things you love, and next to each thing
you love, an opposite thing you hate. for instance: "I
love ravers. I hate hipsters." found this in a book.
the idea is, connect with your passions. the book was
actually called "retire early, retire rich." it
claimed that the keys to wealth are the willingness to
study and the willingness to work for free. theory
was, if you want to get rich you have to study, and
you have to work for free, and the only way you'll be
able to deal with doing that is if you study your
passions and work on your passions for free.

actually this is kind of a tangent but it bears
explaining. say you went and got a high-paying job.
whoops! if you did that, you screwed up, because
that's actually a very bad idea. I can tell you this
is true because once upon a time I had a series of
high-paying jobs, and I hated them all. but the real
reason it's a bad idea is not because it isn't fun.
it's because whenever you need more money, you have to
work some more. if you make something people will buy,
you continue to make money after the work is done.
Stephen King writes a book, following his own peculiar
and indisputably warped passions, and what happens? it
sells for fifty years and he can't even scratch his
ass in the morning when he wakes up without making
some moola.

this is the other reason I can't figure out why there
aren't any DJ/fashion cartels. Cream and the Ministry
of Sound might have figured this out, but if so,
they're the only ones.


5. yet another reason this mysterious absence so
thoroughly baffles me: DJs use image to promote
themselves anyway. they all do it, even the ones who
pretend not to. those folks aren't any different,
they're just promoting an "I'm too cool to care how I
look" type of image. you know? whatever. obviously, if
people buy into the image, they might just buy what
the person in the image is wearing. I mean, if
Oakenfold Sunglasses(tm) had existed last year, it
would have made millions.

I'm not saying ooh money ooh money. money isn't
everything. art is something too. but I'm thinking of
somebody. I won't name any names but I've known him
since I was four, and he's the most art-oriented
musician I know. very talented, very smart, owns and
runs four record labels promoting various experimental
styles. writes music software too. thing is? he's a
trust fund baby. his grandpa's millions fund his
record labels. they also funded his degree in
electronic music. (I can't even tell you how jealous I
am of this lucky muddafudda, but that's another
story.) so, he could easily be losing money on all
those projects, even his day job, and it wouldn't make
any difference to him.


6. it's awesome that you can buy raver pants in Target
nowadays, because this propagation of raver
culture/fashion/etc. means the scene in America is
catching up to the scene in Europe. (this is actually
also the only good thing about the rave act.) one day
the scene in America might even be big enough to
support a music industry which employs thousands, if
not millions, just like in the UK. well actually given
the size of this country it already probably employs
millions, but anyway.


7. this has nothing to do with anything, but I just
found out that Sandra Collins started DJing in
Phoenix.


Giles

X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103

Subject: Re: [sfraves] wonderful transforming Target raver pants

    I think that the issue here, and the reason behind this "absense" of rave 
culture in the real consumer market, the "pop" scene is the fear and the 
unmotavation of a lot of the "big cats" in the rave and electronic dance 
music industry. It seems to me that  a lot of people don't see electronic 
dance music, clothing, and labels as a huge investment anymore because of the 
dieing of the rave scene in recent years due to goverment actions and 
enforced laws regurading drugs and safety issues. We no longer have so many 
EDM fanatics who want to work for free and have lots of extra money because 
most of us have become a little bit poorer econmically in the years, largely 
because of our habit of partying and drugs. And largely because of 
Corporation pregedous agaist ravers, not allowing radical hairstyles, 
clothing, or piearcings at the workplace, in fear that it is "distracting". 
As a result us ravers hate conservative corporations of that sort... thus 
limiting our windows of oppertunity in life. Meaning therefor the EDM culture 
does not have the big buisness boom of pop culture because all of the people 
around it don't have as much money to spend. The people who should be making 
these buisnesses no long have the money or the inspiration to do so... and 
the people who would be buying these products generally don't have as much 
money as people who buy "pop" products (clothing,music etc.)
    In cluclusion I sincerily hope your "trust fund" friend goes out and does 
all he can to push EDM music and clothing into the pop culture. I think the 
scene will just dry up eventually if nobody goes out and promotes it to new 
unexperienced audiences. But as for your question "why is there this absense 
of big buisness?" and your astonishment as to why someone hasn't done all 
this before... I think you have your answer, the rave industry and the EDM 
industry alike have been oppressed by prejudices, stereo-types and even laws, 
therefor as a whole our scene declining, ecomically... we don't buy things as 
often and we don't create buisnesses and stick to them through all the hard 
work because a lot of us are having a hard enough time "just getting by".

************** 
this May 2, [the 40th st warehosue in Oakland] is hosting a May 
Day event. for those who don't know- may day is a traditional 
pagan holiday celebrate the coming of fertility and spring. It is 
also The International Working Class Holiday ( 2 things worthy of 
recognition.. and celebration) for more info on the subject go to 
our links. We'd like to make this a giant potluck- open stage- 
house party type thing. If any one has music, performance, 
artwork, puppet shows, or information they'd like to get out about 
current labor movement so if anyone is interested or has any ideas

Hello!

Just a quick reminder of tonight's benefit event for Expo for the 
Artist & Musician 2003.

http://artsandmedia.net/cgi-bin/dc/expo/2003/03/05_minna_benefit

It happens at 111 Minna Street Gallery (between 2nd. St. and New Montgomery).

** 7-9pm is the opening reception ... $5
	... with FREE hors d'oeuvres from the Patisserie Cafe
	and Gladis Productions.

	Featured DJs: Zeph and Ren the Vinyl Archaeologist.

** 9pm-2am is the dance party ($8-$20), featuring DJs ...
	-Tomas (XLR8R)
	-Ms. E (Future Breaks)
	-Jonah Sharp (Spacetime Continuum)
	-Corey Black (Imperial Dub)

Also, we'll have some fantastic Expo organizations on hand:

ArtSF -- Dedicated to founding a multi-faceted new San Francisco arts 
community space

ArtSpan -- Building a bridge between artists and the greater San 
Francisco community

Electric W.O.M.B. (Women in the Music & Media Business) -- Creating 
community and promoting opportunity for emerging and established 
generations

Independent Arts & Media -- Supporting public arts and community 
media in an era of dumbed-down Pavlovian infotainment

Media Alliance -- Fighting for democratic media in an era of 
corporate consolidation

Planet Drum Foundation -- Saving the world through ecologically 
sustainable culture and community!!

Rhythm & Motion Dance Center -- Freedom for the body and the spirit 
through dance and movement

SoundSafe -- Dedicated to supporting music and arts rehearsal and 
performance space in San Francisco


****Sponsored by the Craigslist Foundation, Remix Magazine, SF Bay 
Guardian and True-Skool.org****

Audio-Visual
      Free Expression *featuring the Trouble cru*

      Trouble presents:
      Kid606 (Tigerbeat6, Ipecac, Mille Plateaux, Trouble) - dj set only
      Uprock (kelpandcircuits, Tristero, Trouble) - live
      Lance Grabmiller (Praemedia, Grinder, Underground Inc.) - live
      Philip Sherburne (Trouble,Cops Fear Pimp Turf War, XLR8R) - dj

      DJ Random (Full Circle)
      Lucretia (So What, Death Guild)
      Visuals: Scott Pagano

      375 eleventh street
      http://www.dnalounge.com/0xC0DE/
      http://www.dnalounge.com/
      9pm-afterhours
      21+ w/id
      sliding scale donation requested
      The Campaign for Audiovisual Free Expression (CAFE) empowers the
creative
      community in cyberspace by protecting the public's access to and use
of
      audiovisual technologies. The Electronic Frontier Foundation is the
      leading civil liberties organization working to protect rights in
the
      digital world. Founded in 1990, EFF actively encourages and
challenges
      industry and government to support free expression and privacy
online. EFF
      is a member-supported organization and maintains one of the
most-linked-to
      websites in the world at http://www.eff.org/

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Need a BB system similar to Slashcode

Hey all-

Weird question but I figured someone here may know-

I'm looking for a bulletin-board/news/project tracking system similar to slashcode.
(Slashcode would work just fine but my needs do not require something that beefy)

I just want to have several largely static "news items" (in reality-projects)-
To which I will add "comments" (in reality-status updates)

Anyone seen such a beast?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Need a BB system similar to Slashcode


Hey Nathan

I highly reccomend zope:  www.zope.org

It's powering the new starrave hyperreal calendar interfaces and does tons
of nifty stuff from blogs, to email, to content management.  Plus it's
open source and written in python.

If you need hosting of such a thing let me know, it's running on our GG
servers too.

-e-

>
> Weird question but I figured someone here may know-

> (Slashcode would work just fine but my needs do not require something that beefy)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Need a BB system similar to Slashcode

I don't know if this suits your needs or not, but I concur with Ed re:
zope. If that doesn't work for your needs, here are a few other options:

1. squishdot (squishdot.org)

2. Powered by XMB 1.6 Magic Lantern Final
Developed By Aventure Media & The XMB Group © 2002

3. YaBB SE is a PHP/MySQL port of the popular forum software YaBB (yet
another bulletin board). Incorporating the same intuitive user interface,
and several of the most popular modifications from YaBB's Boardmod
program. After an extensive period of public beta testing, YaBB SE 1.5.1
final is out! Thanks go out to everyone who helped making this release
possible.

4. Tiki	Tiki is full featured content management system suited to many
types of online communities. Features include news, topics, wiki, polls,
trackers, image galleries, froums, blogs, webmail, and much more. Using
PHP, MySQL and Smarty.

5. Liferay Enterprise Portal	Liferay Enterprise Portal is a Java/J2EE
portal system that provides personalization (like Yahoo!), web email (like
Hotmail), document library, message boards (like Jive), shopping
(e-commerce), Wiki and many other web tools all available in one place.

6. Liferay Enterprise Portal	Liferay Enterprise Portal is a Java/J2EE
portal system that provides personalization (like Yahoo!), web email (like
Hotmail), document library, message boards (like Jive), shopping
(e-commerce), Wiki and many other web tools all available in one place.

7. phpBB	phpBB is the worlds leading Open Source flat style
discussion forum software. It includes all the features you expect to find
in todays top of the line software.

Good luck,
Karina

Message-ID: <20030418004950.64519.qmail@web40706.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 17 Apr 2003 17:49:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: Susan Gwartney <sooziqueue@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] once again, the meaning of PLUR

if you are the kind of person who doesn't care whether
you influence people in a positive or negative way,
then maybe you haven't lived long enough to figure out
that what goes around, comes around.  just wait.

i guess my point is that we have a lot of power within
us, the power not only to choose our own paths in
life, but also the power to recognize that maybe we've
wasted a lot of energy on things that are not within
our control.  we also have the power to forgive
ourselves, so maybe we can stop staring at the past
with regret and start feeling empowered to change the
future.  

i see myself and a lot of my peers moving a positive
direction, people who are finding value in their work,
in their relationships, in their community, and taking
responsibility for their own lives.  it makes me feel
good to know that i care enough to see that.  i see it
making a difference.  it makes the world worth living
in.

it validates the struggle.

if you've lost faith in the world, then maybe you need
to show a little.  and i don't mean to get on a
soapbox and lecture; i am only saying this because i
myself had forgotten and needed to be reminded too.  

there is no free ride.  you can pay now or pay later. 
if your life has lost meaning then maybe you've got
work to do.

for those of you out there who didn't need to hear
this, kudos for truly understanding the meaning of
PLUR.  more power, strength, and love to you for
making your own lives worth living.

peace,
sooz

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) on the road again

from I 80-90, near the ohio turnpike ...

well, i hit the road again today, on the way to the east coast, 
finally.  before i left, though, i got a chance to do something i'd 
always wanted to do, see a cubs game at wrigley field.  i'm not a 
huge baseball fan, but i consider the park a part of chicago's 
culture that i couldn't miss out on, and i've wanted to go there ever 
since '89, when they played the giants in the playoffs, which turned 
out to be the bay bridge series, the earthquake, etc.  so i watched 
the game, they won against cincy 16-3, and then i was outieeee! 
ROTFL!

illinois has been fun, but one thing is, IMNSHO, people drive like 
asses here.  chicago is just a massive metropolitan area, and though 
they have better infrastructure as far as freeways and public 
transportation than we do, it's simply not enough.  rush hour it 
takes 45 minutes minimum to get out of the city if you're going 
anywhere, and when you get to north chicago, there are all kinds of 
extra highways with tons of stoplights and somehow, you end up having 
to stop at every single one of them.  the way drivers handle the 
gridlock here is to go as fast as they possibly can whenever they 
can, to the point of cutting people off and passing on the right 
side, which we're used to the latter in california, but bay area 
drivers are much safer.

after a harsh winter with tons of ice, snow, salt, and a minor 
fender-bender, Fog-GTI has a well-earned quasi-Road-Warrior look. 
i'll probably take a picture tomorrow when it's light out and the 
rain has dried up (as if i don't have enough pictures of my silly 
car) ... and maybe have some pictures of DC, maybe Philly if i have 
time.

peace dawgs, can't believe i'm posting so much ya know?!@  Osby! 
lIkE i"M sOo pSyChIc **0O0***

DF

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-help a female dj out!

Practice... It's all about practice.  Practice for a few hours, and do it
often.  The more time you spend beat matching, the sooner you will get
better.  After all that practice, one day it will just click, and you will
get your ear trained.
My best piece of advice is to NOT fingerf*ck your records.  You just end up
having to fix what you just moved with your finger.  The pitch control is
there for a reason. Use it.  There isn't anything your finger can do that
the pitch control can't do better, and with much greater precision.
peace

cF

  Newsbrief: CIA Propaganda Radio Rap Song Links Saddam to Demon Weed

Ah, those wacky guys at the CIA! According to BBC Monitoring, which selects 
and translates information from media sources worldwide, a Kuwait-based, 
CIA-sponsored radio station has been playing a rap-style parody of deposed 
Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein in which the US's demon du jour brags about 
smoking pot.

To the tune of Coolio's "Gangsta's Paradise," a Saddam impersonator raps a 
message from the missing leader in English and Arabic:

"Bush wanna kick me, I don't know why and if I call him, he does me goodbye.

"Smoking weed and getting high. I know the devil is by my side.

"My days are finished and I will die -- all I need is chili fries."

The parody, being broadcast on so-called Radio Tikrit, also has Hussein 
proclaiming such bon mots as "If you don't like me I will kill you, I am 
Saddam," and "I am so dead, I am so bad, I am big daddy, this is my game, I 
don't have any feelings, I don't have any shame."

Your tax dollars at work.

http://www.drcnet.org/wol/283.html#saddammarijuana

At 02:40 PM 4/18/2003 -0700, knowmad AE wrote:
>there an RG gathering planned for this rare and
>wonderful occurrence?

As usual, Fraser has an agenda:  world peace.  He has, as you know, always 
seen the rave movement as a source for positive transformation and change 
on a global scale.  He wants to meet with some sympathetic folks in the 
community to discuss his ideas and generate action. He will also be 
speaking at some events in SF and LA.

I'm not sure what exactly I'm going to do:  probably a relatively small 
meeting with some peace activists, community people and the like at my home.

Love,

Apollo
