Subject: [sfraves] Which cartridge & stylus do you like?


I'm going to be getting some tables in soon, and am deciding on
cartridges.   The tables will be getting hooked up to my roomates
mackie 824 monitors & mackie powered subs so I'm looking for something
that will compliment those in sound quality yet also let me beat on
as I'm a pretty amateur DJ.    I've heard good things of Ortofon DJ or
Nightclubs, and also a few model Shures.   What are people's experiences
w/those and should I get a spherical tip or ellipt?  I know there are a lot
of opinions on this but I'd just like to guage what people out here think.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Which cartridge & stylus do you like?

i'd recommend skipping the Ortofons, saving up a little more, and getting
Stanton Trackmaster II's. Of all the needles i've used, these are the ones
i've settled on. good low-end and over-all sound, and nice tracking, even
for light scratching.

you're welcome to come by my place and check them out if you'd like.

-philip-

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Which cartridge & stylus do you like?


On Sun, 20 Apr 2003, philip diaz wrote:
-&e->i'd recommend skipping the Ortofons, saving up a little more, and getting
-&e->Stanton Trackmaster II's. Of all the needles i've used, these are the ones
-&e->i've settled on. good low-end and over-all sound, and nice tracking, even
-&e->for light scratching.

WHAT!?!?!?!

I don't like the way they sound (kinda bloated in the bass, don't punch
right with harder music like the Ortofons do), and they track like shit
(just played on a pair last night for maybe four mixes before I switched
em out with the carts I was packing cause I got sick of the needle
skipping on the first beat *my biggest pet peeve* while cueing up
records).

I like the Ortofon Concorde/DJs at parties when I play techno (they track
incredibly well at high volume, and sound great on big systems), and the
Shure M44-7s when I'm at home just fucking around or playing records for
something to listen to (they track well for scratching and fast cueing,
sound better playing older records and LPs, and can be run as light as
2grams to allow for minimum vinyl wear).

andyw

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] STICKY!... a hearty thanks!

Hi all,
Just wanted to say a HUGE thank you to all of you that came thru and 
supported STICKY! We had a freakin' blast, didn't we? Everyone that I talked 
to all night had a grin from ear to ear.. You all were pretty respectful and 
I can't thank you enough. The space was incredible, the sound was great, and 
how about that Andrew Phelan? Holy Shiz.. You rawked it something fierce 
brutha, Chicago Stylee. 4 corner sound thumpin' it tough, Newcastle and 
Wider pear cider in full effect, tons of fruit, fingerfood as far across the 
bar as we could get! (and how about those krispy treats?)
Thank you for all your generous donations, it eased the hit a little bit.. 
Thank you all for your incredible vibe.. this was definately one of the 
best, most intense parties I've had the pleasure of putting out there. I 
want to thank the staff in specific, without all of you, it would have never 
went down like it did.
First, my partners in crime.. Isaac Haze and Kevin James, thank you oh so 
much.. it took a grip of work, but we did it! The ever-so-nice doorstaff and 
greeters -- my wife Nicole and best pal Tom, my beautiful and quick pooring 
beer server -- Miss Bethie, our kitchen specialist -- Misty, the sound team 
-- Gabe and Kevin, the ever popular and always humble Viberation visual team 
-- Terry and Kevin and last but certainly not least, the unbelieveably 
talented guests that performed and kept the place filled with sound and 
style -- George and Delaney {also known as DJ2, Tony, Naz, and Andrew 
Phelan! You all were simple incredible and definately rocked us all night 
long!
One for my history books, a 420 celebration to not be forgotten.
Thanks to everyone that came and shared, I got great photos!
See ya'll on the next round..
-John
Justin Hale
Secret Society -- The South Bay's Greatest Monday Night Bash
The Legendary Club Savoy
3546 Flora Vista Avenue
Santa Clara, CA 95051
408.244.6909
Secret Society continues in loving memory of Chris "Laffy" Taflanidis. We 
miss you brother. ESCT

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Which cartridge & stylus do you like?

They redisigned the ortophon's pins so that you wont have that problem
anymore. doesnt mean I like them, just claifying that fact.

Since the tonearm of the technics are eng'd with a tech headshell mounted
cart in mind, it would only make sense to use a headshell mounting car. I
agree with you there. But besides the stanton trackmasters and
groovemasters, any old needle will do fine. I would reccomend the shure 35
line of needles. Cheap, durable and easy to mount. And the replacemtn styli
won't take a huge chunk of your paychek. And they sound as good or better
than other needles on the market.


-andy

Subject: [sfraves] 4.22:earth, sex, brains and dj's


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
under the radar //
http://utr.praemedia.com
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

[ april 22: under the radar // at 26Mix ]
UNDER THE RADAR at 26Mix
http://www.26mix.com/
3024 Mission Street @ 26th Street
San Francisco
9:00pm - Close
$5.00

Sex and intellect for earth day!

LIVE PERFORMANCES:

THE LOVEMAKERS
The Lovemakers offer up electropop dance songs punctuated with boy-girl 
vocals, electric violin, vibrator solos, and shoegazing Robert Smith guitar 
lines. Although the sweat-drenched stage antics might fool you, a typical 
conversation with TLM will generally bring you into the depths of 
synthesizer geekdom, classical music muses, or most frequently, smack in the 
middle of J.R.R. Tolkien's middle earth! A preoccupation with the fantastic 
colours TLM's approach to music making, taking inspiration from many fronts: 
80s pop legends The Human League, Bjork, Le Tigre, and Oakland's own 
burgeoning synth-happy music scene. According to Lord Grunge (of Pittsburg 
Hip Hop duo Grand Buffet), the Lovemakers sound "like a pink Ferrari driving 
through a mountain of cocaine."

MATT DAVIGNON
Matt Davignon of Oakland, California has been performing and recording his 
own brand of experimental music for the last 9 years. Primarily self taught, 
he creates most of his music (both live and recorded) through improvisation, 
often imitating everyday sound phenomena or focusing on often-overlooked 
aural characteristics. Matt does not own or seek expensive equipment. He 
prefers to make do with what is already within reach. Instruments he uses 
include turntable, tape, sampling/looping devices, cd, found objects, field 
recordings, prepared acoustic guitar, keyboard, slide whistles and vocal 
sounds.

TRI-CORNERED TENT SHOW
Almost everyday in the news there are stories about how a group of 
scientists after so many decades of painstaking research and work create a 
new drug or make new discoveries, but how many times does one read about a 
group of musicians that have done the same thing? A trio of experimental and 
improvisational musicians called the Tri-Cornered Tent Show has done just 
that. It has taken them the last part of the last century (25 years to be 
exact) of dedicated practice, research, and patience that brings them to 
announce the release of "Maze Above the Abyss", "Tri-Cornered Tent Show", 
and "Beneath the Mountains of Madness" all encased in 3 compact discs. The 
musical journey began with initial tracks being recorded using the ancient 
anti-deluvian technology of electronics from the 70's. Though methodical 
deciphering of the Lovcraft short story "The music of Eric Zann", other 
related stories expanded upon Lovecraft's Greater Cthulu Mythos they began 
recording free improvisation and orchestrated sound sculpture over those 25 
years to create the projects now available on the new bay area label 
Edgetone Records. Now, they come out from their exile held up in a 
well-insulated dank little studio in the depths of Richmond California. By 
the shear force of will and their dedication to the world of improvisation, 
they have a unique set of music to merit them worthy of attention. In a 
world of pop can music they could teach a class in patience and creation.

DJ PERFORMANCES
JULIAN DESTRUKT (Tokyo Electric) and ZYGOTE (under the radar //)

VIDEO SCREENING
Works featured from Stephen Williams (scrod media / blasthaus) and a 
premiere of C-Trl's "Glitch Porn".

UPCOMING SHOWS: DAT POLITICS, BALL2000 and MORE...........stay tuned.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

UNDER THE RADAR DJ Night at Julip
http://www.julipsf.com/
839 Geary Street ( between Larkin and Hyde )

no admission

Sounds from a Pretty World: Zygote and Friends serve up Plunder Jazz,

Come early, as the night is usually packed out with super models and jet 
setters of the IDM world........

Special Guest April 23rd DJ WRONG?

> Wider pear cider in full effect, tons of fruit, fingerfood as far across the
> bar as we could get! (and how about those krispy treats?)

> went down like it did.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves]Wicked Party: Small Review

Well, I ended up going to the wicked party this past friday.  When me and my 
friend arrived, there was a line around the building.  It felt like a 
combination of the movies and a massive.  I brought a bottle of coke 
half-filled with hennessy, so I wasnt trippn about the wait.  By the time we 
got to the front of the line, I was feelin pretty good!

I was totally happy with the Venue, it was off tha hook.  I really liked the 
space and the fact that there were three bars made it convinient to get a 
drink.  I hate the fact that bars have to shut down at 2am, what about those 
of us that wanna hang out until the sun comes up?  Anyway, me and my friend 
started dancing.  If anyone noticed a tall white guy in a black and white 
plaid shirt and a short black girl with jeans and straightened long 
hair...that was me and Reverie.  I didn't see anyone from SFraves, although 
it was SO packed Im not surprised.  I danced for hours and I was really 
feelin the music, I never really pay much attention to the lineup, I just 
love to dance, so sorry I cant give any info about the DJs.  Anyway, the 
dancefloor was clearing up at around 5am and I was down to dance some more, 
but I was just too tired and the music didnt make me feel compelled to 
dance.  So me and Reverie bounced out, smoked a blunt, had some breakfast 
and went home.

All in all it was a good party though.

fable....

http://www.angelfire.com/hiphop/fablefour

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 1649 invoked from network); 21 Apr 2003 21:46:40 -0000
Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030421142027.025dfa50@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.1
Date: Mon, 21 Apr 2003 14:50:18 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_14069601==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] A Sticky 420

--=====================_14069601==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Props to Justin Hale and company for giving us a proper 420 
celebration.  This was one very fine underground.  Great venue on a San 
Francisco side street.   Spacious dance floor.  Rooftop garden where one 
could talk and look at the moon and stars.  And that trippy ladder.  I 
don't personally do ladders, but somehow, in my altered state of mind, I 
managed to propel myself down the thing.  Loved the marble shower...

The underground.  For eight bucks there were heavily laced jello drinks -- 
sticky fingers indeed -- free beer, cider, water, candy, and fruit.  Most 
important, there were good friends and vibe.  As Happy observed, it's been 
a dark winter for many of us.  This springtime party was a refreshing 
reminder that we are all still alive,  we can still dance to celebrate that 
life, and that this time of year is pregnant with hope, rebirth and the 
promise of new beginnings.  Certainly the underground is alive and well, 
and I am thankful for that.

We arrived just in time for DJ2's live set.  George and his partner are an 
extremely talented duo -- just released their second successful record -- 
and they didn't disappoint at Sticky.  The high point of the evening on the 
dance floor for me was Andrew Phalen's set.  To my mind, Andrew is one of 
the most talented house DJs in San Francisco.  He is a masterful mixer and 
a true artist.  He brings to the City the soulful flavor of Chicago-style 
house, and he moved my body and spirit.  Hope to see Andrew spinning at 
many more parties in future.

Much love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

which Oracle totally took over & started playin' all this Sick Techno!  =

Wow, what a night! I too would like to thank everyone who came out and supported us on Saturday. We truly had an awesome time with ALL of you who came out and supported us. I seriously can't remember the last party that I've been a part of that ran so smoothly and problem free!  The music was great, the vibe was tight, and so many good friends and smiling faces all night, what more could you ask for ? Nights like these are truly why I love throwing parties and being a part of this scene.     As for the music what can I say, DJ2 , Andrew Phelan, Tony and Naz all rocked the place and kept the dance floor packed. Thank you so much guys, really, you were all incredible! Also a huge thank you to Gabe Black my sound partner for the night, between booth of our systems hooked together, we bumped the hell out of that place! Thanks to Terry and Kevin for the awsome visuals, and everyone who helped with staffing shifts, set up and tear down, and of course kitchen duty. Last but definitely not least thank you to John and Isaac my partners, all of our hard work and love sure paid off with a very rewarding night of friends and music, I still have that wonderfull warm and fuzzy feeling all over!    Also, all sets were recorded and as soon as I check them for sound quality I will be looking for a place on line to host them, if anyone has any suggestions or available hosting space please let me know so we can make them available for download. Thanks again guys, you all rock! Respect,Kevin James P.S. I still have copies of my new mix cd Acid Head left over, so if anyone would like one feel free to hit me up with a mailing address and I'll send one out to you.

sfravers, i apologize if this has already been posted but i didn't see it

Music Promoters Fear Anti-Drug Clause
They say it could bring crackdowns on many events
By Molly Freedenberg
Ventura County Star (CA), April 17, 2003

Buried deep within the 118-page Amber Alert bill is a provision that has
brought fear to the music and entertainment industry.

The bill, designed to heighten public awareness of missing children, also
includes a provision that would make it easier to prosecute club owners and

promoters who sponsor events where there is drug use.

The provision would prohibit an individual from knowingly "making available

for use, or profiting from any place for the purpose of manufacturing,
distributing, or using any controlled substance, and for other purposes."

The bill was conceived to expand the so-called crack-house law passed in
1986, to crack down on rave parties where drug use is rampant. But some say

the wording of the proposed law is so broad that anyone could be targeted.
"All you have to do is prove drug use is going on at an establishment to go

after the organizers," said Bill Piper, spokesman for Drug Policy Alliance.

"In theory, they could go after you if one person smokes marijuana at your
barbecue, the law is written so loosely, you could face 20 years in jail
and
a half-million-dollar fine."

Chip Unruhe, a spokesman for the bill's primary sponsor, Sen. Joe Biden,
D-Delaware, said opponents' fears are a result of misinformation.

"The bill is really a common-sense tool for prosecutors to go after
unscrupulous promoters" who endanger kids for profit, he said.

California Sen. Dianne Feinstein co-sponsored the bill but could not be
reached for comment.

The crack-house law has been around since 1986. Last year, Biden and others

tried to pass the RAVE Act -- Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to Ecstasy
--
which failed. A version of the RAVE Act was proposed in the Senate and
House
this year as the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act, the text of which has

been added in the provision to the Amber Alert bill.
The RAVE Act originally was conceived to bolster the crack-house law. It
specifically was in response to a case in New Orleans where hospital
workers
complained of an increase in the number of overdosed patients each time a
particular promoter held an event, Unruhe said. The judge in that case
wanted
a more specific law on the books.

The crack-house law applies to an indoor space used repeatedly for the use,

sale or manufacture of drugs. In contrast, the provision in the Amber Alert

bill can be applied to a one-time event such as a party at a private home
or
in a vacant field, or outside events such as concerts. It could even
conceivably apply to a party held in a rented church basement.
The provision is meant to target club owners who shut off water supplies to

sell overpriced water to dehydrated drug users, Unruhe said. Another
potential target would be club owners who instruct ambulance drivers to
take
patients to cross-town hospitals to avoid having those who overdose being
connected to particular events. Unruhe said he had heard of such tactics.

Unruhe emphasized the bill is not intended to stop music or dancing.

Piper said the crack-house law already deals with the kind of situations
Unruhe describes. And current drug laws allow the prosecution of those who
use or deal drugs. But the new provision isn't about cracking down on
drugs,
Piper said. "It's the events they don't like."

He said the law doesn't protect innocent club owners and lowers the bar on
proving knowledge or endorsement of drug use.

A common fear, he said, is that prosecutors will argue the sale of glow
sticks and bottled water -- often associated with dancing at raves but also

with the use of the drug ecstasy, MDMA -- or the presence of trained
paramedics will prove "knowledge and encouragement" of drug use.

These were part of the evidence in two recent crack-house cases, said
Piper,
including the one in New Orleans, which led to the creation of the RAVE
Act.

Hans Riemer, of Rock the Vote, said the bill could be a "blanket attack on
youth culture."
Piper also fears political rallies, hip-hop shows, gay and lesbian clubs,
marijuana legalization events and other "politically incorrect" gatherings
could be next on the list.

Although the bill has raised concerns in the industry, few local club
owners
had heard of it, including representatives from Nicholby's, Ventura Theater

and Seaside Park.

But Piper said he doesn't think that will be the case for long. He is
getting
calls from worried promoters, nightclub owners and people associated with
the
electronic music scene. He expects opposition to grow fast.





---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

(mmmm Chambly White with an omelette)

Tomorrow, Tuesday, is Earth Day -- a tribute to mother earth that is more 
often than not forgotten these days.

For events and information, go to:  http://www.earthday.net/

Also, below is an interesting article and quiz.

Much love,

Apollo



On Earth Day, what's your 'Ecological Footprint?'
Karen Youso, Star Tribune

http://www.startribune.com/stories/389/3834234.html

Published April 22, 2003 EARVAR

Everybody loves the Earth. And why not? It supplies us with food, a place 
to live, places to go and ways to get there.

All this human activity puts a demand on the planet. That's not a problem 
as long as the demand doesn't exceed nature's ability to supply.

The question on this 33rd anniversary of the first Earth Day is: Are we 
taking more from nature than nature can give? Or, more specifically, are we 
drawing more than our fair share of the Earth's resources?

One way to address the question is by calculating an "ecological 
footprint." The bigger your footprint, the more of Earth's resources are 
needed to support you as you live, eat and move about. Add your footprint 
to everybody else's and you get the total human demand on nature.

Nature, in this case, is figured as the acres of Earth's land and water 
that produce food, absorb so-called "greenhouse" gases from fossil fuels 
and provide space for roads and homes. In other words, the part of Earth 
that supplies us.

Take the number of productive acres and divide it by the number of people 
on Earth, and you get nature's available capital. according to Mathis 
Wackernagel of Redefining Progress, a think tank in Oakland, Calif.

Every person on the planet would get 4.5 acres before overdrawing on 
nature's bank, Wackernagel says. But some say that people should have 
access to the amount that exists in their country, which doesn't always fit 
the average. For example, productive land in the United States allows about 
14 acres per resident. Yet the average American footprint approaches 24 
acres per person.

We aren't alone in taking more than Earth can replenish. The average German 
uses 12 acres, Australians 19 acres per person. As the human footprint 
increases, resources for future generations and wildlife diminish.

"You may not need elephants to live, but some people don't want to live in 
a world without elephants," Wackernagel said.

It's a choice, he said. What kind of world do we want to live in?

The challenge is to find quality of life within nature's means.

Want to calculate your personal Ecological Footprint? Take the Ecological 
Footprint Quiz (it takes about 5 minutes) at 
http://www.earthday.net/footprint/info.asp.

According to Redefining Progress, the Ecological Footprint for the average 
American is 23.5 acres. Here's an example of how it's divided and ways to 
reduce it:

FOOD: 5.5 acres

The average American eating meat at least once a week requires 5.5 acres to 
allow for food production and energy used to transport, process, package 
and store it. About three-quarters of the typical American's diet is 
prepackaged, processed food that comes from farther than 200 miles away.

To reduce: Eat less meat. Plants generally require less land, energy and 
other resources. Otherwise, buy more locally produced meats, preferably 
from small-scale, organic or so-called sustainable farmers.

Much of the energy in the food system is spent on transportation, 
processing, packaging and storage. Grow food yourself, shop at farmers 
markets or buy directly from farmers.

SHELTER: 5.1 acres

This measures the energy and resources for constructing, heating, cooling 
and maintaining a dwelling. This number is for a 1,000 to 
1,500-square-foot, free-standing house with energy conservation and two 
occupants.

To reduce: A smaller-sized home with more occupants means the resources 
used go farther. Adding to the family, however, isn't an effective strategy 
to minimize your impact. Don't oversize your home. Also, living in a condo, 
townhouse or apartment tends to decrease your footprint.

MOBILITY: 4.3 acres

This is how walking, biking, trains, planes and automobiles affect the 
planet. It reflects the space and resources used for building byways, and 
manufacturing and operating vehicles.

The average American drives about 14,000 miles a year, or 270 miles a week, 
in a vehicle that delivers 15 to 25 miles per gallon and occasionally has 
passengers.

Americans spend an average of 4.7 hours per person on commercial airlines 
every year. This is roughly equivalent to a round-trip flight between 
Washington, D.C., and Chicago.

An average American using public transportation travels 25 to 75 miles a 
week. For many Minnesotans, the weekly average would be zero.

To reduce: Shorten your daily commute, drive fuel-efficient vehicles, 
car-pool and, whenever possible, walk or bike.

GOODS AND SERVICES: 8.6 acres

Goods include appliances, clothing, electronic items, sports equipment, 
toys, computers, household furnishings and cleaning products.

Services include water, sewage, garbage, telecommunications, education, 
health care, entertainment, recreation and tourism, military and other 
government services.

To reduce: Because our lifestyles increasingly depend on goods and 
services, this part of the footprint can be significant. To reduce, lower 
your score on food, housing and mobility. Another approach: repair, don't 
replace. Think energy efficiency when you buy and recycle whenever possible.

Total footprint: 23.5 acres


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

[ april 22: under the radar // at 26Mix ]
UNDER THE RADAR at 26Mix
http://www.26mix.com/
3024 Mission Street @ 26th Street
San Francisco
9:00pm - Close
$5.00

Sex and intellect for earth day!

LIVE PERFORMANCES:

THE LOVEMAKERS
The Lovemakers offer up electropop dance songs punctuated with boy-girl 
vocals, electric violin, vibrator solos, and shoegazing Robert Smith guitar 
lines. Although the sweat-drenched stage antics might fool you, a typical 
conversation with TLM will generally bring you into the depths of 
synthesizer geekdom, classical music muses, or most frequently, smack in the 
middle of J.R.R. Tolkien's middle earth! A preoccupation with the fantastic 
colours TLM's approach to music making, taking inspiration from many fronts: 
80s pop legends The Human League, Bjork, Le Tigre, and Oakland's own 
burgeoning synth-happy music scene. According to Lord Grunge (of Pittsburg 
Hip Hop duo Grand Buffet), the Lovemakers sound "like a pink Ferrari driving 
through a mountain of cocaine."

MATT DAVIGNON
Matt Davignon of Oakland, California has been performing and recording his 
own brand of experimental music for the last 9 years. Primarily self taught, 
he creates most of his music (both live and recorded) through improvisation, 
often imitating everyday sound phenomena or focusing on often-overlooked 
aural characteristics. Matt does not own or seek expensive equipment. He 
prefers to make do with what is already within reach. Instruments he uses 
include turntable, tape, sampling/looping devices, cd, found objects, field 
recordings, prepared acoustic guitar, keyboard, slide whistles and vocal 
sounds.

TRI-CORNERED TENT SHOW
Almost everyday in the news there are stories about how a group of 
scientists after so many decades of painstaking research and work create a 
new drug or make new discoveries, but how many times does one read about a 
group of musicians that have done the same thing? A trio of experimental and 
improvisational musicians called the Tri-Cornered Tent Show has done just 
that. It has taken them the last part of the last century (25 years to be 
exact) of dedicated practice, research, and patience that brings them to 
announce the release of "Maze Above the Abyss", "Tri-Cornered Tent Show", 
and "Beneath the Mountains of Madness" all encased in 3 compact discs. The 
musical journey began with initial tracks being recorded using the ancient 
anti-deluvian technology of electronics from the 70's. Though methodical 
deciphering of the Lovcraft short story "The music of Eric Zann", other 
related stories expanded upon Lovecraft's Greater Cthulu Mythos they began 
recording free improvisation and orchestrated sound sculpture over those 25 
years to create the projects now available on the new bay area label 
Edgetone Records. Now, they come out from their exile held up in a 
well-insulated dank little studio in the depths of Richmond California. By 
the shear force of will and their dedication to the world of improvisation, 
they have a unique set of music to merit them worthy of attention. In a 
world of pop can music they could teach a class in patience and creation.

DJ PERFORMANCES
JULIAN DESTRUKT (Tokyo Electric) and ZYGOTE (under the radar //)

VIDEO SCREENING
Works featured from Stephen Williams (scrod media / blasthaus) and a 
premiere of C-Trl's "Glitch Porn".

UPCOMING SHOWS: DAT POLITICS, BALL2000 and MORE...........stay tuned.

just adding commentary. i didn't really see anyone out and about acknowledging the day. one person wished me happy 420...i don't know if people were just sacked out or what, but also, if you believe in contact highs, well, i must say, that yesterday, i was just FLYING...i mean, there must have been a lot of residual dankness in the air or something...either that, or i was just enjoying myself, and people are just using and recognizing good medicine on an as needed basis. oh, but today, i am SORE as usual, so i will have to do something about that a.s.a.p. i have no vices, so please don't presume..oh, excuse me, i do use coffee daily, and yesterday, i ate at burger king...i'd swear from the photograph though, you'd think i was in a way that people need a little something special to induce themselves...no, as long as no one is bothering me, i am all mellow, but whatever. where's my love'ins, baby? where's my love'ins? oh, one more thing, i was thinking that a good singles ad would read, "small ass, big heart"..hahahahahahahahhahahahah. gonna be some booty shake'in go'in on real soon. as long as you stay true to the music, no one can touch ya. really. tis true. :)

AndyW wrote:
>If you guys can't handle your cars enough to keep them on the road, what
>happens when someone is crossing the street in front of you around a
>corner someday while you're doing a 95% pace all four wheels singing
>carve...

why would that ever happen ?  is this the voice of experience ?

in my situation, i picked up a 5" bolt in the left rear tire of that car right at the "45MPH" turn on HWY 50 (that EVERYONE does 65
around, including you) and even with AWD, could not recover with the blown tire on the very cold winter pavement.

i know this is gonna come of like a condescending ass, but... i have been Kart racing since i was a teenager, Auto-X'ing since i was
20, have instructed countless Driver Safety Courses with the BMW CCA, PCA as well as the Marin Juevinile Traffic Offenders program.
I've instructed various marque club track schools at Sears, Laguna, and Thunder Hill with BMW CCA, Yahoo Extreme Sports Club, UFO,
SLOAX, etc..  I have raced everything from RC Cars, Karts, Minibkes, Street Modified Winston, Solo II, Vintage SCCA, and your moma
(okay, just playin' on that last one ;)

andy, how would you have fared in the same situation ?  life is always full of surprises.  thank goodness.

-=dave

>From the Creators of Power Puff Girls 1 and 2, Enter the Dragon 1-3 and countless other record breaking events.

 

 

Shaolin Presents….Our BIGGEST party ever!

 

June 13, 2003

 

HIGH OCTANE <~~mini-MASSIVE

 

============================

 

 

LOCK N’ LOAD

The Lock N' Load project consists of two Dutch producers / DJ’s: Frank van Rooijen and Niels Pijpers.  One fine day the Club Caviar boys came to visit the Lock N' Load studio, heard the old version of a song and offered to do a remix of it.  In collaboration with Lock N' Load they delivered this stunning result and Niels decided to release "Blow Ya Mind".  After all on Blue White Records, within a period of three weeks, it became the No. 1 club record in the Netherlands, and Europe followed soon after that, the United Kingdom was ready to be conquered.  Through no. 1 positions in both the UK Club and UK Dance chart it had an amazing entry at 6.  Help us welcome Lock N' Load to Sacramento.

 

Chris C.

Now firmly established as one of the Biggest and most popular DJ / Producers on the UK Hard House/NRG scene,  Chris has masterminded the emergence and rapid success of his 3 Labels, Mohawk, Aztec and Nile.  Positioning the former today as one of the genres top 5 marques.  With over 30 single releases and 2 Albums to his name on various labels including Tidy Trax, Tinrib, Eve, Honeypot, Phoenix Rising, GBT, Bulletproof, etc...Chris' reputation as one of Britain's finest exponent of Hard House, both behind the decks and in the studio, continues to grow.

 

Whistler

Victor Cape a.k.a. Whistler shines as a highly respected DJ on the Pacific Northwest dance scene.  Known for his tight mixing skills and uplifting personality behind the decks, Whistler blends energy and emotion from Hard Melodic Trance, Epic Anthems and Hard House to take his listeners on a dance floor rollercoaster ride.  If being a DJ wasn't enough, he also manages Lovetribe which has quickly become one of the most well respected event productions in Seattle.  It's been over a year and a half since Whistler's last performance in Northern California.  So we're excited to bring him out for his first Sacramento performance!

 

 

 

Dyloot

Arguably  Nor-Cal’s BIGGEST Trance DJ/Producer watch him work his MAGIC over the crowd.

 

 

Tom Slik Vs. Tracer

Two of Nor-Cal’s Biggest Trance DJ’s wage war for the first time in Sacramento.

 

Denise Vs.  Paul the Fanman

First ever Teacher vs. Student battle between the establish Denise and the BIG up n comer Paul.  Let’s see if he learned some tricks on his own.

 

Dragn’fly Vs. Scepter

Shaolin’s two BIGGEST DJ’s go head to head to see who really is the SHAOLIN MASTER.

 

Bazooka Joe Vs. Reckless Ryan

Showmanship is the only way to describe the performance these two put on.  Turntablist House at its best.  Watch as these two leave you in a wicky-wick-AWWW!

 

Valerie Sparks vs. The Doctor

Nor Cal’s Best Hardcore Female DJ goes against this up n coming Junglist.

 

Sascha 23 Vs. Gauge

The founder of Xtort bumps heads with one of Shaolin’s Most talented Producer in a must see set with original Shaolin tracks.

 

 

 

IMPORTANT!!!

All High Octane Presale Holders will get into our next event (Aquatech) FREE!

 

Free: Glowsticks, Glow Bracelets, Glow mouth pieces, Stickers, Tasty Candy, CD’s and Gift Bags.

 

ALL RESPONSIBLE AGES!!!

7pm – 5am

Tons of Lasers, Lighting and Visuals.  Plus dancing AIR PEOPLE and vendor village.

 

www.shaolinproductions.net

 

Info Line: 916 484-5610

 

$20 Presale, $25 @Door

 

Presale Locations:

Skillz: 510 704-9876

Retropolis: 775 786-8661

F8: 415 221-4142

Solid Grooves: 408 248-6399

 

 

 



Kris

Scepter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] anyone want popsicle tickets?

Pretty much...

And when I actually stop to think about it it seems pretty silly to me too.  I
like parts of the East Bay a lot, and I'm over there at least twice a week
usually.  But I have this silly aversion to driving over that bridge and paying
the toll... to the point that I'll go out of my way to avoid it sometimes, even
when the actual dollar cost to me is the same...

... or MORE even!!!  Every so often I'll catch myself planning to take the bus
to BART, and the train to Berkeley, even though that round trip actually costs
significantly MORE than the gas and the toll of just driving.  When this
happens, I'll mentally WTF myself, grab the keys and just go.  And yet, I STILL
have these urges to bus/BART it...

I swear, I must have had some childhood trauma involving that bridge.  And the
stupidest part of the whole thing?  I live on Treasure Island now!


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] meat katie and elite force on friday

anyone else planning on checking this show out?

--

Plastîk
Fu Mando returns with a vengeance as they welcome nu-skool breaks super 
heroes Meat Katie and Elite Force!

Hailing from London, Meat Katie and Elite Force have long been pioneers on 
the breakbeat scene both as DJs and producers. With their unique blends of 
tech and tribal, techno, and electro - all with a trademark breakbeat feel - 
Meat Katie and Elite Force gained worldwide support from the likes of Layo & 
Bushwacka, Rennie Pilgrim, The Chemical Brothers, and DJ Hyper.

Check out wy9.co.uk for artist info and sample MP3s.

With local support from DJs Ms. E, DJ Push, Reversible, and Alan Keller. 
Plus visuals by Dr. Fractal.

time: 9 pm - 4 am
admission: $15 cover TBA, 21+
location: fu-mando.com
location: Studio Z




-------------
< Brandon >
http://www.invibe.com

I hate cars too, everyone wants to know why my husband and I don't own separate cars, I haven't owned a car in 4 years and when I did it was a geo metro (40mpg) it cost me $5 in gas a month to drive it. Free yourself from the Automobile Addiction foisted on us by a corrupt capitalist system gone out of control. I am thinking about getting a motorcycle, though. If bart and busses ran till 2 am I wouldnt even be thinking about that.

their nightly homes. Can you imagine? A comfy warm BART seat beats a 
cold cramped doorway any night of the week! Unfortunately many of the

this as a "security problem".

Received: (qmail 3747 invoked from network); 23 Apr 2003 21:05:30 -0000
Date: Wed, 23 Apr 2003 14:05:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
cc: Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <OE72J0gfZe5cncTU4DY00002078@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0304231352540.10311-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr. racing cars


On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, innocentchild wrote:
-&e->If my car would get 40mpg I'd be happy. Performance has a price, and
-&e->I'll pay that price. I like my car because it's FUN. I'm not out to
-&e->save the world, nor a victim of some political agenda. It's plain and
-&e->simple - I like cars. =)

Ryan, it's ok that you like cars.  But your comments about people being a
"slave to some political agenda" are a bit shortsighted.  Petroleum is a
finite resource and very important to the way we live our lives right now.
I think wasting it on performance you don't need (or can't legally use for
that matter) is a bit of a waste.  That doesn't make me a slave to
anything but responsibility to the next couple generations so that they
may lives similar or better to ours.

Emissions, smog, increased cancer rates in metropolitan areas, petroleum
depletion, economic upheaval, unsavory foreign affairs and many other very
real aspects are a direct result of gasoline consumption.  Every time you
don't drive, every time you decide on the crappy straight 4 rather than
the high output v6, it has a real effect in CO2 emissions, and how much
longer we'll be able to live in a petroleum economy.

If you want massive gas mileage and tons of handling/acceleration and all
that, motorcycles can be had that are more than you can handle new for
under $10,000.  And a lot of those bikes can get 100hp for a sub-500 pound
vehicle and still get close to 50mpg.  They can go between lanes legally
in California in traffic on highways, they're easier to work on (mine has
two spark plugs and two simple carbs, yay), and modern streetbikes can
last as long as a car mileswise.

andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves]Technics cheaper in Holland?nrr

don't know about price, but if you're going to use the decks in the 
Netherlands, be sure they'll run on the current over there (which i believe 
is 220V)...it's not unusual for electronic equipment to have a input-voltage 
switcher, but you don't want to get caught with single-voltage 120V decks 
you can't operate over there.

--hb

and btw - it's an supercharged inline 4 that's 10hp shy of the *high output*
V6... I can guarantee you a VR6 will drain it's tank faster than my car
will!

--=====================_16762165==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Raindance  & Yoga Tai Chi Invite You to the first annual

"Festival of Bass"

This event will  be held in a mystical place  2hrs from Santa Cruz
3hrs from San Fran. Where hot water bubbles from the Earth

Beats/Camping/Hot Springs/pool/Yoga/Tai Chi
Celebrate Life, Music & Dance under  the glow of the
Sun, Full Moon & Stars!!!

Line up thus far
*Lorin(Bassnectar.net)*
*Markie(Wicked) * Foxgluv(Live)*
*Tracy(Raindance) * Brother(Space Ship Gaia) * Little John(Raindance)*
*Moon Doggy(Yoga Tai Chi) * Dragonfly(Groove Garden) * Adam(Raindance) * 
C.B.(Yoga Tai Chi)*
*E.O.(SF) * Rob Monroy(Raindance) * DJ Tree(mystikalchemy.com LA)*
*Stryder(13 Moon Tribe) * Mozaic(Space Ship Gaia) * Lux aka Rodman
*Alia(Bass Womb) * Tao(oobero records)*
*Mark Ameba*

2 Sound systems by
Purple Sound & Magnetic Sound
Organic Cafe' by Convergence
Yoga and  Tai Chi through-out the weekend
Cabins & private tubs avail upon request
electrical hook ups avail

This is a Private Event.each person must buy a pre-sale  "membership"
"membership" is =to your ticket
or  obtain a personal invite through this email
pre sale will be $20 each /gate $23
This  includes music,camping,springs, pool yoga and tai chi
to buy a pre-sale on the net  go to-  paypal.com
you can click on this link
https://www.paypal.com/affil/pal=raindance%40surfnetusa.com
enter this address( raindance@merceyhotsprings.com) & send $20
note the extra e in the spelling of mercey
you will be instantly mailed confirmation
For directions and more info on da spot go to

http://merceyhotsprings.com/

or you may buy a pre sale  @ one of the following locations
Streetlight Records in 939 Pacific Ave. in Santa Cruz
Distractions, Haight St. in San Francisco

If you can not get a pre sale ,please print out this e mail ,
write your name in the blank at the top of the page & bring it with you
each person must have one
this will allow you to pay at the gate (note-gate price is $23)
This will keep the event "private"
you must have either an  invite or a pre-bought
"membership" to attend
Bring
camping gear, gifts
to share, good vibes, water
not to bring
(Dogs/Alcohol if under 21/republicans)


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_16762165==_.ALT--

ps: in other news (nrr) mercury retrograde begins
today. worse yet, it continues thru most of may.
mercury retrograde is a time of communication
breakdowns and frustrating delay. it is a terrible
time for starting new projects, taking on a new job,
or travelling. worst of all for travelling in fact.
the last time I travelled during mercury retrograde
was the worst trip I ever had. (I've had more fun
getting arrested.) anyway, the good news is that
almost immediately after mercury goes direct again at
the end of may, saturn finally moves from gemini into
cancer, in june, making life easier for just about
everyone.

actually, mercury retrograde is a terrible time to
post a tutorial on sound design to a mailing list,
being as it has to do with both communication and
electronics. best thing is, save this e-mail, open it
up again in June, and read the tutorial then.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr. racing cars


Sarah,

I applaud you for thinking sensibly and knowing there are alternative
forms of transportation.

I like to ride my horse and my bike as backup. I rode a 12 mile bike ride
yesterday, followed by a 5 mile hike on two feet, followed by a 3 mile
horseback ride. Not ever having taken my car for granted (I drive a
fuel-efficient, low emissions vehicle), this trip gave me a renewed
appreciation for the work and energy consumed by making the same trip by
automobile.

Andy: Thanks for pointing out the truth behind the consumption of oil.
It's a crutch that applies to so much more than fuel for automobiles. How
it impacts the environment, world cost and standard of living, wars
fought, people's health, etc are just as important.

Consumption is the key word.....If we humans continue to consume oil, not
just for cars, but all forms energy, we'll run out, at what cost?
Polluting the earth, the air we breathe and our pocketbooks?

from: http://www.ems.org/oil_depletion/story.html

An article on oil depletion...

"...If critics of the USGS are correct, then the range of estimates most
often provided by experts -- 1800 to 2200 billion barrels -- is a more
accurate reflection of the world's ultimate endowment of oil. In that
case, with historic oil consumption at 940 billion barrels, humans are
rapidly nearing the production peak.

Even if the USGS EUR of 3000 billion barrels is accurate, the extra
barrels will only forestall the production peak by about a decade, experts
say. With global demand rising at 1.5 percent per year, a difference of
800 billion barrels in EUR shifts the production peak by only 12 years,
according to the World Resources Institute..."

From: http://www.etvi.org/Just_the_Facts/New_Benefits_jtf.html

"... Interesting effects of the combusion engine:

Typical Engine Combustion:

FUEL + AIR ==>> UNBURNED HYDROCARBONS + NITROGEN OXIDES

+ CARBON MONOXIDE + CARBON DIOXIDE + water

The most damaging exhaust pollutants (which are created during the
combustion process) include:

    * HYDROCARBONS: Hydrocarbon emissions result when fuel molecules in
the engine do not burn or burn only partially. Hydrocarbons react in the
presence of nitrogen oxides and sunlight to form ground-level ozone, a
major component of smog. Ozone irritates the eyes, damages the lungs, and
aggravates respiratory problems. It is our most widespread and intractable
urban air pollution problem. A number of exhaust hydrocarbons are also
toxic, with the potential to cause cancer.
    * NITROGEN OXIDES (NOx): Under the high pressure and temperature
conditions in an engine, nitrogen and oxygen atoms in the air react to
form various nitrogen oxides, collectively known as NOx. Nitrogen oxides,
like hydrocarbons, are precursors to the formation of ozone. They also
contribute to the formation of acid rain.
    * CARBON MONOXIDE: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a product of incomplete
combustion and occurs when carbon in the fuel is partially oxidized rather
than fully oxidized to carbon dioxide (CO ). Carbon monoxide reduces the
flow of oxygen in the bloodstream and is particularly dangerous to persons
with heart disease.
    * CARBON DIOXIDE: In recent years, the U.S. Environmental Protection
Agency (EPA) has started to view carbon dioxide, a product of "perfect"
combustion, as a pollution concern. Carbon dioxide does not directly
impair human health, but it is a "greenhouse gas" that traps the earth's
heat and contributes to the potential for global warming

In addition to pollutants normally associated with exhaust, ICE's further
harm our environment with evaporative emissions (which are emissions that
are caused by using a liquid fuel) which include fuel in the fuel tank,
the fuel lines and unburned fuel from the combustion process. We all have
had personal contact with evaporative emissions whenever we fuel our
automobile or truck at a gas station.

Hydrocarbon pollutants escape into the air through fuel evaporation. With
today's efficient exhaust emission controls and gasoline formulations,
evaporative losses can account for a majority of the total hydrocarbon
pollution from current model cars on hot days when ozone levels are
highest. Evaporative emissions occur several ways:

    * DIURNAL: Gasoline evaporation increases as the temperature rises
during the day, heating the fuel tank and venting gasoline vapors.
    * RUNNING LOSSES: The hot engine and exhaust system can vaporize
gasoline when the car is running.
    * HOT SOAK: The engine remains hot for a period of time after the car
is turned off, and gasoline evaporation continues when the car is parked.
    * REFUELING: Gasoline vapors are always present in fuel tanks. These
vapors are forced out when the tank is filled with liquid fuel."

Oil consumption is definately a choice.  A consumer choice. Seeing that as
a society and a country is the next step. There may come a time where all
this short-sightedness results in those who justify consumption of oil at
a high rate will realize that it is not only this generation that pays for
it, but your children's, grandchildren's and the mother earth. Resources,
Standard of Living, etc will be effected in the future if our nation
remains so dependant on oil for its main source of energy.

Examples of the World effect of oil consumption:
http://www4.nas.edu/news.nsf/isbn/0309084385?OpenDocument

Policy options:
http://www.cbo.gov/showdoc.cfm?index=3991&sequence=2

The truth about oil security:
http://www.fortune.com/fortune/articles/0,15114,369553,00.html

Books on the topic - the Dirty truth about oil:
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/external-search/104-5433028-6147940?tag=starshopcom-books-20&keyword=the%20truth%20about%20oil&mode=books

Renewable energy research is a start, not choosing to drive vehicles that
only get 8-20mpg is another. This can be extended to our overall
consumption of energy period.

Here are a few alternatives:
http://www.ucsusa.org/clean_energy/renewable_energy/index.cfm

We do not inherit the Earth from our parents, we merely borrow it from our
children. Hopefully people in this country, congress, consumers and
business will wake up and smell the coffee someday.

Regards,

Karina

On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, AndyW wrote:

>
> On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, innocentchild wrote:
> -&e->If my car would get 40mpg I'd be happy. Performance has a price, and
> -&e->I'll pay that price. I like my car because it's FUN. I'm not out to
> -&e->save the world, nor a victim of some political agenda. It's plain and
> -&e->simple - I like cars. =)
>
> Ryan, it's ok that you like cars.  But your comments about people being a
> "slave to some political agenda" are a bit shortsighted.  Petroleum is a
> finite resource and very important to the way we live our lives right now.
> I think wasting it on performance you don't need (or can't legally use for
> that matter) is a bit of a waste.  That doesn't make me a slave to
> anything but responsibility to the next couple generations so that they
> may lives similar or better to ours.
>
> Emissions, smog, increased cancer rates in metropolitan areas, petroleum
> depletion, economic upheaval, unsavory foreign affairs and many other very
> real aspects are a direct result of gasoline consumption.  Every time you
> don't drive, every time you decide on the crappy straight 4 rather than
> the high output v6, it has a real effect in CO2 emissions, and how much
> longer we'll be able to live in a petroleum economy.
>
> If you want massive gas mileage and tons of handling/acceleration and all
> that, motorcycles can be had that are more than you can handle new for
> under $10,000.  And a lot of those bikes can get 100hp for a sub-500 pound
> vehicle and still get close to 50mpg.  They can go between lanes legally
> in California in traffic on highways, they're easier to work on (mine has
> two spark plugs and two simple carbs, yay), and modern streetbikes can
> last as long as a car mileswise.
>
> andyw

US: No One Raving Over Biden Bill
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n549/a01.html
Newshawk: Kirk
Webpage:
http://www.delawareonline.com/newsjournal/local/2003/04/17nooneravingover.html
Pubdate: Thu, 17 Apr 2003
Source: News Journal (DE)
Copyright: 2003 The News Journal
Contact: njletter@newsjournal.com
Website: http://www.delawareonline.com/newsjournal/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/822

NO ONE RAVING OVER BIDEN BILL

His controversial proposal to crack down on all-night dance parties where
illegal drugs are used or sold is on the brink of becoming law, but Sen.
Joe Biden insists he's not out to stop the music.

At issue is a bill -- once known as the "RAVE Act" -- that has drawn fire
from civil liberties groups and grass-roots activists as an unfair attack
on the events, popular with teenagers and young adults, where Ecstasy is a
common ingredient.

The Delaware Democrat's proposal went nowhere last year in either the
House or Senate.  But this year he renamed it the "Illicit Drug
Non-Proliferation Act" and slipped it into a larger crime bill during a
House-Senate conference.  The bill cleared Congress last week, and
President Bush has said he will sign it.

From sfraves-return-101465-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 23 22:06:35 2003

X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Local News Coverage on Biden's Bill

US: Drug Bill Targeting Rave Scene Nears Passage Despite
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n548/a05.html
Newshawk: M & M Family
Pubdate: Thu, 17 Apr 2003
Source: San Jose Mercury News (CA)
Copyright: 2003 San Jose Mercury News
Contact: letters@sjmercury.com
Website: http://www.bayarea.com/mld/mercurynews
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/390
Author: Nick Anderson, Los Angeles Times
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)

DRUG BILL TARGETING RAVE SCENE NEARS PASSAGE DESPITE CRITICS

WASHINGTON - His controversial proposal to crack down on all-night dance
parties where illegal drugs are used or sold is on the brink of becoming
law, but Sen.  Joseph Biden insists he's not out to stop the music.

At issue is a bill -- once known as the "RAVE Act" -- that has drawn fire
from civil liberties groups and grass-roots activists as an unfair attack
on the events, popular with teenagers and young adults, where the drug
"ecstasy" is a common ingredient.

The Delaware Democrat's proposal went nowhere last year in either the
House or Senate.  But this year he renamed it the "Illicit Drug
Non-Proliferation Act" and slipped it into a larger crime bill during a
House-Senate conference.  The bill cleared Congress last week, and
President Bush has said he would sign it.

"The reason I introduced this bill was not to ban dancing, kill 'the rave
scene' or silence electronic music -- all things of which I have been
accused," Biden told the Senate last week.  "In no way is this bill aimed
at stifling any type of music or expression.  It is only trying to deter
illicit drug use and protect kids."

Biden's maneuver was little-noticed when Congress overwhelmingly approved
the crime bill.

But some lawmakers, including members of Biden's own party, were upset at
the impending enactment of a measure that, by itself, had never been voted
on in either the House or the Senate.

Rep.  Barney Frank, D-Mass., a senior member of the House Judiciary
Committee, voted against the final version of the crime bill after having
previously supported it.  Frank said he switched to protest Biden's
provision.

Sen.  Patrick Leahy of Vermont, the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary
Committee, voted for the final bill but also expressed concerns.  Biden's
measure, Leahy said, "has drawn serious grass-roots opposition.  And I
know that I am not alone in hearing from many constituents about their
serious, and well-considered, objections to it." The measure should have
been given "a fuller hearing," Leahy said.

The Biden measure revises a 1986 law that holds owners of crack houses
criminally responsible if they knowingly allow their property to be used
by drug makers or dealers.

Under the new measure, the crack-house law would be expanded to include
properties used or rented for temporary or one-time events.  Violators --
who could include event promoters and property owners or managers -- would
face prison terms or civil fines of $250,000 or twice the gross revenue of
an event, whichever is greater.

When he first introduced the bill in June 2002, Biden said he was
targeting "club drugs" such as ecstasy, which are often found at raves,
concerts and other events frequented by teenagers.  The measure was
co-sponsored this year by Sens.  Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., Joseph
Lieberman, D-Conn., Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, and Gordon Smith, R-Ore.

Biden said his measure sets a "high bar" for prosecuting offenses and does
not punish owners or promoters who follow the law.

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] News: Music Promoters Fear Anti-Drug Clause

US: Music Promoters Fear Anti-Drug Clause
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n542/a06.html
Newshawk: End Marijuana Prohibition: www.mpp.org
Pubdate: Thu, 17 Apr 2003
Source: Ventura County Star (CA)
Copyright: 2003, The E.W. Scripps Co.
Contact: letters@insidevc.com
Website: http://www.staronline.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/479
Author: Molly Freedenberg
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)

MUSIC PROMOTERS FEAR ANTI-DRUG CLAUSE

They Say It Could Bring Crackdowns On Many Events

Buried deep within the 118-page Amber Alert bill is a provision that has
brought fear to the music and entertainment industry.

The bill, designed to heighten public awareness of missing children, also
includes a provision that would make it easier to prosecute club owners
and promoters who sponsor events where there is drug use.

The provision would prohibit an individual from knowingly "making
available for use, or profiting from any place for the purpose of
manufacturing, distributing, or using any controlled substance, and for
other purposes."

The bill was conceived to expand the so-called crack-house law passed in
1986, to crack down on rave parties where drug use is rampant.  But some
say the wording of the proposed law is so broad that anyone could be
targeted.

"All you have to do is prove drug use is going on at an establishment to
go after the organizers," said Bill Piper, spokesman for Drug Policy
Alliance.  "In theory, they could go after you if one person smokes
marijuana at your barbecue, the law is written so loosely, you could face
20 years in jail and a half-million-dollar fine."

Chip Unruhe, a spokesman for the bill's primary sponsor, Sen.  Joe Biden,
D-Delaware, said opponents' fears are a result of misinformation.

"The bill is really a common-sense tool for prosecutors to go after
unscrupulous promoters" who endanger kids for profit, he said.

California Sen.  Dianne Feinstein co-sponsored the bill but could not be
reached for comment.

The crack-house law has been around since 1986.  Last year, Biden and
others tried to pass the RAVE Act -- Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to
Ecstasy - -- which failed.  A version of the RAVE Act was proposed in the
Senate and House this year as the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act, the
text of which has been added in the provision to the Amber Alert bill.

The RAVE Act originally was conceived to bolster the crack-house law.  It
specifically was in response to a case in New Orleans where hospital
workers complained of an increase in the number of overdosed patients each
time a particular promoter held an event, Unruhe said.  The judge in that
case wanted a more specific law on the books.

The crack-house law applies to an indoor space used repeatedly for the
use, sale or manufacture of drugs.  In contrast, the provision in the
Amber Alert bill can be applied to a one-time event such as a party at a
private home or in a vacant field, or outside events such as concerts.  It
could even conceivably apply to a party held in a rented church basement.

The provision is meant to target club owners who shut off water supplies
to sell overpriced water to dehydrated drug users, Unruhe said.  Another
potential target would be club owners who instruct ambulance drivers to
take patients to cross-town hospitals to avoid having those who overdose
being connected to particular events.  Unruhe said he had heard of such
tactics.

Unruhe emphasized the bill is not intended to stop music or dancing.

Piper said the crack-house law already deals with the kind of situations
Unruhe describes.  And current drug laws allow the prosecution of those
who use or deal drugs.  But the new provision isn't about cracking down on
drugs, Piper said.  "It's the events they don't like."

He said the law doesn't protect innocent club owners and lowers the bar on
proving knowledge or endorsement of drug use.

A common fear, he said, is that prosecutors will argue the sale of glow
sticks and bottled water -- often associated with dancing at raves but
also with the use of the drug ecstasy, MDMA -- or the presence of trained
paramedics will prove "knowledge and encouragement" of drug use.

These were part of the evidence in two recent crack-house cases, said
Piper, including the one in New Orleans, which led to the creation of the
RAVE Act.

Hans Riemer, of Rock the Vote, said the bill could be a "blanket attack on
youth culture."

Piper also fears political rallies, hip-hop shows, gay and lesbian clubs,
marijuana legalization events and other "politically incorrect" gatherings
could be next on the list.

Although the bill has raised concerns in the industry, few local club
owners had heard of it, including representatives from Nicholby's, Ventura
Theater and Seaside Park.

But Piper said he doesn't think that will be the case for long.  He is
getting calls from worried promoters, nightclub owners and people
associated with the electronic music scene.  He expects opposition to grow
fast.

which apparently seeks to subsume everything, including people's

Subject: RE: [sfraves] bsp: qool happy hour @ 111 minna

FYI -

The QOOL card program was retired by Qool a few months back. I was @ Qool
about two weeks ago, Spesh rocks the socks off anyone w/ an itch to dance.
This event is worth the trip.. Everyone here is happy, smiling and many
dance - the floor is always packed. I've had my card, thanks to GIL, for
years, I've also appreciated Qool as a great, mellow, and fun place to
spend my Wednesday night.

The Qool card has been replaced by the Qlist - Info:

What's the Q-list?
Here at Loöq Records we've started a new thing, the Q-List. Q-Listers get
VIP treatment at Loöq parties. The Q-List is an inner circle of dedicated
partiers, people who are about the vibe, connecting with each other, and
getting into the music. Does this fit your M.O.? If you want to be on the
Q-List, write us a short essay (or a long one, if you are feeling
inspired) about you, why you go clubbing, and why you are so exceptional
that you belong on the Q-List. If writing is not your thing, feel free to
send us something else that represents you (a picture of you, something
you made, something that made you, etc.).

Please send all Q-List submissions to q-list@looq.com or:

Loöq Records
182 Howard St. PMB 133
San Francisco, CA 94105

If you make the Q-List we'll let you know!

Another FYI from their site (www.looq.com)

04.11.03 MINNA OPEN, BIG ROOM CLOSED UNTIL EARLY MAY(-ISH)
Due to a regulatory/licensing snafu, the Minna Street Gallery apparently
does not currently have all the permits it needs to serve alcohol in the
big room. However, nothing else has changed - Minna is still open (with
smaller, but still full, bar) for Loöq Hard, Qoöl, and other events, they
will just be compressed into the "old room" for the moment. Should be
cosy, and fun (but of course we will be vigilant about not overpacking the
place). We would apologize on behalf of Minna, but in the past this kind
of salad tossing has generally led to even more fun being had than usual,
so we will wait and see how it goes! Back to the way it once was ...

---------- Original Message ----------------------------------
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
Date:  Wed, 23 Apr 2003 14:55:38 -0700 (PDT)

>
>Sarah,
>
>I applaud you for thinking sensibly and knowing there are 

alternative
>forms of transportation.
>
>I like to ride my horse and my bike as backup. I rode a 12 mile 

bike ride
>yesterday, followed by a 5 mile hike on two feet, followed by a 3 

mile
>horseback ride. Not ever having taken my car for granted (I drive 

a
>fuel-efficient, low emissions vehicle), this trip gave me a 

renewed
>appreciation for the work and energy consumed by making the same 

trip by
>automobile.
>
>Andy: Thanks for pointing out the truth behind the consumption of 

oil.
>It's a crutch that applies to so much more than fuel for 

automobiles. How
>it impacts the environment, world cost and standard of living, 

wars
>fought, people's health, etc are just as important.
>
>Consumption is the key word.....If we humans continue to consume 

oil, not
>just for cars, but all forms energy, we'll run out, at what cost?
>Polluting the earth, the air we breathe and our pocketbooks?
>
>from: http://www.ems.org/oil_depletion/story.html
>
>An article on oil depletion...
>
>"...If critics of the USGS are correct, then the range of 

estimates most
>often provided by experts -- 1800 to 2200 billion barrels -- is a 

more
>accurate reflection of the world's ultimate endowment of oil. In 

that
>case, with historic oil consumption at 940 billion barrels, 

humans are
>rapidly nearing the production peak.
>
>Even if the USGS EUR of 3000 billion barrels is accurate, the 

extra
>barrels will only forestall the production peak by about a 

decade, experts
>say. With global demand rising at 1.5 percent per year, a 

difference of
>800 billion barrels in EUR shifts the production peak by only 12 

years,
>according to the World Resources Institute..."
>
>From: http://www.etvi.org/Just_the_Facts/New_Benefits_jtf.html
>
>"... Interesting effects of the combusion engine:
>
>Typical Engine Combustion:
>
>FUEL + AIR ==>> UNBURNED HYDROCARBONS + NITROGEN OXIDES
>
>+ CARBON MONOXIDE + CARBON DIOXIDE + water
>
>The most damaging exhaust pollutants (which are created during 

the
>combustion process) include:
>
>    * HYDROCARBONS: Hydrocarbon emissions result when fuel 

molecules in
>the engine do not burn or burn only partially. Hydrocarbons react 

in the
>presence of nitrogen oxides and sunlight to form ground-level 

ozone, a
>major component of smog. Ozone irritates the eyes, damages the 

lungs, and
>aggravates respiratory problems. It is our most widespread and 

intractable
>urban air pollution problem. A number of exhaust hydrocarbons are 

also
>toxic, with the potential to cause cancer.
>    * NITROGEN OXIDES (NOx): Under the high pressure and 

temperature
>conditions in an engine, nitrogen and oxygen atoms in the air 

react to
>form various nitrogen oxides, collectively known as NOx. Nitrogen 

oxides,
>like hydrocarbons, are precursors to the formation of ozone. They 

also
>contribute to the formation of acid rain.
>    * CARBON MONOXIDE: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a product of 

incomplete
>combustion and occurs when carbon in the fuel is partially 

oxidized rather
>than fully oxidized to carbon dioxide (CO ). Carbon monoxide 

reduces the
>flow of oxygen in the bloodstream and is particularly dangerous 

to persons
>with heart disease.
>    * CARBON DIOXIDE: In recent years, the U.S. Environmental 

Protection
>Agency (EPA) has started to view carbon dioxide, a product of 

"perfect"
>combustion, as a pollution concern. Carbon dioxide does not 

directly
>impair human health, but it is a "greenhouse gas" that traps the 

earth's
>heat and contributes to the potential for global warming
>
>In addition to pollutants normally associated with exhaust, ICE's 

further
>harm our environment with evaporative emissions (which are 

emissions that
>are caused by using a liquid fuel) which include fuel in the fuel 

tank,
>the fuel lines and unburned fuel from the combustion process. We 

all have
>had personal contact with evaporative emissions whenever we fuel 

our
>automobile or truck at a gas station.
>
>Hydrocarbon pollutants escape into the air through fuel 

evaporation. With
>today's efficient exhaust emission controls and gasoline 

formulations,
>evaporative losses can account for a majority of the total 

hydrocarbon
>pollution from current model cars on hot days when ozone levels 

are
>highest. Evaporative emissions occur several ways:
>
>    * DIURNAL: Gasoline evaporation increases as the temperature 

rises
>during the day, heating the fuel tank and venting gasoline 

vapors.
>    * RUNNING LOSSES: The hot engine and exhaust system can 

vaporize
>gasoline when the car is running.
>    * HOT SOAK: The engine remains hot for a period of time after 

the car
>is turned off, and gasoline evaporation continues when the car is 

parked.
>    * REFUELING: Gasoline vapors are always present in fuel 

tanks. These
>vapors are forced out when the tank is filled with liquid fuel."
>
>Oil consumption is definately a choice.  A consumer choice. 

Seeing that as
>a society and a country is the next step. There may come a time 

where all
>this short-sightedness results in those who justify consumption 

of oil at
>a high rate will realize that it is not only this generation that 

pays for
>it, but your children's, grandchildren's and the mother earth. 

Resources,
>Standard of Living, etc will be effected in the future if our 

nation
>remains so dependant on oil for its main source of energy.
>
>Examples of the World effect of oil consumption:
>http://www4.nas.edu/news.nsf/isbn/0309084385?OpenDocument
>
>Policy options:
>http://www.cbo.gov/showdoc.cfm?index=3991&sequence=2
>
>The truth about oil security:
>http://www.fortune.com/fortune/articles/0,15114,369553,00.html
>
>Books on the topic - the Dirty truth about oil:
>http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/external-search/104-5433028-614

7940?tag=starshopcom-books-20&keyword=the%20truth%20about%20oil&mo

de=books
>
>Renewable energy research is a start, not choosing to drive 

vehicles that
>only get 8-20mpg is another. This can be extended to our overall
>consumption of energy period.
>
>Here are a few alternatives:
>http://www.ucsusa.org/clean_energy/renewable_energy/index.cfm
>
>We do not inherit the Earth from our parents, we merely borrow it 

from our
>children. Hopefully people in this country, congress, consumers 

and
>business will wake up and smell the coffee someday.
>
>Regards,
>
>Karina
>
>On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, AndyW wrote:

>which apparently seeks to subsume everything, including people's

>
>--hb

think, tongue and cheek BSP.   Really, how would one identify
"republicans?"  It's a fuckin' joke, people.  Chill out.

Love,

Apollo

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

-----Original Message-----
From: Karina [mailto:karina@hyperreal.org]=20
Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2003 2:38 PM
To: anti.tim
Cc: 'that ravin' mailin' list'
Subject: RE: [sfraves] bsp: qool happy hour @ 111 minna

FYI -

The QOOL card program was retired by Qool a few months back. I was @
Qool
about two weeks ago, Spesh rocks the socks off anyone w/ an itch to
dance.
This event is worth the trip.. Everyone here is happy, smiling and many
dance - the floor is always packed. I've had my card, thanks to GIL, for
years, I've also appreciated Qool as a great, mellow, and fun place to
spend my Wednesday night.

The Qool card has been replaced by the Qlist - Info:

What's the Q-list?
Here at Lo=F6q Records we've started a new thing, the Q-List. Q-Listers
get
VIP treatment at Lo=F6q parties. The Q-List is an inner circle of
dedicated
partiers, people who are about the vibe, connecting with each other, and
getting into the music. Does this fit your M.O.? If you want to be on
the
Q-List, write us a short essay (or a long one, if you are feeling
inspired) about you, why you go clubbing, and why you are so exceptional
that you belong on the Q-List. If writing is not your thing, feel free
to
send us something else that represents you (a picture of you, something
you made, something that made you, etc.).

Please send all Q-List submissions to q-list@looq.com or:

Lo=F6q Records
182 Howard St. PMB 133
San Francisco, CA 94105

If you make the Q-List we'll let you know!

Another FYI from their site (www.looq.com)

04.11.03 MINNA OPEN, BIG ROOM CLOSED UNTIL EARLY MAY(-ISH)
Due to a regulatory/licensing snafu, the Minna Street Gallery apparently
does not currently have all the permits it needs to serve alcohol in the
big room. However, nothing else has changed - Minna is still open (with
smaller, but still full, bar) for Lo=F6q Hard, Qo=F6l, and other events,
they
will just be compressed into the "old room" for the moment. Should be
cosy, and fun (but of course we will be vigilant about not overpacking
the
place). We would apologize on behalf of Minna, but in the past this kind
of salad tossing has generally led to even more fun being had than
usual,
so we will wait and see how it goes! Back to the way it once was ...

-----Original Message-----
From: Karina [mailto:karina@hyperreal.org]=20
Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2003 2:38 PM
To: anti.tim
Cc: 'that ravin' mailin' list'
Subject: RE: [sfraves] bsp: qool happy hour @ 111 minna

FYI -

The QOOL card program was retired by Qool a few months back. I was @
Qool about two weeks ago, Spesh rocks the socks off anyone w/ an itch to
dance. This event is worth the trip.. Everyone here is happy, smiling
and many dance - the floor is always packed. I've had my card, thanks to
GIL, for years, I've also appreciated Qool as a great, mellow, and fun
place to spend my Wednesday night.

The Qool card has been replaced by the Qlist - Info:

What's the Q-list?
Here at Lo=F6q Records we've started a new thing, the Q-List. Q-Listers
get VIP treatment at Lo=F6q parties. The Q-List is an inner circle of
dedicated partiers, people who are about the vibe, connecting with each
other, and getting into the music. Does this fit your M.O.? If you want
to be on the Q-List, write us a short essay (or a long one, if you are
feeling
inspired) about you, why you go clubbing, and why you are so exceptional
that you belong on the Q-List. If writing is not your thing, feel free
to send us something else that represents you (a picture of you,
something you made, something that made you, etc.).

Please send all Q-List submissions to q-list@looq.com or:

Lo=F6q Records
182 Howard St. PMB 133
San Francisco, CA 94105

If you make the Q-List we'll let you know!

Another FYI from their site (www.looq.com)

04.11.03 MINNA OPEN, BIG ROOM CLOSED UNTIL EARLY MAY(-ISH)
Due to a regulatory/licensing snafu, the Minna Street Gallery apparently
does not currently have all the permits it needs to serve alcohol in the
big room. However, nothing else has changed - Minna is still open (with
smaller, but still full, bar) for Lo=F6q Hard, Qo=F6l, and other events,
they will just be compressed into the "old room" for the moment. Should
be cosy, and fun (but of course we will be vigilant about not
overpacking the place). We would apologize on behalf of Minna, but in
the past this kind of salad tossing has generally led to even more fun
being had than usual, so we will wait and see how it goes! Back to the
way it once was ...

Message-Id: <200304231941.AA569573920@helpmejebus.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: "judas" <judas@helpmejebus.com>
Reply-To: <judas@helpmejebus.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: <IMail v7.14>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: Festival of Bass

i feel really strange saying this, because i'm about as far from 
being a republican as you can get.

but, while i seriously don't think it's a big deal at *all*, i can 
see why someone might get upset about that.  it is just a joke, 
and it certainly didn't sound like it was meant with malice.  at 
it's core, however, it is divisive and it is based on the fallacy 
that one's political beliefs defines all or most aspects of her or 
his lifestyle and personal beliefs. (the assumption being that no 
one reading the invitation could possibly be a republican because 
republicans never ever go to raves/parties and presumably don't 
like yoga.) 

i'm sure i've made similar jokes in the past, and i'll probably 
make them again without thinking about it.  but if someone 
responded to such a joke by saying that they thought i was being 
unfair, that it made them feel picked on and that they thought i 
owed them an apology, i would likely agree with them.  it's always 
possible that i'm just totally nuts or overly sensitive.  still, 
it's not like democrats have been any better regarding the revived 
RAVE act or in speaking out against the war or protecting the 
environment.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"Any old soul is worth saving, at least to a priest.  But not 

every soul is worth buying, so you can take the offer as a 

compliment."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
