At 07:41 PM 4/23/2003 -0700, judas wrote:
>i feel really strange saying this, because i'm about as far from
>being a republican as you can get.
>
>but, while i seriously don't think it's a big deal at *all*, i can
>see why someone might get upset about that.  it is just a joke,
>and it certainly didn't sound like it was meant with malice.  at
>it's core, however, it is divisive and it is based on the fallacy
>that one's political beliefs defines all or most aspects of her or
>his lifestyle and personal beliefs. (the assumption being that no
>one reading the invitation could possibly be a republican because
>republicans never ever go to raves/parties and presumably don't
>like yoga.)

That is an assumption that I don't think one can make from a simple BSP, IMHO.

As I have written others privately, I didn't write the BSP.  I'm sure if 
"republicans" attend this event they would be as welcome as anyone else. 
The problem with many people these days is they wish to invest any 
statement with some sinister intent -- and that was where the conversation 
was going.

I know the people who give these parties and they are far from 
discriminatory. There will probably be a lot of people running around nude 
and smokin' weed, so I suppose those who are uncomfortable with these 
things might not find this their cup of tea -- the stereotypical 
white-gloved republican womens' association:)

As for conservatives and liberals, no one I know takes these boundaries 
seriously these days.  The true "conservatives" I know are as outraged at 
the recent assault on civil liberties (by both Democrats and Republicans) 
as those who used to define themselves as liberals.  And most of the 
"Republicans" I know are as wild at parties as "Democrats."

Sure, I can honestly see that some might be mildly offended -- but to move 
on down the slippery slope of fantasying extraordinary motives that might 
be behind all this is a symptom, in my mind, of the tragedy of our times.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_1910007==_.ALT--

Yes I made a political statement, but it wasn't meant to be device-e+ive. I am a capitalist, I own my own business, but it is a choice whether we let it get out of control or not. IMHO, the auto and oil industries are out of control. And Guess what! I helped on a republican (Tom Campbell) campaign. But the no republicans thing was just funny. I have noticed that within the rave scene there are a lot of different opinions, that is something that happens with any social movement as it matures and diversifies.

So, I got a call from Ticketmaster... the show saturday, which was
supposed to have Underworld, Dirty Vegas, Primal Scream, and
KC/Kahuna...
It's been moved from the 7,000 seat Bill Graham Civic Auditorium to the
1,200 capacity Fillmore? What gives?  Is it gonna be the same lineup?
Does anyone know why it got changed... massive underselling of tickets,
or shady promoters promising too much, or... ?
 
Just seems odd to me; Underworld *alone* sure sold a lot more than 1,200
tickets just a few months ago at the Warfield, how could this sell half
as many with this popular a lineup?
 
later

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr. racing cars

--=======60FA5E8A=======
Content-Type: text/plain; x-avg-checked=avg-ok-7E783FFB; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

At 02:05 PM 4/23/2003, AndyW wrote:


>On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, innocentchild wrote:
>-&e->If my car would get 40mpg I'd be happy. Performance has a price, and
>-&e->I'll pay that price. I like my car because it's FUN. I'm not out to
>-&e->save the world, nor a victim of some political agenda. It's plain and
>-&e->simple - I like cars. =)
>
>Ryan, it's ok that you like cars.  But your comments about people being a
>"slave to some political agenda" are a bit shortsighted.  Petroleum is a
>finite resource and very important to the way we live our lives right now.
>I think wasting it on performance you don't need (or can't legally use for
>that matter) is a bit of a waste.  That doesn't make me a slave to
>anything but responsibility to the next couple generations so that they
>may lives similar or better to ours.

How is it short sighted?  Thinking that cars are going to become extinct 
just because petroleum is not a renewable resource is far worse.  We're 
already moving to electric and petrol hybrids, and are making inroads 
towards fuel cells all the time.

>Emissions, smog, increased cancer rates in metropolitan areas, petroleum
>depletion, economic upheaval, unsavory foreign affairs and many other very
>real aspects are a direct result of gasoline consumption.

This is not a fact.  Gasoline consumption contributes to environmental 
problems.  If you want to harp about automotive problems, talk about used 
oil - ground contamination or CFC's eating the ozone layer.

>  Every time you
>don't drive, every time you decide on the crappy straight 4 rather than
>the high output v6, it has a real effect in CO2 emissions, and how much
>longer we'll be able to live in a petroleum economy.

The choice of vehicle (current vs. old) and the proper maintenance of the 
vehicle ensure low pollution rates - not necessarily the engine 
design.  Also, future technology may overtake our petrol supply... we did 
just take over Iraq...

>If you want massive gas mileage and tons of handling/acceleration and all
>that, motorcycles can be had that are more than you can handle new for
>under $10,000.  And a lot of those bikes can get 100hp for a sub-500 pound
>vehicle and still get close to 50mpg.  They can go between lanes legally
>in California in traffic on highways, they're easier to work on (mine has
>two spark plugs and two simple carbs, yay), and modern streetbikes can
>last as long as a car mileswise.

Bikes are great commuter vehicles for those brave souls that don't fear 
losing limbs or dying in a fender bender.  Some people prefer the safety of 
a metal body around them.  Even others prefer a vehicle with utility.


sarilion

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr. racing cars

On Wed, 23 Apr 2003 12:47:44 -0700 (PDT), Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com> wrote:

> I hate cars too, everyone wants to know why my husband and I don't own separate cars, I haven't owned a car in 4 years and when I did it was a geo metro (40mpg) it cost me $5 in gas a month to drive it. I like Public transportation, it gives me a chance to read and meet people. I like my Bicycle. Free yourself from the Automobile Addiction foisted on us by a corrupt capitalist system gone out of control. I am thinking about getting a motorcycle, though. If bart and busses ran till 2 am I wouldnt even be thinking about that.

In case you weren't aware-the average motorcycle is a *far* worse polluter than any modern car.
Even though the engines are much smaller, there are no emission controls whatsoever.
And the mileage is only about 40mpg.

But beyond that-get fucking real please.
You simply can *not* get everywhere you need to go with just a bike and public transportation.
Maybe in NYC-but not here-not in the slightest.
Not when it takes me 45minutes to take the bus from SJ to fremont BART-then another 45 on BART to oakland.
That 2x the time it would take in my car.

And I will not "Free myself from the Automobile Addiction foisted on us by a corrupt capitalist system gone out of control."

I love driving (fast)- and I'm sane-which is why I don't see the future being exotic-fueled underperforming expensive techno-marvels.
Today's Diesel cars do all that is needed-You can go buy a 1.9 turbo VW diesel Jetta today that:
a) doesn't cost much more than a normal one
b) gets something like 50mpg
c) has a "normal" range
d) has "normal" performance

The diesels in Europe are even better.

The final step is biodiesel: http://www.biodiesel.org/
Renewable, relatively clean-an ecologists dream.
I'm waiting.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr. racing cars

On Wed, 23 Apr 2003 14:05:27 -0700 (PDT), AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

> Ryan, it's ok that you like cars.  But your comments about people being a
> "slave to some political agenda" are a bit shortsighted.  Petroleum is a
> finite resource and very important to the way we live our lives right now.

I just posted it, but: http://www.biodiesel.org/

> Emissions, smog, increased cancer rates in metropolitan areas, petroleum
> depletion, economic upheaval, unsavory foreign affairs and many other very
> real aspects are a direct result of gasoline consumption.  Every time you
> don't drive, every time you decide on the crappy straight 4 rather than
> the high output v6, it has a real effect in CO2 emissions, and how much
> longer we'll be able to live in a petroleum economy.
>
> If you want massive gas mileage and tons of handling/acceleration and all
> that, motorcycles can be had that are more than you can handle new for
> under $10,000.  And a lot of those bikes can get 100hp for a sub-500 pound
> vehicle and still get close to 50mpg.  They can go between lanes legally
> in California in traffic on highways, they're easier to work on (mine has
> two spark plugs and two simple carbs, yay), and modern streetbikes can
> last as long as a car mileswise.

Just for a point of reference-my understanding is that most motorcycles (except the BMWs with the cats) pollute much more than most 4/6cyl modern cars.
The auto industry has been focusing on fuel efficiency for about 30 years now-and reducing emissions for maybe 20.
Motorcycles today have absolutely no pollution controls and are not tuned for fuel efficiency whatsoever.

Emmisions-wise-I would bet your 650cc Suzuki puts out roughly triple what my 1.6 Daewoo does :)

Give a man a fire, and you'll keep him warm for a day.=20
Teach a man to make fire, and you'll keep him warm until he runs out of =
matches
Light a man on fire, and you'll keep him warm for the rest of his life.

From: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 24 Apr 2003 10:23:59 -0700
In-Reply-To: <00a801c30a84$79713910$191ae4d1@RMCCORMICKDT>
User-Agent: Opera7.0/Win32 M2 build 2637
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

Ive had some interesting thoughts about even those "alternative energy sources"-

We can sit here now and say that wind power is totally clean, and solar power is totally clean, and tide power is totally clean.
(Tide power btw just uses the water rising and lowering with the waves at the shore to turn turbines-nothing too special there-it works just like a dam)

But-I wonder what the actual implications of using that would be-
We didn't realize that coal plants would cause global gas-mixture changes...
Similarly, what would happen to the weather if all the worlds power was generated with wind.
That's a LOT of windmills slowing the jetstreams and such down.
What would the consequences be?
I certainly dont know-
And tidal?
Would a mass resistance to tidal forces cause some unforseen change in the oceans?

I still can't find any possible downfall to solar-it's not efficient enough yet to cause any sort of surface heat-loss-but when solar cells become efficient, they will convert what now heats the earth in to electricity.
Will this cause some slight planet-wide cooldown?
??????

Anyway-enough rambling for me-

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

ok so does not anyone know what i mean when i say that technology can be 
geared towards cleaning the world? no it does not mean that in one single day 
we'll have the answer because of this one email i sent to sf raves... it does 
not mean that all alternative power sources are clean besides fuel... what it 
means is that if you scientifically look at the pros  & cons for each source 
of polution and each possible alternative to it, and you always chose the 
less harmful process, eventually you have a cleaner world than you would 
have, if, say we just all had negative attitudes and made it seem as though 
the world is just hopelessly doomed... and any suggestion to make the world 
better is just somebody's naive misunderstanding that needs to be made fun 
of. 
    have you ever noticed how in futuristic movies (such as star wars) the 
people on other planets have this "tribal" essense about them, yet they do 
have highly advanced technology as well? that's because we subconsciously 
know what an ideal civilization should be like and what it takes to survive 
that far into the future. if we made all of our technology focused on the 
idea of environmentalism rather than capitalism, there would be 100,000 times 
less waiste. the waiste comes from cost efficiancy, what simple people like 
to buy and what they are accustomed to, and basically just fear and greed. 
    that's my point. am i saying that people are going to read this email and 
send it all over the world and pollution will be gone within a few days? no, 
so don't get it confused when i say we can graduallly stop pollution by 
focusing technology on it, that doesn't mean i'm saying i have the ultamite 
answer to stop pollution forver! i mean it's like i'm sitting here giving 
suggestions that may or may not work and i feel like peopel are reading it 
and they are resentful of what i have to say... it's rediculous if you ask me.

tired of the snickering... - johnny

On Thu, 24 Apr 2003, Nathan Seven wrote:
-&e->On Wed, 23 Apr 2003 12:47:44 -0700 (PDT), Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com> wrote:
-&e->
-&e->> I hate cars too, everyone wants to know why my husband and I don't own separate cars, I haven't owned a car in 4 years and when I did it was a geo metro (40mpg) it cost me $5 in gas a month to drive it. I like Public transportation, it gives me a chance to read and meet people. I like my Bicycle. Free yourself from the Automobile Addiction foisted on us by a corrupt capitalist system gone out of control. I am thinking about getting a motorcycle, though. If bart and busses ran till 2 am I wouldnt even be thinking about that.
-&e->
-&e->In case you weren't aware-the average motorcycle is a *far* worse polluter than any modern car.
-&e->Even though the engines are much smaller, there are no emission controls whatsoever.
-&e->And the mileage is only about 40mpg.

Well, a car's MPG doesn't matter when it's in bumper to bumper traffic.

Actually, all BMWs, I think a couple hondas (the Gold Wing for example
exceeds 2008 CARB specs)  and some Suzukis like the VStrom have fully
implemented emmissions controls on them (catalytic converter and all).

Oxygen sensors which adjust the fuel/air mixture for ideal burnoff of fuel
(good for performance AND for emissions) are commonplace now on fuel
injected bikes, as well as air to exhaust measures like 'PAIR' to reduce
hydrocarbon and particulate exhaust are in place too.

The EPA has a nasty habit of demonizing motorcycles that aren't even in
production anymore, as recently as last year an EPA spokeperson made
comments about motorcycle being 20 times nastier per mile than cars...
that's only possible if you're comparing an off the line 2004 emissions
spec honda in ideal circumstances with a race tuned 2 stroke 750 running a
bit rich or one of those farting harleys that literally burp raw gas and
chunks of carbon out the tailpipe cause they're only tuned to fire one
every 5 revs or whatever.

With these measures in place, and far smaller numbers as far as engine
displacement, etc, modern motorcycles are about the same per mile than
cars.  That said, they still use less gasoline per mile than most of the
cars out there... especially cars in a similar performance envelope.  The
superior emissions controls of cars go out the window in the real world,
especially when people are chipping them, putting different exhausts on
them to reduce backpressure, stomping the gas at every light, etc.

I get better than 40mpg on my sv650s, and a 0-60 of 3-4 seconds.  I don't
get stuck in traffic like cars do.  I can park in 1/3rd the space.  And
it's bone stock... and I bought it cash.

A recent analysis of contributions to smog among consumer vehicles by
vehicle type put motorcycles at less than 1%, and SUVs at over 60%.

I'm sick of all this arguing... just come out and say it... your' *real*
problem with motorcycles is:
http://www.b3ta.com/motorbikes/

andy'i wanna be ponch this time'w

> >finite resource and very important to the way we live our lives right now.

> >anything but responsibility to the next couple generations so that they
> >may lives similar or better to ours.

> >depletion, economic upheaval, unsavory foreign affairs and many other very
> >real aspects are a direct result of gasoline consumption.
>

> problems.  If you want to harp about automotive problems, talk about used
> oil - ground contamination or CFC's eating the ozone layer.
>
> >  Every time you
> >don't drive, every time you decide on the crappy straight 4 rather than
> >the high output v6, it has a real effect in CO2 emissions, and how much
> >longer we'll be able to live in a petroleum economy.
>
> The choice of vehicle (current vs. old) and the proper maintenance of the
> vehicle ensure low pollution rates - not necessarily the engine
> design.  Also, future technology may overtake our petrol supply... we did
> just take over Iraq...
>
> >If you want massive gas mileage and tons of handling/acceleration and all
> >that, motorcycles can be had that are more than you can handle new for
> >under $10,000.  And a lot of those bikes can get 100hp for a sub-500 pound
> >vehicle and still get close to 50mpg.  They can go between lanes legally
> >in California in traffic on highways, they're easier to work on (mine has
> >two spark plugs and two simple carbs, yay), and modern streetbikes can
> >last as long as a car mileswise.
>
> Bikes are great commuter vehicles for those brave souls that don't fear
> losing limbs or dying in a fender bender.  Some people prefer the safety of
> a metal body around them.  Even others prefer a vehicle with utility.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] gabber noise

Take a bench grinder, knock a chunk out of the grinding wheel so it's
unbalanced, then turn it on. It will thump like mad and if you poke it with
various metal objects you can control the overtones. There you have it. The
origins of gabber noise.

:: r ::

On Thu, 24 Apr 2003 13:32:16 -0700 (PDT), AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

> Well, a car's MPG doesn't matter when it's in bumper to bumper traffic.

HAHAHAH True enough :)

> Actually, all BMWs, I think a couple hondas (the Gold Wing for example
> exceeds 2008 CARB specs)  and some Suzukis like the VStrom have fully
> implemented emmissions controls on them (catalytic converter and all).

Yeah-I know a few manufacturers are finally stepping up to bat here and there-
But still-I don't know country-wide demographics-
But most of the bikes I see here are the R1/R6/GSXR ilk-and i sont see any cats getting dropped on those things until it becomes law-what with the intense competetion over a few lbs and a couple horesepower.

> Oxygen sensors which adjust the fuel/air mixture for ideal burnoff of fuel
> (good for performance AND for emissions) are commonplace now on fuel
> injected bikes, as well as air to exhaust measures like 'PAIR' to reduce
> hydrocarbon and particulate exhaust are in place too.

True-but fuel injection has only become "commonplace" in motorcycles literally over the past couple years.
And even then-not all of them are closed-loop o2-sensor systems.
Most bikes even a couple years old are using carbs.

> The EPA has a nasty habit of demonizing motorcycles that aren't even in
> production anymore, as recently as last year an EPA spokeperson made
> comments about motorcycle being 20 times nastier per mile than cars...
> that's only possible if you're comparing an off the line 2004 emissions
> spec honda in ideal circumstances with a race tuned 2 stroke 750 running a
> bit rich or one of those farting harleys that literally burp raw gas and
> chunks of carbon out the tailpipe cause they're only tuned to fire one
> every 5 revs or whatever.
>
> With these measures in place, and far smaller numbers as far as engine
> displacement, etc, modern motorcycles are about the same per mile than
> cars.  That said, they still use less gasoline per mile than most of the
> cars out there... especially cars in a similar performance envelope.  The
> superior emissions controls of cars go out the window in the real world,
> especially when people are chipping them, putting different exhausts on
> them to reduce backpressure, stomping the gas at every light, etc.

Yeah-I guess it just kinda annoys me that motorcycles arent built to be more ecofriendly-
I've always thought that it would be a pretty nice place if everyone rode motorcycles.
(because they *could be* very efficient compared to a car)

> I get better than 40mpg on my sv650s, and a 0-60 of 3-4 seconds.  I don't
> get stuck in traffic like cars do.  I can park in 1/3rd the space.  And
> it's bone stock... and I bought it cash.
>
> A recent analysis of contributions to smog among consumer vehicles by
> vehicle type put motorcycles at less than 1%, and SUVs at over 60%.
>
> I'm sick of all this arguing... just come out and say it... your' *real*
> problem with motorcycles is:
> http://www.b3ta.com/motorbikes/

Hahahah-well-I suppose my ass *is* up rather high on my 748, but not *that* high :p

Date: Thu, 24 Apr 2003 15:48:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: JBlaze112@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] wonderful transforming Target raver pants

--- JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
>     I think that the issue here, and the reason
> behind this "absense" of rave 
> culture in the real consumer market, the "pop" scene
> is the fear and the 
> unmotavation of a lot of the "big cats" in the rave
> and electronic dance 
> music industry. It seems to me that  a lot of people
> don't see electronic 
> dance music, clothing, and labels as a huge
> investment anymore because of the 
> dieing of the rave scene in recent years due to
> goverment actions and 
> enforced laws regurading drugs and safety issues. We
> no longer have so many 
> EDM fanatics who want to work for free and have lots
> of extra money because 
> most of us have become a little bit poorer
> econmically in the years, largely 
> because of our habit of partying and drugs. And
> largely because of 
> Corporation pregedous agaist ravers, not allowing
> radical hairstyles, 
> clothing, or piearcings at the workplace, in fear
> that it is "distracting". 
> As a result us ravers hate conservative corporations
> of that sort... thus 
> limiting our windows of oppertunity in life. Meaning
> therefor the EDM culture 
> does not have the big buisness boom of pop culture
> because all of the people 
> around it don't have as much money to spend. The
> people who should be making 
> these buisnesses no long have the money or the
> inspiration to do so... and 
> the people who would be buying these products
> generally don't have as much 
> money as people who buy "pop" products
> (clothing,music etc.)
>     In cluclusion I sincerily hope your "trust fund"
> friend goes out and does 
> all he can to push EDM music and clothing into the
> pop culture. I think the 
> scene will just dry up eventually if nobody goes out
> and promotes it to new 
> unexperienced audiences. But as for your question
> "why is there this absense 
> of big buisness?" and your astonishment as to why
> someone hasn't done all 
> this before... I think you have your answer, the
> rave industry and the EDM 
> industry alike have been oppressed by prejudices,
> stereo-types and even laws, 
> therefor as a whole our scene declining,
> ecomically... we don't buy things as 
> often and we don't create buisnesses and stick to
> them through all the hard 
> work because a lot of us are having a hard enough
> time "just getting by". 

okay I actually took some to think about this. I think
the answer has more to do with the differences between
pop music and rave music. because a few years ago,
when nobody was even slightly worried about just
getting by, this difference between the two worlds was
still pretty much there.

think instead about the difference between a superstar
DJ and a rap star. or a pop star, not really much
difference any more. Britney Spears works out like
four hours a day. this has nothing to do with music,
but it's crucial to what she does. she works out four
hours a day because she has to. pop music depends
primarily on television for its market. by contrast,
dance music depends on making people dance.

because of this, pop musicians tend to be people who
think about image. dance musicians don't really get to
think about image until they get big, but pop
musicians only get big in the first place if they get
their image to work for them. also, pop musicians only
really get to perform live if they're already selling
their music, but dance musicians generally only sell
their music if they're already performing, and
performing well, in the clubs and at raves.

a dance musician wants their music to make people jump
up and down, scream, shake their asses, and throw
their hands in the air. a pop musician wants their
music to make people continue watching television
until the video is over, and then go to the store and
buy the CD.

these are very different goals.

this means that pop musicians are simply much more
likely to gravitate towards image-centric things like
fashion. for example, Jay-Z's newest hit video is
based on a blue jeans commercial from several years
back.

btw: sleazenation magazine has an article on whether
or not hip-hop is creating the new fashion elite.

actually the hip-hop thing is worth thinking about.
Chicago and Detroit have always been under-represented
in hip-hop, because the black musicians in those
cities have always made techno and house instead. the
weird thing, tho, is that house -- which originated in
black clubs in Chicago -- is not really thought of as
black music, while rap -- which originated in
multicultural New York discos -- is. this perception
exists even tho the first rap single to hit the top
ten was "Rapture" by Blondie, a white woman leading a
white band. "West End Girls" by the Pet Shop Boys was
another early rap hit, and the Beastie Boys still use
disco styles even to this day.

in Chicago, the folks who make hip-hop are mostly
either white kids from the suburbs (like Detroit's
best rapper, Eminem) or black people who decided they
were following the money, rather than their hearts.
it's like, imagine you're a black person living in
Chicago. you have to ask yourself this question: am I
gonna make black music, and be broke, or am I gonna
make the music which MTV claims is black music, and
get rich? there was this one talented house producer
in Chicago who also made hip-hop. one day, Puff Daddy
shows up with a briefcase full of hundred-dollar
bills. that producer hasn't made a house record since.

(however, as shown by the small number of Chicago
rappers and the large number of Chicago house records,
most folks from Chicago, black or otherwise, choose
house over rap. this is because Chicago is awesome.)

the demographic mythology of hip-hop masks the fact
that the real difference between hip-hop and dance
music is that rappers make videos, and money. if
you're a rapper, you need to be able to convincingly
pretend to perform -- like lip-syncing in your video
-- a lot more than you need to actually be able to
really perform. DJs, on the other hand, have to be
able to perform, and because of this electronic dance
music is more real, but the people who make it rarely
make even half as much money as the pop musicians do.
however, this doesn't actually mean they're poor --
top name DJs still make shitloads of money, although
they often have to go to Europe to do it.

but, if your focus is money, rather than music, you're
more likely to be making pop music than dance music
anyway. that's why Eminem makes rap -- because "nobody
listens to techno."

anyway, that might not be the answer, but it feels
like a reasonably accurate explanation.


Giles

At 10:23 AM 4/24/2003, Nathan Seven wrote:

>Ive had some interesting thoughts about even those "alternative energy 
>sources"-
>
>We can sit here now and say that wind power is totally clean, and solar 
>power is totally clean, and tide power is totally clean.
>(Tide power btw just uses the water rising and lowering with the waves at 
>the shore to turn turbines-nothing too special there-it works just like a dam)
>
>But-I wonder what the actual implications of using that would be-
>We didn't realize that coal plants would cause global gas-mixture changes...
>Similarly, what would happen to the weather if all the worlds power was 
>generated with wind.
>That's a LOT of windmills slowing the jetstreams and such down.
>What would the consequences be?
>I certainly dont know-
>And tidal?
>Would a mass resistance to tidal forces cause some unforseen change in the 
>oceans?
>
>I still can't find any possible downfall to solar-it's not efficient 
>enough yet to cause any sort of surface heat-loss-but when solar cells 
>become efficient, they will convert what now heats the earth in to electricity.
>Will this cause some slight planet-wide cooldown?
>??????
>
>Anyway-enough rambling for me-
>

--0-615239525-1051234292=:95535

Johnny,

 

Hey, I know what you mean.

 

And I appreciate your post.  We all contribute to something.  And we can 

all attempt to pollute our environment less and less (or more and more, I guess).

  It’s just a matter of degrees.  And while a lot of people here seem to have

 a flippant attitude in their responses (I can drive a gas guzzler if I want to damn it

 and don’t try to make me feel bad about it) I think our society as a whole is 

getting better about reducing pollution.  Notwithstanding the Bush Administration’s

 push for actually using more oil and drilling in the Alaska wilderness (hey fuck the

 caribou, who needs open clean nature reserves anyway?) I think the younger

 generations get it.

 

At least I can see it in my own family.  I mean my dad still thinks pouring 

used motor oil in the ground in his back yard is all OK and dandy, no harmful

 affects.  What’s the environment?  And he is of the same generation as 

Bush, Cheney, et al.  I on the other hand realize recycling that same oil is 

a lot more logical, sane and forward-thinking approach.  I didn’t learn that from

 my dad.  I learned the lesson from school, media, PBS…from people like you 

who care enough to speak up and say hey, look what you are doing.  Don’t get 

me wrong, I am NOT a super freak nature hippy.  Not that they are bad.  Let’s 

just say I hope I’m headed in the right direction.  And I appreciate thoughtful 

comments given in an effort to help improve the world we live in.

 

So don’t get discouraged.  Haven’t you figured out how lists like this work? Don’t take it personal.

 

-- Original Message –

From:       JBlaze112@aol.com

Date:       Thu, 24 Apr 2003 16:22:18 EDT

To:          scosol@yahoo.com, grindingbassline@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject:    Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

 

ok so does not anyone know what i mean when i say that technology can 

be geared towards cleaning the world? no it does not mean that in one single day 

we'll have the answer because of this one email i sent to sf raves... it does 

not mean that all alternative power sources are clean besides fuel...what it 

means is that if you scientifically look at the pros  & cons for each source 

of polution and each possible alternative to it, and you always chose the 

less harmful process, eventually you have a cleaner world than you would 

have, if, say we just all had negative attitudes and made it seem as 

though the world is just hopelessly doomed... and any suggestion to make the 

world better is just somebody's naive misunderstanding that needs to be made 

fun of.     have you ever noticed how in futuristic movies (such as star wars) 

the people on other planets have this "tribal" essense about them, yet they 

do have highly advanced technology as well? that's because we 

subconsciously know what an ideal civilization should be like and what it takes to 

survive that far into the future. if we made all of our technology focused on 

the idea of environmentalism rather than capitalism, there would be 100,000 

times less waiste. the waiste comes from cost efficiancy, what simple people 

like to buy and what they are accustomed to, and basically just fear and 

greed.     that's my point. am i saying that people are going to read this 

email and send it all over the world and pollution will be gone within a few 

days? no, so don't get it confused when i say we can graduallly stop pollution by 

focusing technology on it, that doesn't mean i'm saying i have the 

ultamite answer to stop pollution forver! i mean it's like i'm sitting here 

giving suggestions that may or may not work and i feel like peopel are reading 

it and they are resentful of what i have to say... it's rediculous if you 

ask me.

 

tired of the snickering... - johnny

Pipes Decriminalized in California Despite Federal Laws
Thurs, April 4, 2003


In yet another split between state and federal drug laws, a state appellate 
court ruled last week that possession of marijuana pipes is decriminalized 
in California. This comes just six weeks after bong-sellers around the 
nation were targeted by a federal raid.

The Court of Appeal panel in Riverside County found that the same 1975 
California law that changed marijuana possession from a possible felony to 
an infraction "deliberately decriminalized the possession of a device for 
smoking marijuana."

Under federal law such smoking devices remain illegal. Drug paraphernalia 
is defined federally as those products that are primarily intended or 
designed to be used in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise using controlled 
substances. This includes marijuana pipes, cocaine freebase kits, and 
miniature scales.

On Feb. 24, federal agents raided more than 100 homes and businesses 
throughout the nation that sell bongs and pipes. Fifty people were charged 
with trafficking illegal drug paraphernalia. Several internet sites that 
allegedly peddled the paraphernalia were also shut down and the domain 
names confiscated. Visitors to those Web sites are now redirected to a DEA 
site that cites the law against the sale of such items.

While federal laws continue to classify marijuana as a dangerous narcotic, 
increasing numbers of people will be prosecuted for marijuana related 
crimes. In an effort to reduce anti-marijuana pressure from the federal 
government, Drug Policy Alliance this week backed the City and County of 
Santa Cruz as they launched the first ever lawsuit by a public entity 
against the federal government on behalf of patients who need medical 
marijuana. The lawsuit, County of Santa Cruz v. Ashcroft et. al., asks the 
federal courts to enjoin the federal government from raiding the Wo/Men's 
Alliance for Medical Marijuana gardens, which operate legally under 
California's 1996 Compassionate Use Act (Prop. 215).

  http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/04_24_03pipes.cfm

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

...with dual turbos ;)

of course they aren't "burning" the hydrogen apollo :P

however, this is still just a method of efficiently storing energy (about 40% total efficiency vs
20% total efficiency of gas and 30% total efficiency of diesel.)  hopefully they will find
technologically feasible ways to do heat recovery on lightweight portable fuel cells and up the
efficiency to around 80%.  gimme a 2 acres of land covered with solar cells storing up hydrogen and
pure drinking water for me all day long, a 200KW fuel cell and lightweight motor that will fit in a
2000lb car and i'll be a happy "sustainable" speed freak hippy.

see, you still have to get the energy from somewhere and that is ultimately the sun.

the first methods of rapidly extracting stored heat energy was by burning dead trees, then from dead
animals.  the only way to sustain without affecting the ecological balance is by slowing down.  and
by this, i mean exponentially from where we are today.  sure, i can slow down even further than i
have by giving up my final energy vice of a fossil-fueled vehicle, but that will only buy the next
oblivious homo sapien another 1/16th of a lifetime in their Unimog.  my life is precious to me and i
am here to enjoy it.  as long as my life does not cause undue harm to those around me, and does not
*directly* harm those of the future (e.g. blatant toxic dumping, etc.) then i feel i am doing as
much as i can by minimizing energy use when possible, in light of driving my *gasp* 26MPG "ricer"
car.  while not trying to harm the lives of the future, i am not willing to give up my livelihood
for theirs.

you can talk "alternative" energy sources into the ground but mark my words : until we unlock the
secrets of easily manipulating quantum mechanics, the only "sustainable" energy source is the sun.

-=dave

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Techno

At 01:51 AM 4/25/2003 +0000, you wrote:
 >I've been enjoying the techno that I've been hearing people like Teks and 
Anton Styles spinning. Can you fine folks recommend some artists that I can 
look for?

Word up to Teks... Just got in touch with this fellow for the first time 
last weekend on the way to a nice house party down in the south bay... We 
laid down a spontaneous 2X4 that was real fun 
(http://www.squid.com/pics/2003.04.18-Charlie_B-Day/mid/IMG_0085.jpg)... 
Probably the most fun I've had doing a 2X4 without previously meeting the 
other DJ. Actually... shit... it really was really just my 2nd time doing a 
2X4 (anyone else up for it?); first time was with a techno DJ from Spain 
who didn't speak English (no Spanish from me); that was a trip too... Who 
knows Teks and I might go at it again out there somewhere..

Hell... one of my most fun experiences was spontaneously running with 
DDR  2xLivePAx2.. heh heh... He totally tried to duck out on me, but got 
into it when I didn't fuck up [that bad! ;P ]..  I highly recommend it if 
any of you gets a chance to try this... The DJ has to keep his records 
locked onto the live PA as the fellow controlling the livePA brings out his 
track to just the basskick/snare/cymbal before building up the next one as 
the DJ slowly EQs/pulls out the record all the while you are cutting back 
and forth grabbing fills from the livePA.... I digress...

Anyway, Teks is more on the progressive/club techno side, so maybe stuff 
like Umek, Henrik B, Dave Angel, Samuel L. Session would fit the bill; all 
fairly popular (though I guess that is debatable out here), etc. Maybe 
labels like Primate, Illgorhythm, Jericho, Phont, Rotation, would be 
"Prime" to check out....

If you get that far do consider joining the dark side by picking up some 
hard techno... ;)

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/

SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: e-mail list services ?

If you are running a Unix box, ezlm.. as far as user friendly.. Here are
some alternatives: (key word here is "free email list management sw"

Majordomo2
http://www.ncsu.edu/it/essentials/learn_more/a_z_tutorials/lists_services_intro/

Topica Email Publisher
http://www.qksrv.net/click-61738-10280459
Send professional newsletters via Topica Email Publisher: try it for 30
days FREE!

CoolList
http://www.coollist.com/
Free mailing list service provider.

FreeLists
http://freelists.org
FreeLists provides ad-free fully functional mailing list services for
technology-oriented lists. FreeLists offers web-based tools for managing
lists, and maintains archives automatically.

MSN Groups
http://groups.msn.com/
The free MSN Groups service enables you to set up a mini-site that
combines message boards, chat rooms and a photo album with a mailing list.
NOTE: To set up or join a group, you'll first need to sign up for a free
Microsoft Passport.

SmartGroups
http://www.smartgroups.com/
You can set up a free "group", which will have access to a variety of
tools such as a photo album, shared file storage, a calendar, polls and
various other goodies. The group can act as a mailing list, and messages
directed to the group get distributed to the various members.

Topica
http://www.topica.com
Topica offers a very attractive and comprehensive-looking service. You can
create different types of lists, such as discussion lists or newsletters.
You can choose to have moderated or unmoderated discussion lists, and open
or private lists. You can even choose to generate automatic digests out of
a discussion list. On the flip side, Topica offers lots of resources to
help you find interesting lists to subscribe to.

YourMailingListProvider
http://www.yourmailinglistprovider.com/
This service provides a sophisticated, ad-free list management service.
You can import a database of subscribers, generate statistics, mail out in
plain text and HTML, and much more...


 On Thu, 24 Apr 2003, Me wrote:

-----Original Message-----
From: Karina [mailto:karina@hyperreal.org] 
Sent: Friday, April 25, 2003 2:40 AM
To: Me
Cc: SF Raves
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: e-mail list services ?


If you are running a Unix box, ezlm.. as far as user friendly.. Here are
some alternatives: (key word here is "free email list management sw"

Majordomo2
http://www.ncsu.edu/it/essentials/learn_more/a_z_tutorials/lists_service
s_intro/

Topica Email Publisher http://www.qksrv.net/click-61738-10280459
Send professional newsletters via Topica Email Publisher: try it for 30
days FREE!

CoolList
http://www.coollist.com/
Free mailing list service provider.

FreeLists
http://freelists.org
FreeLists provides ad-free fully functional mailing list services for
technology-oriented lists. FreeLists offers web-based tools for managing
lists, and maintains archives automatically.

MSN Groups
http://groups.msn.com/
The free MSN Groups service enables you to set up a mini-site that
combines message boards, chat rooms and a photo album with a mailing
list.
NOTE: To set up or join a group, you'll first need to sign up for a free
Microsoft Passport.

SmartGroups
http://www.smartgroups.com/
You can set up a free "group", which will have access to a variety of
tools such as a photo album, shared file storage, a calendar, polls and
various other goodies. The group can act as a mailing list, and messages
directed to the group get distributed to the various members.

Topica
http://www.topica.com
Topica offers a very attractive and comprehensive-looking service. You
can create different types of lists, such as discussion lists or
newsletters. You can choose to have moderated or unmoderated discussion
lists, and open or private lists. You can even choose to generate
automatic digests out of a discussion list. On the flip side, Topica
offers lots of resources to help you find interesting lists to subscribe
to.

YourMailingListProvider
http://www.yourmailinglistprovider.com/
This service provides a sophisticated, ad-free list management service.
You can import a database of subscribers, generate statistics, mail out
in plain text and HTML, and much more...

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

In the bay area growing up the Lawrence Hall of Science would come to your
school and do experiments to bring more interest to science. I'll never
forget the balloon full of hydrogen meets mr flame on stage in 3rd grade.
When I learned that you could produce hydrogen by running high current
through water I did. Made for a nice ball of fire too. The point of all this
is the thought of a hydrogen fueling station scares me in that if that
sucker blew up that would be a disaster. A gas station on fire is pretty
much contained right there. I tank of compressed hydrogen going off would be
like a small nuke. If we could only produce hydrogen on demand internally in
a car that would be killah! Fuel cells basically do that, but they're still
bulky and not super efficient in the production of the gas. We need
ourselves some Protoculture straight out of Robotech or microfusion
generators. Light weight electric motors (or something similar) at all for
wheels of a car with a long lasting energy source would blow my mind. Can I
have that please? You can take the gas pumper out of my car!

:: r y a n ::

powered by hydrogen.

I found the link I was looking for:
http://www.enhancedhealth.com/explosionPic1.jpg

That is what happened when a small NOS tank exploded in the trunk of this car.
Do you really want to be driving around with a tank right next to you that will have to hold about 50x that much?

Note-this is not fire damage-this is purely die to the metal weakening and the gas exploding.

bad...

Acetacillic Acid myself..

Subject: [sfraves]Memories of past parties

When I was 17(21 now) I had a job at a drug store and every weekend I would 
*take* 2-3 big bags of dum dum lollipops.  At that point in time the 
crackhouse on E.11th was poppn!  So in the beginning, everyone was sitting 
around waiting for the vibe to explode so I walked around and passed out a 
bag of lollipops, that was cool...it definitley sets the mood.  But the 
thing I loved the most was when it's like 4am and everyone is totally feelin 
the vibe and in the mood.  So I break out another bag and start passing it 
out.  I just LOVED the look on people's faces when they grab a handful of 
lollipops from my bag.  It's like I was the messiah or something...lol.  
Great vibe.

fable....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] where to go on thursday??  like now!

Well, NEXT Thursday is The Braintree:

The BrainTree, San Francisco's premiere monthly creative arts happening,
launches it's third event, 8:30pm-2:30am, Thursday May 1 at 1015 Folsom
SF. Admission $7-12 sliding scale-free before 9pm.
(www.thebraintree.org)

Springtime, organic-flower day, and the politically charged atmosphere
inspires the May 1st, collaboration, an evening not to be missed.

Performance by: Sutro.  A melodic electro-quartet, led by female
vocalist and renowned producer Tyler Stone, who has remix and production
credits with greats such as Sting and Everything but the Girl.
www.wanderlustmusic.com

Drop Culture, project of the prolific and multi-talented visual/sound
artist Duser or Duserock and his brother Darrell Stubbs- They just
signed a track to OM records. (y4k)

Karmacoda, the perfect aural escape from our ultra-commercialized
planet, trip-hop, drum+bass with live instruments and vocals.
www.karmacoda.com

Drum Fire(om records/ afro mystic) w/ Steve Grant(kneedeep) drum+breaks


DJ's:
Linden C,
Laron(pshychofunkodiscodelic),
DJ 34(braintree)
Evan Madden( www.beattherapysf.com )
DJ Alexander,
Justincredible(dirtylittlebitch)
and Danny Shorago.

Visual Artists:
Visionary organic sculptor Ron Sandoval,
BurningMan Pioneer, sculptor and interactive artist Michael Christian
(www.michaelchristian.com),
Photographer Karl Seifert,
Sculptor/Installation artist Justin Young,
Belgian materials genius Eefje Theeuns,
Poetry sculptor Thwen Chaloemtiarana,
Mixed Media artist Jimmy "Love" Little(www.jameslittlegallery.com)
Sculptor Barry Monigle,
Bio-artist Christopher Fishcer,

Video mix-mastering by Dr.Friendly (www.dr.friendly.com) and DiGiTaL DaN
(www.dandoerner.com)


We'll be giving away tickets on KZSU.

YOUR REQUEST HAS BEEN GRANTED.

esteemed and highly successful gabber noise.

will rapidly degrade the program.

disorders, and hot flashes.

You're very welcome.

Yo Brandon, this is too late for ya, but if you didn’t end up going to DNA, you should have!  That shit was off the hook.  Amber in the main room, laying down some dark techno (although no one was dancing, which sucks – it looked like a jazz show or something, everyone sitting at tables in a semi-circle around Amber.  Maybe it’s because she’s so good – like everyone just sits there in awe watchin??  Or because she’s so cute.  Amber rocks – thanks Amber, I never did get to say hi.  So hi.)

 

And upstairs Femmes Fatales with Audio Angel throwing in sick vocals.  In my version of heaven, these 3 women will be spinning all the time…uh, I won’t go into any more detail than that, cuz it will get me in trouble…but were talking serious-sick heavy bass, all fucked up and dirty.  Then Coop, then StarEyes, shit man, I got all that for 5 bucks?

 

Oh, AND my friend told me there was a fashion show (that I missed cuz I was too busy dancing in the lounge) but he had fun watching it.  Well, I don’t think he actually watched the show; he was too busy tying to catch a peek at the models switching outfits in the upstairs mezzanine area.  Which I thought was funny; he was so excited telling me about it, you would think he never saw naked breasts before.  Like isn’t that just normal for fashion shit?

 

So see, if you were not there, you seriously missed out – strong drinks, sick beats, and naked boobies.  Who could ask for more than that? (rhetorical sarcastic comment – don’t answer that)

> who didn't speak English (no Spanish from me); that was a trip too... Who 
> knows Teks and I might go at it again out there somewhere..

> DDR  2xLivePAx2.. heh heh... He totally tried to duck out on me, but got 
> into it when I didn't fuck up [that bad! ;P ]..  I highly recommend it if 
> any of you gets a chance to try this... The DJ has to keep his records 
> locked onto the live PA as the fellow controlling the livePA brings out his
> 
> track to just the basskick/snare/cymbal before building up the next one as 
> the DJ slowly EQs/pulls out the record all the while you are cutting back 
> and forth grabbing fills from the livePA.... I digress...
> 
> Anyway, Teks is more on the progressive/club techno side, so maybe stuff 
> like Umek, Henrik B, Dave Angel, Samuel L. Session would fit the bill; all 
> fairly popular (though I guess that is debatable out here), etc. Maybe 
> labels like Primate, Illgorhythm, Jericho, Phont, Rotation, would be 
> "Prime" to check out....
> 
> If you get that far do consider joining the dark side by picking up some 
> hard techno... ;)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

what's not sustainable about them ? well, it's like trying to use co-generation as your primary type
of powerplant... there just isn't enough.

first, it is more feasible to do solar-cell -> electricity than to try and spend months and months
to grow a bunch of corn, extract the small about of energy stored in the oils, then ship them out to
your local "mazola" filling station.  there just isn't enough farmable land in the world to sustain
our vehicle needs.

likewise, there's not enough feces in the world to do it.  i'm all for reclaiming that small amount
of energy that is not put to use in fertilizer, but it just doesn't come remotely close as an
alternative to fosil-fueled vehicles.  then again, maybe you shit a lot more than i do ;)

now as soon as we figure out "warm" superconductivity and are able to cheaply build "perfect"
magnets (i don't think we are far off with this one), i will be the first one on the block to
over-voltage my electric sports car :)

-=dave

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] so you want to save the world . . .

hi party people,

i used to think that if we don't change our ways right this second the planet is going to be in trouble in the 
next century.  but since then i've realized that there are 5 billion people in the world that will never agree on 
anything, so changes in the environment are going to happen slowly, and oriented around profit.  i've 
accepted that so it doesn't stress me out so much that we're not moving with lightning speed and all uniting 
to save the planet.  that doesn't mean i don't think people shouldn't make noise about the issues they care 
about, but i'd caution people not to get too stressed out about it.  there's a good chance that what any of us 
have to say will make little impact on the world.

SE/30 wrote:
listen to a crystal radio

synch your waking hours with the sun

do not ride bart

do not ride the bus

do not go anywhere

this kind of stuff is a really funny stress reliever.  i think we've all gone through moments like this where we 
realize our very existence costs *something* and life on earth just seems sort of hopeless.

At 6:13 AM -0400 4/24/03, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
there's no reason to think that that means we
have to eliminate technology and shit in holes in the ground and whipe our
asses with leaves. You can in fact have both, A technologically advanced,
neo-tribalistic environment is the real Utopian dream. just think about it.

this is very true.  i suspect, though, that most of the people on SFR already know this.  having enough 
people that care in the right places in life are what make things really happen.  how many of us have an 
extra few billion dollars in our back pocket ready to start a new wind platform on the ocean to produce 
power?  even if osby got really busy and sold enough tickets for the next SFR fundraiser (hey get to work 
man!), who's to say building something like that might not be more harmful to the environment than we 
originally thought?

At 6:31 PM -0700 4/24/03, Pedro wrote:
At least I can see it in my own family.  I mean my dad still thinks pouring
used motor oil in the ground in his back yard is all OK and dandy, no harmful
 affects.  Whatís the environment?  And he is of the same generation as
Bush, Cheney, et al.

i don't think this has as much to do with a generation gap as we might think.  a lot of the hippies from the 
60's are now about bush, cheney, and al gore's age, as well as ralph nader and jerry brown, to name a few 
people from different ends of the political spectrum.

btw, i just wanted to make a comment about those bio-diesel cars and busses and other cars with 
alternative fuels.  i think it's a great alternative to gasoline, but at its current technology level it's not 
particularly attractive to the average middle american who wants to drive his or her urban assault vehicle 
(SUV) to drop off the 2.5 kids off at school before going to work )and oh by the way can we stop at 
burger king too?)  in order for something like that to make the average person who really doesn't care 
about the environment at all, it has to appeal to those people too.  can you imagine a 170 hp Volkswagen 
GTI running on vegetable oil or maybe hydrogen?   i think it's going to take more years of development to 
make something like that when companies also have to worry about their bottom line and so have their 
resources diverted toward producing gasoline engines.

again, it takes enough people in the right places to get things moving.  so why not take a moment to rejoice 
some of the things that have improved the environment?

oh, ah ... well, uh ... i can't think of anything right now.   =\

war,

deepfog

Subject: [sfraves] re: sober and socially responsible people should set up shows nrr

--0-1668894177-1051398433=:7112
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

something that i have been thinking a whole lot about especially since a big fire killed a bunch of people at a nightclub back east recently and also, since soooooooo, soooooo many people in the local scene and in the country have drinking and drug issues, is the importance that people who set up electrical equipment or spend a lot of time on it or around it and other people simultaniously (sp?) should be sober. it is hard to know who is sober and when, i understand. the fire that killed the people at the club back east had to do with the fact that someone set up pirotechnics (sp? fire on stage for art's sake) at an indoor event, not so much alcohol or drug dependence, however, when people do stuff like that, they apparently aren't thinking straight at all, and so, of course, i question their state of mind and always, their chemical state of being. these are issues people should be taking into consideration pre-accident/pre-event. people do it all of the time in other avenues of social participation, whether it be business or a child's basketball game. i don't know what protocall is like for every production company in the world, but i do know that setting up a gig is much like driving a car. a lot of people are with their loved ones and are quite responsible and sober, also,  a lot of people don't care, will lie to get what they want and will put other responsible people at risk for injury or death. :)

---------------------------------

i only called this post fashion sense, because i just bought a couple of sets of earrings. i am thinking about business, and how people often rely on statistics that are compiled in a variety of ways, and that actually have no actual bearing on what is going on, and how i might actually benefit from that sort of practice. i mean, i wouldn't have had time to go shopping for my cute earrings that i got for a great deal had i not been sort of coherced into attending an early morning meeting this morning, and also, since i do not have a specific title, i get out of a lot of responsibility while also maintaining a high and admirable profile. weird. i can hardly believe it myself. can't help but doubt, you know. :)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Dance Culture Spirituality

Often times when I've gone to a rave or talked to people who have attended, 
I've heard stories about various "spiritual" experiences, people have had at 
these events.  Often these have taken place on the dance floor while dancing 
on some substance.  I'm doing a project for my sociology class, and I wanted 
to survey how wide spread this phenominon is, and just what impact raves are 
having on our spiritual lives, if any.

Please set aside some time to take this 40 question survey.  39 questions 
are multiple choice, with the final question offering space for individual 
feedback.  The survey is totally anonymous, and no identifying information 
from this survey will be requested or used in any way, so please be as 
honest and forth right as possible.  Thank you!

The link to the Survey is here:
http://www.djmook.com/soc/

:-)
MooK<><

Subject: RE: [sfraves] bsp: qool happy hour @ 111 minna

Hi there, guys!

  It's not that entirely that difficult to get on the Q-List if
you still have a Qool Qard...in fact its really easy.  Just go
to the same line as before, show them your Qard and they'll
convert it to a Q-List spot.  No prob.  Ask Big Dave or Tiffany
to take care of the sit' for ya.  It's fun!

--- Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> FYI -
> 
> The QOOL card program was retired by Qool a few months back. I
> was @ Qool
> about two weeks ago, Spesh rocks the socks off anyone w/ an
> itch to dance.
> This event is worth the trip.. Everyone here is happy, smiling
> and many
> dance - the floor is always packed. I've had my card, thanks
> to GIL, for
> years, I've also appreciated Qool as a great, mellow, and fun
> place to
> spend my Wednesday night.
> 
> The Qool card has been replaced by the Qlist - Info:
> 
> What's the Q-list?
> Here at Loöq Records we've started a new thing, the Q-List.
> Q-Listers get
> VIP treatment at Loöq parties. The Q-List is an inner circle
> of dedicated
> partiers, people who are about the vibe, connecting with each
> other, and
> getting into the music. Does this fit your M.O.? If you want
> to be on the
> Q-List, write us a short essay (or a long one, if you are
> feeling
> inspired) about you, why you go clubbing, and why you are so
> exceptional
> that you belong on the Q-List. If writing is not your thing,
> feel free to
> send us something else that represents you (a picture of you,
> something
> you made, something that made you, etc.).
> 
> Please send all Q-List submissions to q-list@looq.com or:
> 
> Loöq Records
> 182 Howard St. PMB 133
> San Francisco, CA 94105
> 
> If you make the Q-List we'll let you know!
> 
> Another FYI from their site (www.looq.com)
> 
> 04.11.03 MINNA OPEN, BIG ROOM CLOSED UNTIL EARLY MAY(-ISH)
> Due to a regulatory/licensing snafu, the Minna Street Gallery
> apparently
> does not currently have all the permits it needs to serve
> alcohol in the
> big room. However, nothing else has changed - Minna is still
> open (with
> smaller, but still full, bar) for Loöq Hard, Qoöl, and other
> events, they
> will just be compressed into the "old room" for the moment.
> Should be
> cosy, and fun (but of course we will be vigilant about not
> overpacking the
> place). We would apologize on behalf of Minna, but in the past
> this kind
> of salad tossing has generally led to even more fun being had
> than usual,
> so we will wait and see how it goes! Back to the way it once
> was ...
>

Oh yes. Good Idea. I am filthy! I mean I smell REALLY BAD! I haven't taken a shower since 1993, and that time I got caught in the rain at Lolapaloza. And a *fucking  shower* is a lot more fun than showering alone, any of you sexy, stinky  hippies want to join me and my husband? (Not you, troll boy) the more the merrier! we can save water and use my homemade pathouli soap that I bartered for at the communist farmer's market!

In case you can't tell, I'm being sarcastic, well, except for the tofu fake cheese part. I really do have high cholesterol. And I  really do have some pathouli soap, but I bought it with money at the most yuppified farmers market i have ever seen in Sunnyvale, and I do think fucking in the shower is fun. And I like to bathe with sexy stinky hippies... OH HELL! you caught me!

Ok, seriously, usualy when I say that "capitalist/conspiracy" stuff, I am holding onto or riding my Specialized Allez with the Ritchie hubs and Kevlar tires and my sweet "Speed She" seat, the fanciest and most expensive bike I have ever owned... The Irony is comletely lost online, aparently. I didn't think anyone would actualy take me seriously! Geeze! Who talks like that? I MEAN COME ON! Just like I don't really think world peace can be achived by dosing world leaders with exctacy! That's INSANE! Yeah, there is a grain of truth to it, I hate cars, but it would be boring as hell if I sat here and told you why, and I don't shower every day, unless im working out, but it's because I have dry skin, but trust me,  I *have * showered since1993, at least a couple of times : P

LIGHTEN UP YOU PARTY PEOPLE!

Subject: [sfraves] Re: [ASR] Dance Culture Spirituality

Just as a reference, I'd suggest you take a look at "Traces of the Spirit:
The Religious Dimensions of Popular Music" by Robin Sylvan.  It's on Amazon
if nowhere else.  He was one of my professors at college, and the Music and
Religion course I took with him was the best class I've ever taken.  It
changed my life and my perception of what "the scene" meant to me.

-Andrew

X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: [ASR] Dance Culture Spirituality

Hmm...looks interesting:

Summary:
Traces of the Spirit: The Religious Dimensions of Popular Music

by Robin Sylvan [8/02]

"Most studies of the religious significance of popular music focus on
music lyrics, offering little insight into the religious aspects of the
music itself. Traces of the Spirit examines the religious dimensions of
popular music subcultures, charting the influence and religious aspects of
popular music in mainstream culture today and analyzing the religious
significance of the audience's experiences, rituals, and worldviews.
Sylvan contends that popular music subcultures serve the function of
religious communities and represent a new and significant religious
phenomenon. Drawing on ethnographic fieldwork using interviews and
participant observation, Sylvan examines such subcultures as the
Deadheads, raves and their participants, metalheads, and Hip Hop culture.
Based on these case studies, he offers a comprehensive theoretical
framework in which to study music and popular culture. In addition, he
traces the history of West African possession religion from Africa to the
diaspora to its integration into American popular music in such genres as
the blues, rock and roll, and contemporary musical youth subcultures."

-t

Subject: [sfraves] Blasphemental

------=_NextPart_000_002B_01C30D18.996EFDB0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi All,
    I had never heard of the Phoenix Family, but I went to their party =
last night at the Noodle Factory, and had an amazing time! I don't think =
I've ever been to a psy-trance party before. None of my friends were =
there, and I didn't know anyone. I felt a little bit awkward since I was =
dressed up a little for the cocktail party that I went to before hand. I =
was talking to one girl and as we talked, I realized that while I might =
think that I'm dialed into the party scene here in the Bay Area, there =
is this whole other circle of parties that I had no idea about. She =
named crews and venues that I had never heard of, and she hadn't heard =
of a lot of what I knew. I realized that sometimes when I am at the =
Tenderloft or New Hack City, there might be other underground parties =
going on within blocks of me that I am totally oblivious to! I could =
tell that my buddy was tired and not feeling the party, so I took him =
home, then ran home to change into more comfortable clothing. It was =
about 4am when I got back to the party.
   I talked to one of the members of Phoenix Family, and he had me add =
my email address to their mailing list, so hopefully I will hear about =
their future events. I had so much fun! While jungle has ruined me for =
house and breaks, I found that the psy-trance, while still slower than =
jungle, moved me and kept me dancing for hours! The party had 2 main =
rooms with djs and dancing, a smoking room and a chill room with djs =
spinning some really mellow, downtempo stuff. A couple of times I went =
in there, sat on a cushion on the floor, closed my eyes and just enjoyed =
the feel of the music washing over me.
   There were a couple of people with poi. I am just learning how to =
dance with poi, but I got to get a lot of practice in last night, and =
actually got a lot better. I learned some new moves and by the time I =
drove home, my left arm was totally sore! I left the party when it ended =
at 6am, and the sky was bright, but the sun hadn't yet come over the =
Oakland hills yet. So, I drove up to the top of the hills so that I =
could see the sun and the new day. I stood on top of the hill, listening =
to the birds chirping, feeling the earth waking up and I gave thanks to =
God for allowing me to experience such simple but profound beauty.

Happy  :-)

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs

"People are about as happy as they make up their minds to be." -Abraham =
Lincoln=20

"Very little is needed to make a happy life;=20
it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking." -Marcus Aurelius =
Antoninus 
------=_NextPart_000_002B_01C30D18.996EFDB0--

In-Reply-To: <Law9-F98NbMrRn01Lrt0000f5af@hotmail.com>
Message-Id: <341C2FF6-795E-11D7-BE0E-000A95675DE0@myrealbox.com>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.552)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-music makin software

Check out Synapse Orion ($150?), Fruityloops ($49+), Reason ($200) Buzz 
(Free). Depending on your budget. There are also a vast number of 
freely availible VST instruments, effects, etc.

Check out http://www.kvr-vst.com for a list of them and also commercial 
ones. The message board on that site is excellent also.

Other good sites are:
http://www.computermusic.co.uk
http://www.futureproducers.com
http://www.fuktstereo.com

You should also get a midi keyboard to enter notes easier. Check out 
the Midiman Oxygen 8. It's going for $100 on ebay. It's build quality 
is questionable though. Check out other companies like Evolution, 
Roland, etc too. I believe they are all coming out some new mini 
keyboards with lots of knobs.

Visit my site also at http://www.deciblast.org/ There's a few producers 
that post on there. I'll always be around to answer questions.

Deepak
Deciblast http://www.deciblast.org/

To: "Alicia C." <redordead1313@hotmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-music makin software


On Mon, 28 Apr 2003, Alicia C. wrote:
-&e->Hi all,
-&e->
-&e->I was just wondering what the best electronic music program for a pc
-&e->computer is.  I have a dell lattitude notebook. I wanna start making music
-&e->but i don't want a janky program with which to get started!  Thanks

Well, I know you don't want to hear this, but the needs of someone
starting out ARE different.  You want something cheap, that will be able
to finish a track, without any step in the process being too difficult to
figure out.

Fruity Loops, Acid, Reason and Buzz (as mentioned before) are all great
places to start.  I prefer Reason and Buzz because they allow a more
creative approach than using mostly sampled loops (the examples in reason
are great, and cover many genres and ways of doing things).

Down the road I strongly suggest freeing those ties and going with Logic,
Cubase, Nuendo, or Cakewalk... as well as a good audio editor, recycle,
and a good batch of plugins (Waves makes great sounding plugins!).

You could even use totally free tools like pure-data (pure-data.org) or
csound (csounds.com) to make full on tracks with samples, synths, effects
and all that (hell with either one of those you can do stuff none of the
above listed commercial products can do at all!).

it's just a matter of how you want to work.

i use a mac running logic for most of my studio work, and wrote my own
application for my live sets using max/msp (I'll be debuting a new version
of that at Mindcontrol if you wanna check it out).

andyw

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


From sfraves-return-101627-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Apr 28 12:53:12 2003

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61471 invoked from network); 28 Apr 2003 12:53:11 -0000
Date: Mon, 28 Apr 2003 08:52:56 -0400
From: ALTRDVISON@aol.com
To: redordead1313@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Message-ID: <3767DBF2.73B37BF4.09D212BA@aol.com>
X-Mailer: Atlas Mailer 2.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-music makin software

Reason with Cubase SX are the hands down best for producing electronic music.  You can scrap the rest.  Having both apps open you can work between them using Rewire (easy to set up one you get the hang) from there its cake.  Rewire all your Reason tracks through SX and then effect them using VST plug ins.  You can sequence in Reason and in SX.  Do your mastering with SX using Waves plugins or equivalent.  After your done with a track hit export - mixdown and your track/song is rendered in seconds.  Many VSTs, Reason and SX are available for free on many warez sites.  Try it out then buy.  Get hooked with a USB2 sound card and your set (M-Audio has a nice new one).  Good luck.

Jon

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

--0-1456732133-1051543622=:49440

Mark, People since ancient times have been having spiritual experiences through dance. This is not a new phenomenon. Some of the differences in present times may be the facts that: Most raves are social functions not the pursuit of spiritual enlightenment, although I grant you that while "just" social in nature, many people after experiencing a few of them and the "oneness" of the music building upon itself, they can't help but feel "inspired" by the "beat". I'm really hard pressed to believe that actual revelation comes from this culteral enigma unless it's on a very personal basis and that type of personal enlightenment usually should not be shared in it's entirety with the world at large because as you know, "You shouldn't cast pearls before swine"! Good luck in your quest for information. I am also interested in hearing of your discoveries. Please forward them to me if you have either the time or inclination  Thanks  Piper

Mark Carey <dj_mook@hotmail.com> wrote:Often times when I've gone to a rave or talked to people who have attended, 
I've heard stories about various "spiritual" experiences, people have had at 
these events. Often these have taken place on the dance floor while dancing 
on some substance. I'm doing a project for my sociology class, and I wanted 
to survey how wide spread this phenominon is, and just what impact raves are 
having on our spiritual lives, if any.

Please set aside some time to take this 40 question survey. 39 questions 
are multiple choice, with the final question offering space for individual 
feedback. The survey is totally anonymous, and no identifying information 
from this survey will be requested or used in any way, so please be as 
honest and forth right as possible. Thank you!

The link to the Survey is here:
http://www.djmook.com/soc/

:-)
MooK<><

Importance: Normal

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Sat. May 10 - Commander Tom @ Trip to Noom

Saturday May 10, 2003

Modified and norcalraves.org presents...

Trip to Noom

Featuring:
COMMANDER TOM
Stuttgart, Germany
(Noom Records, Ultimate, Bush)
Commander Tom has been DJing and creating music for the last 17 years.
He  runs 7 labels, roughly 20 music projects and has played at almost
every major event in the world, including Energy 92-96, Tribal
Gathering, Omni 93, Rave City 3&4, Union Move, Time Tunnel and each of
the Love Parades.

In addition to being the label leader of the successful German Noom
imprint  (which has branched out to New York and London as well),
Commander Tom is  also in charge of Deluxe Germany, Deluxe UK, Monkey
Business, 12 inch  Monkeys and Phan-Tom.  On top of that, he owns the
revered Deluxe Sound Lab  studios 1 and 2.

Tom has worked for various labels under countless guises, including
Commander Tom, Tom Deluxe, Koenig Deluxe, Mandala, Nexus 6, The
Freaquez,  Andy Trex, Chef New Yorker, Phan-Tom, Waterhouse, Toronto and
many more.  His massive list of remixes includes more than a hundred
reworks for talent  such as Sourmash, Baby Doc, Chris Liberator, Eric
Powell, The Acen, U96,  Acrid Abayence, Tesox, DJ Sammy, RMB and Jon The
Dentist.

DYLOOT
San Francisco
(Skills, Dancing Spirit Recordings)

ENEMY
San Francisco
(Skills)

MAJERE
San Francisco
(Elektrosorcery) 

WAVELENGTH
San Francisco
(Oneiromancy/Deciblast)

ELEMENT
San Francisco
(Modified, norcalraves.org)

Sound by Neuroscience Creations
Lasers by Stimulights
Blacklight environment by Modified
Info : 510.663.6268 / triptonoom@norcalraves.org

$25 on sale April 1st at the following locations: 
Skills DJ Workshop in Berkeley: 510.704.9876
Frequency 8 Records in San Francisco: 415.221.4142
Solid Grooves in Santa Clara: 408.248.6399 

For additional information on this event and other events happening in
the Bay Area check out: http://www.norcalraves.org

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 58434 invoked from network); 28 Apr 2003 17:44:13 -0000
Message-ID: <20030428174411.91496.qmail@web41806.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 28 Apr 2003 10:44:11 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>, "Alicia C." <redordead1313@hotmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0304280312540.16592-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-music makin software

--- AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
> 
> On Mon, 28 Apr 2003, Alicia C. wrote:
> -&e->Hi all,
> -&e->
> -&e->I was just wondering what the best electronic
> music program for a pc
> -&e->computer is.  I have a dell lattitude notebook.
> I wanna start making music
> -&e->but i don't want a janky program with which to
> get started!  Thanks
> 
> Well, I know you don't want to hear this, but the
> needs of someone
> starting out ARE different.  You want something
> cheap, that will be able
> to finish a track, without any step in the process
> being too difficult to
> figure out.

this is why Reason is such great instructional/starter
software. it's so easy that you can work extremely
quickly. these days I consider myself to be spending a
lot of time on my music, because it takes me more than
a day to come up with a complete track.

also, I got my first keyboard, a Korg M1, when I was
15. I've worked with a bunch, and if you want an
introduction to how they work, get your hands on
Reason. I admit it's a lot of work getting real sounds
out of it, but if you get the hang of every machine in
Reason, you'll have no trouble at all dealing with
real synths.

plus, in all fairness, there are some "real synths"
out there where getting a real sound from the thing is
even more work. (like the Nord Lead.)

I'm not gonna claim that anybody with real
determination and an extensive background in music
technology could get a pro-level recording just using
Reason for sound generation and composition with Acid
for sequencing, EQing, & compression, but it is true
that if you want to figure out what compression is
for, or how sound generation works in nine out of ten
synths out there -- or more accurately, in every synth
on earth except for the damn Korg Prophecy -- then you
could certainly do worse than combining Reason and
Acid.

I've always believed in combining Reason with Acid.
:-)


Giles


ps: if you REALLY want to learn how to make music,
don't bother with Reason or with Logic Audio either.
this is hobbyist shit. quit fucking around and go to
the real deal: Pro Tools HD.

and if you live in the Bay Area, and you really care
about music, then you should probably go here:

http://www.expression.edu

(I'm just respecting my elders. Dave Aude (Donald
Glaude's engineer) says, "if you're over 20, go to
school":

http://www.neobeatnik.com/aude.html)

http://search.yahoo.com
