X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr-music makin software


For a PC, I would say the following would be a good place to start:

- Acid:
You can get in and start making cut-and-paste tracks straight out the box. 
Easy to use.

- Reason:
It's fairly powerful, and is almost as easy as Acid to start learning. After 
the initial learning curve, you can get deeper into the program and do more 
complex production.

- Reaktor:
This is a VERY deep prgram, but has a nice user intreface and an intuitive 
way of getting tracks made. Like reason, you can get up and running on this 
prgram quickly, AND there's the ability to go super deep into things like 
granular synthesis.

If you want some help in making you decision, there's a relatively new place 
thaat opened up in the Lower Haight called Robotspeak. They're all dedicated 
to music software and frequently have workshops.

Here's there info:
http://www.robotspeak.com/

Stephen (Zygote) - under the radar //
http://utr.praemedia.com/

i like those quiet kinds of guys. they are quiet and they just sit back and let the lady do her thing..sometimes, they are talking too, but when they talk, they just say the darndest things, and that is why i think they are worth sleeping with...0ooops. i was going to cut that part out, and then i thought about it for a second, and got real brave and said it anyway. whoa...just letting it all hang out. i sure do like those guys though. you know something else? even though someone might smell really good in their cologne, doesn't mean someone like me would want to have anything to do with them. i just proved that one, because some guy who gets on my nerves till the end of time and keeps appearing and reappearing in my line of vision, also happens to smell nice in nice cologne. gross. kind of like being a drunk and someone's dad while your married, drunk and learing at another girl in the face. same thing. gross. i sure do like those quiet guys though. they don't mind hanging out or anything. it doesn't make them go crazy or act like a lunatic. some lady keeps waking me up, by the way. when she sees that i am sleeping, she wakes me up and tells me how much she just loves eggs in her salad and she always wishes me "happy...whatever holiday is next, you fill in the blank". saw her again today. she likes bananas a lot too and pudding in a cloud. so do i, however, i am sleepy. peace ooooooooooooooooout. :)

It was an Awesome, Super Duper Fridgin' Awesome Night man!!!  I mean... =
it all totally came 2gether so nicely!!

So like yeah... earlier in the day... I talk  2 a few people on the =
phone!!  Chatted w/ Steph & Andy 4 a few minutes!!  Then I talk 2 BUZZ 4 =
hella long!!!  Gosh man.. I miss that Dude!  So that waa Groovy!!

Went 2 Berkeley 2 get Delia (YaYa) & Sean (Gumby) (wooohooo, another =
Saturday night adventure 4 Me & Delia!!  YAAAAAy!!!

So yeah...got to the location & it's also seems 2 B like YaYa & I r =
always the 1st ones 2 show up & always the last ones 2 leave...LoL!  BUt =
we 3 got there early & kicked it!!  LoL...

OK... 1st off I do gotta say that it was So Fuckin' Dope havin' Family =
2gether & kickin' it w/... it's ben way 2 long!!  I mean... yeah!!!  =
LoL... It kinda felt like Ascension 4 some reason!!  But yeah man... it =
was Good vibes aaaaall around & Groovy hangin' out w/ Fmaily again.... =
So Good!

ok... DJs!! Ummm.... I can't remember who spun 1st or who that guy =
was....well.... he's Tyler & Ryan's House Mate & he was Groovy!!!  OH =
Gosh... I don't think I remember every1 who spun that night!!!

Then Oracle spun next & man... did I tell U I Love This guy!!!  I =
mean... we haven't seen each other in what seems like 3 years & finally =
when we do... we hang out 2 weekends in a row....oh gosh..... & this guy =
is sooooo multi facited spnner!!!  He was always spinning Jungle & =
Techno when I 1st hung out w/ him... but he spun house on Sat night & =
man... I Love it when Oracle spins house 'cause he got all these Funky =
tracks that hella had me movin on the floor!! =20

tore it up!!

that place!!!  Oh MY Gosh.... it's hard whenever we get 2gether 'cause =
she could never ever do a set like that ever again it seems, but man.... =
she had the crowd movin' & it was Amazing none the less!

No G Funk went on I think & spun a few records..wait... there was some1 =
that went on B4 he did... but I soo can't remember... but G Funk went on =
4 a few Records!!!  I swear man... I always hear Homeboy spin Fresh =
Vinyl when he spins & I dunno... I haven't heard this guy spin in ages!  =
But he didn't get 2 spin that many records yet...

OK... then Razz, Ziggy, & kinda GBA got up & did this kinda mash up =
thing!!  OK... as always... Razz errr a I mean.... Senoirita is it.... =
spun exellent, Dope, Hard, Groovy Tunes then Ziggy hoped on!!!  OK...I'm =
not like stuck on Ziggy, but there's a way that Ziggy brings in her =
Records when she spind jungle, right, & l like when when she was =
spinning breakbeats, she did the same things like as if she was spinning =
jungle... does that make sense?  GBA got on & played live tracks ?I =
think? that were fuckin' Dope!!  LoL.... Shot through  the Heart & =
you're to late honey U give Love a bad name!

fucked it up big time!!!  I was Lovin' her set soooo much!!!  I mean... =
she totally knows how 2 bring in her records & literally take U on a =
journey when she spins!  Her set totally build U up when your dancing & =
U can sooooooo feel it!

hella new school tracks & totally mixed in alota old tracks too!!!!!  =
Fuuuuuuck man... it was so good 2 dance to him again!!!

that were there!!  LoL  Loved it! =20

Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030428132553.01271ac8@tyranny.loopfree.net>

From: Catharsis <catharsis@egregious.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] An Egregious 5 Year Anniversary (BSP)

;)

To celebrate the Egregious 5 year I created an icy old school mix of EBM 
and new beat that inspired me during the early/mid 90s. Labels such as 
Antler-Subway, Play It Again Sam, and New Zone highly influenced me; not 
just Wax Trax and the typical "US industrial scene", or whatever that is...

I tried to get booked to do this set by 3 SF "goth/industrial" club 
promoters and was turned down by all of them (some for being too obscure? 
huh?) Fuckers.... That scene is dead...

I just got this set up on a 5 gigabit/s drop, so please hit it while I got it:
http://www.egregious.net/comps/timeless_beginnings/

I want to test this out, so give it some SFR love; there will be no SFR 
effect/ bandwidth reduction!!! Woot woot!

Here is a track listing:
1. ClockDVA                     The Hacker
2. Frontline Assembly           No Limit
3. Micro Chip League            New York
4. Vomito Negro                 The Needle
5. Cyberaktif                   Black + White
6. Nitzer Ebb                   Join In the Chant
7. Front 242                    Controversy Between
8. Borghesia                    She Is Not Alone (Sonic Youth remix)
9. Klinik                       Moving Hands
10. A Split Second              On Command
11. KMFDM                       Liebeslied
12. Swans                       Time Is Money (Bastard)
13. Musolini Headkick           Get Out (Instrumental)
14. Skinny Puppy                Morpheus Laughing
15. Nine Inch Nails             Sin (Long Remix)
16. Coil                        Answers Come In Dreams
17. Negrosex                    Tekno La Droga v 2.2
18. Severed Heads               Dead Eyes Opened
19. Click Click                 I Rage I Melt
20. Einsturzende Neubaten       Feurio
21. U-Tek                       Das Mass Der Dinge (Masslos Mix)
22. A-Head                      Deep Down (Pressure Mix)
23. Death In June               Rain of Despair

mixed with a techno aesthetic.

Even if you were into EBM/industrial there is a high chance that you 
haven't heard all of these tracks.. I gather that this will be new material 
for a lot of people on this list.. Do check it out; all these tracks are 
gems (and I am glad I have them on record!) and guided me as a teenager 
(back in the BBS daze). These tracks parallel the infancy of the early 
"rave" period; provides perspective; a different scene...

I was bummed that DJ Hell beat me to an EBM comp... That bastard... of all 
DJs too..  Haven't heard Hell's though, but I am sure mine is better! ;P

I am slowly transferring the rest of the audio on my site to the 5 
gigabit/s drop, so things will be going quick soon enough... Mmmm... feel 
it flow...

Another set that is on the drop is here:
http://www.egregious.net/comps/live_3_7_01/

--------------------------------

I also have a DVD-Video of my early "experimental" tracks + video. It 
includes a 5.1 surround mix of Drone I which is rather cool if you have the 
audio setup to listen to it. I can't give the DVD-Video away, so if you are 
interested drop me an email and I will send it off to you for $7 (paypal).

--------------------------------

Q: Why Egregious? Doesn't it have a negative connotation meaning something 
horribly bad?

A: I got the idea of Egregious from a Kurt Vonnegut book, Dead Eye Dick... 
Here is the quote:

"...but it was all the neuters that caught my eye that day. These were my 
people -- as used as I was to wanting love from nowhere, as certain as I 
was that almost anything desirable was likely to be booby-trapped.
I had a fairly funny idea. Someday all we neuters would come out of our 
closets and form a parade. I even decided what our front rank should carry, 
as wide as Fifth Avenue. A single word would be printed on it in letters 
four feet high:

Egregious

Most people think that word means terrible or unheard of or unforgivable. 
It has a much more interesting story than that to tell. It means 'outside 
the herd.' Imagine that -- thousands of people, outside the herd."

--Kurt Vonnegut (Deadeye Dick)

Egregious paired with my performance name, Catharsis, results in this one 
liner (pun...):

"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."

--------------------------------

Quick recap of Egregious history...

Well, its been 5 years already... The official date is April 1st, but hey 
who is keeping track... 4/1/98 I threw my first event; an industrial club 
night in San Luis Obispo; the goal was to find new electronic dance music; 
not dwell on the old.. Did that for a year during which I acquired some DJ 
gear and stumbled upon EDM and mixing; all in my bedroom with no other 
local DJs mixing or playing out that I was aware of at the time; complete 
bubble... Then I stumbled upon Greg Adair, a raver from Sac... heh heh... 
He thought I was joking when I mentioned I DJed trance (only for a year!) 
as I dressed quite like an industrial head (and still do)... This was '99 
and the original Egregious crew mostly separated by December '98 as some 
graduated while others just moved on... Well Greg and I started a radio 
show (that lasted a year until the station kicked us off as they didn't 
like EDM; even though our show was popular) at the university radio station 
for mixed EDM and that fall hosted a "rave" at the university. It was there 
that we met the brave few incoming freshman that were into it... We hung 
out played records on the weekend; the newbies started to learn to DJ -> 
then became good DJs quickly... Bad Monkey 
(http://badmonkey.egregious.net/) was born in January 2000 and ran to April 
2001... It was crazy; a bright flame that burned out quick.. The 1st 6 
months were mad... Unfortunately the SLO scene shifted by fall 2000; we 
expected a greater influx of EDM fanatics; that didn't happen... That 
following year SLO didn't see enough new heads to continue to support Bad 
Monkey weekly and attendance started to slow... Inter crew friction was at 
an all time high (mostly a house vs. techno thing) and I broke off from Bad 
Monkey April 2001; Bad Monkey ceased by June 2001.

I did get one last event off in SLO May 2002 that was awesome; 
http://www.egregious.net/taz2002/

I am very sad though as this is the first year that I haven't been able to 
organize an event; though the year isn't finished! :)

Well, for those that stuck through this do come out to Minimal Monday 
(www.minimalmonday.com) on the 5th and I will try to get you a CD of one of 
my sets.. Just say you are from SFRaves.  I am going for an Amsterdam hash 
bar vibe with my set; just switch it up with Tokyo ice teas and you have it 
made though...

Hope everyone is well...
Best,
--Mike


Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/



---------------------------------------------------------------------

At 11:56 PM 4/27/2003 -0700, Happy wrote:
>Hi All,
>     I had never heard of the Phoenix Family, but I went to their party 
> last night at the Noodle Factory, and had an amazing time! I don't think 
> I've ever been to a psy-trance party before. None of my friends were 
> there, and I didn't know anyone. I felt a little bit awkward since I was 
> dressed up a little for the cocktail party that I went to before hand. I 
> was talking to one girl and as we talked, I realized that while I might 
> think that I'm dialed into the party scene here in the Bay Area, there is 
> this whole other circle of parties that I had no idea about. She named 
> crews and venues that I had never heard of, and she hadn't heard of a lot 
> of what I knew.

The Phoenix Family throws wonderful parties.  I've been to quite a few, and 
spent a fair portion of my party time in the psytrance community over the 
past few years.  Did Dr. Spook spin at this event?  The psytrance family is 
one of the most energetic genre-based dance cultures in the Bay 
Area.  While Thump is the above-ground manifestation of the scene, there 
are many collectives that still do undergrounds.  Some of the warmest 
people I've met on the dance floor have been at psytrance parties.  And 
those people dance....all night long, non-stop.

There are many interesting families in the dance community.  Unfortunately, 
there is often little cross over.  The people one sees in one dance 
subculture one rarely sees in another.  I prefer to sample as much as I 
can, and I'm hoping in future to produce some more eclectic 
parties.  Another family that might interest you is Martin Tickle's (DJ 
Dragonfly) Groove Garden www.thegroovegarden.com   Martin's next party in 
Marin is this Saturday, following the May Day Fest of All at Stafford Lake 
Park.  Fraser Clark will be giving a little talk at GrooveGarden.

Much love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: [ASR] Dance Culture Spirituality

--=====================_9538592==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 06:56 PM 4/27/2003 -0700, Andrew Phelan wrote:
>Just as a reference, I'd suggest you take a look at "Traces of the Spirit:
>The Religious Dimensions of Popular Music" by Robin Sylvan.  It's on Amazon
>if nowhere else.  He was one of my professors at college, and the Music and
>Religion course I took with him was the best class I've ever taken.  It
>changed my life and my perception of what "the scene" meant to me.
>
>-Andrew

Yes, Andrew, this is an excellent work and I also highly recommend 
it.  There has been much interest lately in the connections between dance 
culture, music and spirituality.  This year Graham St. John will publish 
'Rave Ascension: Youth, Techno Culture and Religion' (Routledge 2003) with 
some material from my House Music 101.

Dance has played an important role in religious ritual and spiritual 
enlightenment in virtually every culture since the beginning of time.  When 
one thinks on it, a respectful, loving, and peaceful dance floor is a 
paradigm for positive human interaction and, for many including myself, one 
of the best ways to transcend the ego and experience the other -- however 
one may define it.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Blasphemental


Indeed, Dr Spook seems to be everywhere these days, including this past
weekend.

I highly recommend sampling from as many genres as much as possible. The
sad part about this is that I only get to see some of my friends
occasionally, since they too like to stay within their niches. 

I would have to concur though that some of the biggest dance rushes and
days of dancing exhaustion I get still at Psytrance events. Seeing the
same people up all night, past dawn and lasting until the afternoon
dancing or later gives incentive to do the same. The people I meet don't
go to events to mingle, they go to get their rocks off by bouncing as
much as possible :)

-tim

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

The future of online music buying is here!

It's called the iTunes Music Store. It allows you to buy tracks for 
just $.99 each. Only available to Mac users on OS X in the US at the 
moment. But this might possibly represent the beginning of legitimate 
and legal online music distribution. If Apple's venture proves 
sucessful, Windows and International users might expect a similar 
system in the near future.

http://www.apple.com/music/


BS


P.S. I don't work for Apple, I'm just excited as hell that legitimate 
online music is make real progress for once!

with bleeding edge intelligent lighting and really just too much sound.


I mean, geez, a 26 foot wall of sound?!


On a second level though, MINDCONTROL is an influence and media plaything.
MINDCONTROL is brought to you by a gathering of strategists from all medias
whose goal is to push some of your buttons, get your juices flowing, get yo=
u
laughing and thinking and doing.

Before you even attend you will recognize this isn=B9t just another party.
The daily changing voicemail, the hand made ticket packs, the flyers, and
the word on the street are all crafted one part party and one part Skinner
Box.

strobes and dark-casted Cyberlights, look around at the subtlely changing
media and wonder to yourself=8A

heard.
Very Loud and Very, Very Clear.

Some folks prefer Jungle.

really nasty sounds make your thorax shake. Complete darkness envelopes you=
.
The sound is your North Star.  No one sees you smile.

Your pupils are going to get a work out.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Party Busters

By Judith Lewis, LA Weekly
April 25, 2003

Last week, under cover of wartime and paranoia about the safety of=20
America's children, the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act of 2003, known=
=20
in an earlier form as the RAVE Act, became law as a non sequitur tacked on=
=20
to the PROTECT Act ("Prosecutorial Remedies and Other Tools to End the=20
Exploitation of Children Today"). It was a sneaky deal: After having failed=
=20
to make it out of the U.S. Senate last fall, when it stood alone, the bill=
=20
=96 which applies the existing crack-house law to temporary venues and=
 allows=20
for civil penalties against club owners and promoters =96 cleared Congress=
=20
with no hearings and little debate. "It was very sudden," says William=20
McColl, director of national affairs for the Drug Policy Alliance, "but not=
=20
entirely unexpected. It's the kind of thing that happens in Washington=20
these days."


Underhanded as it was, the Illegal Drug Anti-Proliferation Act remains=20
something of a victory for the electronic-dance community, which mobilized=
=20
to fight the RAVE Act last fall. While the original bill, SB 2633, targeted=
=20
"alcohol-free venues" that sell glow sticks, massage oils and bottles of=20
water, those items were struck, along with the acronym, in direct response=
=20
to political pressure from the Electronic Music Defense Fund (EMDEF), the=20
ACLU and other organizations. When Senator Joseph Biden (D-Del.)=20
re-introduced legislation last January, he acknowledged "legitimate reasons=
=20
for selling water, having a room where people can cool down after dancing,=
=20
or having an ambulance on hand," and confirmed that efforts to promote=20
public safety could not be used against any promoter. "In no way is this=20
bill aimed at stifling any type of music or expression," he insisted,=20
borrowing EMDEF's language. "It is only trying to deter illicit drug use=20
and protect kids."


"We can be proud that we took over the spin," says Susan Mainzer of the=20
publicity firm Green Galactic, which promotes many of the events Biden=20
finds threatening. "Last fall secondary sponsors were taking their names=20
off after we educated them about how the bill might be applied. The=20
electronic-music community was able to organize as quickly as the=20
[evangelical] Christians do =96 and we showed that you can't discount us as=
 a=20
political force."


Still, while the new bill is leaner and simpler, it is also more open to=20
interpretation. "It's hard to imagine any district attorney going after the=
=20
Dodgers for someone smoking marijuana in the stands," says McColl. "The=20
question is, who is it going to target? Is it going to be applied=20
selectively to African-Americans? To unpopular types of music, such as=20
hip-hop? To gay and lesbian clubs? We don't know. We're watching it=
 carefully."

http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to=20
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great=20
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in=
=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_14298847==_.ALT--

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

It is a step in the right direction, but why do they
have to charge you per song? The whole point to the
sharing systems was that you could get songs in volume
and it did not matter how many you took. I think it
would be a better business model to charge a flat fee.
I would think that this Apple system is just another
way for the RIAA to keep the consumer tied to their
business model.  Change for real, Music Industry! 

nagabrain

Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
 The psytrance family is 
one of the most energetic genre-based dance cultures in the Bay 
Area. While Thump is the above-ground manifestation of the scene, there 
are many collectives that still do undergrounds. Some of the warmest 
people I've met on the dance floor have been at psytrance parties. And 
those people dance....all night long, non-stop.

 

true that. i've been in  a room full of nothing but pure danceology at a psytrance party. the room doesn't even need to be purely blacked out when done properly, cuz there's no one to avoid. psy and goa...mmmmmmmmmmmmm, yummie. i love to just move and move and move uninhibited. it is just the most magical thing, and when i get like that, i know that i absolutely don't have time for anything else. it is unfortunate that sometimes often the wrong element comes filtering on through. gotta be patient. worth the wait. :)

"single", often the choice cut on an album or an underground artist who will
never have a whole LP, just some 12" and remixes.  Paying that same buck to
Apple for the third song on the B-Side of a Beck studio album just isn't the
same. I'd end up paying $14 and not even get cover art OR be able to resell
it used.

Just because its not "new and inovative" doesnt mean that the artist didnt 
work his/her ass off to write that song that you are illegaly enjoying.  So 
using your ideology, any artist that puts out music that isnt pushing the 
musical limits shouldnt be rewarded for their hard work......yeah that makes 
sense (insert sarcasm here).  Are you in a band?  Do you play shows/concerts? 
 If you did you would realize that there is little to no money that actually 
goes to the band from concerts.  Concerts are strictly promotional gatherings 
so you can try and sell your album and merchandise to the people attending 
your concert.  Merchandise has a high overhead and is high risk for bands.  I 
know I'm still eating 500 t-shirts from a tour i did last summer.  Don't tell 
me that bands dont need the money from album sales, thats crap.  Everybody 
has there hand in your pocket, labels, mangament, studios, equipment 
comanies, venues, sound companies.  It costs $$$ to make albums and videos.  
Do you think that the record companies pay for all of it?!?!  HAHAHA!!!  that 
would be great, but its not true.  The artist is resposinble for paying for 
the studio time, engineer, producer, guest musicians, rehersal studios, 
videos etc.  And you think your not hurting anything by downloading songs and 
never paying for the album all because you dont like the music thats being 
put out.........right.

-BJ

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

on 4/29/03 5:58 PM, Shango Los at Shango@nodeOne.com wrote:

> I'd end up paying $14 and not even get cover art OR be able to resell
> it used.

Actually, you do get cover art with iTunes.. It shows up in the bottom left
corner of the window when you're playing a downloaded song. It's definitely
not the same as having a booklet with the liner notes, but it's still kinda
cool.

Overall, I think as the selection of songs on it grows, it'll be more
worthwhile. 200k songs across all the majors isn't a bad start, but it's not
a peak you want to be at, either. But where this is really important is as a
test bed for this model of music. Apple's audience is small enough to not
freak out the recording industry luddites, yet with a user base in the
millions, it's large enough to make it a worthy experiment in digital music
distribution.

 - omid

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

Music should be free, art should be free...blah blah blah... If the
artist wants to make their music available for free for the sake of art,
that is THEIR choice, not yours. It really is the same goddamn thing as
stealing a cd from a store. 

Sure, the majors in the industry have engaged in price-fixing and there
may not be a surplus of good music but that doesn't give anyone the
right to decide to steal it. If you don't like it, don't buy it. But you
can't just steal it. Gap uses sweatshop labor, and has overpriced
clothing, the person that designed the clothing most likely was some
sort of artist, does that mean I can walk into Gap and fill my arms till
their full and walk out the door without paying a cent? 

The record industry is big business, what Apple is doing is great. Kudos
for anyone launching such a large campaign into uncharted areas. 

The only way an artist is going to be able to stay around is if their CD
sells. Soundscan counts each and every time that CD is sold. Download
instead of buying the cd and the artists numbers drop. What's worse is
when record companies shelve an artist who doesn't produce good numbers
and that persons career is locked into the label until the label decides
to release another track (could be never)

A lot of the independent labels are owned by the major labels. And
labels that could be considered independent are represented by the RIAA.
So it's not really clear cut. And sometimes artists make most of their
money touring. Sometimes they make most of their money off having their
music in movies or having their lyrics reproduced in some other way. Do
you know how the artists you are stealing from make most of their money?
Even if you did, is it fair for you to limit how they make their money?

I'm all about new ways to promote music, and using cutting edge
technologies to further art. But when it comes to simple theft, I am
morally against that. People who download the music and then don't buy
the album ARE hurting record sales. Personally, I think downloading
music to sample new genres, songs, artists and stuff is great. But then
go out and buy it. I understand economics are a reality we all must
face, but as I said earlier, just because you can steal it doesn't make
it ok.

Damn this was a long post.

Peace,
Aaron



-----Original Message-----
Just because its not "new and inovative" doesnt mean that the artist
didnt 
work his/her ass off to write that song that you are illegaly enjoying.
So 
using your ideology, any artist that puts out music that isnt pushing
the 
musical limits shouldnt be rewarded for their hard work......yeah that
makes 
sense (insert sarcasm here).  Are you in a band?  Do you play
shows/concerts? 
 If you did you would realize that there is little to no money that
actually 
goes to the band from concerts.  Concerts are strictly promotional
gatherings 
so you can try and sell your album and merchandise to the people
attending 
your concert.  Merchandise has a high overhead and is high risk for
bands.  I 
know I'm still eating 500 t-shirts from a tour i did last summer.  Don't
tell 
me that bands dont need the money from album sales, thats crap.
Everybody 
has there hand in your pocket, labels, mangament, studios, equipment 
comanies, venues, sound companies.  It costs $$$ to make albums and
videos.  
Do you think that the record companies pay for all of it?!?!  HAHAHA!!!
that 
would be great, but its not true.  The artist is resposinble for paying
for 
the studio time, engineer, producer, guest musicians, rehersal studios, 
videos etc.  And you think your not hurting anything by downloading
songs and 
never paying for the album all because you dont like the music thats
being 
put out.........right.

-BJ

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

Here's how I see it....
1990 some band comes out with a great song....singles are what, $7.00 or
something?
In 1990 I can't d/l (steal) the song, nor will I pay $7.00 for the single,
or $14.00 for the album.
1997 I can d/l it....and I probably will.
Now...I can d/l it free or (now) pay $.99 for the song stand alone.....good
options.
I could understand griping about paying $.99 for each song, I agree this is
still a rip *if*
you're buying albums, but for single songs it's just fine imo.  Now, if you
like a band
enough to get the whole album go ahead and buy the album in the store unless
it's less
than 12 songs and $.99 makes sense financially.  It's all coming together, a
bit, in a way
that d/l for free from those who don't wish you to shouldn't be done, imo.
Maybe 5 years
ago i'd agree it's okay for things I wouldn't have spent money on
regardless.  And maybe
i'd go ahead and d/l for free an album to see how I like it, and if I do
i'll pay for it (online
or bricknmorter) and if I don't I shouldn't have to.  In other words, there
should be some
leeway.  "Art" in the pictoral sense is visual...I can go view it for free
before I buy it, I can
be sure.  Albums?  I cannot hear the whole thing on the radio, so why should
I not be able
to d/l it if i'm unsure I will like it and check it out?

Infidel

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

Well then, the real question is how EXACTLY is it split up?  Obviously Apple
takes a cut.  So does the remainder go directly to the band?  Or does the
RIAA/Metallica siphon MORE cash away from the real artists?  Any scheme which
involves the likes of Hillary Rosen or Lars Ulrich EVER seeing so much as a
penny; is, to me, wholly unacceptable.

Answers to those questions will be the determining factor as to wether or not
*I* will ever buy from this service.

Personally, lacking knowledge of exactly how that $.99 is split up, I'm much
more excited about iTunes 4!  The ability to stream my music library AND
playlists with any other computer in the house via rendevous, and without
having let anyone on my own box via afp or NFS, is just SWEET.  (Yeah, I know I
could set up my music folder as a read-only NFS mount.  But there are non-geeks
in the house.)  They also cleaned up the GUI widgets on iTunes, making it look
much sleeker.  And, though I can't hear the difference on my crappy computer
speakers, the reviews of the AAC encoding are mostly positive so far;
indicating that an AAC file at 128 will sound like an MP3 at 160!  Quite nifty
to lower filesizes, because...

... One day I *WILL* have an iPod <drools on monitor> dammit!  I just have
something of a cash flow problem right now...


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Apple's new online music service

Aaron and DJAklaim make good points. My statement about artists making most
of thier money from concerts and merchandise comes from just what I've
heard. I don't have any first hand expirance. The technology (call it
stealing or not) exsists and it's not going away. I belive that the solution
to artists who want to make money from CD sales is to either make CDs worth
17 bucks (making enhanced cds, or using some new technology not invented
yet, maybe something akin to smart cards) or lower the price of cds.
Otherwise the only thing thats going to make someone pay .99 for somthing
they could just get for free (without the trouble a raiding a Tower Records
with a gabarge bag) is the time and knowhow.

Peace,
Mystic

> > company anyway.. and besides, all the new inovative music is on
> > "indepenadant" labels, which are hard and sometimes imposible to find
> on
> > P2P
> > networks. and again even independant artists make most of thier money
> from
> > concerts.
> >
> > Peace,
> > Mystic
> >

naw...
the best BART-related venue, I think?

Powell Street BART station, definitely.
the east/north end, where there's just this big, long, wide hallway,
which takes you to just in front of Ross Dress 4 Less or just outside
Rite-Aid...

white-tiled walls which would be killer for projections or just lights
reflecting off of them, a big long nice floor that could have carpet or
something laid over it [for easier cleaning afterward and a no-slip
grip], ventillation from the escalators/stairways and the internal air
conditioning... the only issue might be acoustics; I have no idea how
that place would sound, esp filled with people muddling the noise.
There could even be extra rooms, if [once BART was closed for the night]
the rest of the station could be utilized

I'd pay $30 a ticket for that place with the right DJs :p heheh

and hey, BART stops running, anyway, and they could shut that end of the
station early so things could start before midnight... never happen, I
know, even though there's no machinery or equipment to damage there, but
still...

later
-james

From sfraves-return-101692-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 30 11:26:38 2003

Received: (qmail 78277 invoked from network); 30 Apr 2003 11:26:38 -0000
From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <1c4.8da8364.2be10ce3@aol.com>
Date: Wed, 30 Apr 2003 07:26:27 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] A naive attempt at comparing the rave scene to a revolutionary movement

Ok so did anyone take that survery that guy sent out? Well i thought it was 
interesting and cool that he actually took the time to make it in html and 
stuff with the multiple choice questions, so props to who ever did that, i 
took the survey and for the essay question i got a little carried away, so as 
to not waiste all that writing i'm copying the piece over to the SFR list as 
well. (and yes i do know that most of these ideas have already been explained 
in various books and other peoples past discussions but this is just my sum 
and opionin as it is, i guess i feel it's worth a read)

    I believe that raves are a global, unified, neo-tribalistic type of 
culture. Perhaps currently in it's infant stage. Yet unlike native type 
tribes that we know of, raves actually approve of technology and futurism. 
The music at raves is mostly without words, and it is electronic, but there 
is a distinct "tribal" sound to it, and a spirituality that is primal to the 
human being's soul, and it transcends life through time as we know it. I 
believe the spiritual experience that is felt at raves is similar to achient 
tribal gatherings and rituals, yet the experience is a 1000 times enhanced by 
the technology of electronic music and cosmic lighting, rather than hand made 
drums and other such intraments. You can also see raves as an evolution of 
dance style and expression of spirituality through dance, it is 
non-coreographical and entirely intuitive, yet these styles show a mastering 
of skill and grace just the same. 
    On a larger scale... I believe raves show potential for a revolutionary 
movement in the history of the world. Similar to the hippie or peace 
movements in the 60's, yet now I believe they are much more globally 
networked and inteligent. If raves continue to grow at the rate they have in 
the past 10 years, in another generation or two, I believe you may actually, 
eventually see the difference coming through in world politics. As raves no 
doubtably made me grow spiritually, and networked me with people and 
information that I could in no other way, have come to find by myself, I see 
this happening for the masses of other people who attend raves as well. In 
the outcome, you may see the difference in voting polls in the future, 
perhaps more third party votes, perhaps more orginazations for environment, 
more freedom of speach, expression, and freedom to dance in yet even bigger 
and better venues than we now have avalible to us. All these ideas are 
actually quite old ones inside the rave scene, and they are becoming somewhat 
"chiche", and are no longer talked about as frequently inside the rave 
scene... but as soon as the "pop" scene learns to adapt to this philosophy 
and the benefits of it, I think they will filter into it within another 
generation or so. (much in the way rock & rap have filtered into eachother) 
When this happens it will make the notion of a "movement" much more plausible 
and acceptable to talk about. Not to say that other genre's of music are 
inferior to "Rave" music, but no other style can claim to be as futuristic or 
tribalistic, and the combination of those two aspects of the scene makes it 
something that transcends time past to future. Which is special and unique... 
for lack of a better word. 
    The rave scene, as it now stands is absurdly unknown and under 
appreciated by the general public, and I think it deserves at least if not 
more than the significance in art and music, that rock and hip hop get. Even 
the signifigance that people speak of about jazz and classical music... I 
think that techno should be right up there with those. in fact it's almost as 
if techno is a combination of all of the above genre's that i just mentioned. 
but it's just silly how people down play it as the sort of thing that "gives 
you a headache" or "is not real music". There somethign else going on inside 
people's heads that isn't allowing them to open up to techno just yet, 
somehow asthetically they don't understand it, yet us ravers do, Rock was the 
same way when it first came into the public... So you can imagine Raves will 
soon be even bigger than rock. I think that's logical to assume.
    Now as for the drugs... they go way back into tribal history, and 
although they do not define us they are well known to be part of the scene, 
as they were a part of ancient tribal culture as well. Drugs are yet another 
enhancement the spiritual experience perhaps even more profound than the 
music at times. The fact that people abuse drugs and overdose is a problem 
that can't be overlooked, yet I imagine in anchient tribal culture those who 
did such things were looked down upon in some sort of "honor code". If you 
can't moderate your drugs... and you don't have someone who looks out for you 
in doing so, i don't care how old you are, in tribal culture it just might be 
your time to go... (hey at least you go out with a bang)
    

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp]  djhoj.com v2 launched!!!

Hi all,
 
After much hard work the new website, djhoj.com v2, has launched!  The site was created by Chillbox Studios (chillboxstudios@hotmail.com) and is hopefully more than your average dj site.
 
And for the launch, I did what any decent person would do ... I put together a new mix.  It's called "No More Mud" and you can have a listen on the site.  Also, there is an interview with SPESH (no introduction necessary), with XIAN (art director of Looq Records), and with JACKIE (Label Manager of Looq Records).  I also have a little write up about Chillbox Studios in the "Music>Random" section if it suits you.  
 
So make your way over to the site, listen to some music, look at the pretty pictures, and be sure to sign the guestbook (in the "Rant" section).  It would be much appreciated.
 
Oh yeah ... I guess a url would help:
 
www.djhoj.com
 
And if you find any problems with the site, drop me a line.  Those "kinks" always manage to find their way through beta testing.  Also, please forgive the sections with unfinished content.  I really mean it when I say "Coming Soon".  I just had to launch the thing ...   
 
Enjoy!
 
Hoj
www.djhoj.com
hoj@djhoj.com

In-Reply-To: <1c4.8da8364.2be10ce3@aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0304301133590.13663-100000@gere.odin.pdx.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A naive attempt at comparing the rave scene to a
 revolutionary movement


I had a vegetation-induced conversation with Dr. Graham over this one,
actually. Someone (who's name I can't remember! :/) pointed out something
pretty apt.

Assuming raves as a movement and rave collectives as groups become unified
and organized: I.e., groups like Cloud Factory become Non Profit
Organizations and bill themselves out as art groups, these groups then
ascend as minor corporate/NPO entities, and raves (like the acid tests)
become largely commercial affairs (...become?...), this will just be a
repeat of what happened in the 60s. Realize that those kids who were 18-25
in the sixties are now in their 40s and 50s, and are controlling the
united states as people in their 40s and 50s always have.

This is just another generation going through it's growing spurts,
organizing, flourishing, only to become the next generation of industry
leaders. Unless, of course, it's different this time.

Unless, of course, those of you who actually respect rave culture as a
movement, rather than a business, remain true to yourselves.

If the trend goes towards money-making, just like in the 60s, when
psychadelia became big business, those of you who don't sell your souls
will just be the next generation of burnt-out hippies. You know, the ones
your parents told you did all that acid in the 60s (like they didn't. ha
ha) and smoked all that dope and turned out as useless people that didn't
'contribute' to the corporate-industrial model by becoming good little
proles and etc.

I'm getting dogmatic. Shutting up now.

The Rational Hatter



On Wed, 30 Apr 2003 JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:

> Ok so did anyone take that survery that guy sent out? Well i thought it was
> interesting and cool that he actually took the time to make it in html and
> stuff with the multiple choice questions, so props to who ever did that, i
> took the survey and for the essay question i got a little carried away, so as
> to not waiste all that writing i'm copying the piece over to the SFR list as
> well. (and yes i do know that most of these ideas have already been explained
> in various books and other peoples past discussions but this is just my sum
> and opionin as it is, i guess i feel it's worth a read)
>
>     I believe that raves are a global, unified, neo-tribalistic type of
> culture. Perhaps currently in it's infant stage. Yet unlike native type
> tribes that we know of, raves actually approve of technology and futurism.
> The music at raves is mostly without words, and it is electronic, but there
> is a distinct "tribal" sound to it, and a spirituality that is primal to the
> human being's soul, and it transcends life through time as we know it. I
> believe the spiritual experience that is felt at raves is similar to achient
> tribal gatherings and rituals, yet the experience is a 1000 times enhanced by
> the technology of electronic music and cosmic lighting, rather than hand made
> drums and other such intraments. You can also see raves as an evolution of
> dance style and expression of spirituality through dance, it is
> non-coreographical and entirely intuitive, yet these styles show a mastering
> of skill and grace just the same.
>     On a larger scale... I believe raves show potential for a revolutionary
> movement in the history of the world. Similar to the hippie or peace
> movements in the 60's, yet now I believe they are much more globally
> networked and inteligent. If raves continue to grow at the rate they have in
> the past 10 years, in another generation or two, I believe you may actually,
> eventually see the difference coming through in world politics. As raves no
> doubtably made me grow spiritually, and networked me with people and
> information that I could in no other way, have come to find by myself, I see
> this happening for the masses of other people who attend raves as well. In
> the outcome, you may see the difference in voting polls in the future,
> perhaps more third party votes, perhaps more orginazations for environment,
> more freedom of speach, expression, and freedom to dance in yet even bigger
> and better venues than we now have avalible to us. All these ideas are
> actually quite old ones inside the rave scene, and they are becoming somewhat
> "chiche", and are no longer talked about as frequently inside the rave
> scene... but as soon as the "pop" scene learns to adapt to this philosophy
> and the benefits of it, I think they will filter into it within another
> generation or so. (much in the way rock & rap have filtered into eachother)
> When this happens it will make the notion of a "movement" much more plausible
> and acceptable to talk about. Not to say that other genre's of music are
> inferior to "Rave" music, but no other style can claim to be as futuristic or
> tribalistic, and the combination of those two aspects of the scene makes it
> something that transcends time past to future. Which is special and unique...
> for lack of a better word.
>     The rave scene, as it now stands is absurdly unknown and under
> appreciated by the general public, and I think it deserves at least if not
> more than the significance in art and music, that rock and hip hop get. Even
> the signifigance that people speak of about jazz and classical music... I
> think that techno should be right up there with those. in fact it's almost as
> if techno is a combination of all of the above genre's that i just mentioned.
> but it's just silly how people down play it as the sort of thing that "gives
> you a headache" or "is not real music". There somethign else going on inside
> people's heads that isn't allowing them to open up to techno just yet,
> somehow asthetically they don't understand it, yet us ravers do, Rock was the
> same way when it first came into the public... So you can imagine Raves will
> soon be even bigger than rock. I think that's logical to assume.
>     Now as for the drugs... they go way back into tribal history, and
> although they do not define us they are well known to be part of the scene,
> as they were a part of ancient tribal culture as well. Drugs are yet another
> enhancement the spiritual experience perhaps even more profound than the
> music at times. The fact that people abuse drugs and overdose is a problem
> that can't be overlooked, yet I imagine in anchient tribal culture those who
> did such things were looked down upon in some sort of "honor code". If you
> can't moderate your drugs... and you don't have someone who looks out for you
> in doing so, i don't care how old you are, in tribal culture it just might be
> your time to go... (hey at least you go out with a bang)
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> I'd end up paying $14 and not even get cover art OR be able  

> to resell it used.

 

You may not be able to resell it used, but I’ll trade you my MP3 file for your MP3 file…no wait, that’s illegal, and if we do trade they will send cyborg terminators to hunt us down through the web and send us all to jail, or maybe shoot us down because we were “attempting to evade arrest”.

 

But seriously, artists should get paid for what they create.  And for artists that I like, I am willing and happy to support them – pay the entrance fee, pay for the CD, whatever.  But I loved Napster, it was awesome.  And it never kept me from buying CDs because I am so inept at playing back digital music.  Yeah it was great at work, but I don’t even have a computer at home.  It only made me buy more music, because it was so easy to sample stuff and hear new things I liked and then wanted to "own".

 

I just don’t like the idea of some company or government agency monitoring my internet usage and tracking me down like the criminal I am.  Fuck them.

 

I think I just have "authority" issues.

-- Original Message --

Date: Tue, 29 Apr 2003 14:15:12 -0700 

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org 

From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org> 

Subject: Party Busters 

 

Party Busters

 

By Judith Lewis, LA Weekly

April 25, 2003

 

Last week, under cover of wartime and paranoia about the safety of 

America's children, the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act of 2003, 

known 

in an earlier form as the RAVE Act, became law as a non sequitur tacked 

on 

to the PROTECT Act ("Prosecutorial Remedies and Other Tools to End the 

Exploitation of Children Today"). It was a sneaky deal: After having 

failed 

to make it out of the U.S. Senate last fall, when it stood alone, the 

bill 

– which applies the existing crack-house law to temporary venues and 

allows 

for civil penalties against club owners and promoters – cleared 

Congress 

with no hearings and little debate. "It was very sudden," says William 

McColl, director of national affairs for the Drug Policy Alliance, "but 

not 

entirely unexpected. It's the kind of thing that happens in Washington 

these days."

 

 

Underhanded as it was, the Illegal Drug Anti-Proliferation Act remains 

something of a victory for the electronic-dance community, which 

mobilized 

to fight the RAVE Act last fall. While the original bill, SB 2633, 

targeted 

"alcohol-free venues" that sell glow sticks, massage oils and bottles 

of 

water, those items were struck, along with the acronym, in direct 

response 

to political pressure from the Electronic Music Defense Fund (EMDEF), 

the 

ACLU and other organizations. When Senator Joseph Biden (D-Del.) 

re-introduced legislation last January, he acknowledged "legitimate 

reasons 

for selling water, having a room where people can cool down after 

dancing, 

or having an ambulance on hand," and confirmed that efforts to promote 

public safety could not be used against any promoter. "In no way is 

this 

bill aimed at stifling any type of music or expression," he insisted, 

borrowing EMDEF's language. "It is only trying to deter illicit drug 

use 

and protect kids."

 

 

"We can be proud that we took over the spin," says Susan Mainzer of the 

publicity firm Green Galactic, which promotes many of the events Biden 

finds threatening. "Last fall secondary sponsors were taking their 

names 

off after we educated them about how the bill might be applied. The 

electronic-music community was able to organize as quickly as the 

[evangelical] Christians do – and we showed that you can't discount us 

as a 

political force."

 

 

Still, while the new bill is leaner and simpler, it is also more open 

to 

interpretation. "It's hard to imagine any district attorney going after 

the 

Dodgers for someone smoking marijuana in the stands," says McColl. "The 

question is, who is it going to target? Is it going to be applied 

selectively to African-Americans? To unpopular types of music, such as 

hip-hop? To gay and lesbian clubs? We don't know. We're watching it 

carefully."

 

http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/

 

 

Moksha Tribe

 


---------------------------------

--0-1825261709-1051731586=:51540--

-&e->become largely commercial affairs (...become?...), this will just be a
-&e->repeat of what happened in the 60s. Realize that those kids who were 18-25
-&e->in the sixties are now in their 40s and 50s, and are controlling the
-&e->united states as people in their 40s and 50s always have.

Wait... why in hell would you imply that CF became a non-profit in order
to cash in on anything?  For one, CF, the collective is not a NPO...
(CFCA, an arts wing started by people within cloudfactory is).  And
second, given just about every other promoter in the area, how fucking
dare you even imply that CF would have anything to do with the scene going
commercial?  Why not point the finger at the decline that's already
happening, looked at the price of a Skills ticket lately?  Checked your
email and seen nasty list scraped spam lately?  How about clubs that claim
to have the attendee in mind, but will treat you like shit in order to
stay open because of draconian police guidelines?

A lot of people in CF are already well into their 30s, and we happen to
see what we do as a sustainable and wonderful thing, still going strong.

-&e->This is just another generation going through it's growing spurts,
-&e->organizing, flourishing, only to become the next generation of industry
-&e->leaders. Unless, of course, it's different this time.
-&e->
-&e->Unless, of course, those of you who actually respect rave culture as a
-&e->movement, rather than a business, remain true to yourselves.

Maybe I'm going off here, but why in hell would you choose one of the few
flat budget party throwing collectives (it costs to attend what it costs
to throw it for most of their parties, when they aren't free as many of
them have been) as your example of what's going wrong?  There are far
better examples of promoters and collectives that have lost their way in
our scene.

-&e->If the trend goes towards money-making, just like in the 60s, when
-&e->psychadelia became big business, those of you who don't sell your souls
-&e->will just be the next generation of burnt-out hippies. You know, the ones
-&e->your parents told you did all that acid in the 60s (like they didn't. ha
-&e->ha) and smoked all that dope and turned out as useless people that didn't
-&e->'contribute' to the corporate-industrial model by becoming good little
-&e->proles and etc.

Well, for one, they didn't all burn out and give up.  For two, the ones we
remember (i.e. - Bill Graham, Grateful Dead) were sellouts to a degree
back then even.

CF was born out of the ethic of "if you want to know what's going on, do
it yourself", and along with a couple other groups like Pacific, FnF and
others with a similar ethic, they stand for the preservation of the scene
past when it's profitable... hell they have for years.  These groups have
kept doing what they do while watching countless promoters make their
money and run.

I see your point, but your example was horrible.

I for one would love to see Skills, F8, FGE, Brainchild/Orgy or hell, even
Burning Man seek out NPO status.

andyw


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] turntables

--0-1337825053-1051736957=:16617
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

that's pretty good advice.  i first started off in a studio to make sure i actually liked djing because it's not as easy as it looks.  as for tables, remember that they are an investment.  if you get the right tables, ie technics, they'll last forever, and maintain resale value.  if you get two mismatched tables, they may not be in sync in terms of starting and stopping power, which hurts beatmatching.  geri dahl's suggestion of studio time is probably best for cash strapped friends.

Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com> wrote:please don't kill me, however, there's nothing like using someone else's turntables while they are asleep....something you might consider is getting your friend some quiet studio time alone if you can't get the turntables you desire....nothing like a nice quiet studio full of techie toys and a comfie chair...of course, the kitties are not in there unless pre-approved. ::)...hey look, i gots FOUR eyes ::)

Charlie wrote:yo, advice...friend of mine wants turntables fer his
b-day...and like most of us i'm half poor...but i
could scrounge together enough if i put my mind to
it...anyway what are the good ones and um...what are
the good semi-affordable ones and um...stuff...

charlie

Subject: [sfraves] GeeDubya's resume - would be funnier if it weren't so accurate....

WORK EXPERIENCE

Ran for congress and lost.

Produced a Hollywood slasher B movie.

Bought an oil company, but couldn't find any oil in Texas, company
went bankrupt shortly after I sold all my stock.

Bought the Texas Rangers baseball team in a sweetheart deal that
took land using tax-payer money. Biggest move: Traded Sammy Sosa to
the Chicago White Sox.

With fathers help (and his name) was elected Governor of Texas.

Accomplishments: Changed pollution laws for power and oil companies
and made Texas the most polluted state in the Union. Replaced Los
Angeles with Houston as the most smog ridden city in Ameri! ca. Cut
taxes and bankrupted the Texas government to the tune of billions in
borrowed money. Set record for most executions by any Governor in
American history.

Became president after losing the popular vote by over 500,000
votes, with the help of my fathers appointments to the Supreme
Court.

ACCOMPLISHMENTS

Attacked and took over two countries.

Spent the surplus and bankrupted the treasury.

Shattered record for biggest annual deficit in history.

Set economic record for most private bankruptcies filed in any 12
month period.

Set all-time record for biggest drop in the history of the stock
market.

First president in decades to execute a federal prisoner.

First president in US history to enter office with a criminal
record.

First year in office set the all-time record for most days on
vacation by any president in US history.

After taking the entire month of August off for vacation, presided
over the worst security failure in US history.

Set the record for most campaign fund-raising trips than any other
president in US history.

In my first two years in office over 2 million Americans lost their job.

Cut unemployment benefits for more out of work Americans than any
president in US history.

Set the all-time record for most foreclosures in a 12 month period.

Appointed more convicted criminals to administration positions than
any president in US history.

Set the record for the least amount of press conferences than any
president since the advent of television.

Signed more laws and executive orders amending the Constitution
than
any president in US history.

Presided over the biggest energy crises in US history and refused
to intervene when corruption was revealed.

Presided over the highest gasoline prices in US history and refused
to use the national reserves as past presidents have.

Cut healthcare benefits for war veterans.

Set the all-time record for most people worldwide to simultaneously
take to the streets to protest me (15 million people), shattering
the record for protest against any person in the history of
mankind.
(http://www.hyperreal.org/~dana/marches/)

Dissolved more international treaties than any president in US history.

My presidency is the most secretive and un-accountable of any in US
history.

Members of my cabinet are the richest of any administration in US
history. (the 'poorest' multi-millionaire, Condoleeza Rice has an
Chevron oil tanker named after her).

First president in US history to have all 50 states of the Union
simultaneously go bankrupt.

Presided over the biggest corporate stock market fraud of any
market in any country in the history of the world.

First president in US history to order a US attack and military
occupation of a sovereign nation.

Created the largest government department bureaucracy in the
history of the United States.

Set the all-time record for biggest annual budget spending
increases, more than any president in US history.

First president in US history to have the United Nations remove the
US from the human rights commission.

First president in US history to have the United Nations remove the
US from the elections monitoring board.

Removed more checks and balances, and have the least amount of
congressional oversight than any presidential administration in US
history.

Rendered the entire United Nations irrelevant.

Withdrew from the World Court of Law.

Refused to allow inspectors access to US prisoners of war and by
default no longer abide by the Geneva C! onventions.

First president in US history to refuse United Nations election
inspectors (during the 2002 US elections).

All-time US (and world) record holder for most corporate campaign
donations.

My biggest life-time campaign contributor presided over one of the
largest corporate bankruptcy frauds in world history (Kenneth Lay,
former CEO of Enron Corporation).

Spent more money on polls and focus groups than any president in US
history.

First president in US history to unilaterally attack a sovereign
nation against the will of the United Nations and the world
community.

First president to run and hide when the US came under attack (and
then lied saying the enemy had the code to Air Force 1)

First US president to establish a secret shadow government.

Took the biggest world sympathy for the US after 911, and in less
than a year made the US the most resented country in the world
(possibly the biggest diplomatic failure in US and world history).

With a policy of 'dis-engagement' created the most hostile Israeli-
Palestine relations in at least 30 years.

Fist US president in history to have a majority of the people of
Europe (71%) view my presidency as the biggest threat to world
peace and stability.

First US president in history to have the people of South Korea
more threatened by the US than their immediate neighbor, North Korea.

Changed US policy to allow convicted criminals to be awarded
government contracts.

Set all-time record for number of administration appointees who
violated US law by not selling huge investments in corporations
bidding for government contracts.

Failed to fulfill my pledge to get Osama Bin Laden 'dead or alive'.

Failed to capture the anthrax killer who tried to murder the
leaders of our country at the United States Capitol building. After 18
months I have no leads and zero suspects.

In the 18 months following the 911 attacks I have successfully
prevented any public investigation into the biggest security
failure in the history of the United States.

Removed more freedoms and civil liberties for Americans than any
other president in US history.

In a little over two years created the most divided country in
decades, possibly th! e most divided the US has ever been since the
civil war.

than two years turned every single economic category heading
straight down.

Received: (qmail 58176 invoked from network); 1 May 2003 00:35:28 -0000
Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030430173847.040a0b90@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.1
Date: Wed, 30 Apr 2003 17:39:24 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_6288183==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  The Worms Made It...

--=====================_6288183==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

(04-30) 13:27 PDT CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) --

Hundreds of worms being used in a science experiment
aboard the space shuttle Columbia have been found
alive in the wreckage, NASA said Wednesday.

The worms, known as C. elegans, were found in debris
found in Texas several weeks ago. Technicians sorting
through the debris at Kennedy Space Center in Florida
didn't open the containers of worms and dead moss
cells until this week.

All seven astronauts were killed when the shuttle
disintegrated over Texas on Feb. 1. Columbia contained
almost 60 scientific investigations.

"To my knowledge, these are the only live experiments
that have been located and identified," said Bruce
Buckingham, a NASA spokesman at the Kennedy Space
Center.

The worms and moss were in the same nine-pound locker
located in the mid-deck of the space shuttle. The
worms were placed in six canisters, each holding eight
petri dishes.

The worms, which are about the size of the tip of a
pencil, were part of an experiment testing a new
synthetic nutrient solution. The worms, which have a
life cycle of between seven and 10 days, were four or
five generations old, Buckingham said.

The experiment was put together by researchers at the
NASA Ames Research Center in California.

The moss, known as Ceratodon, were used to study how a spaceflight
environment influences cell growth. During Columbia's flight, shuttle
commander Rick Husband sprayed the moss with a chemical that destroyed
protein fiber. He also sprayed the moss with formaldehyde to preserve
it. Seven of the eight aluminum canisters holding the moss were
recovered.

The experiment was put together by an Ames Research
Center researcher and Dr. Fred Sack at Ohio State
University.

"The cells were surprisingly well-preserved, but we're analyzing how
useful it's going to be," Sack said.

Researchers said they don't know if the worms will
still have any scientific value since they were
supposed to have been examined and unloaded from
Columbia within hours of landing

"It's pretty astonishing to get the possibility of
data after all that has happened," Sack said. "We
never expected it. We expected a molten mass."

=A92003 Associated Press


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."

dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A naive attempt at comparing the rave scene to a
	revolutionary movement


>> 
>> On Wed, 30 Apr 2003, Sean Griffith wrote:

>> -&e->and organized: I.e., groups like Cloud Factory become Non Profit
>> -&e->Organizations and bill themselves out as art groups, these groups then
>> -&e->ascend as minor corporate/NPO entities, and raves (like the acid tests)
>> -&e->become largely commercial affairs (...become?...), this will just be a
>> -&e->repeat of what happened in the 60s. Realize that those kids who were
>> 18-25
>> -&e->in the sixties are now in their 40s and 50s, and are controlling the
>> -&e->united states as people in their 40s and 50s always have.
>> 
>> Wait... why in hell would you imply that CF became a non-profit in order
>> to cash in on anything?  For one, CF, the collective is not a NPO...
>> (CFCA, an arts wing started by people within cloudfactory is).  And
>> second, given just about every other promoter in the area, how fucking
>> dare you even imply that CF would have anything to do with the scene going
>> commercial?  Why not point the finger at the decline that's already
>> happening, looked at the price of a Skills ticket lately?  Checked your
>> email and seen nasty list scraped spam lately?  How about clubs that claim
>> to have the attendee in mind, but will treat you like shit in order to
>> stay open because of draconian police guidelines?
>> 

i think what sean was trying to say was the scene seems to have branched off
into two wings ... the non-profit wings, like CFC, moksha tribe, etc. and
the huge profit parties.  he just put it into one sentence, so maybe someone
that just glanced at it might understand something different.

right now there doesn't seem to be any middle ground of promoters throwing
300-400 person parties trying to make a few hundred or perhaps a thousand
dollars profit.  


>> -&e->Unless, of course, those of you who actually respect rave culture as a
>> -&e->movement, rather than a business, remain true to yourselves.
>> 
>> Maybe I'm going off here, but why in hell would you choose one of the few
>> flat budget party throwing collectives (it costs to attend what it costs
>> to throw it for most of their parties, when they aren't free as many of
>> them have been) as your example of what's going wrong?  There are far
>> better examples of promoters and collectives that have lost their way in
>> our scene.
>> 
>> -&e->If the trend goes towards money-making, just like in the 60s, when
>> -&e->psychadelia became big business, those of you who don't sell your souls
>> -&e->will just be the next generation of burnt-out hippies. You know, the
>> ones
>> -&e->your parents told you did all that acid in the 60s (like they didn't. ha
>> -&e->ha) and smoked all that dope and turned out as useless people that
>> didn't
>> -&e->'contribute' to the corporate-industrial model by becoming good little
>> -&e->proles and etc.
>> 

well, i think a point to be made here, whether or not we're willing to face
up to it or not, is that the rave scene has turned out not to be the big
social revolutionary movement that a lot of us hoped it would be.  it's
basically turned out to be a passing scene that most people have lost
interest with except for the really mainstream mindless part ... in some
ways, that's good for the people that like small undergrounds, because there
aren't as many people scrambling to try to find the good parties ... in some
ways, it's dissapointing we couldn't get everyone in the world to go to one
huge party and have a big group hug or something.   but i guess that's
unrealistic.  

it will be interesting to see what happens now with the aging group of party
collectives and if we're able to pass this down to a newer, younger
generation, or if the entire rave scene will just blow into the wind and mix
with all the housey hip-hop that's out there now.

"bitches and hoes, yo, yo, yo ... get me 'nother '40..."

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Happy Beltane!!!

--=====================_7505856==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Beltane begins with dusk tonight, April 30.

Beltane is the last of the three spring fertility festivals, the others 
being Imbolc and Ostara. Beltane is the second principal Celtic festival 
(the other being Samhain). Celebrated approximately halfway between Vernal 
(spring) equinox and the midsummer (Summer Solstice). Beltane traditionally 
marked the arrival if summer in ancient times.

At Beltane the Pleiades star cluster rises just before sunrise on the 
morning horizon, whereas winter (Samhain) begins when the Pleiades rises at 
sunset. The Pleiades is a cluster of seven closely placed stars, the seven 
sisters, in the constellation of Taurus, near his shoulder. When looking 
for the Pleiades with the naked eye, remember it looks like a tiny 
dipper-shaped pattern of six moderately bright stars (the seventh can be 
seen on very dark nights) in the constellation of Taurus. It stands very 
low in the east-northeast sky for just a few minutes before sunrise.

Beltane, and its counterpart Samhain, divide the year into its two primary 
seasons, winter (Dark Part) and summer (Light Part). As Samhain is about 
honoring Death, Beltane, its counter part, is about honoring Life. It is 
the time when the sun is fully released from his bondage of winter and able 
to rule over summer and life once again.

Beltane, like Samhain, is a time of "no time" when the veils between the 
two worlds are at their thinnest. No time is when the two worlds 
intermingle and unite and the magic abounds! It is the time when the 
Faeries return from their winter respite, carefree and full of faery 
mischief and faery delight. On the night before Beltane, in times past, 
folks would place rowan branches at their windows and doors for protection, 
many otherworldly occurrences could transpire during this time of "no 
time". Traditionally on the Isle of Man, the youngest member of the family 
gathers primroses on the eve before Beltane and throws the flowers at the 
door of the home for protection. In Ireland it is believed that food left 
over from May Eve must not be eaten, but rather buried or left as an 
offering to the faery instead. Much like the tradition of leaving of 
whatever is not harvested from the fields on Samhain, food on the time of 
no time is treated with great care.

When the veils are so thin it is an extremely magical time, it is said that 
the Queen of the Faeries rides out on her white horse. Roving about on 
Beltane eve She will try to entice people away to the Faeryland. Legend has 
it that if you sit beneath a tree on Beltane night, you may see the Faery 
Queen or hear the sound of Her horse's bells as She rides through the 
night. Legend says if you hide your face, She will pass you by but if you 
look at Her, She may choose you. There is a Scottish ballad of this called 
Thomas the Rhymer, in which Thomas chooses to go the Faeryland with the 
Queen and has not been seen since.

Beltane has been an auspicious time throughout Celtic lore, it is said that 
the Tuatha de Danaan landed in north-west Connacht on Beltane. The Tuatha 
de Danaan, it is said, came from the North through the air in a mist to 
Ireland. After the invasion by the Milesians, the Tuatha faded into the 
Otherworld, the Sidhe, Tir na nOg.

The beginning of summer heralds an important time, for the winter is a 
difficult journey and weariness and disheartenment set in, personally one 
is tired down to the soul. In times past the food stocks were low; variety 
was a distant memory. The drab non-color of winter's end perfectly 
represents the dullness and fatigue that permeates on so many levels to 
this day. We need Beltane, as the earth needs the sun, for our very Spirit 
cries out for the renewal of summer jubilation.



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_7505856==_.ALT--
